170712. Bottle from local QFC in Seattle. Pours hazy dark brown with a high head. Aroma ripe fruits, orange peel some belgian yeast. Slightly sweet taste. Medium carbonated. Not Bad.

75 cl bottle @ Hotel room, Seattle.
Pours dark murky red color with head. Aroma of spices, ripe dark fruits, herbal notes and malts. Flavor of dark berries, dark ripe fruits, malts, some herbs and spices. Very flavorful and rich taste, spicy citrus fruity finish.
3454
Basement aromas, sweet and dry finish. Very wine like. Dark appearance. Lots of carbonation, but smooth.

Very nice. Definitely got the ripe grape / wine. Maybe some raisin. 

Variety pack from tjs.
Very fruit sweetaroma.  Quite smooth.  Sweet taste with a lingering fruit wine like finish.  excellent.
Extremely smooth, with an after tone of dark sweet cherries.  Very dark pour with a thin mocha colored head.  Looks like a stout, drinks like an ale.
A  little too much coke like sweetness for me. Lots of dark fruits that are quite nice but just too sweet for me

Poured from bottle into stemmed pilsner. Pours a dark dark brown with a red tint. Aromas of raisin, plum, apple, cherry, and some corn and yeasty bread fill the nose. Very fruity. Flavors follow with plum and other dark fruits. Some yeast and port wine characters in there as well. It's hard to put a fine point on it, but still very enjoyable. Mouthfeel is medium with medium amount of carbonation.  Smooth and easy on the palate but with some spice to it. Overall, I was surprised by this Canadian brew. Caught me by surprise. 

--- Cheers
Has a nice dark brown color, gives off a nutty note that is very tasty.  Great beer.

...from the bottle, poured a dark brown, with some big roasted notes on the nose.  Smooth, has some nice spice notes, and balanced well with the dark raisin and other dark fruits.  Not overpowering, well balanced, finishes silky with a dry mouthfeel.
Shared with Holy.  Bready cranberry aroma, a bit of malty sweetness on the tongue.  Pretty good.

Pours dark brown with a solid foam head with creamy lacing. The nose is nuts and spice. The taste is more nuts and spice with dark ripe fruits, and belgian yeast. This comes together very well. Solid.
Hazy nut-brown pour with a tan head. Sweet aroma with dark fruit, yeast, and spices. Slightly sweet, with lots of fruit, caramel, and malt.
Taste how it smells. light roast and spice flavor. Good amber/brown color. Good belgium style, nice and strong to boot.
Bottle shared by quiznoaz - thanks and a good time, as always! Nice representation of the Belgian style...

Ligh roasted malt aroma, slight yeasty-mustiness grape-winey and some spice.  Tastes precisely as is smells with a light body and some alcohol notes in the finish.  Deep brown in color with an amber hue.
Had this for the first time and wasnt bad.  Not a major fan of the Belgium aftertaste but love trying everything once.

On tap ath Ninkazy (Quebec City). Pours medium brown with copper reflect. Aroma: soapy, alcohol, belgian yeast, caramel, fruits. Taste is well balanced. Medium bodied. Very good, would need to be rerate under better conditions...
Had this in a bottle & tap. Both are awesome. If you dig this, try terrible! 10.5% of greatness!

One of my favorite belgian style beers. Pours hazy amber, with a tan, foamy head, Aroma of figs, malts, hops, raisins, and hints of banana. Taste is cherry, plum, sugars, roasty but tasty malts. Medium body with a sick, smooth finish. Excellent Belgian strong from Unibroue.

Cerveza de Aroma interesante y a la vez complejo.... Chocolate, maltas tostadas, cafe y un poco de madera. Notas finas a frutas suaves. Princialmente fresas y zarzamoras...

En cuanto a la vista, color obscuro completo, con ligeras tonalidades rojizas a la luz. Cuerpo ligero a medio. Corona de espuma ligera, pero de larga duración. Carbonatación de media a alta.

En boca, suave y cremosa e primera instancia, pasando posteriormente a dejar un ligero picor, fruto quiza de su alta carbonatación.

Al paladar, es compleja, igual que el aroma. Inicia dejando sentir su grado de alcohol, aun que posteriormente y poco a poco, se dejan sentir notas achocolatadas y maltas torrefactadas, dejando un final largisimo, el cual, y sin esperarlo, hace que se dejen sentir notas frutales, dejando en garganta un sabor exquisito, pero sumamente equilibrado!

En general es una cerveza que va de menos a más, que definitivamente se disfurta al máximo y que se debe degustar en un lugar y ambiente único para poder sentir su grandiosidad.

Appearance was clear reddiish root beer brown with creamy lasting 2 finger  tannish head, spotty lacing. Aromas where dark fruits of cherry, orange, fig, nutmeg, chili?. Yeasts where slight sourish and fruity with a beautiful malt backbone,almost chewy-like qualilty.Taste was complex mix of malts and fruity yeasts of cherry,fig, orange and mild chewy bread,hops very sublime.A wonderful balance of yeasts and malts and hops. Palate was velvety creamy tight carbonation with a balanced body.The long beautiful fruity malty slightly warm of alcohol finish is outstanding. One of the best belgain strong ales I ve had...

Pours deep brown/red with a tall thick tan head......This is one of those turn-over pours, where the bottom explodes in a fizzy rush, then forms the head from beneath....very cool look.
Scent is berries,dark fruits, malt.
Flavour is port wine with heavy carbonation......
fruity, sweet/tart, a trace of alcohol warmth....nicely hidden.
A bit of pleasant earthy funk.
Incredibly smooth, mellow and wonderful.

UPDATED: JAN 23, 2013 Bottle from Memphis Gastropub. pours dark brown with light tan head. Aroma of malt, dough, sugar; taste is unbelievably smooth. This is my favorite beer from Unibroue. ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark opaque brown with touch of red and medium tan head.  Aroma of dark dried fruits and sweet malts.  Full body with a little carbonation and little alcohol.  Flavor up front is sweet in a pleasant way with brown sugar and dried cherry and then gives way to some dryness first roasty malt and then maybe a little hops and a long finish.  Great stuff.
bread, hay, herbs, barnyard, dough, alcohol, bubblegum, raisin, brown, clear, tan foam, frothy, medium sweetness, full body, creamy, lively, long finish.
Tried this one on tap at Yardhouse Boca and the flavor is very sweet like dried fruits with notes of oranges, licorice, prunes, wood. Lots of malt, but isnt too over cloying.
Looks wicked when poured but is surprisingly smooth. Very tasty yet somewhat hard to describe. I think I may have to have another one.
Sampled on tap poured brown with a white head.  Aromas of yeast burnt sugars and malts.   Body is medium and finishes sweet

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2015 Side by side with Chimay Blue and this beer is more sour, the bubbles are larger. It seems a bit less refined than Chimay Blue. Not a fault, just an observation/opinion. A terrific Belgian Strong, unfiltered, high alcohol, big flavour. Lots going on for taste and palate. Itâd be nice if some microbreweries in Western Canada got in on the action like Unibroue. Did I mention it looks good in the chalice.

Poured into a snifter. Murky brown color with a short dirty white head the quickly only barely covered the surface. Lots of bubbles coming to the surface.

Wow. Aroma powerhouse. Malt, bread, yeast and dark fruit. Well balanced.

Nice malty flavor, brown sugar and a cider taste. Interesting, but good.

The body is a lot lighter than expected from the smell. Also light carbonation makes this an easy drink.

Overall a rich but not overpowering strong ale. A real nice balance between malty and lightness.

Pours dark brown with a off-white head. Smell have toasted malts and red wine notes. Taste is smooth and complex with notes of caramel, chocolate, cola, red wine and spice. Med-full bodied. After taste is some what sweet with a slight cherry tartness. Interesting and great.

poured from bottle into a tulip. Pours a medium brown color with a nice head.

very well balanced with very good aromas of malts, toffee, some brown sugar and dark red fruits.

medium bodied with a very good feel. Lighter than would be expected with flavors of brown sugar, malts, and some dark red fruits.

A quality dark ale. It was a bit lighter than I expected and it had been a good while since Ive had it.

341 ml bottle. Pours a deep dark brown with lasting head. Aromas of roasted malt and yeast, and hints of dark fruit. Spicy flavor - almost nutmeg. Earthy with vegetable tones. Malty with a bit of raisin and bread dough. Still a distinctive and good beer.

Pours a dark brown, with ample head and an aroma of raisins, plums, and banana. Taste is light-to-moderately complex malt with notes of raisin and dates, but relatively subtle compared to some in this class. Has moderate carbonation. Finishes with a somewhat papery or cardboard flavor that I do not care for. Its not a bad ale my any means, but I find it to be somewhat average and probably not one I need to try again.

Dark brown pour with a small amount of head.  Rich fruit aroma.  Smells amazing.  Still smells really fresh even though the bottle is two years old.  Taste is very fruit all the way through.  It definitely a mixture of fruit in the taste but the only one I can pick out for certain is cherries.  Somewhat dry, wine like finish.  This would be a great beer to convert wine drinkers to beer.

In Feb 2008 I wrote this on BA: My first proper Canadian beer, even if it is a Belgian style offering.

The same brown 33cl bottle most people have reviewed (I think). Mine was bought in Brussels at a Canadian stall in the annual Christmas Market (2007).

Poured into a Corsendonk tulip shaped glass.

Very dark ruby red (deep purple in a different light) with a huge light biege head which falls away to a good covering.

Raisins and plums come to mind when you smell this, Christmas pudding with yeast and extra alcohol really.

Rich and strong, this is a sipping beer. The alcohol is there for all to find, but there is more to this brew than just alcohol.

Having had a few strong dark beers from Belgium, I can safely say this fits in well, not a leader, but OK. The flavours and smells stay within the feel. A sweetness comes into the mix as the beer warms up, which I dont like much, but all in all a fine beer.
from notes:  bright, peppery, dark fruits, balanced sweetness, satisfying.  theres a reason this one is rated so highly.  well, more than one, but this is a world class belgian
By far one of the best beers I have had.  I am not a dark beer fan, however if all dark beer was like this....I would drink more dark beer.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2012 Pours dark dark dark amber with a thick cream colored head.  Smells of yeast...some fruitiness.  Tastes fruity...with that wonderful belgian flavor that I love so much.  A little tingly on the palate.  A quality brew.

330ml bottle. Caramel, berries and herbal aromas. Pours dark brown, with nice tan head, some peristence and lacework. Medium body and average carbonation.Taste is fruity, some sweetness. Goodsweet finish, warmer.
A nice one

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2012 Perhaps the most complex beer Ive had, and goodness knows Belgians can be complex.  I smell raisins, sundry spices, plums, pepper, etc. - 10 on the smell alone.  Taste is almost equally complex - grape fruit juice, sweet lingering malts that go on for minutes, yeast - a sweet, multi-faceted, slow sipper.  9% ABV astonishingly well-hidden.  Prior to tonight, I last had this at a beer festival and remember it standing out a lot.  A definite four-plusser.

Sombre, fruité, un peu vineux, peu damertume, forte en alcool, le seul point que je naime pas est le goût un peu savonneux typique de toutes les bières dunibroue sur le lie.  Leur levure à un goût caractéristique dont je ne suis pas fou.

One of the best Belgian Ales out there. Strong Dark and full of flavor. I would highly recommend.


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

A pours clear amber cola brown with high off white head that lasts. S - Belgian yeasts, dark dried fruit and cola. M - heavy bodied sticky sweet Belgian yeast. T - Belgian yeast, cola, gum and dried dark fruit. Slight hint of port.  O - sticky sweet darker Belgian 6/6+

Poured from a bomber into a tulip. Aroma is maple syrup and orange peel. Purple-brown with off-white head, dissolving quickly. Light lacing. Taste is grape jelly, maple and malt. Could use a little more hoppiness. Clean finish with little alcohol bite considering high ABV. Great brew from a great brewer. Just a notch under Terrible and Fin de Monde

Mabye my pour was messed up but I got a BIG 3 finger head that was thick and a l;ittle hard to get throw once or twice. Long lasting head that laces a bit but after half beer is gone its a 1 finger head. Smells of a sweet fruity smell with water & a tad chocolate. Looks like a grape or blum so dark cant see throw hint of red at light. Taste up frount quitckly watery and then fruity maily plum then in midle breifly @ one point is a little warmth & spice,then lightly in back is some chocolat & or caremal. More like a tripple or double trappist Beligum ale with hints of some dark ale. Its a crazy bastard that is allright but fails at being called extra strong dark ale and could use a little less %. One bottle fucks ya up! Cheers!

Pours a dark brown with bubbly tan head. Big ripe fruit aroma. Definitely winey overall. A perfect amount of sweet grape taste. Doesnt really stick around long making it tough to just sip and not keep going back for more.
Great appearance and muddy color.    A little too much fruit, almost soury and not a notable one.

Soft, dark malts, candi sugar, and a cascade of yeast characterize the aroma, giving it a citrusyy edge accompanied by some banana, raisins, dust, and other very ripe fruits. The palate is medium, somewhat dry and evenly carbonated. The finish is long and yeasty. Not my thing, but solid brew.

Jai goûté cette bière pour la première fois il y a quelques semaine! Wow quelle surprise! Moi qui suis amateur de bières type belge! Avec son odeur de fruits noir et sont goût légèrement sucré! Un délice!

Bottle. Dark brown with pretty cream head and decent retention. Aromas of roses, hint of lemon, and raisin bread. Tastes not too sweet with a dryness and bitterness and a hint of spice. Warm and boozy. Nice.
From the big bottle poured a beautiful, dark, coppery/red brew with a rich cream head. Medium bodied and delicious. Fruity, malty aromas and lots of malt flavor.

12 oz. bottle poured to a Maudite tulip at Lunar Brewing Co. displaying a deepest mahogany color with enough clarity to detect the ruby highlighting, a persistent, off white, frothy head, and clingy ribbons & spots of lacing. The nose was dark and mid-fruit, concord grape, light spice and sweetness, and a touch of tartness. The flavor was similar notes, adding effervescent, lively carbonation, low bitterness, a noncloying touch of brown sugar sweetness, yet a pleasantly dry character to assist in the drinkability and crispness. The alcohol content was somewhat hidden but still warmly complementary.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a fizzy light tan head that dissipates to nothing.  Aroma and flavor are lots of dark fruits (plums, figs, bit of cherry), clove, touch of banana.  Solid dark strong Belgian ale, but I guess I dont quite see why its all the rage.  Tastes like a very mild quad.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2013 Bottle. Pours a murky dark brown color with a half-inch of tan foam. Strong caramelized sugar, sherry and Belgian yeast fragrances in the aroma along with some raisin and allspice. The flavor is dark and sugary at the start with lots of caramel, clove, bread and fig upfront leading to some black cherry, toasted malt and port wine notes. Mouthfeel is full-bodied and silky smooth with a pleasantly spiced, alcohol warming finish. Rich and complex as a good Belgian Strong Ale should be.
This was very mellow but it had a nice flavor. 1/2 the way through I noticed the kick of the 9.0 abv!

I enjoyed this beer, poured from a 12oz bottle into a tulip glass, head is generous but dissipates to relatively small, aroma is pleasant and mild citrus, well carbonated, it is yeasty and the alcohol is noticeable.

This beer is pretty good and I enjoyed it but there wasnt anything that really grabbed me about it. The alcohol was a little too noticeable. Dark fruits are prominent. I would drink it again but I probably wouldnt buy it again unless it was on tap.

Nice scent.  A heapload of brown sugar, slight banana, clove that are in the background.  Malted caramel and honey notes round out the multi dimentional flavor.  Fairly sweet smelling with no hops.  Taste is lightly peppery, and slight seltzery effect.  Other than that, quite deep.  You have rasins, figs, plums.  Nice creamy head, not much retention though.  Extremely enjoyable, but still not on par with the Trappist breweries.  Enjoyability 5/5.

Bottle pours dark with nice head kind of thin body not much carb after it sits. Tastes smells of banana spice caramel plum raisin not much hops maybe small bit tart cherry. Too sweet for me wish more bit or even dry flavor was on dementional boring.
Very tasty beer. Pours a very dark, almost black, amber with minimal head. Aroma of sherry and fruit. Tastes including plum, sherry and cherry.

Bottle. Pours black with some reddish tones around the curves of the glass.  A little white head on top of this and minimal lacing.  The aroma is full of dark fruit, similar to a quad.  The taste is pretty full with a bit of cherry, fig, and plum.  Pretty solid.

12oz bottle from a Unibroue mix pack. Pours a dark reddish brown with a tan head and plenty of carbonation. One of the most complex beers I have had in awhile. Tons of flavors with new ones emerging as it warms. A few of the top ... caramel sugar, raisin, clove, fig, banana. Wait, vanilla? Maple? Oh man, it keeps changing but my glass is now empty. Need to get me some more of this to continue identifying many more flavors.

Bottle. Pours a murky dark brown color with a half-inch of tan foam. Strong caramelized sugar, sherry and Belgian yeast fragrances in the aroma along with some raisin and allspice. The flavor is dark and sugary at the start with lots of caramel, clove, bread and fig upfront leading to some black cherry, toasted malt and port wine notes. Mouthfeel is full-bodied and silky smooth with a pleasantly spiced, alcohol warming finish. Rich and complex as a good Belgian Strong Ale should be.
If not my favorite beer it is in the top three ever. Best overall color flavor taste in memory

Excellent beer from a excellent brewer, Unibroue. Pours a dark brown/amber color with a tan head. Head stays with the beer throughout the drink, with not much lacing left on the glass. Aroma is of dark fruits, clove, carmel and bread. Taste is a mouthful with lively carbination, easy on the palate, and goes down smooth. Very complex beer with many different flavors.

Pours very dark brownish red with almost no head (careful pour). Smell is raisins, plum, fig, and some spice. Pretty sweet smell. Taste is a bouquet of light and dark fruits, fig/raisin as well as orange/coriander, very nice finish. Very drinkable. Good beer.

From notes.  First reviewed 11/9/2011.  Poured from a 12 oz. bottle into a Trois Pistoles chalice at Firkin.

Out of the bottle Trois Pistoles pours a deep burgundy brown color that actually has some transparency to it. A bubbly tan head fizzes and fades to a collar and leaves a few spots of lace on the glass.

The nose is full of raisins, cherries, plums, and a bit of figs. Dark caramel malt is kind of light compared to the fruit. A little bit of ethyl alcohol is also noticeable in the back.

In line with the nose, the flavor is full of dark and orchard fruit. Some light caramel and bready malt up front supports raisins, cherries, plums, and figs. A white grape note imparts a crisp tartness at the end of the sip.

The body is actually a little bit on the light side, with bubbly crisp carbonation. It has a grainy feel up front with some tartness at the end.

This is something I would order again.

This and La Fin are the unofficial micros of Quebec to the outside world, even if they lead back to Japan now. As a result they are heavily reviewed on here. However, I owe to the brew and to myself to throw in a few words, since Unibroue was how I discovered Belgian ales nearly a decade ago. Trois Pistoles is the darkest and heaviest of the brewers original lineup, witha dark roasted coffee brown color and head that never fully recedes. Aroma is dark berries, heavy caramel malt and the signature yeast of the style. Sweet front and finish, bitter middle, though bitter isnt the right word here. Thick body yet very smooth and drinkable. A proto-quadruple from before the style was popular? Titles aside, this is excellent and the essence of a desert beer.

12oz bottle (from 4-pack), pours dark dark hazy brown with white head, dissolves quickly.  Aroma is complex, fruity.  Full-bodied, medium-bitter, a cacophony of taste.  I think this beer is incredibly good.

Pours an all-but-black colour with a beige head. Aroma is plenty of ripe fruit such as berries, prunes, raisins with hints of caramel and yeast. Taste is sweet fruit, caramel with yeast and spice notes all leading to a nice warm sweet finish. Nice soft mouth feel and so smooth the 9% alcohol is barely noticeable. Fantastic stuff.

I had one that was aged about a year....great great stuff!  Full of wonderful dark fruit flavor (cherries, blackberries, currant) and super smooth.  You cant tell theres alcohol in it at all, even at 9% its that smooth.  Delights your palate and works very well as the end of the evening.  Highly recommended.

Lots of fruit and red wine in the taste without any fermented nastiness. It had the bubble feel of a champaign.  Nice light brown color and a big cloud of raisin smells hanging out at the surface.  Fairly light bodied and very drinkable with an unnoticeably high abv.
Arome flagrant de petits fruits séchés. Robe brune violacée et mousse persistante. Goût de fruits comme la prune rôtié et dalcool. Bonne belge comparable à un porto.

I enjoyed this one. Lots of flavor and an awesome feel make this one fairly easy to drink. 

---Rated via Beerology

It had been awhile since I last had this beer.  Pours a dark ruby red to brown with a respectable head.  Aroma is malty, caramel, ripened fruit ala fig, raisins, grape.  Palate, very smooth and rich in flavour with a nice warm alcohol burn.  One of the best from Quebec.
Very smooth sweet taste. Good to drink one at the time. It is in the high limit of sweetness I can take.

Bottle 750ml (2010) [7/3/6/3/15)

Pours dark brown, with good offwhite head. Aroma of malt, alchool.Taste is of roasted malt, spices (Unibroue), alchool, fruits, unibroue classic yeast. Well balanced, good carbonation. Very sligthly watery, but makes for a good drinkability. 

Bottle 750ml. (2008: almost 4 yo)[7/3/8/4/16]

Pours dark brown, with almost no head. Aroma: sugar, riped fruits. Taste: sweet, malty. The yeast have calmed down, and is no longer taking as much place as it almost always do in Unibroue beers. Riped fruits. Carbonation is softer than the younger one. A good beer, that ages very well (good after 4 years).

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2012 2012.02.21 - 750ml bottle in Chimay glass. As itâs pouring it doesnât seem that dark but once the glass is full itâs quite dark and opaque. A one finger white foamy head lingers and eventually subsides, leaving a ring and a small surface film. Aroma is spicy and a bit of banana ester, maybe. First taste matches that, maybe adds a bit of fruitiness, but may change as it warms up. Mouthfeel is medium, not very thick and creamy, etc. Alcohol hidden pretty well for 9%. Later note: the beer having warmed up and me having finished most of it, Iâd say this is pretty similar to Affligem Noel.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2012 Really nice dark brown with a very thin white head. That white rim remains all the way down. Very complex in smell and flavor. Chocolate, coffee, burnt, dark fruit all come through. Moves away from the coffee/choc on the palate. Little sour off the start, then the sweetness finds you and itâs a smooth ride the rest of the way. Beautiful.

Not much I can add to whats already been said. If anything, I thought some strong Cheddar complimented this ale greatly by allowing fainter aromas such as burnt malt/coffee and nuttiness to better assert themselves alongside dominant phenol/ester profile. Like others, mine got better after warming up to near room-temp.
Brun öl med smutsvitt skum. Doft av jäst frukt och lätt kryddighet. Fruktigheten går igen i smaken. Lätt alkoholvärme som nte stör. Lätt rostad malt.

Poured from  a 750 ml bottle bought from Picks Liquors. 
Pours a dark cloudy brown with a fast fading tan head. Aroma of fig, spice, banana, and bread. 
Taste of banana, pepper, a bit of yeast with a slight alcohol taste at the end but its covered really well by the other elements. Not overly sweet and very well balanced. Another great beer from Unibroue.

Purchased at Breeze Thru Wine & Spirits in Milwaukee, WI; enjoyed on a Tuesday night stressed out from work.  Appearance a very dark, murky, dirty brown with a very thin off white head that rims around the glass.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, dark fruit, plums, a bit of sweet, a bit of pepper.  Taste is really yeasty, getting banana with a very very soft sour note, like a banana thats been left out for two days (as if I know what that would taste like, but I can imagine).  Additional element of pepper, smoothness from yeast, has a kick in the back end from the alcohol, dark fruit/fig quality, a bit of molasses.  This is a nice beer to drink after a hard day, I feel better, must be the alcohol kicking in!  Well done.
Långt varande skum på en mörk öl. Härlig arom av övermogna och jästa frukter. Minnen från barndomen hemma hos farmor och farfar och deras stora fruktträdgård. Citrus och i vin inlagd frukt i smaken.
Bottle. Dark brown pour. Slightly bready/yeast, more fruity aroma. Dark fruits mostly. Taste is a bit sour - but only enough to counter any over-sweetness from the fig and apricot. Great mouth feel.

12 oz bottle poured into a tulip glass.  Deep brown color with a tan head.  Sweet yeast/fruit aroma.  Very subtle sweet taste. Very nice balance.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Clear brown with off-white head.  Aroma is melon, over-ripe banana, light biscuit and a hint of spice.  Flavor follows suit with a fruity mix of melon, strawberry, and banana.  Baked bread, toasted malt, and clove.  Clean with medium mouthfeel.  No booze.  Well-made, but much too fruity and sweet for me.
Pours brown with a white head. Aroma is acidic as well as the flavor.. finishes banana.

Bottle poured into a HOTD tulip.

A - Pours reddish brown with a decent one finger tall white head leaving light streaks of lace down the glass.

S - Smells of all the usual dark fruits, cherries, candied sugar, and the fruity belgian yeast. The alcohol is noticeable from start to finish. 

T - Starts off with an bit of candied sugar sweetness quickly giving way to hints of dark fruits; mostly figs, raisins and figs; cherries and the typical fruity belgian yeast. Finish is still pretty sweet with a good sized booze burn.

M - Medium body and flavor with moderate carbonation. Smooth, creamy feel that really may be the best part of this beer.

O - I enjoyed this one. Lots of flavor and an awesome feel make this one fairly easy to drink. If the booze would die down a bit this one would be really good.
Dark brown pour with small head. Semi-sweet fruit (figs). Perhaps some aging would enhance the flavor.

Bottle.  Pours a deep coppery caramel brown with a medium to large tanned beige head.  Sweet dark fruits and chocolate on the nose, berries.  Medium bodied, smooth and malty, nice dark fruit, candied and caramel filled, but never cloying.  Beautiful.  Finishes with lingering light sweetness, a touch of bitterness, and more lovely fruit notes.  Such a wonderful beer.

Bottle, which said "best used before 070/7/14" poured an almost opaque dark ruby/purple with a small beige head that quickly settled into a ring.  Nose is of roasted malts and spiced rum.  Aroma is quite different and complex with raisins, cherries, and a bit of chocolate.  Tastes quite sweet, with lively carbonation.  Very drinkable for a 9% ABV beer, whose effects crept up on me.  It tastes even better after warming up a bit.  The most enjoyable sweet fruity beer Ive tried. This exceeded my expectations and is one Ill gladly try again.

#1147 bottle (2009); nose is hay, hazel, weak sweet alcohol, plum, red apple acid, feel is watery, carb is mediumheavy, taste is sweet alcohol, sweet cough syrup, some velvet sweet malt, later red apple

A dark brown pour with a small, tan head.  It has a sweet, malty aroma with some notes of raisin and light apple.  The medium body has a somewhat slick texture with average carbonation.  The taste is sweet and mimics the aroma with slight alcohol in the finish.

UPDATED: AUG 27, 2013 Pours a dense plum, amber-ruby in the light, with an off-white head that settles to a ring. Nose is sharp yeast, cherry, almost a little smoke, some more dark fruits. Brown sugar, molasses, and a touch of licorice come through, along with a touch of chocolate. Taste is a nice balance of bitter, sweet, and tart. None overpowers the other. Palate is light, effervescent, with a lingering bitterness and a little tartness. This drinks really easily for 9%. Begs for cheese pairings. Good stuff.

Bottle. Pour is ruby almost dark purple with a beige head, little retention/lace. Aroma is classic Unibroue house yeast: musty, fruity esters, dark fruits, medicinal notes, cherries. Taste is fantastic: black currants, raisin, fig, cherry, more medicinal notes, like drinking a dark fruit smoothie. Palate is somewhat syrupy, oily, soft carbonation, long fruity finish.

This bottle was part of a case lot bought in 2006. As described by ratebeer, but after five years in the cellar, oh BOY!  Mild port aroma and palate. Coating mouthfeel with Belgian sweet aftertaste. Wish I had more...

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
UPDATED: SEP 20, 2012 Pours a nice dark raisin colour. Smells malty and sweet. Grapes, raisins, malts and bready flavours. Very good.
How many times have I had this before I finally got around to rating it? The answer is I Dont Care. Dark and beautiful, smooth and supple.  Love this beer!

750 ml bottle into globe glass, best by 11/18/2013.  Pours clear dark reddish brown color with a fairly dense 2 finger khaki head with good retention that reduces to a nice lacing cap that lasts.  Some spotty lacing on the glass as well.  Aromas of big raisin, molasses, fig, chocolate, caramel, tart cherry, and spicy yeast.  Very nice aromas with good strength and complexity.  Taste of big raisin, chocolate, fig, prune, molasses, caramel, tart roasted grain, and yeast spiciness.  Lingering notes of raisin, prune, chocolate, caramel, molasses, and spicy yeast on the finish.  Medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a fairly creamy, smooth, and lightly prickly mouthfeel.  Alcohol presence is basically non-existent for being 9%; with only a slight warming on the finish.  Overall this is an outstanding and highly enjoyable Belgian strong dark ale.  Tons of fruitiness and complexity; with easy drinkability.

Thanks toSammy !
Head: none 
Colour: dark brown 
Smell: apricots,candy shop,caramel,sweet malts,cherrys 
Taste: anise start, irony sweet malts, lots of fruits and almundy taste, end is dry bitter with herby after , awesome but a bit thin

11.2 fl oz bottle. Very interesting deep brown / red / pink nearly solid color. Big, loud fizzing khaki head that quickly fades to minimal.  Very smooth carbonation. Nice texture and aftertaste. Great dark fruit aroma, very tasty and refreshing, even. Not a hint of bothersome alcohol, here. The whole brew is well put together. Finished off with a nice blend of spices. A bit of sweetness, little bitter, great spice. I could easily and happily drink a couple of these back to back during a rowdy night, if I desired. A great brew.
Poured a hazy red brown with a slightly pink head and left great lacing. Aroma is figs and spices. Taste is raisins, figs, and spices with alcohol coming through in the end. Great beer.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle with a best before date 9-8-2013 into a tulip glass.

A: Deep garnet, which looks black unless seen through a light. Carbonation bubbles meet a thick foamy tan head.

S: Sweet cherry medicinal smell, very pleasant. 

T: Very sweet and fruity, but in a syrupy way, but I mean that in the best way possible. Roasted malts and cherries make the flavor here with a slight spice.

M: Syrupy with good carbonation. 

O: I love this from the first sip. A very flavorful beer with good malty taste mixed with fruit. I like this a lot.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with an offwhite head. Smells of dark red berries and caramel malts with some spices. Tastes of a medium sweetness and very mild tartness. Medium bodied. Medium carbonation. Finishes with a warming alcohol.

A very tasty beer.
Pours a rich dark brown with a small pale head. Sweet but not cloying, lots of fruit notes without seeming like a fruit beer. Lots going on in this one.

Surprisingly dark ruby brown in color. Sticky sweet flavors of dark fruit, honey, yeast, and malts. Burnt sugar foremost, then subtle sweetness of fermented fruits. Very smooth with a lasting aftertaste.

First ever brew from Unibroue and definitely not my last. 1 pint 9 oz. corked and caged bottle poured into a snifter. Dark ruby color with a nice fluffy head. Aroma was beautifully floral, with a bouquet of ripe juicy fruits. The flavor mimicked the nose very well, nice and fruity but not sugary. I could taste a little bit of caramel and chocolate malt towards the finish as well as some yeast. Shattered my expectations! Very good dont hesitate if you find a bottle.

Pours a deep ruby color with almost no head.  Nice aroma of dark fruit, rum, fruit cake.  Active carbonation and a nice medium mouthfeel.  Tastes of ripened fruit, a little rum christmas cake, clove, bread and yeast.  Alcohol is present but not overpowering.  Another solid beer from Unibroue.

from bottle, malty aroma, sweet raisins, and some berries on the nose. Deep red in appearance with a thin laced head. complex flavour. Malty initially with roasted grains leading to caramel and sweet berries. blackcurrents. A little sweet for my taste at the time of drinking.

Pours deep red to black with a very light brown head that lingers well.  Nose is sweet and sticky with a complex blend of dark dried fruits like dates, raisins, cherries, and cranberries. Spicy yeast also in the aroma. Flavor is full on dark fruity esters, heavy phenolics. Sweet but not cloying at all and finishes a little sweet but appropriate and is balanced with some bitterness and carbonation.  Very smooth and easy to drink.  Very flavorful.

Denmark, Aug-Sept 2009. Bottle from Fonefan. Dark brown with red hue. Quickly disappearign head.Sweet malty aromas and flavours. Ripe fruit, caramel, burned sugar, slight alcoholic touch, licorice. A slow sipper for sure and great fora cold night.
Great looking beer, dark brown with reddish tinge.  Surprisingly mellow taste, malty but with little staying power.  Very clean in the mouth.

Pour is a deep dark brown with a small white tan head. Nose is of port wine, doesnt really even smell like a beer. Taste is not at all of the nose, much more of dark fruits such as plums and date, with some candi sugar background. very nicely done.

750ml corked and caged bottle from SI poured into my Chimay Trappist glass. Pours dark brown, almost purple with a minimal bit of white head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of concord grape juice, sour apples, and a slight bit of caramel. Taste is light sweet. Grapes, booze, sour green apples and a little caramel. Medium bodied with a creamy texture. Lively carbonation and a long finish. Overall, very good. I would like to drink this one again.
750 ml bottle.  Pours an opaque cola brown.  Aroma of dried fruit, spice, toffee, wood, wine.  Flavor is spicy, pepper, coriander, dried cherry, raisin, wine.  Quite a nice beer.  Very easy drinking.

750 ml bottle, aged nearly 2 years. Brown and foggy color, thin white head with good retention. Mostly tastes of field berries, a tad bit of caramel and the ever-present yet very enjoyable, classic "Unibroue yeast" flavor. Alcohol can be felt after a gulp or two, yet is not aggressive at all, considering the percentage. Body is not very thick, yet not too thin either. An extremely well-balanced ale, quite possibly Unibroues best one (although I still have to try La Terrible).

341ml bottle.  Pours a dark garnet, with a beige head.  Aroma is dried fruit, port, yeast, cherry, concord grape juice.  Delicious.  Taste is fruity, molasses, fruit cake, yeast, more of the concord grape, earthy notes, red wine.  Awesome.  At $12.95 a six, this is the same price as Keiths, and less than 6 Heineken or Corona.  A bargain!

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2011 Belle couleur bourgogne/violet sombre presque noir. Larôme me fait penser à une purée de prune et raisin avec une touche dalcool. En bouche, beaucoup deffervescence avec des notes de chocolat et despresso mais les fruits foncés dominent outrageusement cette potion. Je suis très curieux de les redécouvrir parce que dans mes souvenirs, la Trois-Pistoles était ma préférés de la série dUnibroue...Peut-être pas finalement. Reste que cest une excellente belge forte.

750mL bottle.  Pours dark brown with some ruby light escaping around the edges; small bubbly head.  Aroma is yeast and spice, some overripe fruit.  Flavor is sweeter than the aroma.  Slightly sticky, thin body, not near as carbonated as it appeared it would be, alcohol is completely hidden.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2011 Fantastica!! olor a maltas dulces y a frutas como ciruela,uva como un vino dulce de barrica, degustandola es una sinfonia, bien corposa deja pasando por el paladar dulces sabores a malta y fruta y una sensacion que me recuerda un buen oporto. Es una de las cervezas que mas me han impresionado,es algo divino
user_location: SANTIAGO DE LOS CABALLEROS, DOMINICAN REPUBLIC

text: Awesomely smooth and mellow, lots of fruits and finish of port wine.  Marvelous balance.  As usual, Unibroue seems to be a bit too carbonated for me but if you let it sit for a while and warm up it is perfect.  Dark dark color with hints of reddish amber.  This one might have maxed the rating scale for me had I not had the pleasure of trying Malheur 12.  This is in a similar vein to it.  Wonderful beer, must have again!

Pours dark ruby with a decent off-white head. Aroma is dark fruit, Belgian yeast and a hint of grape and green apple. Slightly creamy mouthfeel, light carbonation, medium body, slightly dry finish. Taste is plums, figs, malt, caramel.
bottle shared with northropfrye.  i thought i could smell a bit of cinnamon or clove.  bit of a floral or spruce taste.  quite a delicious beer.

Date: October 17, 2011 Mode: Draft Source: Flying Saucer
Opaque dark brown, fruity, belgian yeast, kind of like a red wine mixed with a champagne.  Very good.

Bottle 33cl. Brown beer with beige head. Aroma to sweet malted, caramel, brown sugar, orange, vinous. Taste is mainly sweet at the beginning, with hints of brown sugar and caramel. Final very light hopped and alcoholic. On palate results a beer well balanced, with average carbonation, medium to full body and creamy texture.
Pours a cloudy amber, with tan head. Aroma is sweet with malt and dark fruits. Taste is as a good belgian triple should be, alcohol is there, with lots of richness and complexity. Thumbs up.

6/10/2011 75cl bottle @ Pumpkin BYOB restaurant, Philadelphia - BB: OCT/1/10 (2011-539)
Note: fresh from the shelves, this bottle turned out to be a year past expiration date. With this beer, I can guess it only made it better...
Very dark bit cloudy brown beer, big beige creamy head, bit stable, bit adhesive. Aroma: dried fruits, fresh figs, some alcohol, bit of port, tobacco, dried orange peel. MF: good carbon, full body, alcohol noticeable. Taste: port notes, citrus and oranges, brown sugar, ripe fruits, dried figs and dates. Aftertaste: oranges, tangerines, milk chocolate, bit o tobacco, sweet, bit of alcohol, sweet cherries. Man, good stuff!

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2015 Tasted from large bottle into tulip glass. Poured a beautiful, very dark reddish-brown, almost black color with yeast haze and thick tan head, somewhat short-lived with nice lace. Aromas of Russian black bread, wild cherries, earth and wood, plums, currants, faint hops flowers, pepper, clove, and alcohol. Complex malt-sweetness alongside pronounced hops bitterness (not sure how they dont cancel each other out.) Toasty, roasty, hints of molasses, black coffee, dark chocolate, plums and black currants. Well-rounded "chewy" mouthfeel. Lingering fruity aftertaste. Spritzy, dry finish from hops, roasted grains, natural carbonation and alcohol. High-gravity but no harshness whatsoever. Surprisingly drinkable. Truly delicious.

Ported from BA.

Appearance:
Dark brown, similar to the color of the bottle. Through light more of a Dr. Pepper type color. Thats also consistent with the head, which dissipated very quickly and left minimal lacing.

Smell:
Belgian candy and a grapey flavor sticks out. It smells kind of like a dry champagne. I always find Belgian smells exciting, and this is no different.

Taste:
Again, the flavor initially reminds me of a dry champagne. It gives way to dark fruit flavors and oranges. Lots of orange actually. Imagine a dry mimosa in a glass. Very different.

Mouthfeel:
Bubbly and tingly. I have to make a champagne comparison for the 3rd category in a row.

Drinkability:
Not 100% to my taste when Im looking for beer, but I can certainly enjoy it. I see it as a solid Belgian style beer that lots of people who may not normally like beer could enjoy.
Yet another exceptional brew from Unibroue. This one surpasses Maudite in terms of quality and balance but is very similar when not comparing side-by-side
Rating 950. Very dark orange brown, nice head that should a bit longer. Just a small lace stays longer. A bit wheat, lots of yeast, dark fruits and lightly some chocolate. Sweet, good bitterness.

Reddish dark brown color. Medium creamy head. Malts and some sour aroma. 
Taste of malts, caramel and red fruits. Sweet aftertaste. Expected more
Pours dark with a nose of fruit. Aroma of citrus and fruit with a sour aftertaste. Very good.

750ml bottle. Cloudy reddish copper with a thick off white head that quickly fades out. Aroma of sharp, musty Belgian yeast, dates, caramel and chocolate. The flavor is dark fruit, caramel, earthy/cheesy yeast and a bit of alcohol warming. Medium to full body with soft carbonation and a long finish. This is a great beer and I remember drinking this 10 years ago thinking it was one of the best, most complex beers in the world. Still great but other beers have raise the bar since then.

Yet another outstanding brew from Unibroue! In fact, I cannot recall any of the brews from Unibroue that I have sampled were not of good quality character! This brew poured up a succulent, deep dark mahogany colored body topped with a large bubbly mocha-colored head that refuses to dissipate and then lacing that you will want to run your finger around the glass and lick up! Intense aromas of dark cherries, dark chocolates, and caramel. Medium-bodied, not one single bit of hiding that sweet alcohol flavor, and flavors of sweet malts, chocolates, cherries, spices with a refreshing and enticing dry finish with sweet notes of caramel aftertastes. It is getting very difficult to choose which Unibroue brew is the best  but then, why choose?!

I poured a 12oz bottle into a Belgian ale glass.Appearance: Dark brown color with dark red overtones. Forms a small, yellowish, sudsy head which evaporates almost entirely. Small, slowly-crawling carbonation bottles are visible around the edge.Smell: A basket of dark fruits: cherry, plum, fig, pomegranate, etc. A very organic, authentic fruit smell with slight presence of alcohol.Taste: Sometimes I think I should just have a template for my beer reviews because many of the "Belgian Strong Dark Ale" tend to taste extremely similar, if not exactly alike. Its the certain "je ne sais quoi" that separates them. Not that Unibroue Trois Pistoles is bad - far from it. Its more like the best kind of generic.Much like the nose indicates the palate here is a mélange of dark fruits. Cherry being the most prominent. Its sweet and rich, but never cloying. The beer finishes with a sharp, slightly dry bitterness and alcoholic kick. It reverts back to the fruit notes just as it goes down to bring it back full circle to the sweetness. The aftertaste is surprisingly clean - no sticky syrupy sensation, nor any dry alcohol residue. Im surprised.Mouthfeel: Only medium-bodied with a slight fizziness or minor vibration across the tongue. Drinkability: For such a big beer brewed in the style of Belgian strong dark ales, Trois Pistoles almost seems to be deliberately drinker-friendly. The palate is complex and tasty, but never cloying. The alcohol is noticeable, but not distracting - even at 9% ABV. The mouthfeel is thin and the aftertaste is clean and CO2 doesnt cause belching after each swig. This beer is dangerously drinkable!Overall, I think this is a good example of a what a Belgian strong dark ale can be as made by people other than Belgians. Id love to try a vintage of this to see what happens.

341ml bottle. Poured black with a small coffee head. Lots of carbonation. Aroma and taste are really unique, malts, brown sugar and dark fruit. Thick body without being heavy. Overall, one of the best beers Ive ever had.
How many times have I had this before I finally got around to rating it?  The answer is I Dont Care.  Dark and beautiful, smooth and supple.  On tap at El Rey Burrito Lounge in Montgomery.  Fine.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 Bière couleur de noisetier, voilée, où flotte un fin col dense de couleur de crème.  Des arômes affirmés et floraux de cerises confites et de grappa.  Légère amertume avec des pointes de sucre et dacidités notables.  Elle est crémeuse et veloutée, avec un corps solide.  Elle se termine sur dinterminables relents aromatiques.
Tap.  Pours black.  Strong up front taste of ripe concord grapes. Really unique flavor. Thicker palate.

Very nice beer.  Pours deep brown with light white head.  Nose is subtle and balanced with ripe fruits and berry.  Lively and fluffy in the mouth with immediate brown sugar and sweet wine moving to bitter raisin notes.  Slight whiff of alcohol to finish.  Real good.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2012 A: Deep ruby brown with a thick tan head... healthy carbonation... good lacing...

S: Sweet candy like banana aroma with some pepper and alcohol...

T: The taste disappoints the expectations the aroma gave me... mostly sweet malts with black pepper... the banana candy isnt as prevalent as youd like 

M: Medium-full bodied, mild carbonation.

O: Decent for a Belgian strong... not the top of the pack, but respectable effort

750 ml bottle. Thanks tiong!
Pours a dark brown colour with a small light beige head. Strong aroma of ripe fruits such as plum, alcohol and mandarin orange. Strong flavour of plum, mandarin orange, light spices and some wine-like tannin notes. Full bodied, soft carbonation and a long warming finish of sweet plum with alcohol. Overall a smooth Belgian Strong Ale with loads of plums.

750ml bottle from BC Liqour Store, Vancouver, BC

Pours dark brown with a white head. Aroma has notes of exotic fruits, plum and caramely malts. Taste is quite sweet with notes of plum, exotic fruits and caramel. Crisp finish has hints of port wine, not as malty as many other Belgian strong ales. Excellent, tasty and well balanced dark ale.

Serving glass: Poured from bottle into Snifter.

Appearance: Opaque and near black, but a tiny glimmer of red comes through in the light. Bubbly head and legs. Looks more dark brown once it nears the bottom of the Snifter.

Aroma: Dark fruit galore - plum, figs, raisins and various other sweet fruits which I cant identify. Some light banana as well.

Taste: Very nice mix of the semi-sweet and earthy. Plums and raisins are in full form, but notes of banana, clove and musty wood are apparent as well. Very complex, but surprisingly a little mild.

Palate: Low carbonation, full and chewy body that is pretty smooth. Finish is actually somewhat dry. Unfortunately, it is slightly watery; not sure how it can be both full bodied and watery, but there you go.

Overall: Very nice BSDA, with lots of complexity, but a little subdued and watery. Still great, just not the best of the best.
UPDATED: MAY 17, 2013 I was not to hot on this beer it was a bit too fruity for me. I like strong ales but this one reminded me to much of a wine.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2014 Bouteille 750 ml. 9%. Couleur brune foncé teinte rougeâtre, mousse beige. Arôme de raisins mûrs, porto, fruits, malt, agrumes et levure. En bouche, notes de vin fortifié, alcool, agrumes et autres fruits noirs mûrs. Un peu de pruneaux. Finale avec une touche damertume de torréfaction, pas trop sucrée. Une des meilleures dUnibroue.

Pours a cloudy dark dark brown with rocky off-white head.  Aromas: grapes, brown sugar/molasses, bread, plum.  Funky yeast, bit of barnyard behind it.  In my mouth, the first thing I notice is the surprising light body/thin mouthfeel.  The 9% is hidden and this is much more drinkable than I would have expected.  Oooh I start to get a big warm dessert spices moving in - cinnamon, nutmeg first and foremost.  Tasty!

Dark mahogany/chestnut pour with a fluffy white head that fades quickly.  Aroma of plum, raisin, caramel, toffee, and Belgian yeast.  Flavor is earthy and shows tart cherry skin along with the other dark fruits above.  Medium mouthfeel.  Good but not great.

Refrigerated bottle poured into a trappist glass.  Pours dark brown with small light brown highlights with small beige head that dissapates quickly.  Good small bubble lacing, well small bubble carbonation, medium body, and thick texture.  Taste is dark fruit, candied sugar, complex.  Good beer.

Medium bodied Strong ale.  Very smooth.  Mild bitterness.  Mild sweetness.  It tastes and smells like it has port and red wine in the mix.  After the third beer, it developed a bit of an artificial aftertaste, but still very tasty and enjoyable.
Smells of dough and earthy.  Pours dark and beautiful.  Tastes earthy and sweet, vaguely fruity.

Pours dark brown. The body was lighter than expected with a slight carbonation.  Taste was fruity with hints of caramel.  Overall, the beer was good, but did not meet my expectation.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark with a white head, aroma consists of fine cheeses and fruit (would probably go well with both). The 9% doesnt come through at all in the taste, very full bodied and rich. Excellent ale.
Great colour and head.  Tastes a touch of smokiness with the strong ale touch, reminds me of bush dubuisson.

Not impressed with this one at all. This is one of my biggest pans to date. This was thin, watery, medium-light brown with no body. It had a thin, fluffy head, and almost no flavor. It had some nice roastiness, but just tasted watered down and blah. 

The best thing about this beer was the aroma. Really saved it from being down to 3 or below. Had almost trappist trippel type spice aromas. Kinda nice, but nothing really exciting. 

Overall very unimpressed.
UPDATED: DEC 28, 2011 Bottle. Herbs and dried fruit aroma. Dark brown colour. Nice subtle fruity flavour. Abv well hidden. Very nice.

On tap at petrol station. Pours a hazy plum color with some amber and a near white head that dissipates nearly completely. Aroma is full of dark fruits, especially dark cherries and plums with a bit of yeast. Flavor starts with dark fruits that sweeten slightly to join a dark bread and plum finish.

Pours dark with a nice head. Aroma of yeast, bubblegum, dark fruit (plum, figs and raisin), spices (cloves,nutmeg)  some hay and banana. Taste follows the nose with dark fruit, yeast, cloves, some caramel and toffee notes and finishes with a hint of banana. Good medium mouthfeel, not to thin. Finish has a little alcohol burn but done just right. This beer will warm you up from the inside out. Great beer.

Uncorked and poured a dark mahogany color with a tan head. Primary aroma of dark fruit and spice with a host of others fragrances coming through. Smells delightful. Taste of dark fruit and some spice with a bit of caramel. Delicious throughout. Left a clean, dry finish. Medium body, very smooth and velvety. Very well balanced. Outstanding beer, one of the best I have had to date. Virtually no hint of the 9% ABV. Great choice for any occasion, even a quite evening.

Bottled poured into tulip.  Nice dark brown, nearly opaque, in color with a 1/2 finger wide, slightly brown head that drops to a thin layer quickly.  Aroma is great with notes of booze,  yeast, dark fruit, belgian spice, and muscats and champagne.  Taste is also outstanding and holds the nose up well.  Starts out sweet and malty before a big dose of those dark fruits and spices.  End gets more bitter with a sticky, lasting finish.  Well carbonated and oily across the palate.  This is a very complex, well crafted beer.  A little sweet or my tastes which is why I didnt rate it even higher.
Very fresh aroma. Not to sure it lives up to the hype. Hops are present but the malt bill def the complex part of beer. Alcohol is very well hidden. Flavor is nutty, fruity, creamy.  Pretty tasty.

July 11, 2011; corked bottle.  Dark.  Creamy, enduring head.  Aroma of overripe fruit; notes of herbs & spices.  Slightly sour, pleasant taste.  Some alcohol warmth. Not as heavy as I expected -- enjoyable even on a hot summer night.  Reminds me a bit of Ommegang Abbey Ale.  Will definitely pick this up again, and look forward to working my way through more of the Unibroue line.

Pours dark brown ruby with a halo of off white head. Smells of raisins, dates, bananas, some clove and other belgian spices. Taste of belgian candied sugars, a ton of raisins, dates, even figs and some belgian spicyness. This is medium thick and coats the palate well. The finish is sweet and boozy.

Pours dark and nearly opaque with a brownish-white and creamy head.  Very fruity aroma is clean and strong.  Taste is bold, complex and very good. Fruit overtones are backed by soft coffee and chocolate traces, and a slight toffee sweetness.  Hops provide a great balance and spice.  Mouthfeel is bubbly and thick.  Aftertaste is a slight spicy toffee with chocolate and coffee.  Amazing beer - its ones like this that put food to shame.  Simply amazing.

Bottle @ Chads house. Dark amber appearance with a light tan head. Belgian yeasty, toffee, caramel malty nose with a note of roasted chocolate. Well carbonated, toasty chocolatey, caramel, toffee, slightly vinous, Belgian yeasty flavor. Toffee, caramel aftertaste. Pretty tasty brew.

most of the North American brewers tend to rely too much on sugar on the palate. this is one of the few that I would give exception too, having an overall taste similar to barley port wine? yep, pretty good stuff for an after dinner dessert. 
thanks Unibroue from Texas.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2014 Bière très foncée avec une pointe rougeâtre. Odeur de petits fruits, de fruits séchés et de céréales. Goût de baies (framboises et mûres) et dépices. Légère amertume et touche dalcool peu perceptible malgré quelle en contienne un taux élevé. Très bonne bière. / / Vieillie de 2 ans et demi. Elle ma semblé encore meilleure. Les petits fruits ont laissé plus de place aux épices, qui elles, sont rendues très prononcées; Gingembre, cardamome et muscade. Le goût encadre bien les parfums. Les mêmes épices sy retrouvent. Une touche acidulée ferme la marche et une rondeur lente et réconfortante caresse le palais. (R-190514)

Bottled. Dark reddish brown colour with a nice creamy off-white head. Malts, dry dark fruits, slight yeast and caramel in the aroma. The flavour is very full, dry dark fruits, caramel malts, vanilla, slight roasted twist along with berries and yeast. Also some spices in it.

Beautiful deep clear amber brown light off white head .... aroma of dark overripe fruits plums, raisins ..... smooth no trace of abv at all perfect mouthfeel ... Taste is of raisins, plums, dark overripe fruits, light spice and belgian candi sugar with a dry fruity malty finish ittle grainy at the end and light hop

The pour was dark and foamy, looked a lot like coca cola, with a thin head and messy lacing. Aromas were mellow and sweet, consisting of hops, vanilla, cherries, yeast and maple. The flavor was a rush of complex fruitiness and spicy notes; Yeast, fig/raisins, dates, maple and a bitterness of grapes is to say the least. The alcohol, which isnt well hidden, gave it a warm and spicy touch that put this brew over the top. Complex, warm and fruity are three words to sum up one of the best Belgian strong ales in the world.

This Canadian-made Belgian strong ale is definitely worth a try. 750ml bottle poured into a Trappist glass at around 8C. Poured a very dark amber with light bubbly head that dissipated over 60 seconds and lingered as a light frothy top. Moderate carbonation. Around is fruity. On the palate feels light and crisp on front, smooth on the way down, and a reasonable lingering alcohol burn on the finish. Taste is definitely fruity with some licorice. I do notice the flavor as (very) similar to other beers from this 
brewery. Overall, nice and enjoyable but just shy of top notch in my opinion.

Bottle. Dark pour with a moderate sized off white head. Aromas of figs, prunes, raisins, molasses, booze, toffee, yeast and candy. Taste is very similar. Lots of ripe fruit. See above, Im lazy. Well balanced beer that could have easily been a mess if not tamed properly. Probably the best Belgian strong I have had.

750ml Bottle split with mcberko. Pours murky dark brown with a lasting thick caramel head. Aroma of yeast, brown sugar, maybe some spice. Quite subtle on the nose. Flavour of yeast, brown sugar, a little coriander, dark fruits, candied fruits. Flavour continues to improve the more you drink. Very yeasty. Good.
Very dark amber almost black color. Almost no smell. Sweet fruity and almost cocoa taste. Clean fruity palate
UPDATED: APR 20, 2015 Wow, interesting!  Dark brown pour under a thick tan head.  Caramel and coffee scent, mildly sweet taste, well hidden alcohol.  Well done!

Cloudy, dark ruby red in color with a thick, creamy head. Average lacing. It smells like mint toothpaste. Raisin comes out in the aroma much later to me. Orange and cherry are prominent in the taste. High in carbonation. Oily texture with a smooth finish.

750 ml. bottle- shared with anderson01- Pours dark dark red with an off white head, aroma is Belgian yeast, figs, cherries. The taste is sweet candy sugar, Belgium yeast, cherries, maybe even apples. Carbonation is medium, body is full. The overall impression is impressed, nice beer.

Pours a dark cola color with ample light tan foam.  Aroma is red wine and prunes.  Rich sweet flavor like burnt sugar, almost cloying.  Some tartness becomes evident, like a good dry red wine.  Interesting.

bottle brought back from home; cloudy, dark brown to black with medium tan head; aroma-a light dubbel: sweet, dried fruits, raisins and plums, alcohol, roasty; taste-medium sweetness and bitterness with a touch of saltiness, mild carbonation and warming feel of the alcohol. First beer after a two week hiatus-feels great!

Used a snifter. Pitch black, ¼ white head, and medium carbonation.  Pretty good lace. Nose of light raisin and maybe a dark fruit. Taste of figs. Dark fruit with much more sweetness then when it was cold.  I pickup the ABV a bit as it warms but its not offensive.  Nice to try but not running to the store to buy again.  AirForceHops shared his bottle with me.

750 ml bottle pick up at the local grocery store.  Deep red, almost purple with a light red hue around the edges when held to the light. Initial taste is sugar and grapes. Some plum as it warms up. But, I wouldnt say its like a port wine.  I had a few port wines many years ago while stationed in Europe.  Doesnt remind me of any of them.  I am wondering if Unibroue uses the same yeast for most of their beers.  Doesnt seem much different from the last one I drank just over an hour ago. Not bad,  just not much different from some of the other Belgian Strongs from this brewery.
pours peach, copper, tan minimal head. apple juice, apricot on the nose. fluffy, light body with lots of carbonation. lots of fruit with a slightly dry, tart finish. Interesting but not my thing.

2008 33cl bottle from my beer cellar, shared with friends.
Not much head.  Amber colour.  Port aftertaste
Bottle shared with friends.  Pours clear brown with small head.  Aroma of dark fruit and malt.  Flavor with candy and raisin.  Good balanced beer

Bottle, pours dark black, pretty tasty stuff, aroma of spicy/yeast beligan like stuff. Taste is a pretty spicy and yeasty taste as well, bit of dryiness, almost tastes watered down or something in the back end but not bad, Decent tasting stuff

750 mL bottle in a Trappist glass.  Dark brown pour with small tan head.  Roasty aroma.  Very refreshing for such a strong beer.  Nice cocoa flavor with a hint of hops to balance it out.  Doesnt drink like a heavy strong ale.  Excellent

Dark brown pour with quickly dissapating head. Aroma of raisins, plum and ripe fruits. Taste of ripe plums, raisins and a dash of caramel and malts. A little heavy but very enjoyable from a world class brewer. Good job.

Pours a dark brown, medium carbonation, nice head that melts away to good lacing. Aroma is pretty complex, reminds me of other Belgian Strong Ales. Lightly sweet, can definitely taste the port influence. This is a great beer in moderation, 1 goes a long way.

Bottle from Mane Liquor. Pours a dark mohogony with a very small beige ring for a head. Loads of cherry and sour fruits on the nose. taste is sweet raisins, currants, plum and sour cherries. Yeast throughout. Great beer

Bottle. Pours a dark purple color with a foamy thick head. Smells of graped, cherries and wine. Taste is boozy but sweet and easy drinking. Really good represenation of the style. Kind of reminds me of the tader joes vintage bottle that was put out this year

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2013 75cl bottle into Chimay glass...and I gotta finish this bottle all by myself. 8) Strong, fruity scent. Nose of raisin, grape, caramel, bubblegum, earth, chocolate, coffee. This is one of the most yummy smelling beers Ive encountered for sure. The appearance is a great dark red color, solid three finger off-white head...great! Taste...holy cow, pretty damn good. Candi sugar, malt, licorice and coffee. A bit yeasty. Pretty well balanced, I cant believe these guys pulled this off. Palate is smooth, balanced, co2 well implemented. Thick and creamy too. I will be revisiting this one from time to time.
The beer version of a port. Randomly selected a bottle of this at a World Market. One of my better choices. Recommended.

750 ml bottle served at 43-50 F

Poured a very dark Mahogany with barely any head and a slight bit of lacing.

 Aroma of CLOVES then came some cherry and other fruit notes

Tasted of cloves then as it warmed up came the fruitiness and a wee bit of alcohol, some notes of toasted malts.

Felt warm and creamy then a cleanliness that was apprciated in the end. Not as good as Chimay (blue) Grande Reserve but a solid drinker.
Another excellent strong Belgian style beer from Unibroue. Rich, deep taste that hides the high alcohol content. A lot of flavour but also highly drinkable.

355ml bottle into trappist glass. Deep purple-brown pour. Head dissipated rather quickly. Aroma of yeast (like all Unibroue) and dark fruit. Taste is yeast, raisins, malt, ripe fruit, alcohol. A little sourness. A nice beer, but I prefer La Fin du Monde or La Maudite.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2011 750ml.  Perfect cellar temp.  Pours mahogany with a towering bubbly off-white head that slowly works its way down.  Aroma is of sweet spice, alcohol and doughy yeast; very nice.  The first taste I notice is orange and raisin leading its way to some spice that lingers.  There are so many different flavors here it is hard to pin point just one at any given time - licorice, clove, yeastiness, nuts, etc.  The alcohol is warm and welcome, but doesnt take over.  This is a sophisticated beer that needs to be enjoyed slowly to take in all the depth that it has to offer.  Very nice.

Dark brown but clear pour with a head that increases in size as it sits and warms.  Aroma is of yeast and cough medicine, a little bit of spicy roastiness as well.  Taste not as bad as the smell but mostly reminds me of medicine and bathwater.  Mouthfeel is lively, almost as fizzy as champagne. Sort of o.k. dark fruit aftertaste, but nothing close to an old porto. This beer is basically a bottle of yeast. How the f is it so highly regarded? Drain Pour For Sure.

Very dark but not black.  Off-white head.  yeasty nose with a hint of caramel sweetness.  Not surprisingly, this is a bit spicy.  Malty, yeasty and highly carbonated so a bit prickly on the tongue.  Clean finish.  nice and tasty.  With dinner at Bistro 55 Unibroue beer dinner.

Ale on the Lees?  I say more like yeast in a bottle.  Not getting what everyone else is tasting - all I get is that strong taste of Belgium yeast over powering everything else.  If you read my review of their Maudite beer which I intend to post  in a minute chances are my review will be about the same.

As far as Im concerned everything I have tasted from Unibrou to date has tasted about the same.  This one is at least drinkable.  Some of them have been down right terrible (like the one they call La Terrible!)

Id like to get T&Vs opinion on this because it sure aint my cup of tea - or bottle of beer as the case may be!!!

~1 of 13
Its good, but its not 100.  Something of a sour taste, but only mildly... afterward, a nice sweet aftertaste.  Pretty nice, a good Unibroue example.

12 oz. bottle that was way to cold for this type of beer. Pours dark brown with thin head. Aromas of dark fruits and belgian yeasts, flavor is the same. Sweet malty taste. Full, silky body. I havent really liked Unibroue beers that Ive tried, but this is one an exception. Ill have to try it again at the right temperature.
What a fantastic beer! Dark, malty with strong alcohol presence (in a good way) with a hint of something I cant quite place. Love it.
Nice deep color, good malt and fruit notes, slightly wine like with a hint of sour.

Appearance: Pours black with a thick beige head. Aroma: Smells strongly of malt, nuts, with hints of a smokey flavour. Palate: A very full-bodied beer, but it also feels too dry. Taste: Very strongly of alcohol, very very sweet and very savoury, not bitter at all. Pretty good.
Dark, nice head and lacing. Fruity - cloying, a bit like cough syrup, yeasty. Over-carbonated. Unibroue makes much better than this. Drinkable, but not all that enjoyable.

Pours a deep cola color with a big fluffy off white head... its more like a gargantuan off white head at first, it leaves some lace but it fizzes out relatively quickly considering its initial gurth. The aroma is spicy and reminds me of potpourri a bit but this gives way to some banana and some liqueur. As the beer warms the aroma gets a bit nutty and has some cherry notes. All around the nose on this is just very spice focused. The flavor is dry and spicy and almost a bit overwhelming at first, but as the beer warms it opens up quite a bit, balances its self out well, and sweetens up a tad. The beer has a distinct note of cherry cordial and the spiciness melds well with the tart pear and berry notes throughout. I just cant believe I hadnt tried this yet, easily one of my favorites from Unibroue.
UPDATED: FEB 20, 2012 Pours very dark.  Sweet flavours of fruit, malt, yeast, and alcohol.  I dont think it has much in common with port, other than that theyre both delicious.  A great beer.
poured dark very little head. nice flavour of malts with some tart fruits, raisins, plums. good beer.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2011 Pours a clear, redish-brown, quite dark, under a thin head that remains to cover most of the top of the body.
Aroma is very appealing: Coppertone Suntan Oil with banana oil and citrus carrying light fruits like a lot of cherry and some peach. 
Best of the taste is what carries the nose.  The result is a little sweet and a little sour.  Pretty good. 
Palate is a bit too effervescent and lively for me.  There is a a clean, abrupt, bitter finish.  However, there is some creaminess that is satisfying and lingering and leaving a nice, filling warming.  "Porto" I dont get but get some caramel and prefer the stronger flavors like these.  There arent many better than what all is here.

On tap at Brews Cafe in Granville, Ohio.  Surprisingly dark ruby brown in color.  Sticky sweet flavors of dark fruit, honey, yeast, and malts. Burnt sugar foremost, then subtle sweetness of fermented fruits.  Very smooth with a lasting aftertaste.

Poured into a Unibroue glass. Trois Pistoles pours a rich balck color with a slightly off-white head that fills the glass at first and then drops off to about a quarter of an inch. Beautiful fall fruits on the nose. Pear and apple particularly with a ton of cloves. The flavor of the beer matches the baked apples and pears and cloves from the aromas perfectly. Warm mouthfeel, but not from the high alcohol. High carbonation as well. This would have to be my favorite Unibroue overall.
12oz bottle. rootbeer like appearance. yeast, bready aroma. solid tasting nicely carbonated. dark fruits and malts. light alcohol and yeast finish.

Poured from a 750ml bottle. Smells of candied fruit and sweet bread. Appearance is like an extra thick cola (Hold it to a light and good luck seeing through it). Tastes like it smells; very sweet as well as malty. Very carbonated on the tongue, not unlike a slightly muted (Again) cola. Overall, incredibly satisfying.

It pours a dark amber almost brown with a white head that doesnt last and poor lacing.

It smells very sweet, sweet hops a nice unique aroma.

The taste is great nice dark hops and incredidbly drinkable for its abv. Very reminesicant of a quad.

The pour produced a decent head that dissipated quickly.  The aroma had a nice spicy smell, but I am unable to name the spices.   That first sip let me taste the alcohol, which I love in a beer.  I really like a strong beer.  As I finish the glass, it is only getting better.

I poured a 12 oz bottle into a tulip...

The beer is a very dark brown with mahogany on the edges of the glass. The head is off white and extremely lofty, it stuck around throughout the process. The beer smells of orange and grape and has a bit of sourness to it. First you taste fruits such as dates and plum, a smoothness washes over the tongue leaving a sweet, bready aftertaste. The beer is medium bodied with lots of soft carbonation, does not have a dry finish. This beer is a must dry, Unibroue has failed to disappoint so far.

Bottle pours deep red/brown with a khaki head.  Aroma shows notes of caramel, fig, prune, raisin, and cocoa.  Flavor shows the same with additional notes of apricot, clove, and vanilla.  Overall body is full and 
rather sweet.

750ml bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a nice layer of light tan head that settles to a solid creamy lacing. Huge belgian yeast on the nose, spices, cant discern individual fruits but definitely get something fruity/sweet. Fizzy and light in the mouth, get the typical unibroue spices and sweetness up front and lingering bitterness on the end. Leaves a nice mouthfeel afterwards making you want more. Would be great paired with something spicy, maybe indian. One of my favourite unibroues - need to remember to buy it more often

Poured from a bottle into a snifter. Appearance is a very dark brown with highlights of a caramel color resting underneath a grayish-white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma is of dark fruits, figs, prunes, raisins, some sweet molasses-like accents are in there as well. Nice complexity to the aroma. Taste is very much like the aroma with the prunes and raisins being the dominant flavors and an almost wine-esque, dry finish to it. For such a high ABV beverage, this is very smooth and drinkable. I would say it is very much a medium bodied beer despite wanting to say its located more on the heavy side.

Bottle from Knightly Spirits. Bought this along with three other Unibroue brews. This one had an initial smell of apples/fruit. Trois Pistoles poured a nice dark red/brown color that was quite appealing. Carbonation was similar to a soft drink as in, not over bearable but quite high. Taste was pure fruitiness and spice all the way. This beer hides its alcohol content especially well so be careful. Excellent!

Subtle sweet fruity aroma. Nice reddish-brown color. Very fizzy and surprisingly light-bodied on the tongue. Tasty, dry carmely malts and dark dried fruit. Sneeky and strong alcohol.  I love it, but would like more aroma and less carbonation. One of my favorite belgians (albeit Canadian.)

Pours dark brownish red with white head, aroma has big notes of complex dark fruit, fig, raisin and date come to mind, along with some cherries, toffee and molasses.  Taste is nice dark fruit, cherry, some ripe red fruit along with the complex dark fruits, finishing spicy, sweet, and dry.  Very nice beer, many layers and definitely a sipper.
On tap at Zenos.  Aroma is apple.  Flavor is sweet dark fruit and some caramel.  Good but not great.

On tap at FFF. Pour is dark ruby with a nice off white head initially; retention is mild, lacing is average in this snifter. This brew is almost medicinal initially on the nose. Spices, dark fruits, and Belgian sugars are present here; cherry pits, shortbread, spices, coriander, and a slight earthiness. This brew is medium bodied, slightly bitter, and nearly vinousness, indeed.

Oh the aroma is good. Its like a sweet desert that I know I had and loved, but in my drunkeness cant remember the name. Trust me though, its good. The sweetness bleeds through into the taste and hides the 9% ABV very well. Just figured it out, a baked apple with brown sugar. Overall, a very good dark beer which will be added to my private reserve collection.
Dark, luscious. It has some spice to it including licorice. Just a fine, fine brew.

Pours out the way youd expect a Belgian Strong to: murky dark brown with a white head that didnt linger long.  Oh, but that smell!  It smelled like fruit cake, but not in a negative way.  Brown sugar, belgo-yeast, cherries, plums and figs.  Wonderful aroma.  And the flavor only accentuates the smell.  On the palate it is delicate, hiding shyly its high-ish ABV, but is full bodied enough to intensify the flavors.  You get all the ripe fruits and brown sugar-laden fruit cake action from the aroma, but the finish is slightly boozy-sweet with notes of port wine. A magnificent beer on its own terms, but would go superbly as/with dessert.
Trois Pistoles has a great Belgian yeast aroma followed by some hints of caramel. Tastes incredibly similar to a barely wine, but has an after taste of a strong port. Smooth and delectable.
Another very good dark ale from Unibroue with that great yeastiness and dark fruits flavors in it.

I like unibroue but sometimes there stuff all tastes the same...or sort of the same. i think its the bottle conditions and type of yeast. anyway, this had the usual taste but those dark fruts and toasty malts. alot of carbonation. nice dark color with off-white head. solid beer. it almost seemed like ome kind of unknown style. a dark beer with a ton of carbonation and hefeweizen yeast....

UPDATED: APR 13, 2012 Trois Pistoles poured a dark and opaque brown with a violet hue. Slightly less than one finger of creamy beige head developed and quickly receded.

The aroma is extremely complex. If there is anyone out there that wished to argue that all beers are similar or you cant appreciate them as you would a fine wine  I challenge them to smell this beer.

Ill have to have a more focused tasting sometime but the aromas I mentally jotted down were of plums, raisins, brandy, rum, spices, roasted malts, and a touch of chocolate. A very impressive nose on this brew.

The flavor is an extension of those nose. You are taken on a ride starting with roasted malts tinted with caramel and molasses flavors. As the malts fade away I get lots of ripe dark fruits that seem both a touch sweet and a touch bitter. The finish is dry and nutty with a touch of smooth sweet chocolate.

The complexity of the flavors in this beer have done a wonderful job of concealing the 9% ABV. Even when savored the bottle seems to be gone far too fast.

It is medium bodied with a thick and smooth mouthfeel that holds through the entire beer. This was an absolutely delightful beer.

Poured into an snifter.

3.5 A: Dark brown in color. One finger of frothy light tan head that falls fairly quickly and doesnt leave much lacing.

3.5 S: This one needed to warm up quite a bit before the aromas started poking out. Plenty of fruitiness: plum, grape, and raisin. Theres even a touch of citrusy lime in there. Also a touch of solvent. Pleasant, but fairly weak.

4.0 T: Taste for the most part follows the nose. Dark fruitiness with plum, grape, raisin, and prune. Some toffee in there as well. The malts are okay, but somewhat boring. The good part about this beer, as in most Unibroue beers, is the yeast. They use a wonderful strain. Peppery and a unique yeastiness not really found anywhere else.

3.5 M: Lighter medium body. Perhaps a touch too much carbonation, but I do like the spritziness. This could use a bit more body. Otherwise very smooth.

3.5 D: This is a pretty tame beer overall and one that just about anyone could enjoy. Indeed, I enjoyed it, but it isnt mindblowing. I love the flavor of Unibroue yeast, but prefer it in a better application (such as Maudite).

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-07-2010 01:37:34

12oz bottle.  Murky brown black.  Thin, soda-like beige head.  Deep chocolate covered dark fruit tones, a little pungent and sweet.  A really awesome dark Belgian Ale.  Very well balanced, despite the minimal hop character.  Caramel, brown sugar, prune, raisin.  Smooth and yeasty, quite deliciously drinkable.  One of my favorite Unibroue beers.
Just buy the 4 pack! These beers are great! This one has a very bold flavor and a hint of citrus in the aroma

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2011 Original rating: Dark reddish-brown pour. Ripe vinous aroma coupled with dates and spices.  Banana bread, dates, brown sugar, maple syrup and boozy alcohol. Very little hop influence. Dry, tannic finish typical of other Unibroue products. Far too much carbonation for the style. Not really sold on this. 8-3-7-2-11 >> 3.1

UPDATE 31/7/11: A different bottle that had been aged an extra year in total. Pours beautifully; a very dark brown with a fine, lightly-dappled head that leaves lace and retains almost endlessly.
