Aroma of port wine, grape, spices, christmas cake, molasses and a light Belgian funk. Starts with assertive dark fruits, followed by delightful sweet malt bread flavours on the sides of the tongue and then a dry, very mildly sour finish. Full bodied. The carbonation has also mellowed with age. What a difference an extra year makes. Accompany this with the smelliest cheese you can find.

Very deep brown with a small head. Aroma is quite malty-fruity; dark fruits, cherries, pears and apricot. Flavor is chocolate malt and dark fruits and berries. Creamy palate that gets bubbly after a sec.
A very nice complex Belgian Strong. I got lots of roasted sweetness, spices, and dark fruits. A very nice beer to have at anytime.
Pours with no head from a bottle. Nice brown color. Flavor full of complexity and spiciness.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2011 The port wine of beers!  Absolutely love this one as an after dinner/desert treat.  So smooth and complex.
dark color, extremely complex strong ale and possibly my favorite cold weather beer to drink

Poured a maroon/rust dark reddish brown with a solid amount of off white head that disappeared quickly. Smells winy, with lots of dark fruit, a touch of chocolate, and that Belgian yeast yielding a tropical scent as well. Taste is even better, as its an assortment of different fruit, but not exactly "fruity". Peach and currants are what I picked up, but there was a lot more too. Chocolate in there as well (although not the chocolate taste you normally expect). Feel nice on palate, with the consistency of the beer (average/thick) allowing it to sit on your tongue and bring about a new flavor every couple of moments. Very drinkable beer, and a great offering from Unibroue overall.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2012 pours dark murky brown with a generous tan rocky head. dark roasted malts, grainy, chocolate, burnt caramel, some smoke, ripened fruits, plums, figs with resinous hops - distinctive unibroue spicy belgian yeast. masterpiece!

Sweet ripe fruity flavor mangoey belgian yeast aroma, but sweeter probably due to the yeast at the bottom appearance is a dark brown, first taste is mild bitterness then some sweet fruit like flavors that are very well controlled and not too sweet then finishes dry, definately one of my top favorite belgian beers

Pours a deep dark brown with a thin white head.  Looks like soda just less carbonated. Aroma is dark fruits, raisins and belgian yeast. Flavor is sweet, somewhat fruity like you would get from a wine then a finish of the unmistakeable taste of that Belgian yeast and some warming alcohol on the very end but its not overpowering it really adds to the depth and complexity of this beer. Very smooth on the palate and perhaps too drinkable for its alcohol content. Unibroue makes some damn good beers. Now Lets Go Pens!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2011 I will start by saying I have drank copious amounts of this beer and will easily say it is one of my favorite beers. Pours a deep dark brown with edge that in light will turn a shade of ruby with terrific fluffy  two finger beige head. Aroma of candied  fruit, raisins, prunes, alcohol, and yeast. Creamy and smooth mouth feel with a very well hidden alcohol. Taste of dried fruits, raisins, bread, small amount of chocolate and yeast. This beer is extremely well balanced and very affordable for such a high quality beer. An easy choice for anyone in Ontario looking for a world class beer.

Pours a deep dark brown with the edges of the glass almost tan/amber, beautiful beer.  The nose has hints of bubblegum and apple tart with a hint of yeast.  The flavor starts with an intense sweet flavor of bananas/bubblegum and then transitions to a mildly bitter malt with just enough carbonation and bittering hops to leave an enticing bite inviting you to take another sip.  The palate is fairly dense, and adds to the enjoyment of the beer, but is not the best Ive encountered.  This, overall, is an incredible beer and is definitely worth the $10 pricetag.
extremly drinkable goes down smooth not heavy  dark fruits sum carbonation really good!!!
Wow. A delicious, well-bodied beer that doesnt feel at all heavy. Extremely drinkable. Another great testament to the beers of La Belle Province.

On tap at Yardhouse Irvine just before Disturbed concert! A darker beer pours out with a minimal head. Smells of dark ripe fruits plums grapes and beeries. Roasted malts provide some sweetness but there is very little hop pressence. Warming effect due to alcohol but definitely drinkable. Another good brew to go along with La Fin and Mauldite. Enjoy.

A - Fruity with strong sour cherry.
A - Hazy dark with thin white head.
T - Sweet to stronger sour to nice mellow bitter finish.
P - Full bodied with medium carbonation.
O - Complex, but controlled. A really good beer.

pours almost like a cola with a head that disappears quickly. aroma is of black cherries and yeast, taste is also yeast and cherry, medium carbonation and mouthfeel. i really enjoyed this beer and look forward to trying more from this brewer.

The beer pours a dark brown color with some nice red highlights and a huge tan head. The aroma is Belgian yeast, sugar, cherries, plums, alcohol and maybe a little bit of anise. The flavor is Belgian yeast and cherries, along with some candy sugar, raisins and some darker, but not roasted, malts. There is a little bit of spicyness in the flavor as well as some alcohol that is very warming. Very drinkable. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. A classic Belgian-style ale that I could drink everyday.
Hazy brown beer witha  small tan head. Aroma is sweet. Tastes sweet, with a hint of anise. Nice beer with a slightly alcohol finish.
(bottle) Almost a cola-like aroma.  Sweet, floral and dark fruits.  A pleasure to drink.  Perhaps a perfect winter beer.

Bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a small tan head.  Aroma of dark fruits, spices, Belgian yeast.  Flavor of bready malt with plenty of spices (peppery mostly) and some light fruity undertones.  Overall a little boring, but what Ive come to expect from Unibroue.  Meh, drinkable but nothing Id pick up again.
7/4/7/3/14 [3.5/5]

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2011 Pours a nice muddy, dark red with sediment.  Smell is belgian yeast and deep, but subtle red wine. Taste is slightly sour cherry, yeast, and other kinds of dark fruit. Extremely drinkable. Phenomenal beer.
This beer has a great sweet smell. It is also quite bubbly; the little "D" and the bottom of my Duvel glass was going crazy. This beer is one that can be enjoyed over the course of a night.

12oz bottle in a shaker.  Pours dark brown with a beige head.  Aroma of Belgian yeast, dark fruits, and some malts.  Flavor about the same, a little sweet, and a long toasty aftertaste.  Full bodied.  A pretty good beer, and one of this brewerys best.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2011 Sampled from a 341ml bottle purchased at the beerstore. Pours a dark brown almost black cola like, with a fast to dissipate white head. Lacing is cascading bubbles, just brilliant. Smells of dark fruit. Taste is of dark fruit, figs, prunes and raisin and bitter. An amazing beverage that would not bother you to drink all night.

From the moment you first inhale the full aroma to the sorrowful last swallow and long, pleasant finish, this is beverage well worth your time and the investment. Surprisingly smooth for the high alcohol content. Not a bit boozy. Just extremely nice.
Dark Ruby with a medium rocky beige head. Aroma is Raisin, dark fruits, herbs. Medium body with fizzy carbonation. Taste is sweet, caramel, a bit of sourness at finish. Good as usual...
Deep brown hue with a thick tan head. Smells distinctly Belgian. Raisins and maple syrup. Spicy sweetness followed by a slightly sour finish. Good dark Belgian.
An all time favorite.  Very complex on the palate - definitely the port of beers.  Very enjoyable by itself or with cheese or dark chocolate.   A winer treat.

Bottle into Trappist glass.   Pours dark reddish-brown, little to no head.  Smells of dark malts and fruit.  Taste is sweet, yeasty with moderate carbonation.  I can see the port wine reference with each taste.  Medium body.  Warms a bit going down, but not boozy.  Outstanding beer.

Bottle brought to me in the suitcase of a dear friend. Pours out a cloudy brown. Little to no head. Interesting full aroma. Smells of sweet dried fruit. Dates? The taste is sweet, malty and fruity. It glides over the tongue, and has an overall impressive mouthfeel. This is an excellent beer.

Dark reddish-brown with a small eggshell colored head. Aroma of fruit (melons, plums, berries...), yeast, and dark malts. Taste is fruity and malty sweet and yeasty, like any unibroue. Body feels medium-full, slightly carbonated, and alcohol well hidden. Excellent stuff.
Se una birra di Unibroue mi potrebbe far gridare al capolavoro, è questa. Un vero gioiello.

A: Pours a very dark brown with hints of crimson. Nice off-white, tannish head.

S: Loads and loads of dark fruits and hints of cherry with some caramel and toffee in the background.

T: Creamy dark fruits overwhelm the palate. Raisins, figs, dates, and dried cherries.

M: Nice and creamy. Good medium body with excellent carbonation.

D: Highly drinkable. Big fan of this all around and have to say I enjoy it quite a bit more than La Fin du Monde.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-15-2010

New Beer Distributors 4 pack ($10.50): For some reason I have never had this beer, even though it is very ubiquitous. Pours a burgundy color (i.e. dark brown, that when full is not transparent), topped off with a quickly dissipating beige head. Aroma is just full of fruits and sugars. The yeast was not as strong as I would have expected, but was certainly there in the background. Taste is slightly sweet, especially at the finish. Fortunately, it is not at all cloying, and I would say very well balanced in that regard. There are definitely plenty of winy notes in here, as this beer does aspire to a wine status. Very little bitterness. Fortunately, the alcohol is very well covered up by the proliferation of fruity flavors.
From a bottle. Not too bad for my taste. This is my first decent beer tonight. So a couple more to come.

This beer reminds me a lot of Chimay Blue but a little boozier.. All the flavors are close with the earthiness of the same malts are yeast profile flavors . Pretty good beer and worth seeking out if you are a fan of the Belgian style beers this one worth the try.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a small head. Aroma is yeasty, with malty hints. Has a yeasty flavor with some berries.  A slightly burning alcohol flavor to it, but not bad at all.  Has a Belgian style ale flavor to it, which I suppose is obvious, but considering I usually hate the style...its an impressive beer.  Theres nothing about it I particularly like, but it ends up being a very good beer.  I only wish places like North Coast and the like could make their Belgian ales taste as great as this!  Being honest though, for the price youd do better to go to something like an Avery White Rascal, but its certainly bang-for-your-buck if youre looking for a damn fine beer of this caliber with a decent abv. 9% alcohol.

12 oz bottle from Zipps.  Deep brown pour, eggshell colored head.  Aroma of dark fruit and sweetness (maybe Belgian candi sugar?).  Amazing flavor, more of the dark fruit and some sweetness, but not as much as the aroma.  Tangy, fruity finish.  Awesome beer.

Tap at the Petrol Station in Houston. Ive definitely had this beer before, but its been a while, so its nice to revisit this one. Deep burgundy-brown in color and a little cloudy with an eggshell-white head and some small lacing. The nose is very bready and yeasty with caramel and milk chocolate tones. Flavor is pretty rich, with light caramel, lots of candy sugar, some floral Belgian yeast tones, and some honey. Light floral hops as well. A very crispy and almost grainy palate - coarse, I guess - and fairly thick, even with a somewhat high level of carbonation. A very good brew, and a nice change of pace - this ones definitely out of the ordinary. Unique flavors keep this one interesting throughout the whole glass. I need to drink this beer more often.

Poured from bottle into small yard, nice brown appearance, decent head, very nice aroma...perfect for winter. Whoa, yes on the port wine reference. Nice though, perfect for sitting around a fire pit with friends listening to the game on the radio.
Hazy brown color with a thick, creamy, beige head. Port wine aroma with evident alcohol. Taste: Roasted malt, fruits. The flavor is a bit on the sweet side. Great Trappist strong ale!

UPDATED: NOV 17, 2010 Another Belgian from Unibroue. The owner of the bottle shop was a little tipsy when he recommended I buy a bottle of this, and the other bottle of Belgian I drank last night. This one is much, much, much better. Taste is a lot thicker and darker, less of a Belgian, and more like a Porter or something similar. Go for it!

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a Duvel tulip. Best before 04-07-13 printed on label.

Appearance: Pours an extremely dark brown with a 1 finger creamy off-white head. Excellent lacing.

Smell: Sweet dried fruit, Belgian yeast, bananas and a faint hint of canned pineapple.

Taste: Flavor is much dryer than I expected from the smell. Features a nice mix of spices, black pepper and clove. The alcohol is very well masked aside from the warmth going down. Aftertaste is dry and fairly bitter.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a good amount of carbonation. Nice and creamy.

Drinkability: Very high drinkability. The alcohol is masked very well so this one could sneak up on you.

Overall: Very good beer overall. Another strong offering from Unibroue. I would definitely recommend this one.

Dark mahogany colored pour with a massive, frothy, off-white head.  Creamy dark fruit aroma with notes of toasted nuts, cocoa, raisin bread, clove, nutmeg, port, and some lightly floral funk.  The flavor is a nice delicate balance of figs, plums, candi sugar, cocoa, almond, bread, raisins, and a little bit of alcohol with a floral spiced finish.  Velvety medium body with moderate but soft carbonation.

25.4 oz bottle. Have heard good things and seen it as a popular beer for so long, I eventually decided to try it. Pours a dark brown color with a small off-white bubbly head that effervesces and dies quickly. Reminds me of what a Trappist beer should look like. Lots of good smells, especially grapes/raisins, a bit of vanilla, and other dried fruits. Tastes very similar to the smell, with a bit of bite to it, but has a slight roasted taste to its back-end. Average mouthfeel, but has an assertive aftertaste. Pretty decent beer overall.
1st December 2006  Early amateur rating warning! Dark, sweet, fruity beer. Sumptuos. Was sorry to reach the end of the bottle.

very brown and cloudy as well. belgian esters of cinnamon and spice; some dark fruity notes of dried raisin; as the brew opens up i get a more rhum chocolate note.very complex stuff. palate is dominated by carbonation, good yeast esters, slight nutty note and a dark chocolate/rhum note. finishes hot but not totally out of balance. very interesting beer!

Beer pours a cloudy red-brown with an excitable tan head, nice lacing.  Complex nose of toasty malt and dried fruits, esp prune.  Residual sugars really bring out the dried fruits in the taste, also nuttiness on the finish.  Thinner than the color would suggest, but the flavors are REALLY interesting and compelling.

On tap at Volo.  Pours a very dark reddish brown with small tan head.  Aroma of apple, cherry and spice.  Taste is fairly sweet and slightly roasty with strong fruitiness (apple, dark fruit) and a mild spiciness.  Fine carbonation; light bitterness in finish.  Nice.

dark pour, quickly dissipating head. pretty standard for the style: dark fruit, malty, high carbonation. This style is growing on me. Pretty good, but didnt give me a boner. Of course, Ive only finished half the bottle thus far.

Tap at LIC Craft Beer Festival. Pours a clean mud-brown (screwed up description, I know). Aroma is primarily a cherry-caramel blend. Flavor is heavy of cherry and caramel as well but also vanilla and oak. The finish adds brown sugar to the oak and cherry. Crisp but substantial mouthfeel. I like.
tap - reddish pour, nice sweet caramel piney. arouma of cherries and raspberries. Very tasty. finishes with hints of booze in the finish. Heavy mouthfeel.

12 oz bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. It has a roasted and chocolate aroma.  This is an amazing tasting beer. It has a chocolate taste, a roasted taste, a plum taste and a little bit of a leather taste. The alcohol isnt noticeable at all. This is really a fantastic beer.
Super dark red pour. Kind of a strange fruity aroma. Light body. Dark fruity flavor. A wine finish.

Bottle, poured into Ommegang belgium glass.  Bought a sampler case of Unibroue beers, and this is one samplers.   Complex aroma with fruity tones.  Poured excellant. Taste was fabulous, beginning to end.  Theres  all kinds of flavor going on here.  On the sweeter side, but typical for belgiums of this type.  For 9% this is very drinkable.   Unibroue has some very good beers.  That is probably why i am on my third case of sampler beers from them.   Try it.

Notes from 05/26/2010
4-Pack from Benz Beverage Depot, $9.49

Ar: Big Unibroue yeast aroma along with some dried fruits.
Ap: Pours a deep brown with a slight red hue when held to the light.  Solid 1" head of tightly packed cream colored bubbles retains itself quite well.  This is a beaut.
T: Again, deep dried pit fruits, deep roasted flavors.  A bit of an alcohol bite on the finish.
P: Medium creamy body.

Great offering from Unibroue.

Had this with my brewing partner about two weeks ago.  The taste was remarkably tame with simple subtle notes of roast and chocolate smoothed out by some raisin.  Poured a deep dark brown.  First impression was not as good as the final one.  Very interesting.

Delicious. bottle poured into my tulip glass. very fruity aroma, maybe plum brought to mind the color green. A very beautiful dark dark amber. substantial (thick) and somewhat frothy texture. fruity, hoppy, quick finish with a bright and resonant aftertaste

Tasted at the Cincinnati Beerfest on Fountain Square in downtown Cincinnati, Ohio - This is a beautiful, very dark red "Belgian Strong" type beer, with resinous body and an overall delightful feeling and flavor!

Unibroue Trois Pistoles. I dont know how to pronounce it, but I do know I love it. it pours pretty much black with a large off white head without much lacing. Aroma was delicate, sweet and fruity with hints of chocolate and roasted malt. Slight carbonation, flavor was malty but not very roasted but thats all under the primary flavor of dark fruit, probably raisins. Definitely a beer that you sip as you go along, its not the gulpers beer. Its a pretty strong beer at 9% abv, but it isnt too obvious through the flavor but you do get a slight burn and warmth as you go further into the beer. Its a great balance of sweet, savory, and bitterness that works together to create a decadent experience. Must drink.

Wow... what a shock.  I had no idea what I was getting myself into when I found this on tap at Salty Caper in Salisbury NC.  The alcohol is completely hidden in this one.

Aroma is sweet and pleasant, great mixture of malt and mild hops.  Poured a dark amber with great carbonation.  The taste was a pleasant sweet malt with plenty of body and enough carbonation to get a great mouthfeel and make you want more.  

This is a great beer that I would love to have my own bottle of!

Appearance:  poured into a trappist goblet; dark chocolate brown with a rich foamy head that lasts a long time before shrinking to a modest collar; this thing has more legs than a zz top song--when tilted, a cascade of bubbles curtains down the side, leaving a rich and beautiful lace.  Aroma:  sweet, dark rich fruit--cherries and plums--and booze; some caramel maltiness and a little earthy leather.  Taste:  wow.  rich and sweet, yet light and delicate; sweetly tinged dark fruit notes give way to earthy dark grains and malts in the middle, before an extremely mellow yet powerful booziness kicks in.  Finish:  amazingly clean and refreshing; a lingering sweetness, breadiness, and warming alcohol, yet the tongue and palate are washed clean for the next sip.  Notes:  Amazing beer.  Incredibly rich, yet somehow light.  Incredibly smooth and velvety on the tongue, yet perfectly carbonated.  Sweet and fruity, yet not cloying.  I loved how the sweet faded slightly into the toasted brown bread.  The finish was incredibly simple and refreshing after the rich and complex sweetness.  I could go on and on.  This compares very favorably to the Westy 8 I just tried.  And much more easy to get!  Unibroue continues to impress.

355ml bottle. Pours a nearly opaque dark red-brown, verging on black, with a large head, reasonable retention and passable lacing. When held up to the light, the yeast is easily visible. The aroma is quite strongly alcoholic, and redolent with port and ripe berries. There are some weak floral hops to begin, but they are soon overcome by a burnt caramel sweetness, which in turn segues into a smooth, alcoholic port finish. The description of this beer as comparable to an old porto is very apt, as it does taste very much that way, and is thus a very classy and enjoyable beer indeed.

Pours nearly as dark as a porter with a deep red hue and a medium tan to off-white head. Smells of raisin, plum, and malt. High carbonation gives it a crisp and refreshing finish despite its weight and sweetness. Used a snifter to enhance aroma/appearance. Solid brew...potent.

Bottle.

A - Dark bronze with redish orange hues on the edges. A larger than average, thick, fomay, creamy, meringue-like head. About average retention that settles into a sticky thin layer of lace.

S - Nice rum/port soaked dark fruit with plum, fig, date and some raisin. Hints of bubblegum as well. Fair amount of dark roasted malt and candi sugar. Some slightly burnt brown sugar and a bit of yeasty aroma.

T - Lighter flavors for the style, but similar to the nose. A good amount of dark fruit (see above with plum being strongest). Sweet, juicy taste with a good amount of sweetness. A fair amount of yeast flavor also comes out. Fair amount of roasted malt. Bitterness and sweetness mix together well with sweetness definitely winning. A touch of spiciness as well along with some alcohol heat.

M - Lighter medium body with about average carbonation. Light, spritzy feel for the style with a touch of stickiness on the finish.

D - Fairly drinkable with a good amount of flavor. A lighter on the light side which hurts in light of me wanting to drink more.

Notes: Pretty good beer, but a little light (on both flavor and body) for the style. Nice rum/port like flavors in the background. Didnt taste extremely Belgian, but was tasty. Worth trying although maybe not worth stocking up on.

Bottle bought in Narbonne, cons 2010-08-12, La Grande Motte, France
AR: cherry, plum, fruitness
AP: oily brown body, wee of-white head
F: port wine, chocolate, full body, a bit sour - needs some storage on barrel!, high bitterness

Served in a Unibroue snifter 

A: Dark brown cola like with a finger or two of head off-white in color, slight cabonatation qith a bubbly lace that paints the side of the glass.

S: Kind of sweet brown sugar, no other straight forward smell for me (kind of muddy).

T: Like a digestive drink, alcohol its very present and leaves a warming feel, its kind of watery.

Overall: The taste and smell for me were kind of difficult to retrieve but overall it was good, the 9% ABV leaves you a nice buzz and its a very round beer.
Pours dark brownish-black with a thin tan head and some lacing.  Notes of fruit and alcohol.  Balanced taste a bit on the sweet side.  Smooth.

Pours a dark cola brown with light coming through around the edges.  There is a rocky beige head that recedes to a thick cap and leaves only traces of lacing behind.

The aroma is very sweet with raisins and candi sugar along with some fruity esters from the Belgian yeast.  There is also some licorice and earthy spices.

The taste starts with an initial spicy quick, then transitions to Belgian yeast, caramel and sugar-coated dates.  The finish is spicy and has a definite alcohol heat.

The mouthfeel is prickly with strong carbonation and spicy in the finish.  Dry and slightly bitter with some wood character as well.

Sweet and spicy with some alcohol burn going down.  Enjoyable and recommended.

(bottle at Seans Unibroue tasting).  Pours caramel color with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of caramel and anise.  Taste is sweet like a tootsie rol.  Medium bodied with an oily mouthfeel.  This is a really nice beer.

A-pours a dark plum colored, almost brown, light tan colored head with a solid lacing.

S-huge ripe fruit nose, tons of plums and raisins balanced by citric notes of juicy oranges with light hints of alcohol behind.

T-insanely tasty and sweet, tons of plums and raisins with an underlying notes of yeast, the dark fruits carry through and are backed by a citric presence of ripe juicy oranges and a touch of alcohol.

M-the feel is a little harsh and grainy, the carbonation and strong and tickles the throat like pop rocks, medium syrupy body.

D-this is quite tasty and has a nice balance of a strong fruity malt presence and a nice citric hop finish.  it is very sweet and juicy but not cloying at all.
UPDATED: APR 6, 2017 Again with the goodness from Unibroue.  Very complex. Bit of raisins. Needs to be a little less drinkable to avoid getting into trouble. Serving: Bottle

Long time favorite. Solid Belgian Strong Ale. Low foam, very rich with moderate sugars. Deep levels of flavoring building from first taste through swallow. Complex grape almost light barrel finish taste. Pairs well with Quebec cheeses and assorted fruits.  The alcohol is in moderate ninja mode.. you know its there but it sneaks up on you.
Unique Uniboue yeast with raisin aroma. Almost black shade of brown with very small tan head. Very carbonated yeast with raisin flavour. Refreshing but alcohol creeps up.

Bottle, 75cl. Pours a clear mahogany beer with an offwhite head. The aroma is malt, caramel, some notes of acidity and spices. The flavor is malt, sweetness and spices. The palate is sweet. Overall a good beer.
bottle - pours dark brown and not very opaque without the foam I expect from an Unibroue.  Smells of dark red forest fruit.  As the label reads: mellow.  Aftertaste is short.

Aroma: caramel, floral, perfume, alcohol.
Appearance: brown, black, cloudy, frothy, tan foam.
Taste: medium sweetness, lightly bitter.
Palate: medium body, creamy, lively.
Overall: This is one of my all-time favorite beers. I like the rich, sweet flavor, and low amount of bitterness. This ale has been crafted to perfection, with a flavor profie that is quite complex. I also like the dark color and soft foam head, as well as the 9% alcohol content, which sneaks up on you almost imperceptibly.
Colour is brown with at creame light top. Aroma is fruity note, and caramel. Flavour is roasted caramel and  alcohol,

10.08.06 750 ml Dark black beige head that last. Its fizzy. A: Cloves, caramel, grapes. Nose is superb clean and complex. F:Med body finish is sweet and medium long. Its impressively smooth no hotness from the 9% abv here. A long time favourite simply had forgotten to review it.

Served from tap into an Unibroue slender tulip.  Pours almost black with a subtle brown hue with a three finger off-white head that subsides to one finger slowly.  Maintains decent lacing throughout.  The aroma was comprised of fruit, alcohol, and malt.  The flavor was of bananas, malt, and extremely subtle alcohol.  It had a medium feel on the palate with high carbonation.  Overall a very nice brew that actually reminded me more of a quad.  The flavor was quite nice for the style.  The aroma could of used an extra kick to make it even better.  This is worth trying given an opportunity.

341ml bottle. Pours a very deep amber with tan head that leaves a solid lace. Nose is an excellent mix of malt and hops with just a hint of alcohol. Fairly sweet on the palate with little of the hop character coming through. A nice, strange, bittersweet finish. Almost stellar.

Draft.  A very dark caramel color with a small off-white head leaving a small amount of lacing on the glass.  Smell is of sweet grapes with a bit of alcohol.  Initial taste is sugar and grapes, a bit of chardonnay like.  The carbonation is significant on your tongue.  Light bodied.  The finish is alcohol and a bit of raisins.

11.5 oz bottle from the Beer Store, served in an English pint. Pours deep cloudy mahogany with a tall tan head. Head has good retention and leaves a decent amount of lace. On the nose, a complex bouquet of dark fruit, molasses, spice, alcohol and yeast. The flavour is medium sweet throughout, with complex malts and a fruity and spicy character. The finish is lingering malts. On the palate, it is medium-full in body with a smooth, alcoholic texture and moderate carbonation. Overall, this is an excellent, fruity ale with a very smooth texture. The 9% ABV is well disguised. 2010-07-31

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2011 Le liquide a une couleur brune rougeâtre.  Une mousse fine se dépose mais ne fait pas grande figure.  Au nez, le malt est dense avec un arôme de sucre caramélisé, voire de toffee.  Des effluves de fruits comme le raisin et les pruneaux sont présents et persistants.  Quelques notes épicées sont décelées : on dirait bien du poivre blanc.  La présence dalcool se fait douce et a un côté très «parfum de fleurs».  Pas de traces de houblons.  Le goût est une suite logique des caractéristiques trouvées dans les arômes.  Léquilibre est superbe entre le malt et lalcool.  Fabuleuse sensation en bouche : les bulles sont nombreuses et apportent un souffle particulier au liquide doucement riche.  Léger goût de réglisse derrière la langue.  En résumé, le chef-doeuvre dUnibroue.
Mmm I like this. Sadly the last of my Unibroue stash. Ahh yes that familiar yeast., Strong fruit, raisin, caramel and sweet but warming alcohol balances well. More to order.
Pours brown with a beige head. Aroma is caramel, dark fruit and light acidic. Flavour is caramel, alcohol, dark fruit and light acidic.

Pours a dark amber, with a medium carmel colored head with heavy lacing.  aroma is like a sweet haystack.  Taste is semi sweet with a fruity background.  Palate is mildly bitter and slightly chewy.  medium to heavy carbonation.

Aroma: cranberries, apricots, earthy yeast, brown sugar. Alcohol very apparent. Appearance: cloudy,  murky deep brown. Frothy white head that falls to a steady thin cover. Minimal lacing. Taste: quite sweet but balanced by alcohol. Palate: lively and full with prominent spice on the way down. Alcohol lingers on the roof of your mouth. Overall: lovely in the beginning but flattens quite quickly, which is odd. Savor the first several swallows then pick up the pace.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2013 750mL Bottle. 9%. Dark brown pour with a bubbly tan head, decent retention. Aroma is quite fruity. Full bodied. Mild-medium carbonation. Creamy, buttery mouthfeel. Taste is ripened peaches, apricots, complex maltiness. Extremely smooth finish and a lingering taste of sweet malt. Superb.
Bottle at Beerbistro in Toronto.  Pours a dark amber and tastes of over rippened fruit like figs and raisins.  there is light licorice and some yeast, alcohol is present but nice.

Bottle. Average off white/light brown foamy head (quickly dissapates) over a dark garnet body. Aroma and taste of coriander seed, figs, vanilla, sweet with a balanced slightly acid, spritzy, finish. Medium bodied. Nice.
pours deep dark purples brown with a thick off-white head and some spotty lacing.  fresh sweet aroma of over ripe fruit.  port wine, plum hops and yeast taste.  tart finish with a ginger taste.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2010 This beer rocks. Dark brown/amber pour with a minimal of-white head. Strong spicy aromas, with some hints of raisins and prunes. The taste is very complex, one of cinnamon, dough, citrus notes, raisins, and more noticeably prunes. Medium bodied. Some licorice here too. Very unique and enjoyable with a warming alcohol/boozy/sweet finish. Would definitely buy again.

Tap at Rattle n Hum. Pours a hazy amber-brown with a creamy, beige head. Rich aroma with prunes and raisins, faint toffee, spices, sweet malts and Belgian yeast. Flavor is sweet with fruits and malts, light licorice, cinnamon, some bread dough and some modest Belgian funk. Medium bodied with average carbonation, smooth texture and light alcohol warmth. Finishes with dark fruit sweetness. A great beer all around.

12 oz. bottle. Wonderfully rich aroma with some of the typical Belgian funkiness as well as fruit. Deep dark color, head quickly dissipates to a thin film that lingers. A perceived sweetness that I think comes more from those aromas. Full bodied mouthfeel with plenty of carbonation and an easy alcohol warming. A very well crafted beer.

looks thick and brown, (man i almost stopped for a thats what she said joke). smells raisiny, tastes yeasty, dry finish (quite carbonated), weirdly.

salright.

330ml bottle from The Beer Store.  9% Alcohol.

Pours an amazing, dark dark amber but not quite black.  Cream colored head that is small and quick to dissolve; possibly the result of me pouring into a wet glass.  Carbonation is quite visible.  Smells strongly of black fruits and/or berries.  Medium mouthfeel with noticeable carbonation.  Tastes amazing -- fruity and malty, would never guess it was a 9% alcohol rating since its actually quite refreshing.  Pairs great with the various foods Ive eaten it with.  While this isnt the kind of beer you could drink all night, it is one of my all time favorites because its just packed with so much flavor and scent.  A++

750ml bottle split with DarkBeerChick.  Poured a deep mahogany with ruby highlits and some off-white head.  Aromas of dark fruits, dried figs, candied pears, brown sugar and belgian yeast.  Flavor follows the aromas and adds a nice malty sweet backbone to pair with an almost archetypal Belgian strong ale flavor palette.  I should drink more Unibroue.

Pours a deep, dark brown, almost black, with a minimal tan head.  Nose is banana, sweet alcohol and grapes.  The port description on the label definitely fits the nose, and I can see it in the flavor profile to a certain extent as well.  The banana is in the taste as well, and my first impression is that this beer actually reminds me of a German heffeweizen to a certain extent.  But there are other things going on here as well.  The slightly sweet malt gives the impression of chocolate, and theres just a bit of hops that provide a slightly dry yet extremely smooth finish.  The beer almost has an acidity to it, much like you get with a red wine chocked full of tannins.  Mouthfeel is great.  Not much bad to say about this beer really.  A classic.

Pours dark brown with a medium brown head. Nose is fairly light and brown sugar dominated. Taste is fairly standard brown belgain ale, with abbey yeast, brown sugary malt, and moderate hops all balanced out quite well. Alcohol is hidden. Finish is short and bittersweet. Nothing world changing but a solid belgian strong.

750ml bottle.  Super dark beer with a tan coloured head.  Aroma of raisin and other fruits.  This beer masks the high alcohol content very well.  An excellent beer overall and would definitely have another.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2014 Pours a dark brown with quick diminishing tan head. Fresh, clean, fruity, malty aroma. Complex taste....cloves, figs, Cabarnet wine, big malt. Only mildly sweet and a rather dry finish. The more I sip the more it tastes like a big red wine. This is good, easy drinking for such a big belgian.

My other Fathers Day beer.  Aroma of plum & dried fruits; raisin & prune.  Dark hazy brown color with a similar flavor of dried fruits but added nutty raisin bread notes in the mix.  Overall, its not bad, flavorful and tasty but probably not a beer to drink in the heat of a TX summer.  Ill try it again in the wintertime and see how I like it.

Pours caramel colored clear with small white head.  Medicinal aroma of Belgian yeast.  10%.  Easy to drink and very smooth, well-balanced Belgian ale.  Holy moly.  I like it more than I expected as this is not my favorite style.

Bottle at WOB, Pours deep brown with a purple tint with a nice white head, high in residual sweetness, low bitterness and a silky mouthfeel. There is a touch of sourness and spicyness in the finish.  Why cant more beers be like this one?

22oz bottle from Willow Bend in Lutz, FL. Pours a cloudy, dark brown with a monster off-white head that lasts. Aroma is dark fruits, raisins, plums, pepper, and honey. Flavor is cocoa, pepper, burnt flavor, some alcohol and honey. Medium palate with good warmth. Pretty damn good overall.

Bottle looks great, as well as the beer in the glass. Very fruity aroma. Starts intense malty-fruity, strong, sweet-malty, notes of liqorice and plums. Finish well balanced, still intense fruity, very drinkable. A great beer!

12-oz bottle.
Ap - Pours very dark with an uneven, foamy and dissipating creamy head. Little to no lacing.

Ar - Dark fruits are noticeable right away which lead to an interesting earthy aroma. Theres definitely a bit of noticeable alcohol and anise in the nose as well. Also present are bread and yeast. Very complex. You really have to dig for the aroma though it is not overpowering.

T - Immediately, those Belgian yeasty spices are very accessible with flavors of clove and coriander being most easy to recognize. The beer is rich with dark dates and sweet raisins. The finish is long with the spices continuing to give and give.

P - Texture is oily. It collects on the roof of your mouth like deer tallow. Swirling the beer in the glass reveals a real slippery texture as well: zero retention. Medium bodied.

O -  A beautiful beer. Different and exciting. Another good offering from Unibroue.

Sweet, fruity, alcoholic aroma. Appearance is as dark as it gets without being black...a dark reddish brown. Taste is sweet, pretty bitter ( the abv is 9%). I taste the ripe fruits in the brewerys description, especially fig. Carbonation is the life of the party and the finish is long, like any good finish is. Can this brewery do wrong?

75cl. Easy to drink despite ABV.  Similar to Chimay Blue, but a few more aromas for the palate... mellow taste with notes of fruit, port wine, fig, very sweet.  Full body and complex flavour.  Recommended!

Trois Pistoles pours a deep, dark, hazy, auburn with a tan foam.  The aroma consists of spicy floral notes, doughy earthiness, black licorice, and grapefruit as well as dried fruits.  The taste is both a medium sweetness and sourness with a light bitterness.  The palate is medium bodied with soft carbonation and a long, complex finish.  Overall, Trois Pistoles is a wonderfully complex and unique Belgian Strong.

Poured into a Duvel Tulip.

A-  Deep brown/ ruby red with a rich tan head and nice lacing.

S-  Complexity with molasses, caramel, orange. An earthy yeast, avg/hvy alcohol with figs.

T- Delicious!  Malty sweetness with a touch of bitterness, great balance, depth and complexity. An exceptional beer. 

M- Nicely carbonated, creamy and incredibly smooth.

D- Another dangerous brew from Unibroue. Goes down smoothly and hides the high ABV wonderfully. I could easily drink this all night.

Excellent beer. Another must have on hand from Unibroue.
From the first whiff I got the hint of grapes and dried fruit. The taste was somewhat sweet but more bitter on the back end. It was enjoyable but Ive have better.

Unibroue
Trois Pistoles
Pours out dark brown with a thinner tan head and good retention. Aroma of Belgian yeast, cloves, malty goodness and a tinge of alcohol. Flavor is reminiscent of a coke classic with less sugar and alcohol added and a slightly bitter hop character on the finish. Some basic fruitiness, but not overpowering. Mouthfeel is bubbly. Beer is nice. Yeah French Canucks.

Smells of shoe polish, red wine vinegar,   and a sharp pinot noir, aged cheddar pungency.  Flavor is more of the same but subdued and once I start to drink I pick up some boot leather in the aroma and flavor.  It finishes with a sweet deep dark grape flavor that brings it back to wine again.  Might be a little hot for some but I think it matches the profile.  Nice beer that has to be drank at warmer temps.  A barrel aged version would be sick but this is already muy muy complex.  Thank You Unibroue. 2010 12oz.
12 ounce bottle-cloudy dark brown pour-tan head-aroma and taste of fruit,roasty, alcohol-sweet roasty finish

Pours very dark with a dissapating creamy head.  Dark fruits are noticeable right away which lead to an interesting earthy aroma.  Theres definitely a bit of noticeable alcohol and licorice in the nose as well.  As it sits and warms a little, there are some spices that come out and they remind me of Belgian yeast.   Overall, the aroma is rather faint and mild.  Immediately, those Belgian yeasty spices are very accessible with flavors of clove and coriander being most easy to recognize.  The beer is rather rich with dark dates and sweet raisins.  The finish is long with the spices continuing to give and give.
Pour is pitch black almost. Nose and taste of licorice, arugula, port wine, dark (almost satanically dark) fruits. Rated 7/1/02

From the 750 ml. corked bottle dated 06-12-10.  The pour is very dark and just about black with a soapy, simmering beige head that leaves scattered lacing around the glass.  The aroma is much like wine with its fermented fruitiness. There is a marriage of roasted malts and dim hops in the background. The taste has a licorice, hard liquor feel to it a sharp bitterness for good measure.  I liked the enticing aroma better than the taste, which was a bit too much like liquor rather than beer.  Still, it was a nice experience.
UPDATED: DEC 30, 2013 Tap. Dark brown / grape pour with a minimal head. Aroma is sweet apricot and a bit of sour. Mouthfeel is slightly carbonated. Taste is also apricot and fig. Excellent beer.

Sampled in the Trois Pistole Chalice from Unibroue. Pours a very dark brown with some red highlights, but hard to see through. Head is quite creamy for a non-nitro brew and has very good retention. A layer of it stays the whole time and lacing is good. Coriander is the first thing I smell. Then I get a wiff of Unibroues special yeast. Mouthfeel is creamy and smooth. Very smooth that is, with some sweet beginning notes and a bitter middle. 9% ABV is very well-hidden. Dark fruits and malts are the biggest part of the flavour, but other things roam around (that I cannot guess). A wonderful brew, and must I remind you - very smooth.

750ml. Darker clean brown with thin tan head. Aroma is sweet syrupy and light caramel and heavy sweet fruit (maybe apricot or some dried rich sweet fruit). Flavor is easy sweet fruit and some heavier spice going dry. Really enjoyable...Ill buy again.

A dark but fruity beer! Wonderful and rare idea :)  Unibroues oeuvre is without exception fantastic. TP is malty, yeasty, and high-abv, but this is all balanced with some fruitiness and even Hefeweizen-style spicy esteriness. Good for appreciating but almost sessionable! (Freehold SR)

Very sweet, light, and mellow for a dark Belgian, but to its advantage. Some of the carbonation and taste of champagne, with only very subtle hints of the roasted malt used to brew it. Gives a first impression of yeast and fruit, but leaves only the pleasant fruity aftertaste. An excellent afternoon quaff enjoyed with cheese and crackers.

Numerous tastings.  Color is a pleasing dark blackish brownish red.  Nose is their house yeast of minerals and very light wood plus a little lacto, and also dark fruit.  Flavor is more dark fruit with... candied roast?  Light leather also.  A classic, and deservedly near the top of this brewers rating scores.
Pours cloudy chocolate brown. malty caramel aroma with bitter sweet taste finishing with sweet but spicy palate.

Pours a dark brown color with an off white foam head.  Has an aroma of dark fruit and spice.  Has that hoppy belgian taste, a dubbel feel underneath.  Sweet up front, hoppy and cabonated in the middle, with a dry malty finish.  Notes of dark fruit on the aftertaste.

A- deep brown body with thick tan head. bubbles rise to the top.

S- Whoa intense pungent smell of alcohol and grapes. Smell is similar to a strong port wine.

T- the taste is much lighter than the smell. Grapes and dark fruit at the beginning mixed with some malt. This is followed by a slight alcohol burn. The 9% isnt hidden as well here as in unibroues other offerings. Sugar and grapes remain long after the alcohol burn is gone.

M- high carbonation and sticky body. goes down fairly smooth.

O- this has similar drinkability to a wine. Its not bad and its definitely a different experience that is worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 05-02-2007 19:53:57

I have had this beer many times but am just getting around to reviewing it. It reminded me why I like quads and suggested that this may be the perfect cold, rainy-day beer. I would normally reach for a porter or stout but I think this is so much more than most of those could bring to the table. It pours a deep, cider like reddish-brown. There was a two-finger head which quickly settled, leaving only light lacing. The nose was a blend of alcohol, raisins, cherry, clove, sweet malt and a yeasty aroma I cant describe. Carbonation is heavy. The taste follows the nose perfectly with the addition of some slight bitterness to temper the sweetness - a lovely interplay that really works. At 9% I certainly couldnt drink this all day/night but I might want to. This isnt my favorite Unibroue beer, but it is a great one, nevertheless.

Pours extremely dark, almost black.  Slightly sweet aroma.  Has that distinct Belgian taste, but its not overbearing . A very mellow dark ale.  I pick up some fruits, but cant really pinpoint it.  I enjoyed this beer more than I thought I would.

12 Oz. Pours a dark dark amber with medium head that dissapaits quickly.  Strong fruity aroma with roasted sort of smell.   The taste is realitively mild for the darkness and alcholol of the beer.  Comes on sweet and smooth with that same fruitiness almost making it through to your taste buds.   Thick bodied ale that goes down slick.  Super good stuff!.

Pours a fizzy brown, nice head holds a fair rim throughout.. Aroma of malt, candy, raisin, aprticot, peach, and underlying floral. Taste is very complex, Sweet malt caramel and candy are most pronounced, a bit of spice and grape, after taste does give a little bitterness and then coats with a sweet caramel. Marvelous. Really wasnt wild about this the first time I had it. Ive given it a lot of revisitation- glad I did so.

Brown sugar, dried cherries, a little roast, a little smoke. Darkest ruddy brown w/ minimal head. flavors of plum, molasses, bitter chocolate, some spice, but a little on the sweet side. cloying alcohol finish.

750ml Bottle -- Pours deep mahogany with a nice off-white head. Yeasty aroma with fruity and brown sugar notes. Medium, tart body. Flavor of yeast, dark fruit, brown sugar and some unpleasant chalkiness.  There are much better Unibroue choices.

12 oz Bottle -- Pours dark brown-black with a medium off-white head.  Very doughy and yeasty nose with some sharp fruit, and roasted malt.  Some vinous characteristics, some good chocolate, and is quite tart.  A little funky cellar vibe going on.  The high acidity is quite nice cutting through the darker flavors and aromas.

0,33 l as a gift.
Poured dark brown with a delicious creamy tan head. Fine belgian spicy yeast character in the nose with toffee, caramel, some dried fruits like plum. Smooth mouthfeel with a mild toasted caramel taste, the spicey yeast comes again in the flavor, fruity alcohol with plum and raisins. Some vinous character, some spicies like vanilla, cinnamon. Fine, pleasant aftertaste, the alcohol is wellbalanced, i cannot feel any liqueric taste. Nice, fantastic strong ale!

~Vinous aroma of fresh plums, light raisin, dark grapes, prune, and chocolate as it warms up. 
~Pours a very cloudy dark copperish brown color with small persistant off white head.
~ Fruity flavor of fresh plum, grapes, and malt. Somewhat like a muted port wine.
~Medium full bodied with medium high CO2. Fruity finish.
~Gets better as it warms. Enjoyable malty fruity beer. Well balanced and very enjoyable to drink.

Bottle LCBO. Pours Deep cherry brown with thin head. Fruit and spice in the aroma. Complex flavour again with fruit and spices, some slight sourness. Fine mouthfeel. To date, my favourite Ontario-brewed beer.

pours a dark brown with a thin head.  highly carbonated - even from the bottle.  aromas of coffee and spice.  taste is dominated by coffee and caramel with a nice distinct Belgian finish.  high alcohol content is remarkably disguised - it really only appears a bit as the beer warms. Despite its high rating, this beer is probably not the ideal introduction to this amazing brewery.

Bouteille de 33 cl achetée au Tonneau Verre à Yverdon (CH). Brune à reflets orangés troubles. Parfum alcoolisé de malt délicieux grillé, avec orange, épices et caramel brûlé. Bouche douce mais riche et épaisse paradoxalement texture mince. Epicée et maltée, elle se couronne damertume de houblon et de levure, et de chaleur de lalcool.
Draft. Poured a dark ruby color with a little head to it. Aroma was dark fruit, plums, and figs. Flavor was sweeter. Dried fruits, raisin, and apple. Complex beer. Decent.

750ml bottle. Pours dark brown with a little red and a thick head. The aroma is complex and similar to other dark Belgian ales with dark fruit aromas but more subtle with a little nuttiness and resin mixed in.  Taste is very sweet with a bit of bitterness and effervescence with the finish.
Pours a dark color, with a small white head.  Had some fruity flavors, and was pretty smooth.  Surprising how much carbonation there was, but it still worked with the flavors that were present.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2010 Bottle pours cola-colored faintly cloudy with thick pale head.  Nice fruity aroma.  Taste of dark fruits with a bit of a cough syrup overtones. Mildly sour aftertaste but not bad. Revised my ratings - this one kind of grew on me.  A very nice beer.

Bottle from 2008.  Pours dark brown and burgundy with a thin off-white head.  Aroma of sweet yeast, raisins, sour apple, marshmallow, spices, and sugar.  Flavor is sweet, sour, and spicy; sweet dark fruit, sour yeast, apple, clove and cardamom.  A little too carbonated, and slightly creamy/oily.  Aftertaste is yeast, clove, and fruity esters.  Nice, makes me want to try more of their brews.

Reddish, dark brown color with beige head; somewhat winey aroma of dark malt, ripe fruits and some spices; medium body, quite highly carbonated; flavor starts heavy sweet getting in touch with fruits and spices on its way and the aftertaste really has quite evident port wine notes. However I would have been fine with a little less sweetness that has that almost artificial feeling to it. Overall less than the sum of its parts.

from bottle at pub in Addison.  Need to try again at a home.
definitely sweet and fruity with a belgian ale nice kick at the end.  no real notice of alcohol

UPDATED: MAR 10, 2010 Bottled.  Dark brown pour with a lovely, fluffy off-white head on it that retains for a while.  Has a strong yeasty nose on it that is loaded with fruit.  It has some tropical mango and guava in there as well as dark sticky dried fruits, plus a whiff of spice.  The flavor has a bit of roast and nuttiness to it, a little earth, and is loaded with those same fruit notes.  Finishes with spicy coriander, maybe even some nutmeg, and yet more fruit.  Very drinkable with a pleasant amount of carbonation.  I think Im falling in love with Unibroues yeast.

looks & acts like coca cola, with continuous carbonation.
sweet moss aroma. full-mouth herby yeasty roasty. dark w/ definite alcohol. rich, almost too rich! great great beer. smooth with a definite kick.

the one that i measure all belgian strong ales against, i know,   its wrong, but i cant help it. this is just delicious, everything about it. the only slight mark off is in the palate, strips your mouth a little, but if i could have one beer for the year, it would be this. phenominal beer. and cool artwork!

75cl bottle. Pours dark, much like the noire de chambly. Actually, this was much like the chambly noire but stronger. I love the taste but even better the 9% alcohol does not over power the taste. Very nice.

750ml bottle. Charcoal colour like burnt wood that is left in a fireplace. Lacing of fine bubbles around the rim with ripe fruit and clove aromas that dominate and make you anticipate the taste. Smooth and mellow given the high alcohol content. Worth sipping and savouring.

Bottle, pours dark amber with brown head.  Aroma of dark fruits, caramel, yeast.  Smooth taste of dark fruits with good complexity and some alcohol on the finish.  A great beer you can find in most quality beer stores, I always have a few in the fridge.

Bottle at The Bayou 
Appearance: Dark brown with a small off white head, no lacing 
Aroma: Nutty, dark fruits, bready 
Taste: Dark tart fruits, nutty, yeast 
Very nice beer to finish off the night. Clean and crisp flavors.

Dark amber pour from bottle.  Fruity nose, light foamy head.  Warm taste of berries and fruit, yet not sweet.  Warm and strong enough to satisfy, Unibroue scores yet again with another excellent brew.  Salute!!

Appearance is red/amber with medium white head. Aroma of raisins, fermented fruit and yeast. Taste is round of rasins, prunes, fermented fruit, yeast and herbs. The taste is strong without beeing overwhelming. This is a grate beer that really matures grate.

How has it taken this long to actually sit down and review one of these? So damn good - why waste the time on a review when all I want to do is drink them without thought. Murky dark brown brew with a bubbly, light tan head that just wont go away. Messy lacing. Excellent aromas of nutmeg, cinnamon, brown sugar, caramel, jesus this is awesome. Yeast, earthy, anise, warmth, candied orange rind, ripe plums, white pepper, roasted malts that never dominate a single aroma. The taste is fine as well but not nearly as succulent as the aroma. Roasted malts, alcohol and spice.. which comes first? who knows. Tons of spice and yeast: sweet licorice, pepper, allspice? Hard yeast spice hammers the mouth. Dark berries, grapes. Goes back very easy, quite full, dries the hell out of my mouth on the bottom half and beyond to the point of what seems to be 100% yeast and spice. Damn fine. 4 bottles down and opening the 5th. I party alone............

Had this on tap at Assassins in Chicago, IL at a happy hour with my team. This was poured out of a 12 ounce bottle into a large goblet and had a brown color with some mahogany tints around the edges. It also had a nice half finger width tan head. The aroma was a wonderful mix of dark dried fruit, some sweet malt, and some pleasant spices that I could not really identify. I was surprised to find out that this beer has a nice and smooth medium bodied mouth feel. The flavor consists of a lot of dark, dried fruit and a nice spice background. This beer was very easy to drink and a lot of the more complex flavors came out as it warmed. An excellent brew by Unibroue!

$7 / 750ml bottle  This is my second venture into reintroducing myself to Belgian style beers and I have to admit I like this!  I thought I had forsaken this style, but I do like the variety.  You cant always be drinking an imperial stout.  Lots of fruit elements going on with the nose and taste.  Bitter and sweet at the same time.  This gets a very acceptable pass from me.

Draft in a snifter @ Yard House Las Vegas.  Pours a hazy brown color with some reddish highlights and a small off white head.  The aroma is ripe dark fruits, caramel malt, moderately sweet, with hints of spices.  the flavor is more of the same, with the caramel malts lingering on the palate.  The comparison to a port is not far off base.    Medium bodied with good overall balance.  This is another solid beer from Unibroue.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep dark ruby, amber color with a big, frothy tan head which retains well with strong lacing.  The aroma is very complex, with yeast, dark fruits, spice, raisin and alcohol.  Taste was strong with a deep fruitiness, spices, sweet malt, and hops.  Alcohol comes through in the finish as it warms, but is not tooo overpowering.  The high ABV makes this a fine winter warmer.

A complex and tasty beverage.  Distinct aroma perhaps it is fruit all Im sure of is the malt.  The color is a very dark brown with a tan head.  Its tastes of port wine in a glass of olives.  Not my favorite but very drinkable.

Bottle poured into brandy glass.  Dark brown-red.  Very thick white head.  Bubbly.  Aroma is very yeasty and reminiscent of other Belgian beers.  A bit of grassy notes in the aroma as well.  Taste starts with some slightly spicy notes.  The Belgian yeast taste is there, but it doesnt dominate, which is a good thing for me at least.  Overall, the taste is light and fruity, and Im surprised that its as dark as it is.  Tastes more like lighter colored beers.  Mouthfeel is medium-bodied and not very bubbly.  Very interesting brew.

Truly excellent brew.  Nice dark caramel brown with just the slightest hue of copper.  Good head retention with ample carbonation.  Aroma is a wonderful sweet mixture of plums, raisins and black cherries with a hint of barnyard mustiness.  This brew is so smooth but hearty enough to be delicious.  Carbonation adds some roundness to the mouthfeel while the malt, not being bitter, brings a combination of raisins, black cherries and hints of black currant and almond.  The hops balance this beer out with just enough bitterness but no discernible taste.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy reddish brown with a vigorous tan head.  Smells of bread, yeast, raisins and faint candy.  Taste is better than aroma suggests; raisins malt and some lingering sweetness.  Mouthfeel improves after letting some of the CO2 off.  Aftertaste turns sour after a while.  One glass is plenty for me.

UPDATED: OCT 31, 2010 750ml bottle in Trois Pistoles goblet. pours a murky mahogany, with a thick white head that leaves lots of lacing.. bouquet of ripe fruits, mainly raisin and plum. taste is yeasty and spicy with dark fruits. the alcohol hides itself well, drinkability is impressive. nicely carbonated and a great mouthfeel. this is my favourite Unibroue. Edit: am pairing it right now with Oka avec Champignons, and Sir Laurier dArthabaska. it is a match made in heaven. the earthyness from the mushrooms in the Oka REALLY compliment this beer.
on tap. this is dark, sweet belgian. texture is not as creamy as a good dark quad, but i was impressed with the big belgian taste in a canadian beer.
Nice color. Very spicy belgin nose. A bit onerly sweet. Still not a bad belgin.

Bottle from sample pack - Mahogany pour with a thin, off-white head. Deep, bold spice on the nose, hidden somewhat under a blanket of booziness and dark fruit. Taste is balanced nicely, with some dark chocolate, light booze, raisins, and orange peel. Velvet in the mouth, with adequate carbonation and a nice warming finish.

(draught) very dark with creamy light brown head. Nose is like most other Unibroue offerings -- heavy on the plum/raisin with a slight spice and yeast. Sweet and smooth with a light carbonation. Alcohol was not overbearing!  Another good ale from Unibroue.

12 oz bottle from the local. A quickly disappearing head sits on top of this dark brown pour, some nice hints of red dance through the lively body. The bouquet is inviting, dark fruit (plums?), spice, and yeast. The taste is just as pleasing, malty dark fruits, spices, yeast, and sugar. After the aroma I expected this to be overly sweet but it has a nice yeast character. Sugar is present but it is balanced well with the spice and yeast.
Bottle pours brown with a tan head. Aroma is light bready yeast, some dark fruit, and a bit of spice.  Flavor is sweet bready malt, raisins, spice, and a bit of hop in the finish

Pours a dark ruby/black with a tan head. Some yeast on the nose with malts and alcohol. Taste has some dried fruit character to it (plum, raisin). Strong flavor to it with an even stronger alcoholic feel to it. Overbearing is the word that comes to mind for this brew. Not too good, wont be drinking this one again.

(12 oz bottle into tulip)  Pours a deep black with a half finger creamy light brown head.  Nose is like most other Unibroue offerings -- heavy on the plum/raisin with a slight spice and yeast.  This one was a little sweeter though, almost as though the fruit were slightly sweetened or barely dessicated.  Very smooth and velvety in the mouth with a light carbonation that enhanced the sweetness of the fruit and allowed some spice to develop after.  Alcohol was very well hidden again, so be very careful if you want to try more than one!  Another top notch ale from Unibroue, which is quickly becoming one of my favorite breweries!

From a 750 ml corked bottle. Not black, but very dark amber/brown. Large, light golden head of foam. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Palate is very smooth and velvety. Taste is sweet, rich, yeasty and fruity. Tastes like more!

750ml bottle from Kappys.  Pours dark brown with a 1 1/2 finger head which quickly dissipates. Smells of spicy Belgian yeast. Taste: Well carbonated with spicy flavors up front and a warm alcohol feel on the back.   Also has a sweet caramel after taste.  Not sure why it took me so long to try this.  This is another amazing Unibroue offering.
very dark brown with a medium beige head. nose of yeast, spices and fruits. some floral notes begin arising. complex. pleasing. great beer.

Slightly cloudy mahogany color with a dark beige head.  Yeasty aroma with slightly spiced fruit. Sweet flavor, a mix of spiced dried fruit, sweet caramel malts, and yeasty bread. Medium chewy body, excellent beer.
Very good Belgian strong.  Alcohol is tempered well with the overall spiciness of the beer.  I dont agree that it is similar to a port wine, but a great choice for sharing with a friend nonetheless.
UPDATED: JAN 31, 2010 In bottle; poured Dark mahogany. Aroma of plum and bread. Taste is somewhat typical Unibroue (yeasty) but with plum/fruit and bread notes. Overall an OK beer

750mL bottle.  Pours a hazy dark reddish brown with a thin tan head that quickly settles and leaves no lace.  Distinctive Belgian yeast aroma with citrus, dark and dried fruit, grapes, and a subtle earthiness.  Medium-high sweetness with flavours of plums, grapes and some spice, low bitterness and a well balanced tartness.  The alcohol presence is warming and not excessive.  Slightly over-carbonated, medium bodied, fairly creamy with quite a clean tart finish.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2010 On tap pour: a deep rich mahogany with a generous head that left great lace on the glass. Had it in a pint glass, so perhaps the nose wasnt what it could be, but...still wonderful with notes of chocolate, bread, and a little earth. Tasted wonderful; rich coffee and chocolate flavors, but without the heaviness of a porter or stout. All in all, a wonderful beer -- not surprising, given its from Unibroue.

Dark mahogany pour with a small head. The nose is chocolate, cola, dark fruits, fig, and spice. The taste is similar with a sweet malt and a spicy alcoholic finish. The palate is medium bodied and a little dry on the backend. A great Belgian Strong.

12 oz bottle. Pours a dark ruby color with a light tan froth. Aroma is very strong dark fruits, some spiciness and I get some chocolate in there. Also just a hint of cola notes. Flavor starts sweet and malty, again lots of dark fruits that linger along with some yeast and again the spiciness comes in towards the finish along with a bit of alcohol. Somewhat dry finish. Medium body and a zippy carbonation. Nice little belgian here

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2010 Complex beer. Small bottle. Tan short-lasting head. Malty roasted sugars and milky burnt caramel throughout with a just a hint of smoke. Not my preferred style, but interesting enough (very interesting, actually!) and definitely one to try.

Re-try: If black pepper turned into alcoholic sugar in your mouth; this is what itd taste like.

Hey Northern Neighbor, Nice beer. Dark pour , red tint with a light tan head. aroma od dark fruit, alcohol, yeast. Taste is dark fruits, yeast. Nice carbonation. Smooth, almost creamy finish. Little sugary, but overall tasty.

Pours very dark brown-amber almost black.  Thin off-white head dissipates very quickly.  Aroma of plums, raisins and other dark fruit.  Also has that great Belgium yeast aroma.  Very carbonated, medium bodied mouthfeel.  Has a light bitter aftertaste.  Flavor is dominated by dark fruits, almost over ripe in fruit flavor.  Has a bitterness to the taste as well.  Very strong stuff.  Ok but not great.  I wouldnt drink it again.

From a 12 oz bottle into a snifter.  Pours with an inch of dark foam which dissipates into nothing in about one minute; no lacing.  Aroma is of plums, black grapes, grass, yeast and a little bit of coffee.  Color is dark brown, almost purple; very cool!  Taste is of clove, banana, blackberry, plum, yeast and alcohol.  Alcohol is not overpowering and gives it a nice warm feeling.  I dont have too much experience with Belgian dark ales to compare this one to, but its very tasty.  I think it could have used a slightly thicker body as the carbonation, while a good amount, made it just a little to fizzy to drink.  In my experience, light body and fizzyness is a common thread over most Unibroue beers.  Overall, a great beer, one that Id happily drink again.  Le Cheers!

Pours out of the bottle a dark black with a tan head that is about one finger thick and goes away pretty quick. Mouthfeel is medium, kind of thin but still a bit creamy. Taste is great, pretty malty and earthy with a fruityness to it.

Poured from a bottle giving a slightly tan head which lasted quite a while.  The aroma is typical Unibroue yeast aroma.  Tastes slightly sweet, fruity, and hints of raisins.  The finish is really smooth.

UPDATED: JUL 26, 2014 Sweet but without much fruit. After coming back to this beer a few years later I am only getting a little bit of port character, with more dark sugars than I remembered. Rich and complex but also pretty mellow & relaxing. The molasses and brown sugar go down smooth, like a comfort food.
Pours a deep brown with creamy beige head and some lace.  Taste of sugars and red fruits fades quickly, but the tart smell of the same is quite nice.

Pours dark like a porter.  Small head dissipates nearly immediately.  Smells of caramel, raisons, bananas and yeast.  Mouth slightly effervescent.  Taste: fruit and yeast, bananas and spice, finishes first fruity and then with sharp licorice. Very complex and rewarding.  Alcohol not noticeable at all.  Excellent Belgian.

Dark brown with purple ashes. Small foamy head that doesnt last.  Spicy aroma, with smells of plums, roast and cinnamon. Sweet palate that add to the "douceur" of the taste that is like velour on the tongue. Finish is very charming, when the berries side comes as a final scene.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2011 Small bottle, Trappist chalice. Dun. Beige head fades them returns a bit as it settles to be a nice one cm coat. Superb lacing. Some floating bits. Smells of port and lemon, with some earthiness, spice, berries, licorice and soy sauce. Fruity, yeasty and vintage port. No more alcohol than necessary. Finish is still a bit fruity, but is dry and slightly sour. [4.2] 750ml bottle. Lowered appearance from 5 to 4 - fizzy, but head less lovely in last few. Consistent otherwise.

330 ml bottle. From m/s Silja Symphony.
Dark brown colour with tiny off-white head.
Sweet fruity, sugary port wine-like aroma. 
Sweetish fruity flavour with spices, strong alcohol warmth and winey elements.

(br-btl sv-foil-cap bk/sv-lbl with horse, Ale on Lees, refermented in btl, 9%)

opq-mhgy-top lct-btm, creamy-tan-lasting-head, med-body, ^co2.

warm-alchl cherry-brandy aroma.
§spicy co2 tart-fruit T1 ^malty belgian-ale-fruity T2 warm §sour §bitter T3.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2010 3 year old bottle.  Pours a murky purple brune body with an off white head.  Spicy dark fruits, hints of plums, dates, and some light fig.  Etoh latent fruit warming with cinnamon sticks and Belgian style esters.  Dough y creamy with a hint of mint and a Trappist like tartness.  Lush fruit skins nectar like plum y notes and a tamed carbonation prickle.  Creamy velvet palate with fruit that rolls across the tongue.  Mineral like sedimentation suspended with yeast leading to a dough y raisin sweetness.  Modest subdued warming with a drying vinous palatable finish.  A truly phenomenal Belgian style ale.

Bottle.

Dark color, small head.  Berries, roasted tones, alcohol, yeast.

Lovely and well balanced taste. Berries, spices, chocolate, licorice, a little sourness. Nice smooth finish. A very good beer indeed.

Location: From my buddy Dave who picked it up in Frostburg, MD 


Aroma: Light malty, caramel aroma.

Appearance: Dark brownish, black color.

Flavor:  Medium bitter taste, lightly sweet. 

Palate:  Light aftertaste, thick texture.

Overall Impression:  Good beer, tastes better when warmed up.

Good sweetness and fruit makes Trois Pistoles stand out from the already strong Unibroue lineup.  Dark, nearly opaque burgundy liquid with a creamy off-white head.  The aroma is maltier and doughier than most from Unibroue.  With notes of raisins, plums, bananas and clove, there are many dark Belgian-style fruit flavors from the yeast and malt.  The flavor is mildly sweet for the style but still right in the normal range for a good quad/BSDA.  Mouthfeel is full and lively.  All of Unibroues beers are well-made.  Trois Pistoles is a very nice BSDA.  I have no real qualms with it, but Im not sure how well it would stand out against a field of the top examples of the style.

Dark pour.  Sour yeasty aroma with lots of dark fruit and a subtle citrus notes and some slight dry sweet fruit, primarily pear.  Flavor continues the dark fruit character with a quickly fading carbonated feel.  The fruit sweetness begins the flavor that is followed by the more sour yeast character.  Finishes smoothly with a nice sweet flavor.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2010 Pours dark brown. Nice inch of head that disappears almost instantly. Aroma is fruity with maybe a hint of bread? Pretty loose in the mouth. Not a lot of carbonation.  Taste is fairly fruity, with fig in there along with some floral notes. Finishes really clean. I  liked this one a lot.

Pours a very dark brown, a finger and a half of tan foam that dissipated rather quickly. Aroma of some fruit, maybe cherries and dates, and roasty - can also smell the alcohol. Taste is of dark cherries, a hint of chocolate, maybe some fig/date flavors. Nice and complex, very full bodied. The alcohol burns just briefly, then it finishes quite smooth.

(Draught at The Libertine) Pours dark brown with nice 1 finger head and tight bubbles. No lacing to speak of and head dissipates as it warms to nothing eventually.  Nose of figs, Belgian yeast, and alcohol. Taste is light chocolate notes, alcohol which doesnt burn, and over-ripened bananas. A little under-carbonated maybe, and slightly on the thin side.

UTP pours black with a large beige head that settles quickly into a fuzzy little blanket.  It looks thinner than a stout despite its color.  The aroma contains mild vinegar combined with the smell of canned fruit cocktail.  The taste carries a nice tart punch countered with plum and dark cherries.  The body is medium and the finish is full of flavor.  The carbonation is just right and carries the whole beer through the palate with a nice feel.

UPDATED: FEB 21, 2010 Re-rated on 2/19/10.  750 mL bottle pours very dark brown/black with a two finger khaki head into a tulip.  The head retains quite well, though when it dies down, foamy lacing is apparent.  Typical Belgian yeast aroma with red grapes and apples, grass, plumbs, apricots, spice.  Red grapes and apples again dominate the taste.  It definitely has a heavy, vinous quality to it, as well as a very subtle chocolate presence.  Plumb, date, and apricot are all detectable as well, leading up to a big, spicy, slightly boozy finish.  Full bodied with a fuzzy mouthfeel and a low-medium level of carbonation.  This is a very, very fruity beer.  Great stuff.
Deep, rich coloration.  Very smooth.  Fine carbonation.  Nice depth of flavors in this Belgian style beer.

Location: 750 ml bottle from State Line, 11/13/09


Aroma: Aroma of slightly sour, dark fruits, raisins, dates, some boozy port, roasted malts, spice, and yeast

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color with a slight orange touch and a fizzy beige head

Flavor: Taste is somewhat sweet and quite malty, pretty complex, fruity, but with some balance

Palate: The mouthfeel is quite fizzy, with a bit of an alcohol feel and a relatively full body

Overall Impression: 
Overall this one does a nice job of emphasizing some of the best parts of the Belgian beer style.  It really just does a nice job of showing off that nice Belgian style that it is aiming for, so for that reason Id like to say "well done."

Cloudy reddish-brown body with a nice rich head. The smell is typical for Unibroue, but with its own darker character (cherry, plum, red grape). The flavour is very intense; sweet, yeasty and fruity. The finish lingers with a port-wine character and some breadiness. The alcohol is very well-masked in this one, and the mouthfeel is extremely pleasant. Great one!
a bodacious belgian beer that tastes like a port wine and will knock you on your ass after a few of them!

What a beautiful beer, so smooth, deep brown and sparkling all at the same time.  My biggest issue is with the nose; much harder to discern than the flavor would suggest.  Heavy, burnt straw, brown sugar malts with light perfumey hops.  I didnt catch the Port or the ripe fruit.  But Im no professional.  Unibroue holds up its rep. on this one!

Dark, dark red. Almost looks black, its so dark. Very nice indeed. Totally minimal tan head, which rapidly dissipates to almost nothing.

Smell is also dark. Filled with dark fruit notes. Most prominently, red grapes and black cherries. Slight sweet maltiness. Butter and sugar. Hints of toast.

Tastes of malts and dark fruits. Cherries, figs, plums and red grapes. Sweet and yeasty & rich and spicy.

Feels amazingly good. Lots of nice tiny bubbles. Creamy and sweet and delicious.

Highly drinkable brew here. Nice, sweet, easy drinking. Unibroue does it again.
Very good beer.  Full flavored.  High alcohol content but not an overpowering alcohol taste.  Great Belgian Ale.

750 mL caged and corked bottle from Grape & Gourmet (purchased November 2008, best by January 15, 2011).  Muddy brown pour with a fizzy off-white head.  Raisin and prune juice aroma.  Very well-balanced dark fruit flavor with just the right amount of light tartness blended with a not-too-sweet Belgian candi sweetness.  Very little alcohol detected at first but more so after this warms a bit.  An excellent beer.

Bottle. Very dark brown, almost black pour. Translucent. No head on the beer. Spicy Belgian nose with some dried fruit (raisins maybe?). Moderate alcohol up front. Lots of carbonation. Sweet fruit and some spicy Belgian finish. Bitterness afterward. Nice palette. Overall pretty good, but not my favorite Unibroue offering.
Pours a great looking dark amber.  Aroma of nuts and caramel.  Taste is of nuts, malt, some hops and overripe fruit.  Good beer, taste isnt as deep or complex as I might have hoped.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2009 750-ml bottle Marcellos, Lafayette,LA - Aroma: dried fruit, sweet, alcoholic (esters), caramel (malt), slight medicine (phenols); Appearance: clear, opaque dark brown, tan head, some laces; Flavor: salty, dried fruit, chocolate, (malt), slight alcoholic (esters), bitter (hop); Mouthfeel: moderate to full bodied, high carbonation, alcoholic (no harshness); Overall: let the dark beer warm up to bring out the richness, complex, and balance of malt, yeast , bitter, and alcoholic flavors of the beer with no alcohol harshness.

Bottle 355ml. A delicious treat. Rich aroma of dark fruit, port, alcohol, and yeast. Flavour is sweet, with long-lasting bitterness to finish. Syrupy in the palate, and medium-bodied. Dark brown in the glass, cloudy, with a fizzy white head.
Pretty dark red color.  Big alcohol finish.  Interesting flavor but a bit of a muddle.

Medium head that disappeared almost instantly. Aroma is of lots of fruit with distinct apricot. Quite complex, with a fair bit of malt and slight bitterness. Good offering, alcohol works nicely as well.

This was a very dark brew with a slightly orange tint to it. It left behind a huge head that collapsed pretty quickly. It did leave an almost soda-like carbonation film behind though. This carbonation carried through for the rest of the tasting. It was a very sweet-smelling brew but otherwise it was a little bland - Fonnie and I couldnt ID any specific scents aside from that. It tasted very sweet and fruity. It also had a little bit of a dry taste to it - like wine. Basically, everything up to this point was reminiscent of wine. ...And it didnt stop there. The texture was very smooth but it had very little body. There was no bitterness though - it was all sweet and it had a very nice flow of flavors throughout the tasting.

pours a deep dark brown, almost black color that is completely opaque with only the slightest bit of mahogany color in the edges when held to a light source. Massive 3 finger frothy dark tan head with excellent retention, only slowly fading to a lasting cap that leaves chunks of soapy lacing in its wake.

Dark malty aroma with a lot of estery dark fruit and peppery spice. Silky chocolate and caramel malt as well as some toffee notes along with hints of raisin, plum, fig, sour dark cherries and fig.

Carbonated up front with some smooth roasted malt, sweet dark fruit, candy sugar body with a dry and bitter yet sweet roasted finish. Dangerously quaffable with the high ABV being very well masked. Only a very slight hint of alcohol warmth.

Nice chocolate malt flavor that is roasty, but not too much so. Lots of estery dark fruit notes, especially raisin, fig, plum and sour dark cherry along with sweet candy sugar notes. Very well balanced. Highly recommended!

Extremely dark red/brown. Like usual the head on this brew disappears quickly into a small off-white ring. The smell is what I would expect from a Belgian Ale: roasted malts, brown sugar, molasses. The taste is quite pleasant as well and I can pick out notes of roasted malt, plum, sugar, and alcohol.

Bottle.  I think you sons of bitches are crazy in your description of the flavor.  Pours a brown color with a nice fluffy tan head.  Aromas of sage, celery, grass, and autumnal spices.  Fruit?
