Deguste avec french tickler - Biere de couleur brune foncé avec un bon collet moyennement collant. Odeur de decrise noir , alcohol, sel et sucré en meme temps. Gout de fuit exotique avec malt et sucre,.

Nice deep colour, very rich and powerful nose with deep plums and dates dominating...a heavy malt dosage.

Taste is very malty and dark fruit with moderate carbonation.

This really is one of my favorites ESPECIALLY at the price point.  It’s a heck of a value.

This is NOT a session beer.
Dark brown, ok head. Aroma is fruity and from licorice. Floral flavor with fruity notes. Somewhat bitter in the finish. I could not see what is so great wit this beer.

750 ml. bottle. Pours an overly exhuberant head which deflates into nice tight tannish head, wonderful dark brown, red toned color, good lacing....nose very complex, with fruits, cherry and plum dominating, some malts, bit of bread....tastes initially of fruit, again plum and cherry, then sweet malt, finally hops come in with a  moderate bitterness....reasonably heavy mouth feel, but ,again,rather highly carbonated. Not nearly heavy as a good port.

[Eyes] Excelent Dark deep red brown color and thin but creamy head.
[Nose]Cereal, caramel and hop. 
[Mouth] Nice sweet malt characters, excelent body and good carbonation. This beer has one of the best after flavour that
I´ve tryed.

A bit too much carbonation than I would prefer for this type of beer, starts with sweet taste of fruits and finishes with a bitter balance of chocolate and clove - an enjoyable drink for one glass after dinner...too rich for anything more than one

Pours  very dark, With a full white head,
smells of chocolate, caramel, and dried fruits.
palates intense, reminds of fruits, and strong alchol probably the best belgian ale, brewed outside of belgium.

It seems like coconut taste...
A bit strong but not so heavy
A bit sugared

Pours like a Coke from the bottle, dark amber with an obnoxious tan fizzy head of foam.  Smells of anise and malts with additional notes of caramel and milk cocoa in the flavor.  Frothy mouthfeel, but definitely improves as it warms.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine. Pours an amber/black body with a large off-white head. Smells are dark and cloying with hints of chocolate malts and dark fruits. Flavors are nutty and wood chip-like, but also reminiscent of an Abbey Tripel or Quad with notes of banana, bubblegum, and clove. High carbonation and a full body seem out of balance here. This has a chewy mouthfeel and poorly masked ABV. Not bad, but definitely not my favorite from Unibroue.
Dark brown color, smells like caramel, chocolate, toffee and roasted malts, tastes of dark berries, caramel and a lot of alcohol.

(Canada) Pours a very dark brown wih a sm white head. The aroma is of caramel, toffee, roasted malts,  and chocolate. Taste of caramel, malts, dark fruit, and a hint of vanilla. The mouthfeel is sticky sweet and robust. The 9% is hidden very well in this belgian strong ale. Do yourself a favor and buy some soon.  :)

33cl bottle. Gift from a friend. It poured a dark red-brown colour with a huge beige head that settles down fast in the glass. The aroma is fruity and smells of dark berries and malts. It has a slightly bitter flavour that tastes of dark berries, raisins, caramel, and of alcohol. It has a short aftertaste.

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2008 The best Unibroue Ive tried so far.  Really drinkable but satisfyingly strong at the same time.  Amazingly complex flavors mask the alcohol well.  Almost flawless in my opinion.  Has one of the most unique colors I’ve seen - an earthy brown - which incidentally is how I would describe the experience of drinking this beer.
Hazy murky brown with a small white head that fizzes out quickly.  Notes of overripe bananas.  A little spritzy and a bit thin.  A little too swet for my palate.
from 750ml bottle - need to find my notes from the Unibroue tasting at my local supermarket.  My favorite Unibroue.

Bottle (355ml). Poured deep, dark brown with a tinge of red and a good sized, dense frothy, tanned head which lasted well. Aroma was of currents and blueberries with chocolate & caramel fudge, roasted toffee malts, sticky dates, porty/vanilla notes, hints of licorice and a handful of nuts to top it off. Flavor was of blueberries and raisins with sticky toffee malts, fruit & nut chocolate, caramelized dried fruits, light vanilla/clovey notes and a hint of gingery Christmas pudding. Well hidden alcohol content. Medium to full bodied with medium carbonation, a syrupy texture, warming mouthfeel and a long finish. The standout from the Unibroue lineup (well at least the ones I have tried).
UPDATED: AUG 26, 2008 De couleur rouge foncé, cette biere est dans une autre ligue.  Dark with red fruits flavor.  The best Unibroue.
Another winner from the Unibroue line-up. Poured a dark black with an off-white, almost tan head. Aroma and flavour were primarily of caramel malts, darker fruit and some hints of spice.

Dark, dark carmel with a dense tan head. providing a luxurious mouth feel.  Banana and spice aroma, sweet dark fruit and bread dough added to flavor.  The smoothness is really something to admire.  
A bit of sour at the finish, and some warmth in the belly.  The only thing not perfect for me is that the taste comes and goes so quickly.

4 pack of 12 ozers.  Poured into a Karmeliet tulip glass.  Poured a dingy brown  with a one finger brown head.  Aroma is of dark, sweet over-ripe fruit some caramel, yeast and some spices.  Low to moderate lacing.  Flavor is of the same fruits, malt and a little alcohol to warm.  Body was medium-heavy and the carbonation was medium-high.  Great beer.

Sweet fruits (apricot, peach, orange, plum, blackberry), creamy, earthy yeast aroma.  Some spice (clove, cinnamin, coriander).  Roasted malts, reminds me of the smell of pastries.  
Mellow fruity flavor (fig, raisin, plum).  Subtle roasted malt.
Taste is sweet (carmel + toffee) but balanced, an elegant restrained brew that is a real treat.  The 9% is unbelievable as there is little taste of alchohol.  The earthy yeast flavor complements the fruity sweetness nicely.

Palate is ridiculously smooth (like butta!).
Creamy mouthfilling velvet texture. Plenty of bubbly, but not too much. 

I have had mixed results with imported belgians, but I was very pleased with this one.

Dark brown, almost opaque looking with beige 2 finger head, great belgian style lacing and look, this a belgian dark that really shows well, a complex mix yeast yesters of banana and clove, as well as dark, subtlely candied fruits like raisins, plums and pinot noir grapes, there’s some mustiness typical of belgians, flavors are a soft balance of the afformentioned nose, no need to go any further with that description, though I wish something stood out a little bit more, I enjoyed this almost as much as the Maudite.

Pours a muddy/murky brown with a nice looking tan head. Smell is sweet, with brown sugar dominating. The taste is great, with more brown sugar and plums. Not as much of a raisin flavor as other Belgian Strong Ales and I like this one better because of it.

12oz bottle.  Pours a murky dark brown with a soap scum head and light lacing.  Nose is sweet malt, dark fruits and brown sugar.  Taste is figs, dates, caramelized sugar, yeast and a slight bitter finish.  Medium mouth feel with carbonation thats prickly on the tongue.  Hides the alcohol well but very warming, even after a few sips.  A nice enjoyable strong ale that, as per their commercial description, is very port wine-like.

pours a orange shade of woody dark brown  with some yeasty clumps at the bottom. fluffy almond colored head cloaks the glass with foam as it slowly retreats. immense yeast aroma is savory at times... spice, wood, very soft camp fire smell, dates, raisins and a touch of alcohol. tastes like an oxidized red apple covered with REAL caramel, cinnamon and lots of yeasty dryness. it’s sweet without being over sweet. it leaves an aftertaste that reminds me of fake sugar. medium to full body with a soft velvety mouth feel...
Watery, undefined and too sweet. Bottom line, Unibrew should have put as much artistry into this beer as they did the label.
Oh those dark fruits.  Just discovered this brewery through a chance run-in with La Terrible, but I’m going to keep an eye out for it in the future.  Happy time.

Pours black like strong black coffee with a one-finger head the color of cappuccino foam.  Strong aromas of raisins, molasses, and alcohol.  On the tongue it is a bit sweet, with a subtle tannic quality and no shortage of alcohol heat.  Roasted malts are apparent.  Flavor is somewhere between a ripe fig and a plum.  No hops to speak of really.  Medium to full body with a long finish.  This would go great with a plate of over-ripe figs and creamy goat cheese.

Bomber. Pours beautifully, a very dark and hazy ruby with a two-finger beige head. The aroma is very spicy with coriander and allspice with a pomegranate tang. As the brew hits the tongue, it begins to rapidly carbonate from the temperature change. I’m not a big fan of this effect, but it’s not quite as bad as the De Dolle Extra Export Stout. The flavour also has a lot of spice, but is balanced in intensity. Plum, pomegranate, and other darker fruits are evident aside some woody notes. There’s a very subtle carmelized sweetness to this. The finish is like a dry wine with lots of spices.I’m not a huge fan of spiced beers. But this is pretty good. I feel it’s similar to a spiced up quad.

12 oz. into pseudo trappist glass.  Dark red brown pour with light offwhite head that builds well but recedes very quickly.  Smells like cinnamon, candi sugar, sweet malt, coriander, and orange peel.  Typical Belgian aroma.  Flavor seems pretty complex; the first sip stunned and actually confused me a bit.  Spicy and sweet with notes from the aroma that come out at different points: sweet at first with fruit notes (raisins, dark cherries, and prunes) and finished with a plethora of spice notes (cinnamon, coriander, and ginger mostly).  A bit of a funky sourness lingers behind everything - don;t know if this pleases me or not.  Light bodied on the palate with very lively carbonation - too lively for my taste, but typical of the Belgian ale style. Overall: drinkable, crisp, and pleasant example of a style that is far from my favorite.

(Bottle).  Smells very sweet and fruity, as you would expect.  The color is a deep orange brown, topped by a fizzy off white head.  Flavor is very much in the Belgian Trappist style -- complex, many different fruits, and pleasingly sweet without being candy-ish.  Altogether a wonderfully crafted ale.

Pours and odd orange-brown with some very heavy sediment and foamy, off-white head that settles slowly and leaves minimal lacing. It had a slightly spicy aroma with a citrus bouquet. Very bubbly, crisp, clean mouthfeel- even more carbonated than the Unibroue Maudite. A very bright, fruity flavor with a nice spicenote, that finishes with a slightly sour fruit- like grapes almost- and leaves with a tangy lingering aftertaste.
The sediment almost put me off at first, and not seeing it mentioned in any other reviews confuses me. Maybe I bought an older bottle. But if it were aged, it was very mellow for a strong ale.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2008 750ml bottle. One of my personal favorites. Black coffee color with a thin, lingering head. Highly carbonated mouthfeel. Malty flavor with wine-like fruits keeps me coming back for more.

Pours a dark red with a head that is thin but lasts.  Definite sweet aroma, grapes and ripe fruit, almost reminds me of a wine.  Sweet and fruity with a yeasty finish.  No real aftertase, flavor vanishes kind of quickly.  A very good overall beer, very drinkable and enjoyable.

Poured a dark reddish-brown with a thick light brown head.  Sweet aroma with hints of apple and grape.  Also, smells malty with a bit of caramel.  The flavor is sweet and fruity with a wheat and yeast taste to it.  It finishes almost with the same flavor as the Du Fin Du Monde.  This is a good beer, but over carbonated and not a favorite.

Brown/amber pour, large lasting whitish head.  Sweet aromas, some malt, yeast.  Suprising amount of red fruit with caramel/toffee.  Has a stick to it, but rather medium bodied.  Quite a bit of carbonation, but it does not get in the way.  Does improve as it warms.  Not quite sure what to make of the Unibroue brews, it’s like they’re all the same beer with different flavorings added.  Good but not great.
user_location: from Michigan now in Charlotte, North Carolina, USA

text: Beer # 900 for me.  A huge tan head jumps from the glass during the pour.  Dark brown beer with lots of red, it is almost the same color as the bottle.  Aroma is full of sweet malt, fruit, and alcohol.  Flavor is full of sweet dark fruit, sugar, yeast, wheat, and caramel.  Very much a "Belgian feel" to this one.  An enjoyable and interesting beer but not quite as good as expected.

12 oz. bottle - Poured a brownish red tint with large foaming head that faded quickly. Aroma is quite blahhhh, nothing really. Taste is ok, nothing that great, dry and grainy. Overall a decent beer but not at the level as I expected.
Bottle. Brown/red color with a huge head. Taste is sweet with lots of fruity notes,raisans,yeast and some spice. Easy to drink despite the 9%.

Pours a hazy deep brown with a enormous light brown head. Aroma of rasins, dark fruits, brown sugar and yeasts. Flavor is malt, rasins, dark fruits, belgian yeasts, brown sugar. HIdes the 9% rather well, good belgian style strong ale.

12oz bottle from Racetrack Liquors (Tampa, FL). Pours a dark brown to black with one finger tan head. Good head retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet malt, raisins, figs, dark ripe fruit, yeast. Flavor is sweet and malty with sharp notes of plums, prunes, yeast and spice. Medium body with a sweet malt finish.

Deep brown walnut color with a thick tan head. Rich aroma of carmelized apple, prunes, orange and spicy tannins. Excellent flavor- light spice, dried fruits. Sweet without being cloying or syrupy. Nice body. A bit of alcohol bite in the finish and woody notes. Gets better as it warms and oxidates.

Bottle at bar Becolth, Boxtel (NL). A dark brown colored beer, with a dark beige head. The aroma of dark malts, cherries, little chocolate and port-like. The taste of dark fruits, like prume and dark cherries. als a little woody. A nice gentle aftertaste of everything I mentioned. A very good beer.

Dark, rich and sweet. Lots of ripe raisin and other dark fruit in aroma. Very lively carbonation. Easily tasty at first but gets cloying. Alcohol warmth is a bit of relief from the sweetness. Honestly I think this would be a middling abbey beer over in Belgium.

UPDATED: JUL 31, 2015 Re-rate from 2008, because the bottle I got then was terribly out of date.

7/31/15: 12 oz bottle from Ithaca Coffee Co. Pours black, red highlights, small off-white head, barely any lacing. Aroma is malt, brown sugar, dark fruit, that brown bread from Germany. Taste is boozy, sweet, bready, drying at the end. Sharp but low carbonation, medium/large body, boozy finish (not unpleasant though). Much better than the first bottle I had 7 years ago.

Pours an opaque black with a nice off-white head which lasts a while, but unfortunately didn’t leave much lacing. 2nd pour from the 22 oz bottle (about an hour later, re-corked) had no head at all. Quite sweet aroma. Fizzy mouthfeel and low bitterness. Somewhat sweet, carbonated and malty, but not roasted like a stout. Easy to drink, but a sipper, not a guzzler. At 9% this hits hard after a while, but doesn’t have a strong alcohol taste during enjoyment. Reminds me of the Schneider Aventinus doppelboch, in it’s Coca-Cola like sweetness, carbonation and darkness. Another winner from the always great Unibroue.

Bottle at Århus Ølfestival 2008. Pours brown with red edges and a very small head. Aroma is fruity with raisins and with a hint of chocolate and roasted malt. Flavour is fruity with raisins, and again with a hint of roasted malts and bitter chocolate.

Trappist glass.Pours a dark brown with a beige head, poor lacing on the head. Smells of raisins primarly with other fruits coming in. Slight alcohol burn at first with a small amout of welcomed bitterness much like pecans in the aftertaste. Im glad i found this beer.

Pours dark black with a fluffy cream colored head. Sweet aroma of belgian yeast and plums. Flavor begins with slight alcohol then flavors of plums and brown sugar develop.  Leaves a nice lingering spicy/sweetness in the throat and nostrils. Like a less intense Judgment Day, but still good.  Really easy to drink for 9%!

Bottle aged for 1 year - poured a dark ruby color with a dirty white head.  Sweet fruity aroma with a sweet fruity taste hiding the alcohol.  Starts with a carbonated feel on the tongue that dissipates as the drink is swallowed.  Leaves the mouth craving more.  Definitely recommend trying this beer aged.
Gold head with deep brown body. Aroma of fruit, hops and malt. Complex body with notes of raisins, apricots and grapes. Full finish with a very mild hop. This is a dessert beer to be sipped.

This is [one of] my favorite beer(s).  Great color.  Nice head that diminishes quickly.  Great aroma.  And above all, great taste.  This beer is also less expensive than some beers that I feel ,while they do deserve their recognition, are overrated like the Chimays.

Amazing. Simply amazing. Had at Bottlescrew Bills Calgary AB. Can also get at Kensington wine market, calgary. Aroma of rich fruit mixed with strong malts. Appearance is outstanding. Looks like a black yet slightly purple wine. Tastes like a strong porter- hints of oranges, berrys and honey among many other glorious aromas. Bitter taste, but not overpowering. The perfect beer for a dinner.

Appearance: Dark brown. Little bit of head. Quite cloudy. More head when warmer.
Aroma: Dark fruit and malt. Honey.
Taste: Quite malty. Fruity.Warming, strong.
Info: 330ml bottle, 21/5-2007

This is a very good Belgian ale in classic style. A very high-quality brew from Americas Hat. Pours a nice medium-dark brown, 2/5 of which is head, before settling down. Flavor of dark cherry, prune, wood, leather. Finishes very leathery and oily before slowly dissipating. Booze is evident, but not overly, about what 9/100 should taste like. Id have again.

Sampled during Cellars Wine & Spirits Wednesday evening tasting via Unibroue representative. Pours a hazy brownish amber brew with a heavy tan head that has some nice retention. Aroma of roasted caramel malt, dried figs, brown sugar, some dark berries, and yeast. Taste is medium to full bodied, some carbonation with flavors of chocolate, figs, yeast and brown sugar. Finish is quite sweet, some light metallic character with the high alcohol and a cherry and yeast aftertaste. This was one my favorites of the evening.
Brown pour with a dirty white head.  Sugary nose.  Champagne mouth feel.  Dark and light fruits in the taste.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2008 Bottled 33cl. It pours a hazy dark brown beer with green!? reflects. Moderately tanned, nicely remaining tall head. Vitamin tablets, oranges and candy in the nose which is accompanied by a milky component. Some fudge and figs showing up too. An excellent aroma. Full bodied. Smooth mouthfeel. Vitamin tablets and exotic fruits in the taste. A hint of incense. A port-like characteristic showing up. Wonderfully spicy. Berries, fudge, lemon peel, coriander, cinnamon and thyme appearing. Wonderful finish with hints of oranges and lemon peel. Some bready hints sneaking in. Deeply complex, unique and enjoyable.

bottle from G&G poured into a snifter. pours a very dark burgandy with a thin white head. aroma is very pleasing. sweet smelling with hints of plum, grape, and red raspberry, and a touch of hops in the background. flavor is excellent. sweet and malty with plum, black currant, cherry, and vanilla. the aftertaste is slightly sweet and bitter and long lasting. mouthfeel is very refreshing and fizzy. very smooth and easy to drink with 9% abv hidden superbly. overall an excellent belgian strong.
Another winning beer from Unibroue.  Dar reddish pur wtih a a light beige head.  Aroma is (surprise) yeasty.  Flavor has yeast, malt and stone fruit.  Smooth and creamy mouthfeel.  Nice beer.

Large bottle, pours dark red/brown with frothy off-white head.  Aroma initially of soapy yeast, but as beer stood at room temperature, it became more aromatic.  Aroma became dark fruit and malt, with touch of yeast.  Taste rich with dark fruit and sweet malt.  Fizzy and rich mouthfeel, pretty good beer all in all!

Surprisingly almost zero light makes it through the glass.  Large fizzy head disappears to a thin layer. Very sweet malts and fruits mix well with the carbonation.  A little different but very good and drinkable.

Pours nearly pitch-black-ruby with a few fingers of head with a soapy head that lingers.  Strong odor of plum, malt, and caramel.  Strong plum and sugar malt taste which ends with a warm alcohol aftertaste.  A good, complex quad.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Bottle:  A very well crafted Belgian ale.  Dark in color with an intense off-white head.  This heavily carbonated brew is sweet and sugary with dark fruits and malts.  It has a hint of yeast in the aroma and flavor.  The alcohol is well hidden and it is extremely drinkable.  A great all around Belgian Strong Ale.  UPDATE: With the last few experiences of this beer, my opinion has steadily dropped.  The aroma and flavor was overpowered by a soapy yeast smell and taste.  Over carbonated and not as flavorful as I remembered.  I hope to try it a few more times and see if my thoughts change.

scura bella schiuma mediamente persistente note molto fruttate malto tostato in bocca tendente al dolce note di porto il fruttat dopo un po si perde letilico si sente leggermente allinizio data la gradazione ci puo stare

Appearance: Pours a rather dark, reddish-brown body with a foamy, off-white head.

Smell: Spicy, sweet-smelling aroma of rum-soaked spice cake, orange zest, random berries, and dark caramel malts.

Taste: Sweet, sugary dark malts with well-blended tastes of caramel, milk chocolate, and vanilla. Punchy, tangy fruit character throughout. Mild bitterness. Dash of white pepper. Very, very slight sour hint. Touch of alcohol near the end. Fruity, fizzy finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied. Moderate carbonation.

Drinkability: Very tasty. Id been quite some time, years in fact, since Id last had one of these. I oughta be ashamed of myself.

Lots of aromas coming out from the bottle since you open it. Very dark colored with red brights when seen to the light. Thick head that vanishes into a persistent thin layer. Tastes like roasted malt, some dark fruits but not sweet. Some alcohol, but still smooth. More carbonation than needed, but nothing serious. Nice aftertaste persists for a while. A good one.

Ruddy brown with a substantial, but short-lived head.  Aroma dominated by dried fruits and yeast.  Taste profile has boatloads of raisin, cane sugar, and roasted malt.  Lingering alcohol burn, but nothing suggesting the huge ABV.
What a brewery!!!! High alcohol but does not taste or smell like it.  Great full body flavor excelent composition of malt and fruit flavor.  Would recommend this to anyone.

OK, the cork must have been bad on mine. Almost no head at all, and very undercarbonated. Either that or the yeast didnt take the priming sugar.

Dark brown with no head. Aroma is dark fruit (dates and figs and raisins), some apple, and roast malt. Flavor is molasses, with burnt notes, a hint of alcohol warmth at the finish. 

Too bad this slipped through quality control or I might have rated it quite highly! Will have to taste it again, given the previous rave reviews. I think I will write a strongly worded email to their American distributor and try to get myself a freebie.
Dark brown colored pour with medium sized head.  Floral, sweet, citrusy aroma.  Sweet vanilla, fruity, carbonated finish.  I liked this.
Bottle. Huge head. Flavor of port, roasted malt, and alchohol. Flavor gets more and more complex as it warms. Very nice.

Best belgian Ive had so far. Strong fruity flavour and alcohol hidden well. Impressive foamy head and wonderful fruity smell. A good intro beer of its type.....I typically dont like belgians, even those that everyone here are so fond of. But this was very tasty.

12oz bottle. Pours deep dark brown, very nice looking with a towering tan head that leaves a small head for the duration. Nose is dates and wine with a hint of cheese and that Unibroue yeast. Taste is big on dark fruit and plum, pretty spicy on the tongue with too much carbonation, kinda waters the palate out to much but the flavor is still very tasty. Well done but if this had a little less carbonation it would be world class.

Almost more akin to wine than beer.  Pours dark brown/maroon with very little head.  Tases of port, dark fruit, lightly roasted malts, alcohol, and almost vinegar.  More carbonated than one would expect from a beer with as much head as it has.  No lacing.  Definitely a complex taste and interesting, but not particularly suiting to my palate.

Bottled. Dark brown, almost no head. Aroma plums, raisins, port, smoke. Taste the same, extremely full even though I have almost no taste left after this massive hangover. Oh boy, Tallinn really takes the spirit out of you...

Incredible!  This is fine, fine stuff.  First thing I noticed was a burst of aroma, flowing out of the bottle, full of alcohol, dark fruits (figs or raisins), combined with roasty malt.  Its poured a very dark-reddish color with a reddish foam head.  Nicely carbonated.  Its flavor was very complex with fruits, vinious texture, alcohol, and roasty malt.  Its smooth and right.  Nice cool, nice warm.  Not abrasive whatsoever.
Heavy Aroma of raisins, roasted malt, and alchohol.   Flavor gets more and more complex as it warms.  Lively carbonation and mouthfeel.

Bottle... Poured deep, opaque ruby with a beige head.  Aroma of figs, fruit and roasted malt which lends to alcohol.  Great carbonation and bubbles on the palate.  Flavors of ripe fruit like plums and raisons that create a sweetness that match the malt nicely.  Tiny bit of citrus and maybe hops, but just there to accent.  Alcohol presence is low for 9%/

750ml corked bottle served in a chalice. Poured a dark copper with lots of carbonation. Two fingers of off white head. Fruity with some spice in the aroma. Smooth, medium bodied beer with some malty sweetness and a little spice in the finish. Sometimes the Unibroue beers blend together with me. Nothing really jumps out at me, but I still enjoy them on a purely hedonistic level. Good value for your money.

The beer pours a deep red almost hazy copper colors with a thin brown head that is mostly lasting. The nose is a sweet mix of stone fruit, raisins, oak, spicy ginger and yeast. The flavor follows the nose with a sweetness and hints of orange, spice and wood. The finish is sweet malts that is short lived.

Pours a dark hazy chestnut brown with a beige head. The aroma has a rich dried fruit sweetness without being overpowering or cloying.

The flavour is nothing short of spectacular, though it perhaps doesnt pack quite the same deep flavour as say, Rochefort 10, it is actually better balanced. No single flavour dominates, the bitterness, alcohol, licorice, spices and dried fruit all working together perfectly. Because of this, it is flavourful enough to enjoy as a winter warmer whilst at the same time being suitable to drink in quantity with food.

Fruity overtones were neglected by the pure fashion of beer.

A great and pure beer at birth, but, it became too simple. It became a concoction of materials.

It was tasty, fruity, indulgent. But, I didnt want it to be like that.

It was special, but it didnt want to be. and thats why I like it.

In the first intial pour the head is an enormously tan colour that you think is going to attack you, so you take a step back. Cautiously, you bring your nose forward and smell the lively fruit that bounces around inside the glass. Once it settles a few minutes later, the colour of the beer is dark red or light chocolate. Lots of citrusyness, a very intense taste, with every sip I never got used to it.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 smells like spices when you open it and then a smell sort of like a wine. fruity tasting. a pleasant appearance with a unique colour and very creamy. i stopped drinking this regularly for a while i cant believe i did, its good value for the price considering each one is almost two 5 percent beers..

re-rate due to buying a pack that seems to be worse quality than when i had it before

Deep chestnut with a ridiculously creamy head.  Unibroue beers always have amazing, lush bubbles and mouthfeel.  This one pretty much has to warm up a bit before being consumed, or else a trademark cardboard flavor will dominate.  Prunes, malt, almost red-winey flavor.  Still a little of that cardboard.  A bit boozy, but still covers the 9% decently.
Drak brown brew with thick tan head. Strong malt aroma followed by fruit: prunes (duke of), datte, raisin. Alcool, chocolate and winy taste. Quebecs pride.

Bottle from Matt! Poured a light black color. Big head! Smells like sweet raisons. Smooth...and easy to drink. Quite good. Flavor is dried fruits such as raisons, cherries, etc... Mild Carbonation. Not a trace of that 9%! Over all a good brew! Thanks again Matt!

This delicious beer has an aroma of cherries, figs, plums, and deep fruit.  The flavor delivers all that plus a ton of carbonation.  It is very smooth and filling, I barely notice the alcohol presence.  Nice beer, but between the intense flavor and the carbonation it is not a light and easy-drinking beer, but a filling and deeply flavorful beer.
not bad I enjoy some of the other unibroue beers better, but nice flavor, malts spice and fruit. some alcohol and a very stong finish a good sipping beer.
Appearance: Ruby red with a creamy head. Aroma: Sweet and sour, almost juicy aroma, nice. Flavour: Bitter and cinnamon,sour too some underlying malt and fruit, the 9% is well hidden. Nice
amber pour with generous head, very suttle taste to suggest the stated ABV, would drink again
2008-Apr-25 from a 750 ml bottle (Served too cold).  Dried fruit, figs, and brown sugar aroma.  Dark brown with a light t brown head.  Big plum flavor at first and then a hot finish.  Think palate.

bottle poured into a tulip glass has a very dark brown color with almost no transparency and a huge three finger tan head that took forever to fall and never disappeared completely. aroma has spice, licorice, banana, raisin, figs, malt, and very little alcohol for a 9%. high carbonation pushes the roasted malt, charred oak, fermented dark fruit, spice, and light bitters. does have some port wine characters, champagne like carbonation, and completely hidden alcohol.

Dark brown, w/ large off-white head. Very fruity aroma, spices. Taste is sweeter than others of the category, with tangy fruit notes present, smooth malt character, and almost no hop presence. Fairly thin. I liked it, but it wasnt my fav from this brewery.

Vinous cola nose, some spice and caramel notes.  Dark brown to black color, bubbly head with quick dissipation.  Spicy clovey burnt caramel sweetness, mild bitterness, more tartness, alcohol hits aggressively.  Fizzy, surprisingly thinner easy mouth feel, finish is long with the alcohol burning through in a big way.  Huge beer, has some really interesting spicy complexity, very different, would go fantastic with a steak.
Pours a dark, murky brown with generous head. Very fruity and spicey, perhaps a bit more bitterness and less sweet than Belgians of the same style...like Chimay Blue.

Deep brown with long-lasting beige head. Complex, endless nose of dominant raisin and plum coupled with a citric components (grapefruit and orange) and alcohol. The taste is a little simpler and displays more plum and raisin sweetness but its balanced with bitter malts and a dry, alcohol character. The palate is a little overkill (carbonated feel) for me, but this is still a great beer.

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2008 12 oz bottle.  Pours solid brown with medium tan head.  Aroma is fruity, with aromas of apple and spice.  Taste is of dark fruits, caramel, and malts.  Carbonation is a little too fizzy for me, but the flavor is really nice.  First Belgian ale Ive really enjoyed (out of four so far, but hey, gotta start somewhere).
bottle, fizzy head that disappears quickly, clove and spice nose, coca cola color with lots of malty  caramel flavors, nicely carbonated finish

Ruddy color and a ruddy flavor. Fruity taste with no carbonation. Tasted and felt like the bottle was never corked. Dont understand the score it has. Couldnt force myself  past half a glass. Will not buy again.
Very cloudy brown pour with a beige head. A good belgian style fruit driven beer. Sweet in flavor with hints of spices oranges, raisins, and bananas. Decently balenced. Pretty good.
Dark cloudy pour with a creamy off white head.  Lots of malt and fruit in the aroma.  Great flavor, with a nice alcohol bite on the finish.  A very good brew.
750 mL bottle.  Dark pour with a generous white head.  Damn good.  Goes down ever-so-smooth.  Dark fruits, raisin, a little bit of banana.  Sweet.  Strong.  Good alcohol warmth.  Very enjoyable.
750ML bottle. Its good. Dark and cloudy as can be with an effervescent head and lots of bubbles. Tastes very fruity but not very thick on the palette like would be expected.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 Poured this wonderful brew from a large sized bottle into a trappist glass.  The roasty aroma was mostly of dense fruits, some raisin and apricot, a touch of caramel, and maybe a touch of citrus.  A very nice appearance, a cloudy dark brown color, almost black, with a very big, creamy, off-white head with good retention.  Great, sweet and rich fruit taste, with a mix of bitterness and sourness for balance.  Slightly thin on the palate, just a tad watery, but overall, a wonderfully fluid body with the alcohol well maintained; good cling inside the mouth.  The beer cost $8, but was worth it, a masterful brew.

12 oz Bottle, $2.99 @ Kegs & Barrels in McKinney, TX. 
Pours a Hazy dark ruby brown with frothy Beige head with nice retention. Aroma of raisons or dark fruit, notes of clove. Flavor dark fruit, slight roasted malt, clove, slight bannana, with excellent alcohol spice to compliment. Palate is full, medium carbonation. Nice!!!!!

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2008 What a treat.  Sampled at 08 Unibroue tasting.  This one was the most anticipated by my girlfriend and I, both of us being fans of darker style ales.  The appearance was STUNNING.  Not bright, not black, directly in-between.  A soft, beautiful reddish/brown, like light coffee or cola, and topped with a tannish white, whipped mousse looking head. Beautiful.  The nose is presented with sweet aromas of anise, ginger, and sassafrass (similar to root beer), that complement one another very well.  The taste is nicely bitter but well balanced, with toffee, cocoa, hints of raisins, dates, ginger, root beer, and roasted malt, all lingering long after the last sip, as well as a vanilla bean creaminess.  Excellent.  Interesting.
So smooth not filling, fruity aftertaste, deep brown in color, with a nice foam, Malty and fruity, not to sweet. very pleasant beer at the end of a truly crappy work day

A 12 oz bottle with a best buy date. A super foamy head and a bark brown body. The smell is a fruit and malt. Taste is smooth and complex . A very good beer
 
6 pack.

33 cL bottle. Pours hazy deep brown with a slowly collapsing and light tan head. Mild spiced and yeasty aroma. Mild roasted malt flavour with a light sweetness. Followed by a fruity flavour and mixed with a light yeast notes. Light fruity flavour into the finish.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2009 Dark ruby red/blackish color with all assortments of fruits on the nose and an ever complex taste. Orange, spice, cinnamon, banana and raisins are all notable in the aroma which gives way to a little more malt in the taste. Often described as port-like for its deep flavors, this is perhaps the best line produced by Unibroue. 

Caution: it rather stings if you get some in your eye.

This was an exceptional beer. I dont know if I have all the adjectives to describe the beer, other than to say it was delicious. 

Very dark, ruby colored pour into an oversized wine glass. Nicely balanced aromas, followed by an exceptionally smooth taste. Extremely balanced. 

Mouthfeel was like velvet. This went down very easily. Id give it a 5 on drinkability except the ABV would limit how much you could drink in one sitting. Overall an exceptional beer.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2009 33 cl bottle from Systembolaget. Very dark beer with a nice head which remains until the beer is finished. It smells fruity and a bit yeasty. Notes of spices. Very interesting! You definitely want to taste it. Flavour is beutiful of dark fruits and berries, although the liquorice is what distinguishing the beer most. The spiceness reminds a litte of a stronger wheat beer like the weizen bock Aventinus surprisingly enough. Great!

Poured a brown laquor color with a nice frothy head. The nose was intence with molasses, chocolate, raisins, figs and clove. The taste started very vinous like port combined with chocolate, molasses and raisins. There was a slight roasty aftertaste that merges well with the hops for a slight burnt cider tatse. Im quite impressed with this one. Excellent!
Extremely good tripel style ale from our friends in Canada.  Flavors were a delicious blend of dark fruits, spice, and malt.  Great strength and finish.

Pours a nice dark ruby/maroon with a pretty thin off-white head. The aroma is of sweet and sour fruits, lots of grape and berries I would say, with a bit of spice in there. The flavor continues to impress with tons of rich fruit flavors coming through, grapes and berries again. I cant even taste the alcohol. The finish is nice and dry. The mouthfeel is pretty syrupy, but is balance out nicely by the carbonation. Very solid beer overall, I would drink this one any day of the week.

Pours a ruby like hue with a head that stays just around the rim of the glass.  It smells like spicy fruits and yeast, but not all that doughy.  Spiciness prevails on the tongue with plenty of rich, sweet malts coming through.  It finishes dry.  Its very bubbly and light on the palate.  A really well done brew.
Bottle. Dark brown with tan head. Yeast, bread, spices, as well as some mild berries and port. Slightly syrupy. Lingering after taste. Good, but not great - I prefer La Maudite.

It is a good brew but it has fell short like the other Unibroue products have had .  I have only had Maudiet and La Fin so far this is the best Unibroue product I have had, but in my opinion There products are more about the hype of the beer rather than the actual quality of the beer.

pours a dark burnt caramel color with a nice two finger fluffy light brown head. aroma is yeast and some hops with dark fruits, a little bread, and a little citrus. has a medium body with descent lacing and good carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but stronger. it has a port wine finish and aftertaste and all together not bad i guess. i would take a couple of the other unibroue beers over this one though.
Muddy brown with thick creamy beige head.  Aroma of spice, clove and Belgian yeast.  Medium bodied taste of fruit, caramel, and spice.  A little tartness in the finish and it hides the alcohol well.

75cl bottle.   Dark brown with hints of purple, and a really white head considering the dark color of the beer.   The biggest impression that I get from the aroma is licorice, then some sugarcane and pineapple, with a yeasty character over it all.   Nothing as dark as I expected.   The flavor is likewise pretty light tasting, though rich and sweet, with the same licorice flavor and light yeastiness.   Closing my eyes, I can almost imagine a lighter, tripel style ale.   The body is pretty full and smooth, but missing the silkier texture that I like in a BSA.   A nice drinkable ale, but unremarkable for me.

Bottle. Pours very dark and cloudy brown with a beige head that never really goes away. Aroma is sweet ripe fruit, almost like a nice red wine, with notes of cherry, berry, prune and apricot. Full and velvety body. Flavors are subtle and never overpowering. Berry, plum, peach, yeast, raisin, and probably much more my unworthy palate cant find. Very nice, very well balanced, easy to drink.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2010 An awesome beer!  Gift from Sarah for my 32nd birthday. (Thanks!) Extremely dark brown color with a light, light brown bubbly head.  This beer leaves no lacing.  Sweet aroma with a little dark candy sugar in the nose, a little spicy and earthy.  Yeasty up front, but theres a strength in the back that makes you quickly forget about the yeasty sourness.  Together, these balance well and give an overall punch-like experience and only a slightly sour, yeasty finish.  Light-bodied for such a dark beer (and a Belgian strong ale at that), but superbly tasty with a kicking flavor.  The alcohol didnt hit me hardly at all.  Looking forward to my next bottle!  More malty and not as light-palated and yeasty as alot of beers of this style usually are to me.

Part of a blind taste test with Don de Deu and La Fin du Monde.  My favorite of the three.  Aroma of cloves, bread, yeast.  Great appearance, dark and cloudy.  Flavor is strong and complex.  Overall a great beer.
Dark brown of color with a nice beige head. An aroma of spice, dark fruits, port, prunes and sweet liqurice. A flavor of spice, dark fruits, port and notes of liqurice.
Pours very dark. Nice roasted malts in the aroma. I get a sweet fruit taste with light spicy notes.Alchol came on a little strong for me, but not as much as say,  a barley wine. Good beer.

Pours an incredibly dark mahogany with small whiteish head.  Some lacing is there, aroma is huge dark fruit and dark esters.  Flavor is cherry and currant.  Dark esters from fruity yeast exist.  Real nice on the finish.  A very nice belgian.

Pours a hazy dark brown color with a thickish tan head. Quick alcohol, yeasty, semi sugary aroma. Slightly sweet and vanilla yeasty tasting but not crazy overpowering like I was expecting and the alcohol seems to be hidden very well in the flavor. While the abv his hidden well I do assure you its there, youre body will tell you that! Theres also a roasty almost chocolate flavor in there mixed with some caramel. Very good. It does have a little tangy sour taste as well but it is much more controlled in this one and mixes in quite well.
I love this beer. Has aroma that reminds me of port or an old red wine. Similar flavors. If you have had the Maudite by Unibroue, this is similar but with a raisin flavor.

Dark brown beer that pours a creamy brown head. The aroma is very sweet and fruity, but I cant tell which, maybe raisins or prunes with some yaest. The flavor is also sweet with strong roasted malty notes. I love the  well-balanced presence of alcohol. Leaves a fabulous fruity palate. Very tasty beer.

Unibrowe Trois Pistoles
ABV: 9 %
Calories: estimated at 200 C
Volume: 12 fl oz
Glass: 6 oz tulip
Purchased at: Princeton Community Liquors
Price per fl oz: $2.49 / 12 fl oz = $0.20 per fl oz
Consumed at: home

sensory first impression: No head, deep ruby, dark malty aroma brew. Cherry overtones. Hoppy bite, cherry flavor, malty depth, and a very rich experience.

Aroma/Olfactory: 9 out of 10
Malt flavor is: syrupy, cherry, malty depth.
Hop flavor is: citrusy bite, a bit salty
Yeast flavor is: dusty, dirty, dry
Other flavors include: cherry, raisin, vanilla, birch

Visuals/Appearance: 5 out of 5
Color is: pale, amber, red, brick, fiery, ruby
Liquid is: clear, lightly carbonated
Head and lace are: minimal, tan

Taste/Flavor: 9 out of 10
Maltiness or Sweetness level is: medium
Hoppiness or Bitterness level is: medium
Sour level is: heavy

Palate/Tactile: 4 out of 5
Body or Mouthfeel is: full
Texture is: oily, creamy, sticky, paper napkin, scratchy
Carbonation is: soft, flat
Finish is: astringent, bitter, long, Japanese

Overall experience: 17 out of 20. I liked the cherry overtones, the flavor, generally, and the color especially. I did not like the head or the lacing.

Bouteille de 341 ml. La bière est de couleur brune très foncée avec de léger reflets rouge ténèbreux. Une mousse plutôt imposante au début mais qui laisse place rapidement à un simple cercle en dentelle se présente à nos yeux. Au nez des arômes de  bleuets, de fraise murs, de framboise , de raisins, de prunes, de levure, de chocolat noir, dalcool et de malt grillé se font convaincant pour laisser un bon souvenir à mon sens de lodorat. En bouche, le corps est moyen et les saveurs présentes sont lalcool, les fruits rouges murs, le chocolat noir, la levure et un léger goût de café. Le tout se termine par une pointe de mûres et de groseilles.
Pours dark brown/black with a minimal reddish head.  Aroma of strawberries to an extent.  Good flavor though the carbonation was a bit much.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown, just slightly translucent with a hint a of red. Head was beige and dissipated quickly. The aroma has some hints of fruit and malt. The taste was not quite a fruity as I expected but still had some fruit flavor. The aftertaste had some alcohol in it. The carbonation was noticeable and the beer felt slightly thick. Very nice.

Tasted 4/3/08.  330ml bottle.  One of the ideal times when I used the actual proper glassware for this beer.  Sedimented and bottle conditioned but most of the gunk stayed in the bottle.  Hazy and murky brown hue with a touch of red.  Quickly dissipating beige head.  Aromas of raisins and plums.  Toffee cocoa and vanilla.  Bright fruity esters and a wet wood nose.  Great complexity.  Rather full bodied with that nice Unibroue yeast character.  Tight effervesecence and sugary malts.  Lively body with tingling lingering citrus and orange candy flavor.  Rolling palate and cloying finish.  Truly special!

Bottle.  Muddy brown pour with an orange tint and beige head.  Aroma of malty fruit (prunes), light roast, belgian-like spicing and yeast.  Flavor of dark fruit and other lightly citric fruit, grassy and spicy yeastiness, candy sugar; overall sweet but balanced with spices and yeast.  Nice palate, the same as other unibrous.  Enjoyed this beer.

I know Ive had this before I guess I just didnt rate it, thankfully Douglas sent me another bottle to try!  First trade to Japan! Thanks man! The pour is beautiful with a deep and dark brown body and a light brown head, not too thick but very nice. A thin foamy head retains during the entire glass. Aroma is strong and very complex, man this stuff smells good. Dark fruits such as plum, black cherries, and dates fill the air. Add a touch of maple syrup, cinnamon, and nutmeg and sweet yeast to round out the finish of the bouquet. The taste is again very flavorful. Black cherries and plums mix with brown sugar and spices to add a very sweet but wonderful flavor on the tounge. The yeast is very noticable in this one but doesnt take away from the beer at all, if any thing it adds character. Awesome stuff!

750 ml bottle from Surfas in L.A.
Aroma of raisins and oak plus alcohol.
Pours dark brown with a light brown head that disappears rather quickly, very little lace.  Medium body, roasted malt, light sweetness with bitter finish.
Except for appearance. which is not too important to me, a very good brew.

The gothy label is cool and reminds me
of a Lovecraft, Poe or Stoker novel. The beer is DARK brown with a sweet and complex aroma of citrus, orange, chocolate and dark dried fruits. The flavour is bittersweet like liquorice and apricots. The carbonation however is a bit too aggressive.

THICK brown pour.  Slightly clear with a tan head.  Really great aroma.  Lots of apples and other fruit with a little bit of alcohol.  Some grain and malt.  Very complex.  I was a little underwhelmed by the flavor; still really good, I was expecting something amazing after the aroma.  Slightly sweet wine like taste, but with lots of grain and yeast.  Turns to a dry alcohol aftertaste.  Some hints of molasses.  Very good.

pours a thin black, with huge cream head.  aroma of rich grapes and fruit.  taste is predictable with grape and plum and a hint of spice. it has a crisp dry finish.  I have had a couple beers like this now and it sits somewhere in the middle

750ml bottle from BevMo.  Near black and barely translucent in appearance with cherry accents when put to light. Audibly fizzing with a mossy and tan head. Aroma is one of a kind, with Fruity Pebbles, grapes, currant, black cherries, liquor-lacquered chocolate cherry cordials, prune juice, pepper and nutmeg. Rich and expressive flavor. Chocolate, cloves, pepper and figs invigorate while a wrap-around fruity nature comprised of plums and chocolate covered strawberries pull at the heart strings. Some cherry pipe tobacco and a spicy complex akin to Christmas (cranberries, orange peel and nutmeg.) Effervescent, but not over the top. Titillating on the palate. Balance speaks for itself, finishing with chocolate raspberry liqueur and a lasting holiday spice that sings its song long after each sip.

Pours a very dark, almost opaque, copper-brown with an extremely thick, foamy, long-lasting off-white head.  Strong aroma of Belgian yeast and sweet fruit.  Sweet, fruity taste.  You dont really get much of the alcohol flavor until the aftertaste, along with some malt and toffee hints.  A tingly, carbonated mouthfeel.  I wont often say this, but this one could have probably been better with a little lower alcohol content.  Still, a very, very good beer.
Very dark beer, poured straight into my glass and it almost overflowed with foam.  Taste is smooth and similar to a good tasting wine but better.  No bad taste at all.   great beer.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 "Port wine" indeed. My all time favorite beer. I just which I was richer so I could drink it everyday. eep aroma of dark fruits and sweet malt. Solid flavor of plums, figs and a wine sweetness. Very carbonated. Very good

Bottled. You can smell the alcohol right from the start. This combined with the fruit flavors is interesting. This pours a dark read brown with a highly carbonated head of creamy brown color. The flavors fall hand and hand with the aroma, fruits of cherry plum and possibly apricot, the crisp bite of herbs and alcohol. Smooth on the tongue, and the flavor lingers. This is one of my new favorites.

Had this in a bottle at Baileys Chocolate Bar in STL.  Poured with a brown-reddish color and rather quickly disapperaing reddish head.  The aroma was typically Belgian with sweet yeasty aroma combined with some plum and other soft dark fruits.  There was little hop aroma and flavor.  Flavors of mildly sweet fruits came through in the flavor as well as it eased into the finish.  I almost seemed to cleanse the palate with each sip and made for an excellent dessert drink.  I was shocked to see the 9% printed on the label.  I had it with the most decadent brownie and ice cream which may have given this this beer the opportunity to offer a nice cleansing contrast.

Bottle. Pours a hazy reddish brown colour with a tan head. Aroma is very yeasty and a bit fruity (sweet dried fruits). Flavour is very yeasy (and herby). It also has some earthy notes, some tartness and a harsh taste. But primarily this beer is yeasty. You can feel the alcohol in the finish. I think this beer will be so much better after some years in the cellar.

Very port-like beer. Deep aroma of dark fruits and sweet malt. Solid flavor of plums, figs and a wine sweetness. Very carbonated. Very good example of a Belgian and definitly enjoyable as an after-dinner or sipping beer in front of a fire.

Mostly large bubble foam, dark brown pour. Obnoxious amount of foam, as is the case form most beligians. Smells like sweet apples and alcohol. Tastes like wild yeast acidic malt, sour ale. Rather light despite the color. More fruity than regular beer. What is it with you people and these belgians?? Oh if anything has 9% alcohol, it must be good right? And this ones brewed in Canada by a Japanses company? Give me a break.  Oh my God, it went down the drain, you know Im just not in the mood for this shit,  
drunk with 2 beers, mediocre apple juice, wine like beer.

bottle that has been sitting inside my closet for way too long.... pours a murky dark caramel brown with a one finger soapy off-white head.... aromas of dark fruit, yeast, and sweet malts.... flavors dont stray too far from the nose other than the fact that it leaves just a slight bitter finish to it but doesnt detract away from it. a little too carbonated for my taste and which it was a little more smooth and creamy....a decent bsa.

Pours a dark dark reddish brown with a healthy big bubbled light tan head.  The nose is hard to pick up through the foam.  Big fruity Unibroue yeast smell, sometimes it bugs me, but here it works better than in most of their other beers.  Raisins and some light dark fruit.  A bit sweeter than most of their beers and a bit fuller on the malt bill.  Alcohol, hidden.  Creamy, with robust small bubbled carbonation.  The flavor is in line with the nose, though the alcohol pops out quite a bit .  Sweet estery goodness.  The apple pops back a bit, the banana up.  This has some nice dark malt complexity.  But it plays well with a chewy juicy fruit like flavor.  Raisin.  A bit creamy.  Some caramel, a dry floral finish.  A small bit of toffee hits in the finish.  Better than I thought it would be.

Pours dark brown with off white head. Aromas of fruits, yeast and some citrus. Flavors of sweet dark fruit and malt. Meduim body with a creamy mouthfeel and prickly carbonation. My favorite beer from Unibroue.

Pours black with a thick tan head. Highly carbonated. Nose is yeast and citrus even though it doesnt look like it would be. Very smooth beer. Very fruity but im having a really hard time putting my finger on exactly what. Hides its alcohol really well. Fun to drink.

Pours black with a tall, frothy tan head. This is a very carbonated beer. Aroma of yeast and citrus, wit ha few other fruity notes. Very smooth and fruity all the way through. Almost like spiced apples dominating a fruit salad that ends with a sweet hoppiness. Very tasty and complex, but hard to identify any dominating character out of the fruit.

Poured a dark brown color with fluffy white head that stayed for a while.  Aroma was of sweet dark fruit.  Flavor was dark fruit and sweet maltiness with a touch of spice. A bit of chocolate taste at the finish.  Mouthfeel was pleasant, and this beer hid the 9% abv very well.  Great beer.

A rock solid entry from the boys at Unibroue. Pours a deep cola with a big off white head that eventually deteriorates into a decent ring that lasts. Aromas of soft fruit, alcohol, and fresh vinyl. Flavors of sweet malt, with more fruit, apple, spices like nutmeg, and a rich bitter hop. Great stuff.
Dark brown with a decent head. Sweet malty grain aroma with some honey and carmael. Taste is caramel, licorice and orange peel.

Bottle from Utobeer. What was left in the bottle poured a murky brown colour with frothy tan head. Aroma is of dark fruits, malty, toffee, some spices. Taste is liquorice, chewy, creamy and full bodied. Nice effort but not one of the best.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2008 That classic Unibroue pour and aroma.  Pours near black with a medium beige frothy head.  The usually Unibroue sweet grain aroma but with extra sweet and lots of licorice.  Very fragrant.  The flavor is like drinking very airy bubbly black licorice.  Some orange and coriander as well.  Pretty sweet and very rich finish.   The malt is roasted to perfection.  A slight woody finish.  Not the most well crafted brew, but it is delicious.

While this is a great beer, it does not match up with others of its class. For a darker beer it has a surprisingly warm feel but is lacking in complexity. I would recommend a St. Bernardus Abt 12 and other Trappist ales over this beer. While this beer does have a high alch content (9%) St. Bernardus (10%) has a higher content as well as others so this should not enter into the equation.
Nice dark ale!  First had on tap.  A little sweet at first, but pleasant aroma and aftertaste.  Higher alcohol content not noticeable in flavor.   Smooth drinking and will definitely drink again.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2008 The ideal winter ale for me...rich, malty, subtly spicy, nice caramel, and that touch of Belgian yeastiness. The finish is long, smooth, and warming, and the body is velvety, and slightly creamy. Yum!
Not 100% on board with the trois pistoles craze, but a good beer nonetheless....

341ml bottle 
9.0% ABV 
I tried this beer on January 17, 2008 at "Smokeless Joes" in Toronto.  Ive been trying to get a hold of this for a while but it has been rather elusive.    The beer poured a dark brown, with a thick creamy tan coloured head that lingered a few minutes.  The aroma was sweet malt, some yeast, some dark fruit, and some spices.  The mouthfeel was creamy, full-bodied, with high carbonation.  The flavour was malty, sweet, yeasty...with a little licorice.
Malty start with pears and cinnamon.  Sweet.  Pours dark with a small, quickly diminishing head, good lacing.  Aroma is yeasty and appetizing.  Full-bodied, mild lingering after taste.  Very good.

Several reviewers have remarked on the fruity qualities of this beer, but I think they are a bit overstated - this is not a fruity brew by any stretch, although the references to port are apt (I personally dont think of good port as being particularly "grapey" - it has a character of its own). Rich, caramelly, malty, and pleasantly roasted; tremendously well-balanced for such a relatively high-ABV brew. This is a classic, cold-weather strong ale. Highly recommended, and one of my favorites both of the genre, and in general. Nice job, Unibroue!

This beer is a tawny brown.  It pours with a bubbly head like a soda.  The smell is malty and sweet and there is a slight, very slight grapey smell.  The bubbles tickle my mouth as I drink it.  The taste is pleasantly roasty without being burnt or bitter.  It has the flavor of a nice sweetbread and a bit of a creamy, doughy mouthfeel and would be a perfect pairing with some Moravian sugar cookies.
An excellent Belgian strong ale. It has a fruity and caramel maltiness to it. Highly drinkable. I didnt know Canada made good Belgian style beer!

Got as a gift,at first was thinking wow 9% Im gonna taste alcohol .Thick foamy head & nice lacing ,Fruity esters throughout,0 alcohol taste,.much better than their Blanche de Chambly.I will buy again next TRIP to the store

Im the guy that will buy a beer if it has a cool picture on it and a winged black horse falls under that criteria. I like this beer, it has a good taste and aroma which is kinda fruity but still quite delicious.
Corked bottle.  Rich, dark brown pour.  Faint aroma of fruit, perhaps plum.  Sweet, malty, fruit and caramel flavor.  Medium body, smooth, malty and carbonated mouthfeel.  This was a very nice beer.
Pours dark brown almost black with long lasting frothy head.  Very tasty beer.  smells of fermented fruit.  taste is of fruit and hops.  Has somewhat of a wine taste.  I would purchase this again.

Thin head carbon good,yellow/brown pour getting toward dark ochre.Aroma liccorice,plum.Flavour plums,wheat with a mellow touch at the finish and spice.Tasted a few of these now very nice tasting ales.

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2009 Pours molasses brown with magnanimous, boisterous frothy head. Aroma was very strong of caramel malt and a hint of fermented raisin and dark fruit- almost grape like. Mouthfeel was crazy smooth given the 9% ABV. Rich, pillowy and oily palate that lingers on the tongue. Flavor is powerful and pronounced- and despite this fact, you literally cant taste the alcohol. Caramel, molasses and raisin dominate the flavor. This beer is just plain delicious and ridiculously well balanced.

Rerate: Extremely dark brown- almost black with a suitably frothy off white head. Aroma is riddled with huge amounts of dark fruit: plum, fig, date, raisin, and pear complement some spicy, doughy, anglefood cake, and ethanol character. Flavor is sweet and slightly boozy- dark fruit pummels the palate again with caramel, molasses, grapes, and spicy fruitcake. Palate is rich, thick, and effervescent. This brew never ceases to wow me.
UPDATED: SEP 30, 2012 This pours a dark caramel colour with a white head but is surprisingly sweet and fruity.

aroma is subtle but very pleasant. Pours a dark chocolate brown with a hint of toffee coloration on the edges. Boisterous head, laced the edge of the glass as it dissipated. Flavor has elements of a typical english strong, but is so much more-- nuttiness, hint of caramel, fruity undertones. Great palate, sticks to the tongue, and is absurdly smooth for a 9% ABV beer. absolutely fantastic overall.

Pours a dark golden brown to jet black, non transparent, thin creamy bubbly head. Apricots, grapes, spice, yeast, alcohol, and golden raisins in the aroma. Flavor: Spiced fruit, caramel, and classic unibroue yeast flavor. Palate is smooth, thick, and creamy. Not theyre best, but good all the same.

Pours an amber color with a vanilla ice cream colored head. Fantastic pleasant aroma, smells very fruity. Flavor has slight spicy pear taste with just the right amount of malt. Palate has a slight tinge of vanilla. Overall, a great beer. My favorite Canadian beer!

Pours dark amber brown color with off white head.  Beautiful aroma:  plum, cherry, candied sugar, belgian yeast, rasin, breadiness, some spice, vinous notes.  Flavor reminds me of a fruit roll-up with yeast.  Slightly spicey, slightly sour, and the sweetness is not overpowering.  Maybe some chocolate coming through as well.  Palate is a little sticky with a fairly creamy body.  Has always been one of my go-to beers and its a wonder its taken me this long to rate it.

Purs dark brown.  Frothy head.  Aroma of dark cherries and raisins.  Has a vineous quality.  Taste is very complex  and well balanced.  Had it one day after Trappistes Rochfort 10, and it doesnt shrink in the comparison.  Exceptional beer.

DARK BEER WITH A SWEET TASTE   SMELLS OF FRUIT LIKE RASINS AND GOS DOWN WARMAND SMOOTH
THIS WAS A VERY GOOD BEER ONE OF THE BEST IVE HAD SO FAR

A beautiful, warm, dark, sweet beer. Appearance wise, its as dark as an imperial stout, almost. But this is betrayed by the taste, which is deinitely sweeter and mellower. Lots of aroma of plum and grape, sort of a delicate port tast. Like an esibock almost but more drinkable, less overwhelming. Theres some alcohol in this but you sure dont taste it. This is a wonderful "ice cream" of a beer, nice and thick and creamy. This is a new favorite of mine. Yum.
750 mL bottle - pours clear and dark brown with no head; banana and fruity aromas dominate; fruity flavor follows mixed in with some spice; drinks slightly creamy and relatively smooth

Currently drinking: The aroma seems to be of fruits such as apricot and plums...grape as well. The flavor iS quite powerful it tastes more vegetarian than like fruit which was a tragic mislead for myself. The mouth feel iS a nice tingle with warming alcohol that iS well hidden but the bitter lingering aftertaste of seemingly celery leaves me to give this a seemingly low ranking for this brew. Everybody has different tastes.

12 oz. bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Pours cloudy dark brown, like molasses. Aroma of banana and yeast. Mouthfeel is effervescent and light. Fruity taste. Just a tad bit of sourness at the end. This is excellent, and now Im glad I ponied up for a four-pack!

Bottle. Strong cherry aroma with a little spice and caramel, followed by the characteristic Unibroue yeast nose. Dark scarlet color, thick and foamy beige head that holds its form against the glass indefinitely. Fruit upfront, a little too sweet but followed by a spicy sourness that evens things out a bit. Still a little unbalanced, but good overall. Creamy palate with a little carbonation on the middle of the tongue.

Bottle. First of I opened the bottle and the beer spilt out for an inordinate length of time. So, off to a bad start there then!  Nose of cream, raisins, some alcohol and malt. Pours a murky dark brown beer with (once all the beer had finished spewing out the bottle) a small  brown head.  Mouthfeel is soft, medium body. Malty, bready, sweet with a small burn of alcohol.  Some cloying. Very much reminiscent of a belgian beer - since typed Ive noted  its classification - but not as well put together. All in all a not bad beer but the alcohol intrudes too much for me so I dont share such a high rating as others.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2008 Agree with some that this beer lacks some of the depth of the Belgian Quads, still, belgian yeast character is there as well as some perfumed plum and other dark fruit and a decent palate. Side by side with the LaTrappe, this tastes like a Belgian copy rather than the truth... geez, have I become so snobbish? Its a very good beer, maybe even in my top 10 or so on this continent.
Ive had this on draught and from the bottle. Hard to find anything bad to say about it. One of my all-time favorites. An excellent brew.

pours a dark reddish brown with foamy head. Smells of bubblegum and rootbeer. Mellow sweetness balanced by a some spicey hops and alcohol tingle. A well rounded beer with some really wonderful characteristics.

#100!  I discovered Unibroue through RateBeer, so decided to celebrate #100 with this delicious ale.  Red black pour, slight head.  Aroma of a Belgian Quad- raisin, vanilla, brown sugar, dark fruit- dried cherry.  Some biting carbonation at first, but it mellows as it warms in my goblet.  The taste is of sweet malt, alcohol, more raisin and fig.  Some dark rye at the finish.  Warm and mellow, substantial and delicious.

Cola colored with a light tan head. Spicy sweet, yeasty aroma. Med. body with a prickly mouthfeel. Great taste same as the aroma is spicy, yeasty, vinous, and sweet with ginger bread, cloves, and dark caramels. Has a tangy spice/alcohol taste to finish. Good stuff. 81105
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: This is by far the best beer I have tasted so far!  I could drink this all day.
12oz bottle. Smells of spice and nut. Very dark brown with full body. Larger sized head with smooth carbonation. Strong malt taste with semi-bitter aftertaste.

The aroma has notes of malty fruitiness and raisins, but also some acidic tangy lemon & orange. Mouthfeel is smooth and thick, but finish is drier than youd think. Taste shows acidity and small amounts of sweaty yeast.
Pours black with a white head.  Has a sweet fruity aroma with a flavor to match.  Extremely good overall.

Tasted this one after the triple fermented.  For a Belgian Strong, it holds up with rich European fruit flavors, but lacked a depth of taste.  Still, its one of the better of its kind, and Id drink it again in a heartbeat.

Aroma, just like the description says,
was of ripe fruits. Poured a dark brown with good sized head. High alcohol content is not noticable because of the complex flavor of dark fruits and spices. Great brew!!!

Let me start off by saying that I really dont like this paticular style of Belgian Ale too much, but this one is decent for the style. Aroma is dominated by figs and persimmons, followed by tangy smells with clove and cinnamon too. Hops smell like equal bit flowers and grapefruit but are far in the distance. Appearance is quite nice. Large creamy light brown head with some okay lacing and retenetion covers a very dark orange (nearly dark brown) murky body. Taste is bitter with a yeasty-near Celery finish, this is not my cup of tea, although I have only had one other BSA that tasted like that (cannot remember which one, but I rated it around the 10th of January). Texture and Palate are nothing special; watery mouthfeel and lively carbonation are the best discriptions. Very little port wine similarity for me.

Pours a dark brown with a smallish off white head.  Big, yeasty, sweet candy sugar aromas fill the air.  That typical Unibroue yeast is noticeable as expected.  Some nice spice characters in there too, maybe some nutmeg for sure.  The flavor is much the same.  The nutmeg really is apparent in the flavor with much of the yeast and Belgian candy sugar is evident as well.  Really drinks nice.  Maybe just a touch too sweet, but doesnt take away from the flavor too much.  Definitely one of their better offerings.

Pleasant fruity aroma, creamy head, dark brown.  Tastes of ripe dark fruit, warming alcohol, like an old port wine.
Very good when enjoyed slowly.

From a 750ml bottle . Best before 06/12/2010.. so a newer batch.
Nice enough looking ale, turbid dark brown with a lovely light tan , thick creamy head.
Very prominent yeasty aromas,, dark sugar,slight alcoholic aroma, i get raspberries too.
Taste is actually pretty tame compared to the aroma,typical belgian yeast and "spice, yet it is somehow subdued by a stronger  malt base, again I get warm alcohol., sweet at the end.
Palte to be hnest was pretty average.
This is a good beer, but IMO not the great beer which its percentile on here denotes.
I wonder if this one was too new, or that its gone downhill since Sapporo took over?

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2008 341 ml bottle. pours a rich mahogany with a medium tan head that quickly receeds but stays with you as you enjoy. aromas are dark fruit and yeast with some alcohol present. flavours : fantastic dark fruits dance across the palate and typical belgian yeastiness which makes this brew very enjoyable. slight metalic tinge kept this from having a 5 in palatability. im glad its now readily available where i live. a great beer.

Best before 01/21/2006. Im pretty sure they date for 3 years, so this is a 2003. In the glass its gorgeous. A deep purple with a strong tan head. Fruity aromas (apples, pears, grapes, plums) with tons of brown sugar and molasses notes. Very doughy as well. Rich and complex smell. When it hits your tongue, its immediately bubbly, with doughy, bready characters everywhere. Then, as you dig a little deeper into the taste, you notice the beautiful subtleties beneath - plums, dates, figs, raisins, brown sugar, wine, fresh apples. There is so much to taste in this beer, and not a sign of anything bad happening in its near future. I think the best by date is a joke - Id venture to say 10 years in the bottle and this beer could still be improving. What a great experience. Proof that in cellaring, patience pays off.

Bottle 33 cl (when I opened the botlle the beer gushed out of it and I lost about 10% of my beer, is this usual to all Unibroue beers?). Pours a murky brown with a small tan head and a slightly sweet and yeasty aroma. The flavor starts with a very short sour note and then becomes sweet caramelly. Lots ofripe fruits in the finish, a pretty good brew.
Pours a dark dark brown with a small tan head. Nice aroma of fruits and yeast. Good sweetness. Alcohol is well hidden. Good stuff.

Shared bottle from Total Wine in DE.
$6.49.
Went well with portabella sandwich.
Snuck in a bit of dark chocolate with last tasty sip
Pours dark brown with a white head. Aroma is very fruity with hints of Belgian yeast. Very yeasty flavor. Some darker malts give off some nice fruity flavors as well . Spicy too. Very wine like.
Fantastic beer.  Hints of heavy malt, wood, passion fruit, ginger.  Great finish.

Aroma is metallic for some reason.  Over ripe banana also.  Roasted flavor and almost no hops.  The thing I like about this beer is the alcohol quality to it.  It is stronger than most, but it gives it a kick that goes well with the fruit flavors of it.  The description is pretty accurate about the port qualities to this beer.  I look forward to trying more of the Unibroue beers since we can get them in my area pretty easily.

Rating 250, quarter of the way to beergod status.  12 oz. bottle poured into tumbler- poured semi-transparent very darken amber, tan head slowly bubbled away, light carbonation.  Aroma of yeast and a touch of sweetness (almost a lab quality sucrose).  Hits the mouth with a great medium body, fruits and sweetness dictate the tones, and kicks you in the mouth.  Very little, if any, hops can be noticed; alcohol not very noticeable at all.  If I had to choose one word to describe it, it would be UNDERRATED!
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 It was way under my expectations. It poured a dark, dark black but the head was small. It tasted a bit over processed for such a good brewery.

Brown color; big lingering light brown head.  Aroma of funky tropical fruit and malts.  Significant carbonation.  Rich malts, funky fruits, passion fruit, fig, wine/wood flavor, earth, alcohol, toffee, sweet malts, bitter and rough finish.  Not my favorite Unibrou but tasty and rich.

This is my standard drinking beer. I always have at least 1 bottle of it in my fridge. It pours foamy and dark, on the deep brown side, never as dark as Guiness. The aroma is fruit and smoke and malt. Mouth is cloves and fruits, bit of smoke and barley. Alcohol doesnt make itself felt, even if its 9%.
12oz bottle, part of a sample pack. Dark pour, with malty aroma. raisen mouth with hints of alcohol, clove and spice, remarkably smooth for 9%.
Bottle: Pours brown with a full thick head.  In my opinion, this is not beer.  It did not taste bad, but I am sick of the fruit taste.

12 oz. bottle from Plaza Liquors - Pours a fairly clear brown color with lighter edges and a one finger thick off white head.  Faint lacing.  Aroma is light yeast, big esters, and spice.  Flavor is much of the same.  Medium body.  A good beer.

Pours a clear brown, with a 1 1/2 finger cream colored head, that quickly disappeared. Very light lacing.  Aroma of yeast, roasted malt, and  esters. Flavors of spice, a light yeast, malts, and esters. A little bitter on the downslide. Over all a decent beer.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: Hazy brown with medium light brown head. Sweet aroma with overripe fruits, yeast and roasted malt. Flavor is quite sweet with notes of dates, prunes, roasted malt, liquerice and yeast. Very vinous and good balanced. Alcohol is warming and well hidden.
Pours dark brown with a nice foam. I like this a lot. High in alcohol but its  good balanced.

I dont know if it is "as dark as can be," but it pours a quite dark/opaque black/brown with a good-sized, off-white head.  Aroma is sweet and of alcohol, caramel, and sweet wine... like a port.  Reminds me of a Christian Brothers port I had two Christmases ago.  Flavor is of red grapes, caramel, alcohol, roasted malt, and apple.  

1 pt. 9.4 oz. bottle, caged and corked.

Pours a dark brown (nearly black) with a huge white head.  Nicely malty and smokey, with a plum flavor.  Real good rounded sweetness.  Remarkably balanced, a great balance of hop, malt and sweetness.  Relatively thin and with a markedly alcohol finish.  One of Unibroues best.
Dark in appearance. Aroma of sweet dark fruits. Plenty of carbonation hitting the palate. Smokey,malty, plum, banana flavors. Long lasting earthy aftertaste. Another great beer from Unibroue.
Excelente canadense. O aroma e o sabor se equiparam. Muito cravo, mel, malte, canela e frutado.

Bottle.  Pours a purple hued dark brown, thin lightly lacing head settles after a huge foamy head upon pouring.  Sweet rich fruity flavor with a hint of citric sourness.  Full creamy with a lingering sour note.
Excellent beer that holds tons of flavor. Easy to drink and not too rich. Sure beats the heck out of cyclone power 8.5

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 750ml Bottle, BBD 3-13-09, I stored this about one and half years, pours a hazy dark brown, you see some ruby hidden in there when held up to a light, a good foamy off-white and tan head sprung forth, this ale has lots of bubbles, very effervescent (when the cork was removed from the bottle, it spewed over with wet bubbles), nice foamy lacing left on the glass, aroma of raisins, plum, prune, candy sugar sweetness, dark bread, malt, faint chocolate and yeast, faint spices, faint fruity and spicy alcohol aromas emerged as it became room temperature, flavors of dark malt, bread, raisin and prune, molasses sweetness that tapers off quickly, some dark candy flavor that resembles horehound keeps popping up here and there, petite spices on the palate, has a fine pepper bitterness at the finish that leaves some sweet and fruit taste on the tongue, very little alcohol on the palate, just a calm warming around the edges, this never got sweeter as it warmed, the hops and alcohol kept it in good balance, mouth feel is lively, bubbly, pretty dry at the finish, a really nice drink.

Dark brown pour with fluffy white head.  Has a fruity wine smell to it.  Nice smooth, flavored mouthfeel.  No wonder I felt terrible on New Years day.  I must have had at least 6 different Unibroues and I dont think any of them are less than 9% ABV.
By far the best beer of the night. Very interesting taste loads going on in this beer. Would most certainly buy again soon.
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: APR 22, 2008 Poured a dark amber to dark brown with a medium amber head.  aroma of wine and nutmeg with taste of dark fruit, spice and roasted malt.  Had light to medium hop character.  The flavor hid the alcohol quite well.  I really appreciated the complexity of this beer.  I would buy again and and suggest it to anyone looking for a tasty brew.

750 ml bottle from Brvmo.Pours a dark brown with a frothy off-white head that recedes to 1/4 inch holds. The aroma is strong with plums, dates, raisins and a bit of spice. The flavor is that of a big Belgian with plenty of bold tastes,--I note  cloves, allspice, sugarcane, raisins and dates. The mouthfeel is smooth but not as full and creamy as the better Belgians. The finish is long and sweet. Overall: Nice, but just a bit too sweet for me. Recommended with reservations.
Bottle. Pours a translucent mahogany color with very little head, but lots of lacing. Aroma of citrus and ginger. Sharp, spicy, floral taste that ends almost like iron. Nice beer though.
D-lish yummy mmm-mmm taste! Nice light carbonation with a dark rich color and nut-fruit, yeasty flavor. Mmmmm put it in my tummy!!!1!1

355 ml->Trappist: Pours a small, off-white head onto a body that is dark brown and murky.  Heavy malt smell that is akin to molasses and/or caramel, lightly perfumed hops, and a tad yeasty in aroma.  There also is something sweetly decadent like brown sugar or maple syrup about the aroma.  Medium bodied, thick and alcoholic in consistency, and soft carbonation.  The finish is lightly sweet and is somewhat astringent.  All-in-all, a very good beer, but too heavy for my taste for any, except the coldest occanions.

Very dark (almost black) colour with a tan, foamy head. Faint malty aroma. Very pleasant raisiny taste with the suggestion of alchohol. Not as strong tasting as I expected. It reminded me of drinking a (good) fruitcake in some respects.

Bière noire, claire et brillante qui donne une mousse café au lait abondante et persistante. Superbe et appétissante.
