Arôme de fruits noirs : dattes, prunes, raisins secs. Il y a aussi des pointes de réglisse et de coriande. Le goût est très sucré, un peut trop. Cela contrebalance lalcool qui se fait discret malgré la teneure élevée. On reconnait aussi les levures Unibroue, quoique délicates dans ce brassin.
Le palais est bien rond, la bière est bien pétillante.
En résumé, cest une bière à déguster comme un dessert. 
Le sucre trop présent, et les saveurs qui ne sont pas suffisamment nuancées léloignent de peu de la perfection.
Very dark brown pour with a lasting white head. Very heavy carbonation. Aroma and flavor very yeasty. Flavor of cloves and spice. Very complex. Not at all my favorite style but a very good brew.

Dark brown color witha finger width white head that left a nice ring around the glass and spotty lacing. Plum, raison, red grapes, cloves, and fig were all noticed in the smell. Taste was of clove, plum, vanilla, candi sugar, spices, and yeast. Medium bodied with a good carbonation. Gets better as it warms and will try this one again.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2008 Dark black in color with a thick head the fizzles down quickly. Looks like a porter but much more carbonated. Flavor is yeasty, light chocolate and fruit undertones. The beer fizzes in your mouth. A good beer with many flavors to  entertain the palate.

Appears near black and barely translucent in appearance with cherry accents when put to light. Aroma of malt and pine with floral and berry undertones.  Flavour is of sweet dark fruits, yeasty, with some of the earthy tones in there. Very smooth, rich beer.  A pretty good beer, even if it is french/canadian.....
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: 1 to 1 and a half year old bottle, poured into its namesake glass (which I didnt know existed until I saw it for the first time at the store!).  Pours dark reddish brown, mostly clear until the very end where you get some particles, with a large fizzy beige head.  Aroma is vinous and malty, lots of plum and red wine notes, some toffee, and some slightly peppery gingery clove type of smell, which is the only way I can describe that Unibroue character.  Taste is a nice blend of toffee, toast, and cocoa malt flavors with a vinous red wine, grape and raisin flavor and an abundant spicy/sweet clove and cardamon note.  Finishes nothing like I remember the fresh beer, and is very similar to the year-old Chimay Blue I recently had.  Very nutty, hazelnut, with a faint chocolate and coffee note, while the spices take a bake seat.  Fizzy overcarbonated mouthfeel, but thats the name of the game with Unibroue.  Medium bodied, but still substantial, and only slightly warming.  Very good stuff, but it occupies a strange middle ground.  Its not as smooth as Chimay Blue, and yet the spicy notes arent as exciting as Pannepot.  Perhaps another would diminish the poky spice notes to a level that would make this beer really awesome.  As it is, its still excellent, and one year did it a world of good.

Bouteille brune de 331 ml. Nez dalcool présentant une belle touche fruitée. Robe brune aux reflets pourpres. Goût dominé par les fruits mûrs et des saveurs boisées. Arrière-goût dalcool. Il sagit dune bière unique en son genre parmi  les produits brassés au Québec.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2008 341ml bottle, from a much sought after six-pack (as Unibroue brews, this one in particular, are becoming increasingly more rare; thanks a lot beer store)(that was sarcasm)(the beer store kind of sucks, sorry). Appearance: Pours a really nice murky, dark red, almost black, with a large tan head. Aroma: Sweet candi sugar on top of ripe fruits, with the classic Unibroue yeast as the perfect background character. Taste: Surprisingly refreshing? Wow, thats different for a BSA! Nice yeast character of course, all the sweet elements combine to give it its complexity, very fruity, with decent bitterness (more than Maudite or other BSAs Ive had). The carbonation is perfect, providing just enough bite without distracting from the flavours. The aftertaste is sweet, sort of like a port wine I guess, but I wouldnt say its a defining feature of this fine brew. The aroma seems to get better as time goes on, and the mouth-fell is great, nice sticky malts. Weird, its actually almost mouth-watering. Totally not what I expected. I was expecting something dry, alcoholic, bitter, and roasty. What I get is something fruity, refreshing, lightER than I was thinking. But despite all that, I actually still really like this beer a lot. Id also like to say that the image of the church with the storm-cloudy horse in the sky is incredibly cool looking. I cant wait to try this again after its aged for a few years! EDIT: At room temperature and with the carbonation more settled, this stuff is at its best. This 1-year old bottle Im having at the moment is actually quite similar to a port wine, but with a VERY sharp spicy character to it. Gooooood stuff.....

I havent had the pleasure of being familiarized with the entire unibroue family, so far this one is my favorite, and one of my overall favorites, the best thing about it is the aroma, it is a collage of exotic ingredients, lingeing aftertaste, and nice full body

I am in love with this brewery.  Trois Pistoles isnt my favorite of theirs (currently Maudite or La Fin would probably win that title), but its fantastic.  Dark and bold. Quite complex, with a slight hint of blueberries, overall amazing.
This is excellent with dark-chocolate brownies.
Very good.  Nose was a bit simple, but taste was great.  Malty with fruit, caramel, maybe a bit of nut.  I drank it while watching ONe Flew over the Cuckoos nest.  I rate the movie 8/10.

UPDATED: AUG 6, 2016 rated 12/15/07 --- Unibroue has to be the finest brewery in the western hemisphere.  Trois Pistoles is one of their best offerings, a "belgian ale" with a full-bodied taste full of caramel and tart citrus.  Big taste going in, full mouth feel, and a clean lingering finish.  My first encounter was in Perce Quebec on tap for dinner in a seafood restaurant during an autumn storm.  It was a perfect restorative!  Re-rate 8/06/16 --- Aroma of malt and toffee. Opaque black, tan head that sinks to a full cover, thin stripes of lace.  Taste is full-bodied roasted malt that moves through strong carbonation to orange zest in a long finish.  Still a terrific brew, but not a 5.0 anymore.

Bottled 75cl. Dark brown color, with a nice and persistent beige head. Aroma is complex, sweety, hoppy, roasted malt and fruity. Flavor is fruity and sweety, notes of green grapefruit (White wine), cider, alcohol and some smooth chocolate. Mouthfeel is a quite bitter and dry.Português: Cerveja de cor marrom escura com uma espuma bege persistente, aroma complexo, adocicado, frutado, lupulado e malte torrado. Sabor doce e frutado com notas de uva verde (tipo vinho branco), cidra, álcool e um suave chocolate amargo. Retrogosto é um pouco amargo e seco.

This beer pours a weaker head that dissipates right away leaving a kind of sticky little lacing and head. It has dark to amber color tones. Smell of sweet candy and hops is strong, and its coupled with some breadiness and yeastiness. The smell has also plum, nutmeg and very strong clove. The taste has a vanilla undertone that I noticed right away and the taste also had plum, nutmeg, and clove. The first mouth feel is a little watery, but gets better as it warms. Its definitely intriguing and makes you want to have more.
Great aroma of berries, fruit, and spice.  Nice fruit flavor with roasted malt and dark sugar.  Warming alcohol and fruit on the finish with a lingering spice.

Ale forte noire/ Bière riche, corsée et veloutée, dominée par la richesse du malt/ Nez très malté aux effluves de chocolat, de mélasse et de rhum brun

La Trois Pistoles est une bière sur lie de la couleur obscure des ténèbres et dun goût très moelleux qui dégage un arôme de fruits mûrs et une longueur en bouche qui la compare à un vieux porto. Elle est brassée à partir dun malt bien torréfié et titre 9% dalcool.

pours a cloudy (bottle conditioned goodness!) brownish color.  fruity, berries to be exact.  has some nice spice and a good helping of malt to balance it out.  moderately complex, lots of fun to drink.  i think what i loved most about it was its complex nature without being too rich to finish the glass.  definite keeper!

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2008 The mouthfeel on this one was a bit off being slightly absent. Thin. The flavors seemed to wash away with the swallow and not linger. Slightly sweet beer with all types of berry fruitness. Molasses and brown sugar notes. Perfect carbonation.
75 cl bottle, from Ølkonsortiet in Aalborg. Dark brown  color, lovely brown head. Sweet, fruity and floral, dark fruit, malt, some bitterness. Very balanced.
Bottle: Poured a black with a thin light brown head. Aroma is soft berries and sugary. The taste is rich dark roasted malt. The finish is tingly and fruitish.

Strong overripe fruit aroma (strawberry, plum perhaps). Medium spritzy feel. Same fruit flavor, also brown sugar, candi sugar, yeast. Good but a whole bottle is too much; a glass would have been enough. Do people taste port? Not very port-like to me...
750ml bottle. Pours a deep red, Smells of dark fruits. Tastes of fruits and yeast and is a little tart. Liked this beer before but did not do it for me this time. Will not try again.

12oz bottle, cellared 6 months, fridge kept the entire time. Pours a gorgeous grape kool-aid colored body with ruby red edges and highlights. Topped by a 2 finger thick tan head the settles into a ring of everlasting foam. Spotty, soapy looking lacing as well. Nose of funky yeasts, candied sugar, dates, raisins, plums, apricots and some mild alcohol notes. Flavor is very similar, heavy dark fruits, malts, fusels, candied sugars and I guess what Port would taste like, but Ive never had the pleasure of trying it. Also the back of the swallow brings a nice array of spices into the mix. Dont really get a sense of any hops here. Creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied, lively carbonation. Finish is yeast, plums and figs, and then a lingering sweetness. Stays with you quite a long time, begging you back for another taste. Alcohol is noticeable but not jarring, very warming and comforting. Excellent.
Tasty! Velvety mouthfeel, tastes of figs, dates, dark sugars, some spicy yeast notes. Sweet aroma. Brown with white head.
Brownish hue. aroma a bit of a perfume smell. Tastes of mild dried fruits. Alcohol is hidden very well.

UPDATED: AUG 14, 2008 Bottle at home ... Deep brown ... sweet fruity yeasty very typical belgian hop ... rich sweet ripe fruity plums and cherry ... definite port tones ... good depth and rich alcohol... TK2 bottle at home ... deep brown ... yeast and dark fruit nose ... deep fruit ... little bready ... deep rich dark fruits ... ITs going lovely with Fins home made Chorizo.  Cheers Fin for the Sausage

12oz bottle- pours a cloudy ruby color with a fairly thick head. Fruit notes on the aroma and a definite yeast presence on the palate. Taste raisins in the flavor. Still smooth and cannot taste the alcohol at all. Easy to drink and pretty good overall. Another good Unibroue for me.

Bottle. Pours a great dark brown beautiful creamy head. Aroma is fruit and yeast. Flavor, has much to be desired, a first sip reveals a unidentifiable flavor that just doesnt belong. After your taste buds acclimatize to it, the beer is ok, but it takes almost the whole beer. Palate is medium, aftertaste is ok. Not trying this again.

Bottle. Aroma of sweet fruit, like a port. Thin quick dissipating head, cloudy brew, dirty ruby brown colour. Weird initial flavour, smooth texture of the fruit. Its sweet but then it mutates into a satisfying bitterness. Once you think you know where you are it changes back to this subdued smooth sweet fruit flavour. I like this beer. Its a bit like the misss, I just dont know where  I am with her but I go back for more and I like it.
Suntan lotion. In fact if anyone wants this stuff hit me up - I have 3 bottles up for trade. Really didnt care for this at all other than it had nice color.

Served from a Growler Fill.
Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  Smell is wine like with lots of dark fruits.  Plums, grapes, its all in there.  Taste is much the same, with some belgian candy sugar.  Mouthfeel is creamy velvet.  This is an easy drinker.  There are definite port like qualitites with it.

This beer reminded me of suntan lotion that got spilled into a budwiser. Had a very strong coconut taste that was a total turn-off. Maybe Ill try this one again down the road to see if my tastes have changed.

Poured from a bottle into a tulip glass. Color was dark brown with a smell of fruit, like cherries, and raisins. Could get a raisin taste, with sugar and the belgain spices. I would agree with the description of this being like a port wine.

Sweet raisin aroma. Brown pour with a thick and tight tan head. Medium to full body and tastefully sweet. It is rather complex  with flavors that seem familiar but are uncommon in most beers. There are discernible apple, strawberry, and clove notes and possibly molasses. Decent lemon grass finish. It doesnt resemble a wine and the alcohol content is a nicely kept secret. Very well crafted and unique.

Bottle conditioned and from the Beer Store. Very dark pour into a Chimay glass, with an off-white head. Very fruity aroma. In the flavour I taste sour cherry, vanilla ice cream, dried fruit, figgy pudding and brown sugar. Finished with the signature unibroue yeasty aftertaste. Alcohol is very well hidden.

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2012 Havent had this in an age, but my wife brought home a bottle today. Lovely, dark, lively pour with a substantial head and considerable fruity aroma. Nice and tart, dark fruits blended with a dash of citrus and esters. Malt is there amongst the plum and fig, along with some hops for body and liveliness. Nice and warming, and admirably distinct from some of Unibroues other offerings.

Pours out dark red, black this a thick white head. Very nice dark fruit, wheat aroma. Nice carbonation. Taste is yeasty, dark fruit, raisin, and wine. Finishes with a nice tang of alcohol as if an after dinner drink. Very nice.

0.34 l bottle. Dark reddish brown color with tan head. Tart fruity aroma with raisins, plum, cocoa, vanilla, clove, pepper and coriander. Sweetish, vinous, raisiny, nutty and bready flavor with notes of vanilla, plum and cocoa. Warming palate. Very pleasant.

This I feel is the best brew from Unibroue.  Its true to the genre of Belgian Dark strong ales -- malty with hints of dark fruit and brown sugar or molasas  and a nice ABV content at 9% will get ya there.  Not as good as Chimay Blue or Grand Reserve, nonetheless a very nice beer.
UPDATED: MAR 22, 2008 a good belgian, dark and fruity with a nice sweetness, lot of bananas and light body. deep purpley brown. Very nice.
A fruity aroma filled the room when I poured this beer.  It is redish brown with a tan thin head. Clean thin taste with a deep fruit flavor and a nice hoppy after taste.

Wining & Dining Tasting. Pours a hazy brown with a small head. Very sweet with a light bitterenss. Aromas of dark fruits - prunes and dates. Quite heavy alcohol aromas. Full bodied. Medium fizzy carboantion. Long dry finish.

A good Belgian strong from Unibroue, but I think this one is a bit over-rated by my fellow reviewers.  There are better Belgians out there.  Pours a beautiful deep brown with a thin tannish head.  Aroma is filled with fruity spiciness and works well with the strong malty body.  A good beer, not a great one, in my opinion, compared to others that are out there.  Unibroue never disappoints.

I love the Maudite but this one should be Unibroues forerunner.  Its a magnificent Belgian that is near black in color with a lovely abundant off white head.  The fruityness is greatly complimented by its roasted caramel malt presence.  Its a Belgian Strong in an almost porter like outfit.

WOW. I do not understand these low three ratings!!! Had on draft at Brews in Granville. Dark brown with nice creamy head. Smelled of sweet malts and fruit. Taste was molases, caramel, malts, plums, raisins, even a hint of black licorice, followed with some cinnamon or some spicey finish...VERY delightful Belgian.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a dark cola color with reddish hues and a quickly dissipating and very minimal light tan head.  Aroma is of dark malt, dark fruit, grass and alcohol notes.  Taste is of rich roasted malts and subtle grassy hops with dark fruits and notes of brown sugar.  Medium to heavy bodied and smooth with low carbonation.   Ending is of molasses and spice with a slight alcohol burn.
Very Dark amber with a thick white head.  A lot of dark sweet malt and some spicy chocolat.  Very good.
Strong aroma of a variety of fruits, and incrediby complex, although many flavors come thorugh distinctly. Alcohol present but not overwhelming. My favorite brew from this company.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2007 341ml bottle. 
Pours almost black with amber/brown highlights and a ghostly white head. Aroma of fresh fruits. Plums and raisins as well as some malts and molasses. Thin mouthfeel with biting carbonation.  The flavour is of fruit and spices and maybe with a very mild bitter spicy finish. Not bad but not really my style.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2007 Pours deep caramel brown with a fluffy tan head. Great aroma of malt, caramel, raisins, sugar. Flavor is quite complex with dried fruit, molasses, brown sugar, and an alcohol burn. After letting warm for a few, it opens up and actually gets sweeter, with crystalized sugar and caramel, a touch of cola, with a subtle bitterness in the finish. Pretty good brew.
UPDATED: APR 1, 2008 Fantastic beer.  Pours deep brwon.  Tan head dissipates.  Smells of caramel.  Nice mouthfeel with tastes of plum, blueberry and clove.  Finishes bittersweet.

(33 cl bottle from Systembolaget) Particle filled dark red color with a tan head. Spicy, yeasty sweet alcohol scent. Spritzy, sweet, spicy taste with a metallic aftertaste. Spritzy mouthfeel. Low bittereness.

Bottle. Near black color with amber edges. Off white big bubbled head. Smells like cola with hints of vanilla, fruit and roast and a belgian character, maybe some root beer. Flavor is unique, hard to describe. Its sweet but not real malty. Hops are subdued and alcohol is apparrent but not overwhelming; warming but ot hot or harsh. Medium to full bodied. Different and pretty good.
8/23/05. 12oz. best by Oct. 2007. Hazy brown with small off white head. Sharp yeasty and sweet malt aroma. Thin with little flavor.

Very distinct presence of alcohol both in the aroma and the taste.  The alcohol is not overwhelming, simply noticeable.  No real head to speak of on this beer, but the carbonation seems to be slightly higher than what Im used to with these belgian strongs.  I am picking up pretty well on a spicy flavor that is complemented by the presence of dark fruits.  I like this beer, and I recommend it to anybody wanting to try a fairly unique but good beer.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text: UPDATED: DEC 21, 2007 One of the best Unibroue beers. A supremely well-crafted, rich yet not heavy, deep dark delight. Cant say enough good things about this tasty morsel. Pours opaque  with big head. Aromatic and yeasty. Fruity and slightly alcoholic.

Wow!  This one is fantastic...
The beer pours with a spicy, yeasty, sweet aroma with a creamy light head.  The beer is dark in colour, brown and red.  The flavour is... a very smooth fruity sweetness, with a tad of maltiness - lots of different flavours in there that seem to drift in as you sip it.  Very mellow, and delicate.   This one is one of the very best for certain...

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 Bottle from a 4 pack from either Johns Grocery (Iowa City, IA) or Binnys (Orland Park, IL). I cant remember. Poured into a tulip Unibroue glass. Pours a nice brown with also some deep dark red colors. Head coca-cola-esque and comes on fiercely and then subsides. Great aroma that leaves notes of berries and spice. Initial taste is wonderful. Smooth soothing fruity feel (dried fruits at that!). Malt is apparent and a decent carbonation is as well. Alcohol seems well hidden in the taste, but the warming sensation is apparent pretty quickly. Slides down like silk and leaves a very mellow aftertaste. Nothing harsh about it. A favorite of mine (And I dont say that lightly) and in the tops of the top in its category.
very fruity, berry aroma. Great smell. Incredibly deep brown color. Flavor is fruity and oaky, very sweet. Great, unique beer.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 Wow, what an aroma.  Ripe berries. Raspberry.  Some alcohol.  Deep brown, whitish head.  Flavor is awesome. Very light and fruity as well. Lots of creaminess.  Full mouthfeel. Great beer.

Dark, deep brown pour with a bubbly, fleeting light orange head.  Huge aroma that is the selling point on this one for me.  Flavor matches up with the noise very well, lots of sweet cherry, oranges, and a hint of sweet maple?  Syrupy but not viscous, if that makes sense.  Loads of carbonation that is backed up pretty well by the malt.  Finishes well, with mostly sugar that lingers.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2008  Bottle, Ive been impressed with all of Unibroues product, and the reviews and ratings are pretty accurate. Trois is sweet port like beer that has a complex malty taste. It is not my fave, but still a top beer. Drinking it up!

Bottled(330ml). -Brownish/ruby coloured, pale brown head, spicy fruity nose. Nice lace with lots of small bubbles on the glass. Roasted malt and spicy aroma with notes of dried fruits, yeast and cinnamon. Great beer. This was my fifth Unibroue, and I simply like them all.

Dark reddish brown with thin head. Nose of grilled plums, dates and figs. Taste is raisin with some nice sweet malt characters. I wish it were colder outside, cuz this was a perfect fall evening beverage.

Pours with a monstrous head that settled to a light but lasting rim. Dark brown almost ripe plum color. Raisiny sweet nose. Malty intro with light carbonation and pleasant alcohol in the finish. Sweetness marked by raisins and/or dates are noticeable from beginning to end. Well-balanced beer that would be great as a winter warmer.

This bomber poured dark burgandy whith a thin white head that goes quickly to lace Aromas of grapes, dates, (yes this smells like port )yeasts, and some light florals (herbs) Clean and crisp mouthfeel  almost sprity Tastes of grapes and sweet malts with an alcohol warmth to it  Nice balanced Belgian
12 ounce bottle purchased at ABC LIquors Pembroke Pines, FL $2.80 Clove taste.
You need to like a strong beer for this one. Great malty tatse with a slight bite. Some what of a fruity flavor. Liked it.

Pours a brown color with a light tan head.  Aroma is of lemon, banana, dark fruits, caramel, and some alcohol.  Slightly light on the palate.  Flavor is of lemon, banana, dark fruits, slight nuttiness, spices, and a decent alcohol warming on the finish.  Very delicious brew.

Bottle from BOE  This bottle opened with a Krakatoa like urgency and found me desperately wanting in an effort to get some into the glass as a large slick of brown liquid and off white head covered my work top.  The remainder of this beer that found its way into my glass was very dark, almost mahogany in colour with an off white head some molasses were present in the aroma as was alcohol. I found the taste to be on the rough side, definate port flavours but alcohol forever evident it mellowed over time but this really wasnt my thing (Loz loved it) I seem to be going somewhat against the grain here, but I can only be honest, I was a bit disappointed, its a rough beer.

A great after dinner beer, with port like quality.  Deep brown pour with off-white fluffy head.  Nose is that of dark fruit and covers alcohol very well.  Taste is complex with plum, hazel nut, caramel and yeast, amongst other unknown flavors.  Interesting mouth feel that is more and more pleasant as the beer warms.  A very nice beer overall!
WOW! dominant Licorice or was it Plum? either way i was not at all impressed by this so called "Port wine like."

Bottle into pint glass, purchased at Frugal McDougals, Nashville.  Fizzy pour with bready yeasty smell spilling all over the place; large fizzy fluffy head, clear nut brown in the glass.  Smells like Rochefort 12 plus sour apple plus lime plus CO2 plus orange peel plus cardamom plus Squirt; theres lots going on, but none of it packs much of a punch.  Light bodied for 9%.  Flat and nutty in the mouth, with thin grape flavors and sour dough bread.  Odd that its so warming on such a thin body; reminds me of a British mild in feel.  Breadiness comes out in the middle, expansive: nice texture.  Lime plays on the tongue in the finish.  This would go well with Hint-of-Lime Tostitos.  Sticky foamy lace on the side.
dark brown appearance with strong white head.  flavor is a wonderful dubble but the end somewhat lacks the alcoholic depth that would take it to the next level.  very nice overall

I find most of the Unibroue line too sweet, but this beer has a really mellow with a rich ripe fruit taste. Reminicent of an after dinner cordial.

Dangerous in the 750 size, consider buying the 4 pack on 12oz. You might not end up drinking them all in one sitting.

dark red/brown in colour with big fluffy white head. bi caramel apple aroma. Spicey peppermint flavours, big body, crisp finish.
Very pleasant drop obtained on Wellingon road trip.
750 ml, 341 ml, QUELLE BIÈRE !!! noire avec des touches de violet, longue en bouche, chaleureuse,

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2015 A fantastic brew the only thing holding it back was the price!! At $8 a bottle it was more expensive than most belgians. Still the port like flavor is exceptional and it gets better as it warms up..If only it wasnt dominated by the damn house yeast!!!

330ml
Aromas reminiscent of sparkling shiraz, 
yeasty, carmel and slight roasty flavours, from a deeep dark brown pour. A pleasure

Tasted from 341ml bottle in a chalice glass. 
Deep brown pour with little head subsiding quickly. From first taste the lingering taste of caramel flavours, and a modest amount of spice. There is enough flavour to hide the alcohol.

Wonderful beer.
An intense taste which takes you by suprise, quite thick and sweet, had quite a buzz after i finished this one
75cl bottle.  I will definitely try his beer again.  Very well produced.  Poured a hazy dark brown colour.  The aroma and flavour are ripe with spicy fruit and floral notes.  Great beer.

draft. dark almost purplish pour. very small thin head. dark fruit and alohol aroma. coating mouthfeel with a slight medicinal character. touch of raison and plum sweetness and fairly rich. alcohol was definately there and warming. nice well balanced belgian style ale.
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.
Very dark, and very tasty. Fruity almost grape leaf taste and I like the bubbly sensation it makes on the tongue.

From bottle :  A deep dark brown pour with a big beautiful white creamy head.  The head leaves very nice lacing, so that by the end of the beer you have a wonderful design on the sides of your glass.  Nose is complex like with many great belgian style ales.  It has Sweet malts, little hint of alcohol, and plenty of dark fruity aromas, i can detect plums, apples, grapes, and more.  Palate is thin to medium bodied, creamy and smooth as silk.  Taste has some sweet malts and the same array of fruits that was found in the aroma.  Alcohol is somewhat present in the taste, but not overbearing or overnoticable, it is hidden farely well.  It has very lively carbonation.   A excellent Belgian Style Ale.

Very dark reddish brown with a bubbly tan head. Nice retention and a bit of lacing. Ample carbonation with some dark fruit in the aroma and a tart plummy overtone. The malt underbelly is nutty with some sweetness and a warming finish that creeps up. This beer hides its alchohol content well, drinking very smoothly. The sprightly carbonation tickles the tastebuds, receding into a lightly sweet brown sugar finish. This is, as they say, all that and a can of beans.

Strong aroma of anise on this one, which doesnt bode well for me, as I hate anise.  Very dark brown in appearance, almost opaque, with just some light peeking through the edges of the glass.  A thin white head, and some sediment are visible in the glass.  Flavor is of dark fruits, just a hint of anise.  Fairly long slightly sweet finish.  Not a bad beer, but not something Ill pick up on my own.
Very dark brown with quickly disappearing head, fresh clean aroma. very smooth.  High alcohol content was suprisingly hidden. Black licorice flavor great malt. No nasty aftertaste.  Im impressed.
It had a very dark body with disappearing head, very strong, but the alcohol was masked beautifully.

UPDATED: NOV 8, 2007 Dark pour with a bit of head. Fruity aroma with roasted malts and a finish of hops. Every aspect commonly associated with  beer was present in the flavor. I was impressed with how much flavor existed in this beer.

Rerate for bottle: even better served just below room temperature. It really brings out all the flavors.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2008 341 ml bottle poured into large vase glass. Dark chesnut color. A beer novice might think its a soda by the look. Not much head and dissipates quickly. Caramel tones, can sense the roastiness for sure. Then the fullness hits, more dark but not overpowering flavor. Fruit, dark berry and roasted nutty flavor toward the end. The 9% alcohol was well subdued, unlike the New Belgium Trippel for instance. Excellent beer.
Reddish color with a quickly rising and falling head.  Smell is fruity and very inviting.  Some alcholic bite with a nice taste.

Dark brown with fine large & lasting creamy white head & good lacings. Aroma of sweet malts, alcohol & dark fruits. Sweet earthy, dusty & aged taste. Again dark fruits like prunes and raisins & a bit of sugar. Very soft & smooth carbonation. filling body. Nice!

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2009 Bottle. Pours dark brown with a good head that quickly dies. A strong taste; a fruity aroma and taste with a strong alcohol bite, and a nice mix of hops and a burnt malt. Lots of yeast, and some alcohol warmth. Great drink. Reasonably priced, and an awesome label. A real go to beer.

Pours a dark dark brown with a nice head. Aroma has yeast and dark fruits with some nuts in there. The flavor is wonderful... licorice, dark malts, yeast and dates with some hints of chocolate and malts that bleed through. Actually, it tastes like root beer in many ways. This is a great beer... Ill be drinking this again.

Big yellowish brown head. Opaque dark brown body. Sugary yeasty fruity aroma with bready soft metal notes and a touch of herbal licorice. Full, sweet herbal licorice taste with bready, yeasty notes. Somewhat earthy. Chocolatey notes. Strong alcohol heat. Dry brown sugar aftertaste. This is really good, especially as it warms up. (0.33l bottle at Cardinal, Stavanger.)

Black with a huge head that goes the distance. Malty smell. Alittle on the sweet side, malty dusty flavor. Tastes better than other sweet Belgian strong ales. Carbonation is rather smooth but boring. Id drink it again.

Brown bottle, 341 ml, purchased in Trois-Pistoles, savoured in the Trois-Pistoles	 trappist glass on September 18 2007; eye: dark mahogany, hazy, good effervescence - you can hear it crick, crack, crock like Rice Crispies, nice creamy beige head that disappears a bit too quickly, no lacing; nose: rich odours, a mix of caramelized malt, of alcohol warmth, of candied fruits, of freshness, of Belgian yeast, of spices; mouth: velvety, smooth, caramelized malt, nice hops that stands to the malt, but then dances with it so that the malt and hops each come to the forefront, small dark berries, a bit of tobacco, the yeast is present throughout the sip, the alcohol only appears as faint pepper, oh yes, I forgot the spices and its fruitiness, long finale in caramelized malt and yeast with an enjoyable hint of bitterness, nice balance between all of the flavours, lightly sweet, mildly bitter, medium to full body, average carbonation; overall: really good

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 341 ml, achetée à Trois-Pistoles, savourée dans le calice Trois-Pistoles le 18 septembre 2007; il : acajou foncé, voilée, très bonne effervescence - on lentend pétiller comme des Rice Crispies, belle mousse beige crémeuse qui disparaît un peu trop rapidement pour moi, pas de dentelle; nez : riches odeurs, mélange de malt caramélisé, de chaleur dalcool, de fruits confits, de fraîcheur, de levure belge, dépices; bouche : velouté, doux, malt caramélisé, beau houblon qui « accote » bien le malt, puis qui danse avec le houblon où tour à tour ils séchangent lavant-scène, petits fruits confits, un peu de tabac, la levure est présente pendant presque toute la gorgée, lalcool napparaît que sous une petite présence de poivre, ah oui, joubliais quil y a un bon bouquet dépices, on trouve aussi un côté fruité, longue finale en malt caramélisé et en levure avec une agréable petite pointe damertume, belle équilibre entre toutes les saveurs, légèrement sucrée, moyennement amère, corps moyen-corsé, carbonatation moyenne; en résumé : très bonne

Aroma is rich with hints of fruit and a mild roasted scent. Color is a deep almost black amber with very good carbonation and beautiful tight tan head.  Taste is sweet and clean.  Starting with a medium body that has a much lighter mouth feel then you would expect.  It goes down with a creamy feel that leads you into a finish that is a sweet malt flavor with a very mild roasted taste and a nice Belgian yeast fruit flavor.  Its not as rich and bold as I was expecting it to be but it is a very tasty brew.

This may have been the most wonderful beer I have encountered yet.  Purchased at Shores Inn, SCS, MI.  Poured from bottle.  Very dark brown color with a very light brown head.  Smells of floral and fruits, and same for the tastes.  Very light yet lasting fruity flavor on the palate makes this beer desirable, and the almost unnoticeable taste of alcohol for such a high content is a major plus.  Just wonderful.
It is a very good beer. The hops and boquet hit you nicely - very floral. Its a little malty, but still very good.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2011 A great beer. Strong flavor but not overpowering, the alcohol is barely noticeable. Aroma and flavor dominated by plums and mellow wine flavor. Not as complex as some other beers of this strength. Sweet finish.
cool art, cool name, high alcohol content.  give it a shot, definitely not my favorite beer ever, but still pretty good.  i would not rush out to buy again, but wouldnt shy away from it either.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2013 Pour from a 12 Oz Bottle. 5 years old. Aroma is dominated by and old nuttiness, lightly dusty caramels and sweet vapor. Pours of ruddied mahogany, soapy lightly in off-white. Flavor behaves similarly aged, with sherried, oxidized yeast. Theres unique and peculiar spice musk and dried fruit, but everything is very muddled and mixed. Finishes a nip sticky. 9/9/2007. 7/3/7/3/15


12oz Bottle, November 2013. This was much more exciting than I remember. Its a very stand up dark Belgian Strong, in my opinion, full of great dark fruits and nice toasted malts, complimented by a subdued and enjoyable Belgian yeast. Alcohol well integrated. Compared to the Maudite, this was a much more interesting specimen.
Nice dark pour. Excellent and complex aroma. The flavor is incredibly smooth. Excellent aftertaste. I could drink this like candy.

Pours a dark clear amber brown with minimal head. Nose almost seems like clay really. With a touch of cherry tones. Very sweet edge too. The taste. Slightly complex. After several seconds a thick smoky flavor kicks in. Starts off with a thick fruity edge, somewhat cherry really. Feel is thick but bubbly. Hits me like I want my Belgians to. Damn good brew. Very drinkable.
Great dark brown/black beer, large head, smell and taste was really wonderfull, smell of dark fruit and no sign of alcohol for a 9% beer, very nice beer I will have again

The aroma has a wonderful fragrance which reminds one of the autumn.  It has a smell reminiscent of fallen leaves and damp earth.  This reddish brown ale has a hazy appearance that prevents you from looking through your beer glass.  This is definitely a full bodied beer that is not for the uninitiated.  It has a nice creamy texture and lively carbonation due it being bottle conditioned.  The finish of this beer will last well after youve emptied your glass, which for this reviewer is a good thing.

this was the beer that first introduced me to the dark fruity belgian flavors ive come to love. lots of dark fruit, some cocoa, with a little bit of yeasty spice in the finish. no signs of the 9% alcohol either. deserves to be right up there with that authentic belgian offerings.

330 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal pub, Stavanger. Dark brown beer with a huge beige head. Very fine and complex aroma with vinous notes, also notes of oak, spices, cocoa, red berries and dark fruits, hints of barnyard and tobacco. The flavour is sweet, vinous and fruity, quite smooth for 9% ABV beer. Moderate hops. Many of the elements of the aroma stay with you through the flavour and aftertaste. An excellent beer!

Pours from the 750 ml bottle a dark gold brown with a colorful tan and white head. Aroma of yeast, fruits, and gunpowder. (Just kidding!) Minimal tornado shaped lacing, and a medium body. Flavor is distinctly Unibrouey, yeasty and fruity; this almost tastes like cherries. Slightly bitter and alcohol finish. The three pistols must be referring to the fact that this is so strong that you need two friends to share it with!
Pours very nice, with a little foam. Settles very nice and smells great. The taste is phenomenal with a fruity aftertaste

Pours a reddish brown when held to light with a slight frothy head that continues to develop through the pour of the 750ml. Nose of Unibroue yeast, berries, molasses, alcohol.  Medium full body, bitterness towards a vinous finish, yeast tart,cloves, some raisin, plum; like most Unibroues, the champagny yeast comes through quite strongly.  Probably their best beer.

Bottle.Poured with a huge head and soooo dark, looked inviting from the get go. Very bubbly. Nice fruity aroma with a lively smooth mouth feel, then a tart finish. Malts and fruits predominate. A wonderful brew...Maudite is my favorite but this is tasty. I love there work. no kidding

From bottle marked 11-08-09.  Consumed on 9/1/07.  Pours a dark, slightly cloudy raisin color.  A big head quickly dissipates, leaving only a thin skin of off-white foam on the surface.  Above-average, lively lacing keeps minimal head constantly replenished.  Nose is fruity and sweet, full of malt character.  Slightly thicker-than-water mouthfeel marked by a noticeable astringency (almost a  pleasant burning).  Goes down smoothly.  Flavors of raisin/figs/dates and malt (as in the nose) mingle on the palate with a bit of vinous acidity.  Sweet, but not overwhelmingly so with hints of spice (cinnamon?).  Clean finish with fruity aftertaste is both agreeable and short-lived.

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2008 Date: 03/28/1998
Mode: Bottle
Source: total beverage, DC

Appearance: hazy dark amber, big tan head, 
Aroma: rich malt aroma, 
Flavor: strong malt flavor, high carbonation, warming, but not alcoholic (9%), low bitterness, one dimensional
-------- />
Date: 05/29/2002

Appearance: rusty brown, scant head, 
Aroma: rich malt aroma of figs and dates, 
Flavor: very rich malt flavor, lots of rich fruit essence, just a hint of bitterness on the back of the tongue
-------- />
Date: 01/19/2005

lots of good rich fruity aroma and flavor, 
-------- />
Date: 07/09/2008
Mode: bottle
Source: brick store

Appearance: hazy dark red, fine beige head, 
Aroma: sweet dark caramel aroma with lots of rich ripe dark fruits including figs and plums, 
Body: light body, 
Flavor: rich malt flavor, nice dark fruit character, hint of chocolate, sweetness comes out of the dark caramel, light bitterness with a peppery edge, 
Overall: needs less attenuation to bring in more depth of character

Aroma: 7/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 5/10; Overall: 14/20
Rating: 3.5/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **4
An OK ale.  A little sweet for my palate.  Sweet malts for the nose and taste.  Some dark fruits as well.  Good mouth feel as well.
Pours a dark brown with a lasting tan head. Has no lacing. Hints of sweet dark fruits, caramel, spices, and cinnamon. Finishes semi-sweet with some spice on the tongue.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 Pours maple with a slight brandy tint. Little head leaves slight lacing, and with very little carbonation. Smells of sweet grape wine, and slight sweet malts. Has a slender port taste that is well accompanied by a dimly lit wheat/yeast finish. Reedy spice is also extant.
It poured a dark brown, with a tan head. Some lacing. It had hints of fruits, cloves, figs, and spices. Finishes with a warm spicy feeling on the tongue.
Bottle. Pours dark brown with a porous head. Aroma of apple and overripe pear. Taste has prunes, yeast, a bit of alcohol warmth and some apple. Fruity finish.

Dark plum brown with a decent, long lasting beige head. Aroma of dark fruits, aged barrels and yeast. Vinous mouth feel with flavours of more dark fruit, spice and coffee. A long, bitter finish. Excellent.

tastes of aged port. looks a good bit darker. alcohol a bit strong/harsh.  plum, and easy on the clove and coriander. probably more grapey with raisin than cherryish. spicey touch of cinnamon and pepper. smooth with a nice touch o vanilla in the finish. gotta age one and re-rate. the alcohol taste is off -too perfumey-.
Oh_hell_yeah.  Whats better than an amazing Belgian Strong?  A BLACK Belgian Strong.  Well, not black, but dark like the night.  So awesome.

Pours a opaque dark brown colour witha  medium off white head. Aroma is metallica, heavy clove, floral and spicy. Initial taste is heavy cloves that fizzes along the mouth and dark fruit. Finishing with a clove palate and bitter hops. Spicy ending. Palate has a great duration. Great head retention and some lacing of the glass. Very nice.

Oww, twist cap, surprising. Thick hazy dark brown with off white foamy head. Mild malty clove & spice aroma. Nice, smells like the holidays. Mellow, honey notes give way to heavy all spice and clove flavor. big spice big warmth in the chest. Notes of dark fruit, interesting, flavor attack of the palate.Spicy, then fruity then spicy again but outstanding through out.
a big fruity and oaky aroma. Dark, with a bit violent head. Very complex, lingering carbonation, oaky, berries, smooth and very nice. A very nice north american belgian

750 ml bottle.  Very thick head.  Incredibly dark brown color that is soil-like in its darkness.  Strong yeasty and fruity aroma but even more intense hoppy and fruit flavors in the taste.  Smooth finish and nice palate.  Certainlybetter in a tulip glass than my trappist glass.  Also, like desert wine, better in small quantities and with food.

Pours a beef stock brown with a thin creamy beige head that has good retention. Aroma of fruit and raisins, notes of caramel. Lots of flavours on a velvety smooth palate, malty caramel sweetness, lots of fruit flavours, plums being the most distinct. Pretty damn tasty, certainly one of the better belgian ales Ive had.
Bottle. Dark brew with tan stiff head. smells of caramel and dark fruit. Taste is very complex, there is malt, caramel, fruit, and even a hint of oak. Very nice.
Bottle.  Pours a dark color with a white head that quickly dissipates.  Tea-like aroma.  Full flavor with a hint of cinnamon?  A good belgian style ale.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Poured from a bottle.  Poured a deep brown color, similar to cola, topped with a nice tan head.  Fruity/yeasty aroma that is very enticing.  Opens with an excellent sweet taste that gives way to plum flavors that taste delicious with just the right amount of carbonation.  Thick mouthfeel adds to the beauty of this one.

Pours a dark brown with a tan head.  Has some magenta highlights.  Aroma is amazing with ripe plum, apricot as well as a perfumy, rose-like note.  The taste reflects the nose with the addition of dark caramel.  Finishes dry.  Excellent.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with lots of head and carbonation.  Aroma is divine - smells rather wheaty and yeasty, kind of like Unibroues Maudite.  Flavour is wonderful - again it feels somewhat like a weizenbock.  Delicious stuff, with a bit of fruitiness creeping in.  Maudite is a regular beverage in my fridge, but this one hasnt been.  Id like to taste them side by side to compare as I feel there are some similarities.

Poured deep brown to black with NICE head. Mouthfeel is slightly more carbonated than I would like. Taste was also rich and a nice balance of Belgian sweet without overdoing it. A nice brew I wouldnt hesitate to recommend. Heck, even my Dad liked it!
Tasted 2007-04-25. 2 years old, 35,5 cl. Dark, dense brown colour with off white head. Aroma of caramel, yeast, burned sugar and some acidic notes. Ditto taste. Lovely! It ages well!

LIke a doppelbock to me, so immediate love set in.  You cant really look any better than this, thick lush head sitting on top of a  dark dark brown brew.  Dough and plum aroma, a bit sharp too.  Palate is sour, sweet, creamy, a tiny bit thin during one part of it, then it comes in with the sweet and alc-ish part.  Now Im intrigued enough to seek out a few more of their products.

this beer has a nice aroma of apples and mild malt. It also has a dark bron color to it but the head retention is not that great. as you drink it there is a mild hoppy taste but it does not stick around for long. the more you drink it the more apple mainly green apple and hopps you taste. It is like drinking a granny smith apple mixed with allspice and hops that is the main flavor.

Pours a hazy brown with a frothy, quickly fading tan head and effervescent carbonation. The aroma is candied orange peel, sweet malt, and a host of ripe fruits. The flavour was figs, raisins, plums, port, apricot, that typical bubblegum yeast ester, carmel malt,  bourbon cask, and maybe cardamom or peppercorn. The taste was very complex, but not overwhelming. This beer has a very reasonable drinkability for its complexity. Its tingly medium-bodied makes it mellow and easy to drink. Another knock out brew by Unibroue.

355 ml, bb 02 22 10. Dark brown-black with a medium, lasting head. Aroma of bubblegum, yeast, and peppercorns. Flavor is all spicy bubblegum; maybe some licorice, slight dark fruit and alcohol. Palate is medium bodied, and tingly. Good, but not really a very complex flavor profile. I like malty beers, but this one seems sweet in mostly the wrong ways - dominating taste of spicy bubblegum overpowers anything else that might be there. Many better Belgians out there. Overrated.

750 mL bottle from Jovi, served at cellar temp in a tulip glass. JL28/07.
App.:  Deep brown-copper, clear, frothy tan head.
  
Aroma:  Yeast and lots of dried fruits  raisins, figs, prunes; brown sugar and molasses, cherries; wood and alcohol, apricots; nice and rich!
  
Palate:  Medium-full body, soft effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Some yeast, lots of dried fruits, brown sugar, some alcohol, a little woody.

Nice!

Bottle conditioned, 330ml at Take 1, Maastricht. Black brown with cream head. Heavy, full, alcoholic sipper with burnt, caramalised character. The body becomes fruity with touches of raisin and sultanas, but it takes some drinking, its not a quaffer for the pub and I struggled with it. I understand its charms, but it was not totally for me.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Flaske. En blanding af en rating på 33 cl og 75 cl. Desværre var den lille flaske al for kold og havde ikke opnået den samme kompleksitet som den store flasek, ellers havde det været ne højere rating. Rigtig flot mørk farve med et udemærket skum. Lækker smag af nødder og en anelse alkohol, perfekt afbalanceret. Super øl.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2011 Beautiful black brown pour with swirling hypnotizing action. Gunk on the bottom of this unfiltered brew. Attractive off sweetish aroma, but clean and fresh. Ooooh, this stuff is smooth yet powerful. Really numbs up the taste buds with pleasure. You would never think of it as 10%, this is more like the flavor that was as low as 6%.  Smooth and sly, sneaks the alky into you as if was a wheat or dunkleweizen. I bought this thinking it was wheat, well now I see its a strong ale. Medium to strong whisky and fruit background. Or is that wine soaked plums or bing cherries? Good creamy carbonation for a low level tingle. Finish is strangely middle of the tongue associated with  alky bitter bite, it  hangs for a while. Not impressed.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Finally entering all my "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07 results.  Nose was a lot of yeast, banana, raisin, plum, and vanilla.  Nice mahogony color with off white head.  Flavor was a lot of spicyness, and plum.  Med body.

750 ml bottle.  Very complex.  Aromas of bananas, raisins, yeast, grapes, apricot and  liquorice.   Lively carbonation on the palate with a spicy sweetness.  Tremendous aftertaste that lingers well after you swallow.  Alcohol is well hidden although it makes itself known after you are done with the 750.  Highly recommended Belgian strong ale out of Canada.  Would drink again and again....

Dark color and a nice head, that is quickly disappearing. The aroma has notes of yeast, sweetness and spice. The mouthfeel is nice and full. You are not in doubt: Its a strong beer, but the alcohol is well hidden. The flavour has sweetness and notes of yeast, spice, ripe, dark fruits (plum, figs), caramel and a nice bitterness that lasts throughout the long finish, in which fruity notes pop up once a while. A nice and complex beer.

UPDATED: JUN 14, 2009 old rating:
4/3/4/2/8 - 2.1

pours a maroon with a huge beige head, lots of little bubbles, and good lacing.

smells of grapes, dark pitted fruit, some yeast, cocoa, and malt.

taste is fizzy, prunes, raisins, malt, cocoa powder, and a few hops in the back, ends dry and a little bitter.
12oz bottle. Pours deep brown in color with full foamy lite brown head. Aroma of fruits and yeasty. Taste is fruity, yeasty and sweet with dry finish.

From the bottle.  Aroma is fruity with phenolics, candy, caramel, dried fruit and alcohol.  Appearance is very dark with a well-retained off-white head.  Flavor is a wide blend of alcohol, malt, caramel, various esters, bubblegum and no hop bittering.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with med/high carb strength but no carb bite.  Slightly warm.  Overall, a very complex and interesting beer.  Still, just not that in love with all the ester influence.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2008 Initial rating, 7-28-2007:

Strong, salty, sharp, spicy aroma that is more like that of an abbey tripel or a saison than that of a dark Belgian ale; smells like a more pale-colored beer than it is. Lemon and orange scents as well as a hint of cherry. Alcohol smell noticeable but not overpowering.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with a tan to amber hue. Some suspended particulate in the liquid. Moderate to large amount of dark beige head. Looks like a cola.

Very sweet, sugary taste. Pitted fruit (plum, cherry), fruity chocolate, and spice flavors. Alcohol noticeable in the taste. While it smells like a light-colored Belgian ale, it certainly tastes like the dark-colored Belgian-style ale that it is. Relatively dry finish.

Herbal aftertaste. Medium to heavy body. Oily, fizzy, frothy, and lively in the palate. Easy to drink for such a high alcohol brew.

Honestly, there is a lower quality character to Unibroue Trois Pistoles than I expected given how highly rated it is. Usually, even if I dont share the common opinion on a highly regarded brew, I understand why people like it so much. Thats not the case with this beer. Its okay, but I have trouble finding the appeal. Poured from a 12 oz. bottle.

7:3:6:4:14  3.4

Re-rate, 2-29-08:

Im re-rating Trois Pistoles as part of Re-Rate Day (February 29, 2008). This beer did not impress me much the first time around, so I figured Id give it another chance. This 12 oz. bottle comes from the same four-pack as the bottle from which I derived my initial rating. I poured it into a Unibroue Maudite glass. Yeasty aroma features apple, bubblegum, Mike and Ike candy, grape juice, lemon, and curry scents. Pours a clear, dark brown, almost a deep purple. Burgundy hue. Thin beige head. Short-lasting lacing. Sweet flavors of candy, fruitcake, and root beer-flavored sucking candy. The finish possesses a sharp tartness and a dry, cola-like taste. The flavors fall broadly within those that one would expect from a strong, dark Belgian Ale, but a weird and not particularly good one. Medium body. Fizzy, oily, and lively in the palate; soda-like. The palate sensations are not pleasant. Unfortunately, Im even less impressed now than I was the first time around. Trois Pistoles is an interesting beer, but not a good one.

7:4:5:2:11  2.9

Im going to average the two ratings to come up with the official score:

7:4:6:3:12  3.2

A dark crimson/amber pour with a pleasant foamy head that reduces nicely to a light coating on the top.  Fruit and alcohol upon the taste with lots of sweetness of raisin and brown sugar.  Somewhat fizzy on the tounge.  The 9% alcohol is very well hidden.  Would be a very nice drink to enjoy around an evening outdoor fire.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2009 My 3rd try from this brewery and favorite from Unibroue. Very complex aroma, taste and finish, with a diverse mix of plums, grapes, apricots and other fruits. Warming alcohol feel but not burning with a tart aftertaste. Excellently designed, premier Belgian that is very unique.

Pours a dark red color with a small soapy head. Smells of liquorice and fruits. Tastes like brandy. Kind of has a bubblegum taste with lots of yeast. Not crazy about this one because it is bitter when it should be sweet.

Pours a dark brown, almost black color wih a small tan head.  Aroma is rich, trademark Unibroue yeasty with dark fruits lingering in the background.  Nice malty character, abundance of dates and raisins.  Medium body makes this an easily drinkable, Belgian style ale.

This is definitely one of my favorite beers. Very unique taste. Pours a dark ruby color, not very thick, with a light head that dissipates fairly quickly. Smells and tastes of raisins and grapes with a hint of banana. Sweet not bitter.Alcohol well hidden...great bottle as well by the way... bonne biere quebecoise

Deep dark brown with gentle but persistant  head, ample lacing. Fruits-banana, cherry, apricots, wheat and yeast are all apparent on the nose as well as quiet spice aromas.  Quite rounded and fruity to taste, both sugary and syrupy yet bouyed by a mysterious hoppy presence.  An intriguing, complex beer, and one that masks the high abv well; conisdering the only aspect of the alcohol is faint whispers on the nose and in the warming in the back of the mouth. This beer makes me feel like someone from the middle ages (1200-1330) for some bizarre reason.......  A meaty motuhfeel, almost brothy, but it works quite well.  A fine beer!
Not bad.  Complex, but for whatever reason, it just wasnt my thing.  Ill try it again with a better context, but until then...not so great.

my favorite of all the unibroue beers. very strong but not overdone. a very different taste almost like carrot to me, but no one ive talked to seems to agree. a nice sweet taste and a very good smell. smells better then it tastes to me. good still
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Dark and mysterious. Has that Belgian ale aroma going for it. Tastewise, its the same. Strong, and sweet with some banana and bubblegum. Very complex, damn good.

Poured a dark brown almost coke like color with a thick tan head that didnt stop. The aroma was complex of dark fruits, spices, caramel, and a hint of alcohol. The flavor follwed with a nice blend of fruits, spices, and malts. It had a slight vinous quality to it as well. It was a good full mouthfeel and a little creamy. You could taste the alcohol a little, but it wasnt bad. It was different for this style, but it was good and worth trying.
UPDATED: JAN 2, 2008 i had heard about this stuff through some friends.  i thought id try it out and its actually a very good, thick, hearty beer.

Its true, this is similar to Port.  The thing is thoug if I wanted to drink Port, I woud do just that.  I want my beer to taste more like beer.  This is too sweet for my taste.  It is complex and a good beer, just not my thing.

Pours a dark brown color with a nice white head.  Even the aroma in this beer is complex, as i noticed numerous fruit and spice notes with each smell.  The taste is a balance of fruit, spices, citrus, coriander, and it even has some characteristics of a nice dessert wine.  The alcohol is noticeable but does not take away from what is overall a superior offering.

A Sim rate (bottle at Quinns): One of the most complex aromas I have ever smelled. First things that jump out are coconut and blueberry. Definite orange, brown sugar, caramel and a slight (though not unpleasant) alcohol. DAMN! The aroma is intoxicating enough on its own. The flavour is similar with even more coconut. Corriander. Red wine. Not quite as good as the aroma and the alcohol hit is a bit too fierce, but still lovely. Tingly on the tongue and down the throat. Fine, fine ale.
Pours dark tan with lots of bubbles. light head that completly disapates.  This has a nutty/ roasted malt flavor almost like a cola. perfect sweet/bitter ratio.

A very good beer. Strong aromas of cloves and over-ripe fruit. Notes of cinnamon papaya, dried fruit, raisins, and brown sugar. Complex and balanced. A little heavy--lacks the elegance of the classic trappists (Westvleteren and Rochefort).

330ml bottle, courtesy of the Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam. Pours a chocolate brown, with lively carbonation and a large tan head at first. The aroma is caramel and spices and the flavour is a wonderful mix of berries, fruit, raisins and liquorice. The palate is full and slight creamy and the strength is apparent but held in check. Overall, a cracking Trappist beer. It may not be in the same class as Westvleteren, but few things are. This is excellent beer and I was gutted I only had a single bottle to enjoy!

Poured from a bomber.  One of the first craft brews Ive tasted and worth the $7.99.  Dark brown in color, a bit of red in the light.  Malts, spice, fruits, and very complex aroma.  Flavor is equally as fruity but not as pronouced as in the nose.  Subtle hints of ripe fruit, meshed in the intense malt and yeast.  Mouthfeel is a bit too strong in the alchohol burn dept.  One of only a few downers.  Easily overlooked as the rest is so enjoyable.

Bottle. Pours deep mahagony with glints of translucent tan color. Aroma is holiday spices, ripe bannana and dampness. Flavor is mellow and vinious. Throughout is damp, earthy yeast flavors. Sweetish caramel malt flavors are the backdrop for all of this. Finish is alcohol and carbonation. Thick and carbonated palate. Prickly alcohol sensation as it warms.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2007 Bomber:  Reminiscent of Chimay Blue in body and bite.  So at least the style is dead on.  Ive never had anything sub par from these guys.  Pours an Earthy brown with a mellow consistently regenerating head.  Nose is of a recently mown orchard....grassy with the nose of dropped fruit on the tires.  Mouth is champagne zingy with some spice and fruit. Finish is rasins and dried apricots.  9% is noticable and present but not overpowering.  Powertool use is Ill advised.  Farm equipment use is forbidden.  This beer was nearly too much for me.  After it warmed a bit in the glass it the "Bigness seemed tor grow."  I suppose it may have been the 9% ganging up on me, yet there was something that made me cap half the bomber and put it in the fridge for a rainer day.

750 ml bottle shared with rebelbeerguy. Poured a dark brown with red highlights and a large off white head. There was some visible sediment floating around in this one. Aroma was yeasty and sweet with notes of dark fruit, raisins and brwon sugar. Flavor was slightly weaker then the aroma but sweet and had a nice mouthfeel about it from the lively carbonation which reminded me of champagne. Very nice beer but I still prefer Maudite.
355 ml bottle.  Pours a hazy dull brown with a short lived tan head.  Figs, plum and spice in the nose.  Medium body, complex multi-layered flavors dissolve into a nice crisp lingering finish.

Poured from bottle....very dark and cloudy (I love that) with a ringing of reddish brown...the head starts huge but fades to nothing almost immediately.  The aroma is very heaving with fruit and spice, very pleasing.  The taste starts out sweet...and finishes quick.  The flavors are very complex. Nice creamy mouth feel.  The memory will be of a sweet beer...
xxx very very good brew.  Unibroue is great.  This had a nice head, a nice taste, it was just good all around.
12oz bottle Poured very dark with a foamy brown head.  Aroma is very sweet.  The flavor is pretty typical of a Belgian quad with flavors of dark fruit and dark sugar.  Not my favorite.

12oz bottle.  Pours black with cherry highlights.  A foamy head forms and disappears immediately.  Aroma is cough syrup, sweet malts, and that Belgian smell that is present in all Unibroue beers.  Not a really good smell, honestly.  Taste is much better.  Tastes like a Belgian quad.  Sugary, dark fruits, raisin.  Nice and thick and smooth.  Not the most drinkable beer but one of the better from this company.

This beer has superb flavor, and it improved dramatically as it warmed.  The mouthfeel was too thin for my liking, and the aroma did absolutely nothing for me.  Tastes great though and would probably be a nice one to have in the middle of February when Spring is still a little too far away.

Yet another dark pouring Belgian from Unibroue. How these Canadians manage to produce such lovely Belgians still amazes me. I got a bottle of these to re-taste so I could rate it more accurately. The head pours off-white and laces nicely. I noticed molasses as I was pouring, which intensified as I nosed the beer. There is a fair bit of raisin and plum flavor that culminates with a rich, sweet drizzle of molasses. There is a definite creaminess to the mouth feel.

Bottle.  Poured a very dark purplish-brown color with a very, very thick, off-white head.  Sweet plum aroma to it.  Nice mouthfeel.  Flavor was sweet with a yeasty flavor to it.  A little too yeasty for me.  It was okay, although I dont see what all the fuss is a-boot.

Bottle. Pours dark, almost impenetrable brown with a decent sized off-white head. Dark candied fruits and some nice spice dominate the aroma. Fairly rich on the palate. Decent flavor profile: raisins, fruitcake, plum, yeast and a hint of alcohol. is this really deserving of a 4.02? This is good.... but a 4? Really?

Bottle. Im wary because I am not thrilled about beers trying to be wine but here goes...Originally looks black but really is a very dark ruby red with a thick off-white head. Smell is very noticeable they definitely got the ripe fruit part down - a masterful mix of orange grapefruit and raisins and sweetened with honey. Taste is sweet starts off like candy - mostly mollasses, anise, same fruit concoction and light spiciness is noticeable which is refreshing. Vanilla is in there too! Mouthfeel is pleasantly creamy. I can see how it can be compared to a wine but it definitely has its own sweet thing going on. An excellent beer!

dark maroon brownn with a small lasting tan head. some dark fruit, roast wood and coriander in the aroma. medium body with active crisp bubbles. alcohol is apparent in the taste with coriander, earth, and almost a hint of grapefruit. good and well balanced but i feel its a little overrated and nothing that special

Bottle, 33 cl. Pours murky reddish brown, with a creamy and stable small beige head. Roasted malt aroma with dried fruits, some woody and earthy notes, some spices and yeast, and a clear but not overwhelming touch of alcohol. Medium bodied, quite smooth but with a lively carbonation. Nicely balanced with a light sweetness lingering.

Very dark beer. Lots of dark fruits and spices in the nose. The head is small and thick. The flavor is that of dark fruits, wines, and alcohol. The carbonation is bubbly, and the mouthfeel is smooth and creamy. Alcohol is definitely present with the warmth after its swallowed.. Finish is fruits and hoppy bitterness. A very good beer.

Appearance: dark brown with reddish touches. Medium head, beige color and persistent.
Aroma: sweet, malty, spicy, winy, candy, notes of vanilla and honey. Touches of ripe fruit, aniseed and cloves. Complex.
Flavor: Very complex and delicious. Sweet like of vintage wine, candy, fruity with touches of ripe fruit and sourness of orange. Spicy of clove, aniseed and coriander. Malty, liquory and a few yeasty. 
Palate: Medium carbonation. Medium body with silky and viscous texture.
A great beer, wonderful.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a cloudy brown with small cream-colored head.  Has a sour malty aroma which was pleasant.  Very bubbly mouth feel.  The malt comes through nicely along with a slight puckering citrus flavor.  Has some hints of rock candy as well which helps it come together to mask the mild alcohol burn on the finish.  Good beer.

Bottle. 12 fl. oz. Very dark garnet color with thin, off white head. Sweet, malty aroma of figs, apricots, and spice. Soft mouthfeel with little carbonation and a dry finish.  Flavor is malty sweet with a tart, cherry ending. Alcohol is well hidden but still provides some warmth. Very good.

UPDATED: JUL 2, 2011 Pours very dark cloudy reddish-brown, tons of tan froth.  Deep spiced fruit aroma, lighter-than-expected taste.  Summery spice, fruity, and lots of caramel.  Medium body and a bit fizzy.

pours very dark brown, almost black. scents are strong malts and fruits. flavor is malty, with the fruits showing up in the lingering aftertaste. goes down smooth for its abv. a very nice belgian style ale.
Rich brown.  Light fruit aroma. Fruity taste. Smooth. Slightly creamy.  Bringing glass to mouth aroma is slightly pungent.  Taste fades well, but not the best taste.  Too fruity for me.

Aroma is fruity, very malty, and has hints of marzipan. Colour is black with some dark amber at the edges. Cream-coloured, fluffy, lasting head with nice lacing. Flavour is dominated by lots of malt and strong molasses, with hints of dates and raisins. Very smooth, On the thicker end of medium body with a good bit of carbonation. Wonderful beer.

Bottle. High creamy white lasting head. Hazy dark red / brown body. Sweet and fruity aroma with hints of caramel. Sweet caramel malt flavor. Not much bitterness. Low carbonation. Short aftertaste. High alcohol percentage well hidden and not too dominant.
Looks dark.  Wow.....wasnt expecting that.  Smells like sweet fruit and bread, and tastes the same.  Very effervescent.  Maybe my favorite from Unibroue.
Hints of Chocolate, cherries, caramel and tobacco. This one of my top Trappist beers!
Sampled at Mondial de la Biere. Nice heavy beer, but not overpowering. Tasted dark chocolate and cherries. Great one to sip on a cooler night.

Jungle Jims Second Spring Beer Fest
5/12/2007:  Unibroue Trois Pistoles has to be one of my favorite (and one of the best) Unibroue brews...  Dark brown/amber in color with an lasting, foamy, beige-colored head.  The flavor and aroma contain dark fruits, sweet caramel malts, and some interlaced spiciness (clove?).  This beer also tastes strong, but the alcohol is not outwardly distinguishable in the overall flavored.  This beer is very well-balanced overall and has a smooth, medium palate with a generous level of carbonation without being going over the line.  Trois Pistoles is a very tasty beer that is quite versatile and a must-try for all beer aficionados!

Sampled from a 750 ml corked and caged bottle (9% ABV).
Wow... Pours dark brown with average head.  Sweet dark fruit, light fruit, roasted malt aroma, more fruits etc.  Flavor was great - the fruit is not overpowering and balances nicely with the malt.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2009 750 as pictured.  Pours a root beer color with a very transient active head.  Sweet fruity caramel aroma, slight cherry, raisin, plum.  Carbonated, kind of intense, but really good.  Best non-Belgian Belgian Ive had so far.

UPDATED: SEP 22, 2007 Bottle. Dark amber coloration, with a beige head, not so consistent and persistent, but very nice. Complex and well balanced aroma and palate. Lightly floral and fruity, maybe red fruits (I feel notes of blackberry). High carbonation; however, it does not harm the set.

Had in a 12oz bottle. Pours a dark brown with a reddish tint. Fluffly smooth white head that presses high. Lots of carbonation that you can hear. Massive amount of fuit on the nose. Cheries, fig, rasins, dates, sugar, roast, and slight alchol. Rolls smooth on the palate with the carbonation disipating. Taste of fruit and carmel. Littleheat but no alchol taste. Lingering taste of cherries and roasted malt.
Oscura, de gran cuerpo, sabor amargo bastante interesante , algo fuerte, proveniente de los mejores frutos y granos canadienses. Una excelente cerveza.

750ml. Bottle
$7.49

Trois Pistoles poured dark dark mahogany into a snifter. When I hold it to the light there is a tremendous amount of big carbonation bubbles quickly rising to the 2 finger frothy antiqued white head. The head eventually falls to 1 finger and then much later to a cap. Its one of those beers that just looks packed with all sorts of deep flavors.

The smell is really nice. Starts with bread dough and a spicy yeast aroma. That is the backbone but there are many other aromas that compliment each other very nicely. Lots of fruit including plums and bing cherries along with remnants of brandy. There is a big layer of caramel sweetness as well. Very rich and deep.

The malts come strong with each sip including the sweet fruitness. Doughiness and caramel set the stage for the plum, cherries and possibly some black raspberries. Wonderful fruitiness. This is all intemingled with a spiciness from the yeast and a sprinkling of wite pepper. As it warms the alcohol comes through by warming my throat.

Mouthfeel is excellent. Prickly carbonation but in no way offensive. Coating medium body that allows the entire mouth the pleasure of this excellent brew.

Drinkability is really high on this one. Really easy going down because of the body and carbonation. The abv is nearly non-existent except for the warmth in the throat that is perfect for this time of year.

This is a really well made and enjoyable beer. I really try and sip these slowly when I have them but they taste so good and go down so easy its tough. Trois Pistoles is one I go back to over and over.

12/24/06

bottle shared with friend.  aroma was of deep fruit flavors with some raisin and plum in there with a hint of clove?.  Poured very dark, darker than all other abbey-type (I say its abbey-type even though its not marketed that way) ales like this.  flavor was quite deep and complex.  lots of nice malty notes that contained raisin and plum, along with some mellow spice, and a note of nutmeg.  palate was lively and mouth filling.  a nice belgian style

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2007 First taste 5/23/07.  Semi-cloudy dark brown caramel color.  Moderate off-white head that quickly fades.  Aromas are malty with a hint of dark cherries.  Flavors follow along those same lines.  Palate is very unique.  There is a welcoming fizz on the tongue, with a clean finish.  Very nice offerring.  This might be my favorite from Unibroue.  Strong recommendation.

Brown wood colour. Excellent appearance with good white head. At first lot of bubbles that dissapear slowly. Aroma is fruity.. dark fruits. Taste is sweet. Bready malts  and apricot, melon notes. Good body and a little too much carbonatation... Bitterness is perfect.

Nutty brown/black appearance, not entirely opaque.  Aroma is of dark fruits.  Flavor is deep sweet malts and mellow fruits.  Lots of carbonation, bubbly in the mouth and light on the palate.  A nice belgian strong, better than fin du monde in my humble opinion.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2007 Dark color with ruby tints. Rich aroma of sweet fruit, maybe like plum. Effervescent palate with a very smooth finish. The sweet malty flavor manages to smother the 9% alcohol.

Pours a deep, opaque brown with a thick and rich head. Aroma is nice, unusual, very fruity, more like that of a cider. Very pleasing flavor has strong pear overtones, is mostly malty with some smoky hints.

Bottle. Cloudy dark brown.  Average head lingering lace.  Carbonation tough to see from the outside but clearly there from the bubble pools rising to the top.  Raisin, plum, and apricot smell with a hint of potent hops toward the end.  Very bubbly evervescent palate, also thick feel.  Sweet flavor containing apricots, plum and bananna, like a fruit shake with alcohol included - think sangria.  Tasty.  A bit of hops but it does not compete with the fruity mix.  Sweet and potent.  Another great representation from the group in Quebec.
From bottle pours dark amber almost brown with lots of off-white head.  Nice strong flavor with a pleasant lingering aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy very dark brown with ruby highlights and a large light tan head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of dark dry fruit, yeast spice, and a small amount of roasted malt. Taste is dark fruit and cherries with hints of caramel and roasted malt. Medium full mouthfeel with good carbonation and a mild bitterness. Another wonderfull brew from Unibroue.

Sampled on tap @ the Houston Flying Saucer, served in a tulip glass.  Very dark reddish brown pour, scant light tan head that quickly faded.  Nose is complex  notes of tobacco, pungent cherries, and moderate earthiness.  As it warms the alcohol becomes more present.  Palate is smooth, maybe a bit chewy.  Carbonation is light.  Hints of ripe cherries and Belgian spiciness dominate the flavor.  This beer has a very wine-like finish.  Another nicely done beer from Unibroue.

Bottle from Some Pizza Joint in South Beach - if I could remember the name of the place I would rate it - nice beer selection of Unibroue and other Belgian and UK labels - I cant believe I found one from Unibroue that I like better then La Fin Du Monde - as some said earlier that chewy come to mind - spicy and full - great finish

A fizzy and dark ale.
Aroma of dark, dried fruit, alcohol and the signature unibroue yeast.
The flavour is of raisins, plums and date. the alcohols is not very well-hidden, but the burned malt and the bitter end somewhat makes up for it.
I dont really know if I got a bad bottle, but this beer seems to be surfing on a hype...

12oz bottle, Brickskeller.  Pours a dark brown color; fluffy, off-white head with brilliant lacing.  Yeasty, doughy, and light coriander aroma.  Medium-to-full mouthfeel: plenty of yeast, chewy vanilla esters, and doughy character; dense, chewy belgian core; some spice and white pepper.  Lengthy, yeasty and marshmallow finish.

750mL bottle. pours a dark brown almost orange color with a thick head that laced very nicely. the aroma was a a melting pot of fruits and the taste is malty with hints of cinnamon. not the best from unibroue but still a very good strong ale.
Dark brown with white head. Fruity.. a decent Belgian style brew, but not up to par with some of the trappist brews.

Rated 1/28/06:  Wow, what can I say to best sum up the overall experience of this remarkable brew. Got it in a 750 ml bottle (which I will be keeping for my home brew). Poured into a wine glass a very dark reddish purple with a big foamy head that soon diminished. I allowed this one to warm up a little before sampling. The aroma consisted of sweet fruits perhaps grapes, cherries, and maybe even plums. Finally it was time to try a taste and the flavors bursted inside of my mouth. This dark ale is very unigue in that it drinks like a beer, but finishes almost like a red wine. Good carbonation and rather smooth to drink, I enjoyed sipping on this for a good while. The strong alcohol content is masked by all of the complex flavors in this beer. Wonderful experience, not an everyday selection but worth the price for a long cold night.

750ml bottle, $7.59.  Aroma is fruity with notes of orange, plum, prune, cherry, ruby port, and cola.  Average sized, off-white, foamy head that is mostly lasting but left no lace.  Murky dark brown body.  Flavor is moderately sweet and acidic with a short finish.  Palate is medium bodied with a creamy texture and fizzy carbonation.  Very good brew even though Im not a fan of the style.  The aroma and flavor is of dried fruit, cola, and young port.
Lots of stuff going on in this one.  Nice fruit that stays with you for a little bit.  Dark brown almost black color with a clean white head.  I have a hard time beleiving its from Canada.
Dark brown with aggressive head that slowly tempered.  Really enjoyed this Unibroue brew.  Great flavor...dark fruits.  Truly enjoyed.

Another great beer from Unibroue.   This was actually my first from them but I didnt rate it then.  
It has a wonderfully complex taste, lots of fruits and some hop/malt as well.
The first time I had this it was from a 750ml bottle but this time I got the 12 oz. bottles.  My first impression was that it was excellent but something was missing that kept it from being a truly great beer and I get the same feeling this time.  Im not sure what, but whatever it is La Terrible has it.  Unfortunately its a damn seasonal so I have to wait a while for that one again.....
On draft at Zenos, Penn State.  Poured beautiful mahogany that left a little lacing.  Lots of complex fruity flavor:  plums, apples, pears.  Very tasty.

Man, Im kinda bummed about this one. I think I didnt let it warm up enough before I drank it because I was disappointed with it based on the reviews I have read here. I had high expectations. I had an amazing experience with Unibroues La Fin Du Monde recently and was hoping for a repeat with this one. It wasnt there. Again, perhaps I should try the 750ml instead of the 12oz bottle capped. Nonetheless, the aroma offered up a sharp, distinct black licorice smell up front. Followed by some lesser bubble-gum, banana and maple notes. The yeast is present in the aroma as well, a little earthy. Root beer brown with small head. Bubbly, with a slightly hoppy/bitter bite at the end. Next time Im doing it right with the 750ml at about 55-60 degrees. I look forward to a re-rate with this one....in the mean time, pass me a La Fin Du Monde!

Hazy dark brown with big fluffy, short lized white head.  Aroma of apple, pear, cherry, and caramel.  Tastes of dark malt and grapes transitioning to a brief bitter dark chocolate taste and finishing with a sweet, yeasty taste.
Amazing brew, one of my favorites to enjoy after a nice meal, defenitly the best offering unibroue has to offer.

Bottle. The yeast stands out most in this beer. Heavy aromas of earth and basement (cobwebs?) with notes of grass and straw, and port, clove and maple syrup in the background.
