Its got a lasting head that is off white and fully lasting. Color is a clear, rootbeer brown. Taste is sweet  and midly sour and salty. Palate is a medium oily/creamy with a fizzy carbonation and an alcoholic finish. Not a big fan of the Three Pistols.

Deep rich brownish red color.  First pour into a pint glass (I know) gave an exploding 2" head that wouldnt die,  I had to drink my way through it.  Poured the second half of the bottle 4 hours later into a wine glass, with little head.  Its got a faint plastic smell a little similar to Judgement day,  Hmmm, I wonder if it is a hint of corriander?  no wait, banana, thats it.  The head is thick and creamy, with excellent lacing.  The flavor is too light and needs some sweetness, which makes it an excellent beer to pair with food.  Should i give it a 16 or 17?  Hmmm

UPDATED: JAN 19, 2008 Pours dark deep rosewood, with deep garnet highlights. Mocha head that disolves down to a film very quickly. Aroma has a complex play between spicy yeast, caramel malts, liquorice, and dark fruit.. mainly plum and raisin. In the back is a faint chocolate. There is also  something I cant quite place... almost a cotton-candy and bubblegum mix. As it warms up it starts to reveal its alcohol... like a rum soaked raisin. That rum-raisin carries over into the mouth with other fruit, sherry, and caramel. Somewhere in the begining is a quick dash of cocoa-powder... keep your tongue on it or youll quickly miss it. Big spice, and liquorice come in towards the end, then the caramel sweeps back in to finish it off. It seems to finish too quickly, leaving you to want more. That in turn makes you quickly take another sip. Easy drinking, but as it warms up it lets you know its strength. Overall quite a nice beer, but perhaps a little too overly confident.
I cant hide the fact that I am absolutely in love with this canadian offering.  i often debate whether or not it is my favorite beer.

Pours brown with small to medium light tan head.  Nose is spicy yeast and cream.  Flavor is dates, banana, allspice - rather like a dunkelweisen, but much stronger, and very sweet.  Long, lingering, spicy aftertaste.  Nummers.

Very dark brown with a big head. Fruity aroma and a sweet fruity taste. Alcohol is well hidden until the beer warms and then it hits you like a ton of bricks. Its very easy to put away several of these but I would recommend against it if youre driving.

Really wanted to try this beer for a long time. It did not disappoint. Truly wonderful beer, on of the best Ive ever tried. Aromas of dark fruits and sweet flavours in the mouth. I have several bottles in my cellar, and cant wait to try this again in 5 years!

Bottle from Beer Bistro.  Pours a very dark brown with a thick tan head  Aromas of yeast and a bit of banana.  Flavour is initially sweet and quite surprising for a dark beer, but finishes spicy.  Overall is not bad, but not as special as I would have hoped.

Pours a dark brown with a good sized head. Complex aromas of caramel, raisin, dark fruits, and some spices. Flavor is strong with alocohol, roasted malt, yeast, and some molasses. Medium body with a great balanced. an excellent belgian strong
Dark brown with an off white head. Sweet fruity aroma, gentle and soft, with yeast and leather.  Taste of raisin and other dark fruits, with sweet malt, spices and liquorice. Very, very good.

Brown pour with light brown thin head.  Aroma of malt and nuts, with some coffee and pine.  Taste of the same, with various spices throughout and some alcohol.  I liked it, but expected to love it since their other offerings have been fantastic.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2007 bottle from uto. Another great one from Unibroue - possibly the best. Dark chestnut with tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, cola, nuts, dark fruits / berries. It does smell a bit like a port wine - also smells a bit like Dr Pepper. Taste has the same qualities of Belgian christmas ales - roasted malts, dried dark fruits (prune, raisin, dates), rum and cola with espresso hints and a spicy edge. Finish of spice, berries and cola. A shorter finish than I prefer. Medium to full body. I could do without the taste of cola, but overall its a top brew.

At Asterix Bar, São Paulo. Pours hazy redish brown with a quickly fading brown head. Aroma is very intense, fruity and sweet. Flavor is sweet also. Notes of wood, yeast, dried fruits and roasted malt. Noticeable alcohol and very nice mouthfeel. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2009 341 mL bottle.  Deep, deep copper brown with abundant head that quickly fades. Aroma is much milder than youd expect.  Quite heavily carbonated, very smooth, little alcohol presence until the end.  Quite drinkable.  Dark, roasted fruit, molasses, a little spice, roasted malt, and alcohol.  Little hops presence.  Good.

Bottle.  Purple-black color.  Limited head.  Citrusy, acidic carbonation.  Lime.  Dates.  Even body.  Not tart, but with light licorice in flavor and similar to a flat port wine in aftertaste.  Not a big fan.

Got this on recommendation from a friend.  Pours dark reddish brown with large head that leaves nice lacing.  Dark fruit flavors with some molasses as well.  Pretty complex.  Not really my cup o tea, but still enjoyable.  Id go for Unibroues Trader Joes vintage over this one, though.

UPDATED: AUG 21, 2007 I thought this beer was pretty enjoyable - much more so at a warmer temperature.  Sampled in both bottle and draft with my boy Justin.  silky smooth, caramel, raisins, fruits, licorice, lots of brown sugar, alcohol, malts, yeast... A little lacking on the palate.

Botte: This beer pours with a huge slighty tan head. Pours mostly head. The aroma is very intersting and compex. I get dark fruits and brown sugar and a bit of spice. The flavor, not so much. I get some of the dark fruit flavor but the body is a little to sweet malt and candi sugar without any richness. Frankly I find it a little bland, atleast compared to other Dark Belgians.

Pours very dark, ruby-hued, opaque brown, with a nice creamy, pinkish-tan head. Lots of sweet and sour fruit, notes of candy sugar, and light yeast in the aroma. Flavor is mainly creamy and semi-sweet candy sugar, with light notes of berries and apples. Palate is medium, lightly effervescent, and a bit sweet. Nicely balanced and super easy drinking. Very enjoyable
best unibroue ive had yet, more full flavor, had no idea it was 9%. some fruit flavor, dark color, almost roasty finish.
In a bottle, a personal favorite. A dark belgian with lots and lots of taste. Its Fruity its spicy and its strong but the alcohol flavor is well hidden. Try it you wont regret it!

(bottle) Hazy, mahogany colour with a fluffy, laceless beige foamy head. Dusty, sweet malty, almost flowery, moderately fruity and spicy aroma with a present, vinous alcoholic note. Sweet flavour, full bodied with a well-carbonated mf. Chewy malt-character, raisin-fruity, slightly molassy; sweet, vinous, but also alcoholic finish. A bit too fat for my taste.

Very smooth and sweet. I cannot believe this is 9% alcohol. The fruit notes are very heavy, but ridculously good. I am very impressed with this ale. Probably one of if not my favorite belgian strong so far. The color is a dark brown almost black. The funny thing about that is, is when I was pouring the beer it appeared very light. What a surprise. The only problem with this beer, as is with most belgian ales, I do not enjoy the soda-like carbonation, but I feel that with this beer it is called for. May I remind other drinks that this beer is fruity, but very good.

My first Canadian beer! If theyre all this good, Im migrating.It doesnt quite have the complexity of the Belgian strong ales Ive tasted, but is very fine. Pours with a thick, elegant looking off-white head with good retention and OK lacing. The aroma is chocolatey. Flavour is roasted, malt and fruity. Quite sweet but in no way cloying. The high alcohol content adds warmth without intruding on the flavour.
Hardly a Port wine!  However, its good.  I would call it a "dark" Belgian Triple.

750ml bottle.  Cherry/blackberry like aroma.  Porter like appearance - dark with an off white head.  Sweet, syrupy, malty with some complex fruity flavours like cherries and blackberries.  The texture is quite similar to port .  The finish is long sweet and malty.  Very good indeed.

If the Dark lords of the Sith drank beer, this would be the beer period. Half a gallon of this is my best friend. I enjoyed it very much, and afterwards  my growler and I have decided to reveal ourselves to the jedi.

Poured from a 12 ounce bottle into a trappist glass, very dark brown with a small tan head. The aroma was of sweet malt. The taste was sweet with notes of cola, licorice and perhaps some dates and raisins. Nothing really dominated, just very smooth and well carbonated. No alcohol apparent. Just like drinking a good tasting soda.

This beer pours a deep dark brown, almost black color with a smallish light tan head.  Tiny bubbles dominate the head with a small lacing hanging around.  Smell is fruit, malt and yeast...begging you to sip.  The taste doesnt disappoint...excellent mouthfeel... a first class strong ale.  I loved this beer.  Highly recommended and I will try again.

Another impressive flavorful strong ale from the folks in Chambly, Canada.  Its amazing how they can brew such a sweet, smooth beer without the usual unappealing strong alchocol feel of a 9% ale.  Nice beer.

Gushed when opened and aroma exploded from bottle. Dark brown in color. Cloudy with small diminishing head and no lacing. Nice aroma, but faint, with small fruit tones. Flavor is amazing- malty and fruity. No alcohol flavor at all which is great for 9%. Smooth and clean finish. Extremely easy to drink. Very nice.

Bottle at home. Very dark, roasty ale. Bold taste of dried fruits, spices, wheat and chocolate. Sweet and mysterious. Well-layered. Nice finish. Would like to try on tap. Proof that Canadian beers are encroaching on sacred Belgian territory.

750ml bottle - trappist glass.

Very nice.  Just what I needed this evening.  Id elaborate, but I didnt share.
Very sweet, light body. Roasty, fruity notes. So sweet I dont think I could drink two. The flavor was there but it wasnt as rich as I had expected.

(Draught at Akkurat, Stockholm) Dark brown colour with ruby notes and firm beige head. Malty, yeasty and spicy nose with notes of port wine, chocolate, cherries and black-currant. Malty taste with notes of yeast, dark rye bread, dried fruit, blackberries, spices and hints of chocolate in the slightly vinous finish. Amazingly complex with all impressions mingling very well together in a nicely balanced brew. Brilliant stuff!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2007 Just had it on tap at Map Room in Chicago.  Ive had it previously in bottle and wasnt blown away, but maybe I wasnt in the mood.  On tap it was so tasty and complex that my buddy and I couldnt believe it was the same beer.  An outstanding dessert-like beer for finishing off the night.  Reminded me of Maudite, but has its own character.  Definitely not a session beer-- meant to be slowly enjoyed.

Bottle, at Waldo Pizza KCMO.  Dark Brown, somewhat hazy pour.  Aroma has a yeastiness to it, but mostly its the big malt that you smell.  Taste has a big body and many layers of flavor, malt, with some dried fruit sweetness.  Nice finish.

Pours a dark brown, with mediumish head.  Aroma was great; yeast, bubblegum, dark fruit, brown sugar.  Pretty good palate with some fizziness in the end (initially) and some throat warming.  A sipper for sure.  Flavor was similar to the aroma; fairly complex with dark malt, some caramel, candy sugar, some pepper.
Dark, flavorful and complex.  This to me is very similar to Chimay Blue Label.  However, I believe this to be slightly more flavorful.  Mostly I attribute this to the fruitiness and alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: JUL 16, 2007 Mmmm... A huge step up from Maudite. Pours a deep marble mohogany color with great head right out of the bottle. Heavy aroma of yeast, malts and fruits. Complex flavor of raisins, caramel, candi sugar, dark fruits, and a bit of licorice. Served it a bit too cold, but it just got better as it warmed up. Great palate, finishes like silk once at the right temperature. Good shiznit
score one for Unibroue.  great tasting. full of flavor, lighter malt, fruitty prunes, dark rasberry color. light head - just wonderful.
Pours a dark brown with an off white head. Aroma is fruit and yeast. Flavor is quite sweet with rasberry and plum notes. A bit simple, and a bit too sweet to be a top rank Belgian.

Had this at a tasting.  Went back for a couple more to see if I could get it straight.  Very nice aroma like a melon, plummy brown sugar-ish.  Color was a nice deep ruby/caramel.  sweet on taste and like others say, more of a desert beer.
Gold head with deep brown body.  Aroma of fruit, hops and malt.  Complex body with notes of raisins, apricots and grapes.  Full finish with a very mild hop.  This is a dessert beer to be sipped.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text: Bottle - Memphis.  Pale Gold head with fizzy bubbles on a dark amber body.  Complex aroma with apricot coming through in the end. Flavor is also complex but satisfying in every way with a warm alcoholic finish.

25.4 oz bottle.  Pours a dark cloudy caramel color with a one-and-a-half-finger off-white head.  The aroma is of malt, yeast, apple and caramel.  The flavor is sweet and bubbly with yeast, malt and pepper prevalent.  Very good.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 Dark amber with big, creamy tan head / Light nose of banana and caramel / Medium body, with Uni fizzy carbonation, sweet malts and good finish / Flavors of banana, chocolate, raisins, and caramel /

Very good nose.  Smells of kriek and plum.   The flavor certainly doesnt  disappoint, and the sweetness makes it a nice drink to serve after dinner. As the label suggests, it does bear some striking similarities to a good port.
Superp ale.  Tastes almost like a desert wine, well rounded, with a mellow maltiness, and a subtle sweetness that dissipate the high alcohol content.
Big bottle pours a dark brown with a reddish hue, and a thick tan head. Another damn fine beer from Unibroue.
Dark beer, stong alc content for the flavor.  A great beer for dinner with red meat.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2009 Good solid beer, the third belgian strong ale Ive tried, poured dark, but not thick body. Very easy to drink considering the high alc content. SECOND TASTING: Havent Had this beer in over a year, but 300 and some beers later, its even better than I remember. Sampled this back to back with the Maudite at Shortys in NYC. THIRD TRY::: Bottle split with Pat. Pours a dark stout like body. Aroma suggests that this beer is anything but a roasty stout - with notes of spice, malt, and sweet sugar. Taste is unbelievably smooth. Great flavor.

Very dark red/brown, almost black. Steady medium-sized head. Very nice floral, sweet, and citric aroma with the Unibroue-stamp all over it. Honey, vanilla, yeast, orange, plum, brown sugar. Taste was rounded and full-bodied, pretty sweet with lots of vanilla and dark fruit. Somewhat high carbonation & a bit of a watery mouthfeel, it doesnt really carry the bold flavours, pretty dissappointing. But nonetheless, this is great stuff.

The aroma is of citrus and spice. Maybe a touch of the banana/bubble gum smell. The head is off white, creamy, the body color is dark brown and the lacing is good. The initial flavor is bitter with a burst of fruit and then bitterness in the back of the tongue. The duration was average. The body is light, the texture watery and the carbonation fizzy and lively.
By far one of my favorite beers. It has such a rich golden color and great thick head. Goes down amazingly smooth with a nice aftertaste. A truly great brew.

Bottle. Yet another world class beer at this evenings tasting. Head was huge off-white and very fizzy that mostly lasted. Excellent lacing. Hazy dark brown color. Close to perfect appearance in my book. Aroma was complex. The first sniff is clear Belgium yeast with an array of other notes. Caramel, wood, grain, licorice, nutty, molasses, light chocolate, some celery like sharp notes, date, prune, peach, port. This one leaves and impression of being very unique in the bouquet. Nothing I have ever experienced before. Full bodied with a fizzy carbonation and light alcoholic texture. Moderated sweet flavor, not much bitterness here. Sweet fruity and light alcoholic finish. Excellent!
Pours burgundy with a nice white head.  Aroma is sweet and malty.  Flavor is vinous and complex but on the sweet side.  Nice Chimay knock-off.

Easily the darkest Belgian Ive ever set eyes upon. Thin bubbly head, minimal lace. Dark fruity aroma - dates & dark plum with sweet malt. Wonderful dark taste - almost overripe with fruit. I actually had to transfer this and re-pour, as it was HEAVILY carbonated and I could barely taste it for all the fizz. Much better on second pour. Dark plum & darker malt, very present alcohol, light but crisp hopping hangs in the aftertaste. Warming, pleasant. Strong! This is one heck of a beer.

[159-20061225] 341mL. Ribena raspberry/blackcurrant aroma with ginger and a hint of plastic. Lightly cloudy, dark brown ruby red body with a medium-lasting off-white foamy head.  Medium body with smooth alcohol integration. Very nicely blended.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2007 Bottle, pours a dark brown with a lively foamy tan head and slight lacing.  Sweeter aroma of malts, with plum, raisin and some light spice.  Taste is higher in carbonation, with a medium mouthfeel; malty throughout.  Alcohol is slight perceptible, but not too distracting.  A bit over carbonated and sweet, but very flavorful.

12oz. Bottle:  Very sweet aroma of ripe fruits.  Smells of prunes, raisins, plums, and maple syrup.  Poured ruby/purple in color with a HUGE tan head that mostly diminished but lasted throughout.  No lacing.  Cloudy.  Almost opaque.  Purple color looks like a Port or red wine.  Sparkling.  Flavor is moderately sweet and matches aroma well.  Tastes of cola, grape, plum, raisins, and dark malts.  Medium body.  Sticky texture.  Very fizzy carbonation. The properly stored bottle almost exploded.  Too much fizz.  Lightly sweet, medium dry finish.  Overall, good beer I was not sure I would like.

sampled at blind "Better Know a Style: Belgian Strong Ale" tasting 07. poured a wonderful mahogony with creamy off-white head. nose has cookie, molasses, yeasty, and cloves. flavor is nicely balanced with subtle spices, raisins, and plum. alcohol is well hidden.

Poured a rich velvety brown with nice ruby highlights.  The head is off-white and nearly two-fingers of tight bubbles that evaporate quickly.  No lacing to speak of.  The aroma is of fruit (I got mostly banana and plums) and some malt with some spice lingering in the background.  The flavor.  Oh the flavor.  What a unique flavor.  The sweet syrupy  beginning, the cloves, the cinnamon, the fruit.  A bit of hops?  Yes, I believe so.  What a remarkable finish.  Truly the whole is greater than the sum of its parts.  While the appearance and aroma are quite honestly unremarkable, this beer closes the gap like a true thoroughbred, blasting down the backstretch to steal the win.

Bottle. Pours a dark dark brown with a minimal nead.  Aroma is light citrus and malt.  Flavor is thick and rich.  Strong roasted malty taste with accents of dried fruit and  spices.  Palate is creamy and well carbonated with a bitter finish.  Good.
Incredibly tasty....theres not much else to say. Smells of fruit, and has a slightly sweet finish. Good stuff.

Beer #2 in Linus Sticks Belgian Adventure. How unique this beer is. The aroma was of yeast, fruit and some malt. The taste was full. If you took dates, plums and malt and put them in an oven for an hour, put them in a blender and added alocohol you would have this. Delicious and different.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Deep mahogany with a big head. Aroma of dark malts, dates, alcohol and dishwater. Taste was much better, with more dark fruits and toffee. Slight warmth of alcohol. Finishes barely sweet.

750 ml Bottle.  Very dark brown with red tinge.  Aroma is subdued and sweet; overripe fruit, mainly raisin, plum, and prune.  Roasted malt and fruit flavors are muted and balance well.  Full bodied and smooth on the palate.  Excellent.

dark mahogony pour with thin tiny bubble off white head.  floral, yeast, dark fruit, sweet malt aroma.  medium body.  tart dark fruits and big maltiness.  very  sweet flavor.  bitterness comes quick and lingers.  you wouldnt know it was 9%.  This was the first belgium style beer I ever tried.  Its nice to finally have it again.

Bottle.  Fizzy small tan head that quickly vanished.  Orange-brown body.  Cherries, figs, and bread in the aroma.  Flavor of  medium to light sweetness .  Mild, easy drinking belgian strong ale.  The alcohol is hidden extremely well.
This is one of the finest beers i have ever tasted. It has a complex taste, alcohol warming. It is so good that i will try and make a clone of it.

Drank in a tulip glass.  750 ml dated April 25th 2006.  Amazingly thick frothy head on top of a pitch black poor.  Aromas of sweet plums and bread, figs, black cherries, blackberries, very autumn like, coriander, grapes, red mcintosh apples with a slight vanilla twist...  Very even bodied excellent beer.  Slightly under carbonated but a part from that... The alcohol is an obvious feel to the palate and taste... Flavors are exactly the same as its aromas... Very ununibroue like in taste yet incredibly rich and tasty.  Ive drank quite a FEW of these and ill say it again... this beer ages beautifully in perfect conditions.  ENJOY!

Very carbonated, nearly black beer; light-cream coloured, fine-bubbled head, slightly irregular. Coriander soup! Ouch. Some dark leaves, but the coriander (OK, I hope its in there) overwhelms everything. Slightly sourish, fruity-coriander infested flavour. Thanks to all the malts, the coriander is not alone there. Ends on a molasses note. Very well-bodied, alcoholwarming, slick, nearly viscous.  Mais pourquoi toujours cet herbe infecte?  Id rather see cannabis in a beer, than coriander, d*mmit.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2007 Very unexpected sweet taste, nice tan head, but dissapated quickly. Fairly dark in colour, around a medium brown.  Sweet aroma, and medium carbonation.  Amazing flavour, with high alcohol content masked by brown sugar and fruit taste. 

6pk for $12.95 CND

Dark as night with a decent head. Dark fruit aroma, solid sweet smell. Reasonably sweet taste that lingers with the after taste. Has a high alcohol content but you can hardly tell by the taste. I enjoyed this beer very much and would recommend it, along with all the other beers Ive had from Unibroue.

12 oz bottle.  Deep dark color, though not as thick as motor oil.  Thick tan head, nice.  Ive been sniffing beers all day, so this was a tough judge, but nice firm aroma.  First sip reminded me of some of the barleys Id had at todays festival at Coles.  Way sweeter than I thought a dark brew could be.  Going to have to drink all of this to figure out if I like it or not, it is that different.  Im going to give it a high rating cuz the Sabres are on and I want to finish this review.  The different tast gives it a high rating.  Try this if you can.

Pours a darker brown, topped by a couple inches of tan foam. Decent head retention, good lacing. Malty aroma of plum, fig, maple, and brown sugar. 

Toffee, brown sugar, and a little chocolate flavors up front. Not overly sweet, in fact, very good balance. Some tart stone fruit in the finish, almost dry at the end and into the aftertaste - with just a bit of bitter chocolate along for the ride.

Medium body, moderate carbonation, and very drinkable.

Bottle:  dark pour, frothy head.  Aroma is very slightly grassy and roasted chocolate.  Mouthfeel is a little above average;  a little thinner than expected.  Flavor is fan-fuckin-tastic.  As it warms this beer is a dead ringer for a Tootsie roll on a haystack.  I spent the better part of an hour enjoying this brew.  This is a tremendous beer that might only improve in mouthfeel/thickness.  Wow.

This may be my favorite beer.  The flavors, the aroma and the experience are wonderful.  The fruity flavor and the long lasting nutty undertones make this beer worth sipping and relaxing with all night.
Dark mahogany pour with a thin head.  Roasty, malty aroma, woody, dark fruit - raisin, plum, fig, date - well balanced aroma.  Nice full flavor, good finish.  A good BSA, one of Unibroues best.

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2007 Sipping a tulipful getting ready for the Superbowl. Its below 10 degrees outside. My 9-month pregnant wife, my parents, and my in-laws are huddled around the fire. The turkey chili is stewing, the cornbread baking. And life seems so very good. I know this doesnt describe the brew at all...but Trois Pistoles isnt just a brew...its an event. A warm, merry, peaceful event.

Wow, I love me some Belgians.

This was very good brew. Strong flavor, after taste. This on is one of my favorites and i must track it down again. Very, very drinkable with the 9% ABV. I think I could go through 3-4 of these a night. :unsure:
Bottled.  Really really good beer.  The head pours out tall, but eventually goes away and leaves a great brew. Not much else to say, but damn it try this beer if you havent, cause its worth it.

12oz bottle.  rarely have i heard a nice high alc fizz once poured, but this toasted amber brown fade beer in color does.  initially, a 2 inch head, but bubbles down to a thin layer of tiny bubbles atop an aesthetically pleasing brew.  that dominant aromas are of fruit malts, mainly raisin, grape. and plum, and noticable hops.  tastes of sweet red grapes and rapidly disappearing hops are very up-front.  this is the most wine ive ever tasted in a beer, even if it is on the sweeter side of the vine.  the finish is definitely reminiscent of a belgian/abbey/trappist ale - that is, slightly dry, but successfully leaving a flavorful palate.  in addition, this great canadian brew offers a fig newton-esque taste.  a faint hint of oak, rasberries and blackberries carry over from the taste to the finish, which is rather long in duration.    though it is probably my highest rating, i will say it isnt my favorite.  the drinkablility is not as high as the abv.  its more of a beer to admire and respect, and less of a beer with the buddies.
UPDATED: JUL 16, 2007 Pours  dark brown with a quickly disapating white head. Aromas of fruits and Chocolate. Taste of what its aroma is very malty. One of my favorite Belgian Strong ales.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2007 Pours a deep brown with a light chestnut head that goes away after about 20 seconds. The initial aroma is what I love about this beer; there is so many distinct notes to it like chocolate, several ripe fruits, maple wood, and many others which I could not fully distinguish. The first sip surprised me with the explosion of flavours I tasted, it lived up to all the hype Ive heard about it. 

This beer is too complex for a beer newbie like me to rate and describe now, but perhaps I will re-rate it once Ive tried more beers.

For now, this is by far the best beer Ive tasted and I would recommend it to anyone wanting a quality beer for a meal.

Appearance: Pours a muddy dark brown with a super carbonated one finger head that dissipates very quickly to a paper thin layer. 

Smell: I have grown to love the smell of this style of beer, specifically the offerings from Unibroue. A particular spicy, fruity, malty sweetness that cannot be found anywhere else. 

Taste: The taste mirros the aroma perfectly. Wonderful fruits and malt sweetness, with just a hint of alcohol presence. Spices (nutmeg? cinnamon?) that I cant quite put my finger on linger in the background.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and well carbonated.

Drinkability: Despite how great this Dark Ale is, I cannot picture myself drinking more than 2 or 3 of these in a sitting. Bewteen the medium/heavy mouthfeel, and the wonderful sweetness this beer has to offer, and the 9% ABV, more than 3 of these could spell trouble.

I will 100% most certainly buy this again.
Pours an incredible purple/maroon color with a bubbly white/rose head. Strong flower nose with a bitter finish.

[Sampled at bænken in 2005.]  

Brewed by the brewer of Chimay, therefore it makes reminders to Chimay Bleue, but some truely differents are visible. More oaky and portvinously with a complex fullbodied sweettaste.
Light roastiness some plums/prunes in the flavor profile.  Has distinctive Unibroue spicy/yeasty aroma.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2007 Easily my favorite from Unibroue.  One of my first Belgian-style ales from years back, and I completely fell in love with it - on a trip to Niagara Falls, drinking it out of a red plastic Solo cup, no less.  It was good then and every single time since, it has not disappointed and has held up exceptionally to some of the more classic names within the style.  Dark ruby red bordering on brown with a distinctly creamy tan head that lasts and laces.  Strongest explosion of dark stone fruits - plums predominant - that I have experienced in an aroma.  Slight roast, brown sugar or chocolate sweetness as well, but the dark fruits really carry this one.  Taste is complex, sweet but not approaching cloying in any way.  Again dark stone fruits, some hints of red wine or port, slightly acidic, and an overarching malt sweetness.  Creamy, not overly carbonated but enough to produce a crisp sipper of an ale.
Aroma is very sweet and strong, as is flavor.. sweet with a nice long finish.  Its a beautiful dark brown with an awesome head.  Full body with great carbonation and a clean finish.

Bottle. Dark red-brown colour with a nice fluffy and creamy light brown head. Aroma of roasted malts, dark fruits, caramel and some chocolate. Flavour is smooth, roasty, quite fruity with plums and raisins, bitter-sweet chocolate, old port. Bitter hoppy finish. Taaaasty!!!!!

Wow, found this in a 12-oz. bottle at World Market.  It pours a frothy dark brown with amber edges.  Sweet & fruity aroma.  First taste is maple syrup with a dose of plums, followed by an almost wine-like finish. Plenty of spice in the background; I sensed cloves and maybe a little pepper. Just a touch of hoppy bitterness at the tail end.  Very good.

Wish I could afford this more often.

This beer pours into the glass as a cloudy dark leather-colored potion with a thick and fluffy off-white head.  It has a rich lacing and the head is mostly diminishing.  The clarity stops a couple centimeters into the glass.  There are certainly living creatures in it.  The aroma is a backdrop of a barn full of hay and the aroma of night-- of the flowers that were in bloom during the day but have closed up for now.  At the forefront of the aroma is a big plump prune, tawny port and possibly black pepper and tamari.  The initial flavor is moderately sweet and a barely detectable bitterness.  the flavor becomes startlingly balanced-- lightly sweet, acidic, and bitter.  the blast of flavor quickly recedes and the aftertaste is quite short.  It has a soft and even mouthfeel with a slight whiff of alcohol in the nose after swallowing.  Very refined!

From the Northcoast Coop here in Eureka, CA.   I paid $6.49 for a 750 ml bottle corked & caged. It poured an opaque and cloudy brown with large off-white head that diminished slowly with average lacing.  The nose was of burnt caramel with overtones of plum and berries. Flavors were simply explosive in the mouth and were sweet malts, caramel, citrus like touches of oranges and grapefruits, grapes, tantalizing spices, berries and chocolate. Mouthfeel was smooth and rich.  Finish was great with just the slightest hoppy and dry bitterness.   If it didnt cost quite so much I would drink this all the time.
Pours dark brown with a nice tan head.  Great fruity aroma with a smooth mellow taste.  A great beer!

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 Pours dark redish brown. Dark ripe fruit aroma with spices like clive, ginger, nutmeg and others. Undertones of dates, plums, pears, cherries, pineapple. Also some yeast, tea, liquorice and sugary malt. Maybe some fudge. Sweet flavour with tones of yeast, spices, sugar and sweet fruits. Sourish notes in both the flavour and in the nose. Medium body. Pretty complex stuff.

Brownish color with orange hughes is I looked through the edges of the glass. Big, fizzy tan head. Very complex aroma of dark fruit, wine, and some alcohol. Taste is similar, heavliy malty. To be as complex as it is, it remains very pleasant and mellow. Great balance. If it wasnt so expensive, I would get this on a regular basis.
Pours deep dark brown. Nice foamy head.Very pleasent aroma. Fizzy is an acurate discription, with a mellow tatste.

The color was a made color with orange hues.  The head was thick, fizzy, and offwhite and laced a little.  The aroma was alcohol, a hint of fruit like jam preserves.  There was almost a slight starchy smell.  The flavor was alcohol, fruit, slightly sour, and maybe a little roasty flavor.  The palate was nice.  It was medium body with just the right amount of carbonation.  The finish was warm.

Deep dark mahogany in color, ruby tinted, with a bit of greyish head.  Its bracingly COLD outside! and I really need a brew like this.  Aromas bring to mind red grape, chocolate, alcohol, toffee, a hint metallic.  Even a touch of authentic indescribably Belgian funk.  Tastes of pears, raisins, chocolatey port.  Prickly and lingering in the mouth.  Nice warming - about the right speed for winter weather in MN.
Pours deep funky brown with an airy off white head that dissapates.  Lots of carbonation.  Aroma of oak, musty cellar and fruit.  Taste of cola, fruit, raison, yeast, spice. A nice solid beer.

Dark mahogany with a light creamy head. Cola, caramel, fruit and pear aromas. Rough texture with a malty finish- cola like.
Great.

Dark amber pour. Medium light tan head. sweet fruity/raisin aroma, slightly "citrusy". Smooth on the tongue, after the fizz quickly goes away. Awesome sweet flavor. Hints of berries/raisin, and fig. After taste lingers sweetly making me want more. One of my favorites. I am so glad this one is easy to get ahold of.

750. Shared with my beautiful beer-loving girlfriend... dark auburn pour with grape aroma, and a surprisingly light and crisp mouth feel for the dark appearance.  The flavor is brown sugar with a spicy citrus lemon finish.  This is much more complex than I remember it being.  The 9% abv blend with the fruit flavors to make this beer delicious.  Canada? Belgium? I cant taste the difference! (jk)

What can I say, another awesome brew from my favorite Canadian brewery!  Such a great head, aroma, and aftertaste.  This is a great beer to snuggle up to a fire with or watch a movie on a cold night with.  Get you some!
Bottle at Byens Kro. Dark -> almost black - white head. Wheat, yeast, licorice, spicy, fruity, raisins, roasted, caramel - typical belgian characters - but not fantastic.
Very tasty brew, that is dark and strong but even with the high alcohol it doesnt taste strong.  Nice dark brown cloudy color. Malty goodness. My favorite from this brewer. Good in colder months

Bottle. Pours a deep mahogany color with a medium light tan head. Aroma of fermented fruit and roasted nuts and malt. Taste is slightly sweet and yeasty. Very well balanced with a wonderful warming finish of dates, raisins and malt that hide the alcohol nicely. Outstanding!
12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark red, with a thin tan head.  Smells of vinegar.  Sweet taste, and suprisngly drinkable for a 9%.  Nice belgian strong.
IMO the best beer that Unibroue offers.  Very dark, extremely smooth (easily drinkable), and yet still complex.  Brought in the New Year with a 750ml.
Bottle. Poured a dark murkey color with very little tan head. Aroma is hoopy with some citrus. Has a malty oak taste.

Pours crimson brown. Moderate head that dissipates slowly. Nose of raisins and figs almost overwhelm the malt. Complex fruity taste with a finish like a fine dessert wine. Smooth and creamy and frighteningly drinkable for the alcohol content.

Bottled. Dark reddish brown colour with a nice creamy off-white head. Malts, dry dark fruits, slight yeast and caramel in the aroma. The flavour is very full, dry dark fruits, caramel malts, vanilla, slight roasted twist along with berries and yeast. Also some spices in it. Very full with lots of stuff, yet wellbalanced and pleasant in any way.
750 bottle-This poured out a dark brown with a thin tan head.There is most definetly a strong malt aroma and dried fruit.The flavor is vanilla,molassas,cherry with a bitter finish.Ok beer.

Mmm, really good, really tasty, Alcohol is hidden very well, flavor is great dried fruit, maybe curants, figs, and raisins, no overwhelming cloying sweetness or over abudndant ester profile. Just really good easy drinking beer. Fantastic finally in oklahoma we are getting good beer.

UPDATED: MAR 14, 2007 Definetly Unibroues best beer. Seeing how i cant get Chimay blue on a regular basis in Ontario, this is a perfect replacement, and im even starting to enjoy it more than the Chimay. Keep it up Unibroue!

I find this to be the flagship product of Unibroue.  Very unique and rich tasting but not over the top sweet.  Kind of fruity and strong.  Very unique and delicious.  As previously stated, this is what I consider to be their best.

341 bl bottle, from The Beer Store. Dark chestnut colour, with hints of auburn. Excellent, thick body. Rich, malty flavour and aroma. Dried fruit on the nose. But do they have to put that damned coriander in every single one of their beers? I like coriander in belgian ales, but i think it clashes a bit with the rest of the flavours here. Overall, still a delightful beer. The coriander taste/aroma seemed to disipate a bit.

UPDATED: DEC 27, 2006 341 ml bottle - pours a nearly impenetrable dark brown/red, with only a hint of lightness showing through at the bottom of the glass.  Large tan head.  Spicy, yeasty dark fruit aroma.  Deliciously thick in the mouth, with nutmeg, banana esters, prune, fig, and a full vinous quality.  Light carbonation dances on the tongue.  Does not seem like 9% abv, until the very end, when a warming burst appears.  Exceptional.  I love the story on the bottle.  One of the best beers Ive had.  Ecstasy.
A misty, dark brown appearance with a hearty mouthfeel. Geat tasting full-flavored beer. Very palatable. This beer is what got me started searching for great beers.

12 oz. bottle dated 01-29-09.  Dark brown with reddish hue, huge bubbly head with great staying power. Aroma hints of cellar-aged dark fruit.  Creamy mouthfeel, medium bodied, wonderfully balanced and smooth flavor that requires thought to pick out any component beyond a pleasant malty sweetness.  Mild aftertaste with alcohol just slightly evident at the end.  This would be a great choice for helping friends transition to higher quality brews.

Bottle.  Pours a nice dark burgundy, brown with a small bubbly head.  A sweet dark fruit aroma, almost like a dark wine.  Flavor is sharp with flavors of dark fruits, plum and dark cherries (as Heathen mentioned) and grapes.  Very good.
Black, with ver little head.  Smooth beer with fruity/floral taste.  Strong beer with a very sweet taste and excellent finish.

Bottle. Poured a dark brown with a large off-white head that quickly became paper thin. Dark fruit (black cherry and plum maybe) and yeast aroma. Much carbonaton. Caramel, chocolate and brown suger aromas developed as it warmed. These aromas all come through in the flavor as well, but not as strong with the addition of sweet molasses and some coffee as it warmed in both the aroma and flavor. But dark fruits were the primary flavor. I keep coming back to this beer from time to time. It is very good.

Bottle.   Pours a cloudy darkish brown color to it with a long lasting beige head.   Aroma is raisins, dried cherries, malt, yeast.   Flavor is raisins, coffee, roasted grain, dreid cherry, yeast, alcohol.   Palate is medium bodied, creamy, highly carbonated.   This pairs well with many different types of food.   Served with Thanksgiving dinner.

12 oz bottle. aroma of cherries, grapes, extremely sweet, as was evident from beer exploding from bottle after cap was taken off...dark purple/black in color.. very sweet and smooth flavor of various fruits and malt, with alc hidden extremely well..will get again very soon.
Bottle. Nice big head with ok duration. Color is brown. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is sweet and malty as well with some fruits in the finish.

Gets better as it warms up, more fruity and yeasty both in taste and aroma.  Very similar taste to La Fin Du Mondue.  Must use the same yeast?  Some dark malt flavor, along with a lot of fig, fruit, and yeasty taste.  The yeast is especially apparent in the aroma.
A bit disappointed from the bottle.. Brown colored, sweetness overwhelms the flavor a bit, not a lot of things going on from what i can tell..

The aroma has a ripe fruit smell with a strong smell of alcohol along with an acetic acid smell. The appearance has a cloudy darkish brown color to it with a long lasting head. The flavor is a sweetish alcohol flavor. It is very fizzy with a long aftertaste. You really couldnt drink a whole lot of these with the 9% alcohol content. Its good, very similar to Maudite. It probably has a little too much alcohol for my taste.

Bottle - Pours a very dark reddish black/brown in color with a small tan head.  Aroma is quite fruity with a Belgian-type yeastiness.  Some roasted malts with a heavy amount of malt.  Flavor is quite fruity with estery malts, dark fruits and hints of nutmeg and either caramel, toffee and/or molasses.  Belgian-type yeast quite strong.  Warms the tummy... alcohol slightly apparent.  Quite thick.  You should let it warm a bit to get the full effect!  Quite good... easy to see why it so highly rated... too bad it soooo expensive... well worth repeating!

Pours out a nice deep mahogony color with a nice beige head.  Aroma is slightly yeasty and malty.  Flavor is fruity, malty and has a nice hop finish to it.  This brew is a darker than i had expected.  Flavor also more flavorful than i had expected.  I havnt had many unibroue beers, but this one is by far the best that i have had.

This had a strong aroma of biting alcohol and roasted malt.Average head.Color very dark brown,almost black.It tasted of good balance of grapefruit,roasted malt,and maybe some nuts.The alcohol almost was overbearing,but it is a good beer.It does taste kind of like a port wine.

Unibroue Trois Pistoles
12 oz bottle
Medium pour in a tulip glass
Best before 10/08, plucked 11/06

Poured a dark murky ruddy brown with a large light brown frothy mostly lasting head.

Smelt of whole wheat bread, raisins, cinnamon, molasses, dark fruit.

Taste was upfront moderate to strong, yet perfectly balanced bitter, sweet and sour, with raisins, coffee, roasted grain, bitter spruce, dark fleshy fruit, followed by a strong spicier and maltier taste, less sourness, notes of  good port or brandy, on an exquisite finish.  Palate was medium bodied, creamy and velvety, lively carbonated, and light to moderate astringency.

Overall, there is so much to enjoy in this beer, it deserves multiple sittings.  Classic.

Starts foaming out of the bottle as soon as its opened.  Pours a very dark, nearly opaque brown with a large, long-lasting, sudsy tan head.

Deep, expressive nose of mixed ripe and dried fruits, with some sweet malt, a whiff of nutmeg, and even some oxidative notes.

Carbonation level is high, giving the body fullness but also making it lively on the tongue.  Acetic acid also is there.  Flavor profile is a bit exotic, with grapy/berry fruitiness, spice, and molasses.  Thins out on the smooth and moderately brief finish.

Impressive in its own way, but the oxidative style and vinegar flavors just dont appeal to me.

Brown coloured beer with a soft red glow and a fine beige head.The aroma is fruity, malty and slight spicey. Taste is smooth and well ballanced. It has an interesting softness with hints of malts, sugars, fruits and some spices. Afthertaste is elegant.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2006 Great aroma, sweet like ripe fruits. Poured dark brown/black. Medium head. The taste masked the high alcohol (9%) alowing for a very smooth dark high-alcohol beer. Warm fruits highlighted the palate, though you could still tell that it had a high alcohol content.

Wow, didnt expect it to be rated so high.  Pours dark brown with a huge tan head.  Aroma is full of malt and dark fruits.  Lots of raisins and some apple.  Taste was kind of thin.  Almost nothing up front, then a burst of alcohol, sugar, spice, and grapes.  As soon as these flavors appear, they disappear in the back.  The aftertaste is nice and smooth, with malts and the port they advertised.  I let it warm, and it was nearly the same.  I just got tired of trying to appreciate this beer.

Poured a deep black brew with a thick, foamy, off white, and quickly receding head. Smelled of mature/ripe fruit, raisin/prune, and sweet. Taste began slightly sour, gave way to alcohol, and then a lingering fruit. Very crisp and full mouthfeel with a warm finish. Masked the alcohol well.

12 oz bottle. .. Malty aroma, molasses, toffee, spices. ..	Tan head that deflates quickly, but laces the glass nicely.  Dark brown color - cola like. . . 	Sweet, malty flavor with hints of dates and raisins. . 	Sticky, coating, med/hvy body. . 	Complex, tasty beer.  Well crafted - need to drink this cool, not cold. .

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2006 Well, I originally rated this beer based on a 2006 bottle.  I ran across a fluke pack of 2003 bottles at the beer store the other day, and Im back to tell you that its a much much different beer.  The aroma is unbelievable, smelling better than some of the good ports Ive tried.  The taste is no different, all the qualities of a really good port, and all the qualities of an excellent beer!  Strong notes of port (obviously) figs, dates, raisins, chocolate, espresso, maple syrup and molasses.  This beer in phenomenal if you leave it to age for at least 3 years.  -  What follows is the original review of the 2006 bottle  -  I tried this beer at Lot66 in Thunder Bay, and it was refreshing to see that someone in this city actually servers a proper beer! This beer pours jet black, with a nice head that fades away to nothing much too quickly. The aroma is very nice, and quite complex. I picked up a hint of sweetness with a little black licorice. I found the taste to be somewhat lacking, with a rather sharp initial attack, and a bit of a watery body and finish. To be honest, I very much preferred the Unibroue Maudite, which was smoother and had a better balance. I know all this sounds a bit negative, but it really was a superb beer overall. well worth a try, and Ill definitely be having this one again!

750ml bottle. Pours a hazy dark brown with a massive off-white head that settles to a lacy ring of foam. Aroma of fruit, spices, citrus, ginger and plum. Medium body with fine carbonation. Same notes in the taste as the aroma, with a bunch of spice in the dry finish. Lots going on in this beer.

Dark black color with a beige head that dissapointingly disappeared too soon. Very rich complex aroma of ripe fruits, yeast spice, ans roasted malts. The flavor is even richer and very well balanced: again ripe fruits, spice, malts, some hints of chocolate, coffee, caramel, brown sugar, wood... The palate is unexpectedly a bit watery.  Clean and good aftertaste. An excellent beer.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2007 Thick beige head of three fingers with a very black body.  Aroma of carrageenan and freshly baked cinnamon rolls.  The flavor is a maelstrom of malts, spices (nutmeg, carrageenan and cinnamon)  sweet, ripe fruit hits you later in the aftertaste.   The finish is warm, sweet velvety smooth.

I had high hopes for this brew, considering most of the ratings, and was expecting at least a score of 4. The smell was pleasant and appearance highly drinkable, but as arayaga2 mentions, this beer lacks complexity. The finish is unimpressive and surprisingly light. Maybe it was just the bottle I purchased, but I doubt it.
Blackish brown with tight tan head.  Aroma is sweet and finely blended.  Taste is sweet, but lacking in complexity.  Finish is spicy, and it leaves a tingle of carbonation..  $3/12oz
Fascinating offering again from Unibroue!  Nothing you havent read already... a little to much like the Port Wine as described, but other than that this one is fabulous!

750 mL bottle. Pours a very dark ruby amber with big beige head. The aroma is mildly spicy with zest, pepper, anise, and a little bit of clove; there are some sweet brown sugar and caramel notes in there, too. The flavor is mostly raisiny malt and honey, augmented by very subtle rose petal and spruce notes. It works toward a spicy finish with cinnamon, anise, and corriander. It leaves a clean, sweet aftertaste and a warming sensation. As it comes to room temperature, more wood and caramel comes out. Very well balanced overall.

Bottle, 330 ml. Sweet, just noticed this is more or less readily available in Sweden now (beställningssortiment..) This beer is huge.. Dark dark red. Sweet fruits, plums, dates and raisings matched with yeasty spice. Very effervescent carbonation. One of the best beers in a long time..

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2006 341ml bottle. Pours very dark amber, almost black, with ruby highlights shining through. Very fragrant stuff, full of sweet and "ripe" fruit aromas, with that recognizable Unibroue spiciness. That same quality shows up in the flavour, full of sweet dark fruit and some distinctive spiciness. The port/wine character that others (including the brewer) have described is right there in the finish, with a lasting pleasant sourness right at the end. Carries an swesome vinous character all the way through. Boom ! Its a masterpiece. Its a crime The Beer Store in Ontario has decided to de-list it. I heard that an angel loses its wings everytime The Beer Store/LCBO delists a good beer.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2007 Thick head, very strong, but fairly easy to drink. The first thing I noticed was how sweet it was. Very surprising, and the most complex beer that I have run across. So many flavours that its hard to tell what is there. I can definitely smell the ripe fruits and the smell of malt is very strong. Thick, very dark and a nice mouthfeel. Definitely one of the best beers I have ever had the opportunity to drink.

[Bottle from Hollingshead Deli dated best before 07-13-08]  Aroma of dried fruit and toffee.  Small head.  Dark brown opaque appearance with a thin layer of bubbles remaining on top.  Beautiful taste of aged fruit, caramel, and a bit of grape.  Quite a bit of carbonation at the end, but its not a problem.  Love the taste, but a hint on the sweet/sour side at the finish.  Alcohol level is perfectly balanced.

lots of prune and dried dark fruit with on the nose with some vegetal characteristics. very clean crisp palate with significant carbonation (maybe a bit too much).  The palate mirrors the nose and the finish is like an aged tawney, with nice dry spiciness..

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2007 12 oz bottle from Johns Grocery in Iowa City: dark rasin colored with a smooth creamy head of tiny bubbles. Distinctive belgian unibroue yeast aroma, sweet with cloves and spices.  Sweet prunes, raisins, dark fruit, chocolate, and a little warming alcohol.  Dry and overcarbonated in the finish.  The overcarbonation becomes distracting and annoying, once i swirl for a while and release some more of the carbonation it finishes a little smoother and more enjoyable.

12 oz. Bottle, I must say the logo and the description on the 4 pack case is awesome. Pours a dark reddish brown with a very nice off-white head on top. Beautiful pour. Aroma is full of fruit, with cherries, plums, raisins, and grape dominating. Flavor is full of fruit right upfront. Tasting grapes,  plums and raisins mostly in the flavor. I can taste the port wine finish at the end and is a great accompaniment. An excellent beer!

12 oz. bottle.  Poured murky dark brown color with thin tan head.   Aroma of clove, cane sugar, a little alcohol.  Taste is spicy, and fruity with a smooth finish complemented nicely by a yeasty flavor.  Might be the best of Unibroues regular lineup.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2011 Rerate on 02/20/2011.   Awesome beer.  Aroma is this beautiful fruity scent, slight farmhouse, yeasty.  Very inviting.  Appearance is a gorgeous red/brown, a hazy but slightly translucent, fluffy tan head.  Flavor is spicy, fruity, nutty, a bit like dry red wine.  The finish is spicy, peppery.  medium in body, noticeable carbonation.  Excellent.

Served at NYC Brewtopiafest.  Pours a dark brown body with a tan coloured head that lasts. doesnt leave much lacing. smells sweet and malty, semi-sewet chocolate and fruit.  Tastes sweet, def. of alcohol, cherry, plum, nuts, cidar and grapes. well carbonated. yeasty at finish.

Pours a hazy dark brown-charcoal with a greyish-tan head.  Powerful fuit fragrance like plums and cherries, and a little bit of spice.  Classic Belgian bouquet.  My first sip is an explosion of fruity, spicy flavor with a slightly tart bite and some clove and vanilla overtones.  The force is strong with this one... I can feel the alcohol as this slides down my throat and warms my belly.  Body is medium and the high carbonation makes this beer seem lighter than is it.  No discernable bitterness with a dry, coffee-like finish.  Quite a complex brew.  Wonderful.

Pours a hazy burgundy with nice tan head. Fruity aroma which is plummy, soil-like and a hint of raspberries. Flavor is slightly tart, fruity bouquet. Has a crisp grape-like aspect, toffeeish. Hint of slightly sour berries, winey. Nice ale.
Sampled this at the Great Decatur Beer Tasting Festival.   brown color, white head.  Lots of malt and raisin in the nose.  A very sweet flavor.  Rich and robust malts.  A full-bodied strong beer.

Bottle:  Nice dark pour with fruity and malty aroma.  Taste is a blend of roasted malts, fruitiness (cherry and plum), yeast, and some sugary sweetness.  Nice complex taste that is still balanced and very refreshing.

Pours dark, cloudy brown with off-white head. The aroma is very malty sweet and yeasty, with some chocolate, fruit (dried cherries), and alcohol. The flavor is fantastic: very malty (but balanced - not too sweet) and yeasty, some belgian funk (aromatic, grassy), some fruit (cherries and figs), some caramel, and hints of smoke and chocolate. The mouthfeel is wonderfully creamy and light for such a strong beer. The finish is long, full-bodied, and full of some other flavors: a touch of hops, burnt toast, and alcohol. Amazing beer.

12 ounce bottle.  Gusher.   Dark mahagony.  A bit of tan head that quickly faded.  Aroma of roast, dark fruit, fig, smoke, tobacco, soy sauce.  Some cherry notes in the flavor.  Still kind of smokey/tobacoo ish.  Lots of carbonation that thins the palate.  Im not enjoying this bottle much, but Ive had it on other occasions and really enjoyed it.
Good almost chewy its so full of flavor. Dark dark flavor ale. One bottle then switch to somethnig else. Be a waste to be drunk and not be able to taste all the flavors of this.

Poured a very dark brown, nearly black with very little whispy off white head.  Very interesting aroma, smells of brown sugar and pear and plums.  Initial flavor is syrupy, almost candy like with heavy apricot flavor.  Finish is heavy, alcoholic and acidic.  Overall this was worth a try, but one glass and youll have your fill.
chocolate malt flavour, good finish, definatly worth the trip to your local lcbo

12 oz Bottle:  This one is a treat.  Nice roasted malts with dark chocolate and fruits and a crisp port finish.  Beautiful!  If you are in the Americas it is a great substitute for some of the more expensive Belgian Trappists.
UPDATED: DEC 18, 2006 Very dark brown. Huge head! Lots of interesting fruit smells and tastes. I like hops better than fruit and yeast---but this is a fine brew.

Pours a cloudy dark amber with a very large rocky brown head which settles nicely. Fruity aroma of raspberries, candy, yeast and alcohol. Taste is alcoholic but smooth, with more berry flavours and sweet caramel. The finish is quite alcoholic and fruity, with a slight bit of chocolate. Wonderful

75cl bottle at Stellas Tap and Tapas Bar, Vancouver.  Hazy deep brown, sparse beige head.  Belgian yeast aroma, citrus lemon, some choc malt.  Quite sharp in mouth, but then lovely choccy malt matches the lemon and yeast.  Spritzey finish.  Lovely balance and flavours.  Best Unibroue beer Ive had.  Some vinous fruits.  Does remind me of a Rochefort 8.  Got a strong Belgian beer style resemblance.

Dark fruit nose with notes of  plum, fig, raisin, black cherry, black curant, molasses and anise. Wonderful flufy chewy mouthfeel with perfect carbonation. Layered and complex flavors develop as you drink thru it, nice peppery finish.

UPDATED: NOV 18, 2006 Nice beer.  A good choice for after dinner.  Nice aroma of fruit, especially bananna, caramel and yeast.  Flavor is very fruity and the alcohol is pretty well hidden.  I have to take some points for the excessive carbonation.

i really enjoyed this beer, poured dark, dark brown with a light brown head that faded quickly.  aromas of spice and dark fruits, cherries.  delicious taste, smooth with lots of complexity.  very good finish and nice aftertaste.  beer got much better as it warmed.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Definitely a fine beer, but not quite my style choice.  It is yeasty, but good yeasty, dark red/brown, evenly sparking, and overall quite nice.  There is a bit of a bittersweet fruit flavor to it, but I think the yeast and bitterness cover it up...Maybe a bit too much for me?
Dont let the creepy flying horse scare you away.  This beer is an incredible drinking experience.  A highly carbonated, almost purple-y liquid with a sublime flavour profile.  Highly recommended.

Was the last beer in a long night of tasting. It had a aroma of ripe sweet fruit (appricots) and a long lasting fizzy head. It was a little on the carbonated side (like Orval) but still another great tasting beer from Unibroue.

Dark brown, carmelly and fruity like a doppel. fruity top, with hints of apple, pears and berries. ALso hints of nutmeg and cinnamon in the middle, resembling a spicy, oaky apple pie. Good bitter tingle. Mouthfeel was perky, not so creamy.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2016 Bottle was an enormous gusher, probably lost about half of its contents, but at least the room will smell nice for a while.  Hazy deep-red beer that shines brown, loud and fizzy beige head.  Too strongly carbonated.  Smells of thick malt, belgian yeast, dark pitted fruit, raisins, light oranges, sweetish but restrained.  Taste is layered and complex ... nuanced flavors.  Full-bodied and roughly the consistency of port.  Far from sludgy.  Light, pleasant alcohol felt more through numbing than burning, but the latter could do with some calming.  Yes, rather vinous texture.  Sweetness is here but slight, and just slightly stronger than the balancing bitterness.  Beautiful dark fruitiness and elegant maltiness.  A subtle beer rather than a powerhouse.  The classy adult entertainment for the evening. [2006.10.02: 3.9]Bottle BB 12-18-18, but here two years earlier.  Screw-top under foil, which is annoying, but at least no gushing this time.  Nose sweet caramel and thin but potent overripe red fruit.  Pour is chestnut that collects to a deeper mahogany with bits of ruby around the bottom, airy overall with a foamy cola-like tan head.  Taste alcohol and jammy, moderately dry, mild fusels that arent bad, strong orange and cherry, subtle raspberry, darker plummy notes and gentle waves of roast.  Pleasantly tart (indeed, that is the unmistakable identifier and hidden strength of this yeast; its thinness is the drawback) with mild spice, presumably from the hops, but who knows, could be coriander and black pepper.  This one tastes a little too fresh, as if time would help with the melding, and perhaps a little pressure release?  It does approach a porto in the fruity sense but not in sweetness or (obviously) strength, but Id still like to a see a denser, less fizzy version for a better comparison.  [2016.11.27: 3.7]
UPDATED: APR 2, 2007 Poured a brownish color with a small  white head. You smell fruit right away like an apricot smell. Tasted very fruity to me. Pretty good brew.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2007 After a year of aging... Deep, dark maroon and murky with a huge, light tan, fizzy but pillowy head which has decent longevity and minimal lacing.  Nose is very fragrant!  Fruity esters dominate with plenty of port notes.  Fruits noted include currant, fig, plum, grapes, and backing notes of spices including clove, nutmeg, and allspice; estery yeast presence with miscellaneous anise notes.  Flavor is nice and similar to the nose; currants, plums, raisins, and lots of figs some nice chocolate notes and hints at coffee.  Alcohol is noted when young, but just adding the port similarities; aging settles it a bit.  Sweetness is quite high with little notes to balance, but not necessarily unpleasantly.  Palate is medium to full bodied with a nearly lively bit of carbonation and a round, silky mouthfeel.  Finishes still sweet like a port, like the bottle suggests, with lingering ripe fruits, yeast, and chocolate flavors.  A very vinous and port-like Belgian with plenty of great fruit flavors.  Unlike any other BSA Ive tried but certainly among my favorites; unbalanced and tilted towards the malty, estery notes.  A year of aging helped the palate and possibly some fruit flavors (if that was possible), but still a great experience nonetheless.

Aroma of darkish fruit. Nearly opaque brown color with a fine, determined, but not thick, tannish head. Starts with fruit reminiscent of cherries. Followed by malt. A fairly strong carbonation. No noticeable hop. The malt goes on. Good.

Another gift from my cousin to try. Very complex rigth from the start with a sweet aroma of fruit (maybe cherries) and caramel. Pours a deep red with tan head and A LOT of carbonation bubbles. Taste was somewhat hidden behind the carbonation bubbles, but taste of malts, fruit, and some spices comes through. Finishes very easy with a bit of a alcohol warming just like a port. Very interesting, gets lots of points for complexity, but loses on the carbonation.
Raisins, toast,  sweet aromas.  Smooth, sweet, dried fruit flavors, a little spicy hop in there as well.  Finishes very lightly despite being 9%.

12 oz bottle.  Clear burgundy brown.  Tan head builds quickly and slowly fades with some lace.  Sour yeast, cola and spices.  Ive had this several times but cant get used to the taste.  Mostly sweet but seems artificial and medicinal.  Caramel apple gets an odd sourness with metallic vegetal notes.  Medium body; a bit fizzy.
Poured with a  huge head. Very bubbly. Nice fruity aroma with a lively smooth mouth feel. Malts and fruits predominate. A classy  product.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2007 Bottle. Pours dark red with a full tan head. Aroma is slightly sweet malts, dark fruit, and spice. Flavor is spicy dark fruits, sweet malts, and a strong finish of figs, brown sugar and plum that lingers for a while. The alcohol stays hidden pretty well, and the mouthfeel is rather full.

12oz, poured dark like port with generous foam and carbonation.  Aroma is complex with some sodium, almost like a sea breeze?  Lots of carbonation on the nose, tastes of malt and some dried fruits, similar to prunes.  A myriad of flavors going on here, hard to sort them all out.  Very similar to a port wine.  Will certainly go back for more of this.

Sampled from Bomber as pictured. Appearance was a murky dark reddish brown liquid that you could barely see through if held to light.  Lots of carbonation and a two finger fizzy head that behaved almost like soda. No lacing was apparant.  Flavorwise,  If I were blind folded, I would have sworn I was drinking a hefeweizen with diet grape faygo mixed in it. Dont get me wrong, in this case that isnt a bad thing. Those flavors actually worked for me.  Theres a big hefe robust clove spice that is the initial taste. Big pop like fiz on the tongue combined with light mouthfeel.  The 9% ABV is hidden VERY well, I really couldnt detect until it was too late. (if you know what I mean!)  Aftertaste was definitly like a grape wine or porter.  Very complex brew that I really enjoyed tasting.  I would drink this again anytime.

750. Hugely black with an invasively large tannish head that gets in the way of the pour almost instantly. Settles on its terms to a still-impressive bubbly/moussy head. Some slow-rising carb in the visible body. Big dark fruit nose with some sour tartness and even a little bit of the good wild Belgian horse blanket funk. Big, dark, assertive fruit attack with cleansing bubbles and a nice hollow fruit-pith finish. Clean hollow nothing once the beers gone down the zero. This is a deep dark rewarding and delicious beer. Cheers again to Unibroue. Theirs must be the best lineup of Belgians in the hemisphere.

Dark reddish-brown body with very thick khaki head (the bottle almost overflowed on me!). Smells sweet, citrusy, kind of earthy/peaty (sp?), similar to a scotch ale or wee heavy. Tastes malty and citrusy. Relatively smooth. While its high in alcohol, you almost cannot tell that thats the case. Fruity. Tasty but not overly strong or unbalanced. Medium-to-full body. Definitely a sipping beer, but not overpowering. Good alcohol warming. Another good ale from one of the best breweries in North America.
Hazy deep, dark brown with thick tan head. Malt, fruits and cane sugar. Might be a bit of herbal to it as well.

UPDATED: OCT 27, 2006 Bottle. Pours dark and murky with an off-white head. Smells of nuts and spices and very ripe fruits. Taste is much of the same, with lots of malt and caramel flavor as well. Aftertaste lingers longer than any beer Ive ever tasted. Very carbonated and surprisingly easy to drink. Excellent excellent beer... quite possibly my favorite.
341ml bottle.  Deep mahogony colour with a  malty and  fruity  taste (grapes , apples, plums, raisins).  Good carbonation. I really enjoyed this beer, it will be a regular for me in the winter time.

Dark pour with a off white head. Full aroma that smelled of grapes and cherries..a touch of plum and licorace as well. The flavor was smooth and full of spice and dark fruit. It really lasted and finished full with a nice creamy mouthfeel and almost soda like with its sharp carbonation. Good brew from the north people.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown with a very substantial thick head with light mocha coloring that leaves good lacing.  Theres only a bare hint of fruit in the aroma; smells slightly like wine, or oddly enough, grape soda.  The taste starts quick with a malty-fruit explosion of grape with the mid-taste being slighly less intense but full of banana esters and a bit of melon.  The finish is earthier  and the aftertaste is that of almonds.  The palate is very silky, with a perfect amount of mouthfizz. That slight warm presence of alcohol is every easy on the stomach. An excellent strong ale.

Deep red in color.  Another gusher from Unibroue.  I should just expect this.  Head is white with a red tint and huge.  Aromas are of strong fruit...cherries, grape, tannins, port like.  Also some caramel hidden beneath.  Texture is creamy...mmm, pretty good.  I think Ill have another.

Opaque, dark brown.  The yeast in suspension traps the light and creates some white.  A pale brown head sits atop but collapses quickly after pouring.  Lime leaf aroma with licorice and chocolate that is reminiscent of Dr. Pepper soda with some paint thinner.  Flavor has a very pleasant orange character with chocolate notes and licorice with caramel enveloping everything.

Extremely volatile, super-foamy tan head.  Hazy, dark mahogany color with some reddish (even purple) highlights.  Sugary, candy-like aroma with undertones of yeast, citrus, fresh fruits (blueberries, strawberries, grapes), and (strangely enough) grape-flavored candy.  Deep, complex flavors of malt, yeast, citrus, fresh fruits (pears, blueberries), spices (nutmeg, clove, coriander), molasses, and brown sugar.  A true gem.

A dark red beer with a thick beige head.
Sweet aroma with a complex taste.

341ml Bottle: My latest taste from this classic Canadian brewer, hopefully I enjoy it more than I did the Blanche de Chambly.  Pours a velvet black/red with a thick, rich head that never fully disappeared.  Complex aroma of raisins and cherries alongside your pick of alcohol or cough medicine; but in a good way.  Taste is also heavy on the complexity, and that makes this a journey worth traveling.  Hits dry as dry can be, melts into a tingle as it goes down.  More cherries, but raisins turn to grapes with an interesting blend of spices.  Port wine style tones with prevalent alcohol, but well hidden for a 9% brew.  This is a true conversation starter, and well worth the investment.

Deep, mahogany brown.  Head is white and fluffy, like a cloud.  Aroma is fruits, yeast, spice, and malts.  Flavor is malty, with the spice and a sweetness.  Tastes like, well, a Belgian. Very smooth on the tongue.  Excellent!

A nice deep brown color, with a fluffy white, dissipating head. Wonderful aroma of fruit and malt. The flavor is deep and dark, but not heavy, striking the right balance of fruit, malt, yeast, and some mild spices. The alcohol is well-hidden. Excellent.

An excellent selection. Hits all the belgian notes....strong fruity nose, sweet malty flavor, long finish.  Pretty mellow compared to most.  Very frothy on the pour but calmed down quickly.  Definitely one to pick up anytime for a good dinner or dessert beer.
Very nice dark brown body with a white-brown head. The taste is very well balanced with the malt and yeast. Touches of nuts, caramel and raisin. Also very sweet but not excessively.
Poured with a very small dissapating brown head. Deep fruity aromas and a smooth mouthfeel. Despite the 9% alcohol, the throat-warming is minimal, but doesnt seem masked by the deep flavour. amazing

I love this beer. It is intense and malty. I drink it in the bottle in Michigan and on tap at Zenos in State College. Americans need to wise up to this brewery across the border. Trois Pistoles is their best.

Great stuff. Pours a deep dark brown with a big head that fades rather quickly. Has that signature Belgian taste and aroma. Very malty and some mild spice. Seemed to have pretty big carbonation that lasted thru the whole glass. Very very nice.
A medium rare rib eye with vadalia onions and this beer .A match made in Heaven. 10pm on the deck!

(06.09.06) One pint, 9.4 oz brown bottle from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL. 9% ABV.  Bottled 2005. Bottle labeled at best before 6-28-08. Poured clear reddish dark brown with small off-white head. Average carbonation.  Spicy malt aroma. Medium bodied ale that starts dry with caramel/spicy (clove)/ fruity flavors. Some tanginess and sharpness (carbonation?) in the mouth.  Finished with light linger bitterness and tangy acidity. Complex flavor character.  A very good, drinkable ale.

Bottle: The bottle is gorgeous with the cork popping out like a bottle of champagne.  Very nice.  The color of the brew is a rich deep brown with little to no head.  It has a quite strong and complex aroma.  I picked up rotten hay, plastic desks, catholic highschool, strong spices, saddlesoap, ripe fruit and maybe some dust.  In some ways the aroma is very hefe-like.  The flavor is also noteable: cola, tangy ripe fruit (perhaps, plums?), bag balm ointment and other things I couldnt identify.  The carbonation is high and the drink is crisp initially, but has a smooth, soft finish.  I am not a big fan of Belgian Strong Ales but this one kept me interested and coming back for more.  It is more of a sipper.

Bottle Nose of plums, spices, and a little caramel; Transparent cherry-brown. with a large, long-lasting, lacing, tan head; Flavor of dark fruits and malts, with spices that provide the finish; cant hardly feel much alcohol.
UPDATED: OCT 26, 2006 Bottle. Dark and nice, strong and soft aroma, full body, strong lasting head, what a brew.

Bottle.. - Pours a nice dark dark brown with a very high carbonation that is apparent upon opening the bottle - Aroma is yeasty with fresh fruit and a hint of cloves - Flavor is fruity with a spicy alcohol warmth - The palate is very campange like...

Overall a nice full-bodied belgian ... what u would expect from Unibroue
Wonderful aroma of strong fruits.  Flavor covers up the strong alcohol content.  Amazing!

Stunning brown colour, very hazy, with orangy sides. Not much head, slightly beige. Powerful aroma with oranges, plums. VEry high carbonated with a champagne feel. Sweet, but with roasted malts as well as a powerful flavour of dried fruits, such as raisins, plums and suchlike. Not too vinious despite the 9 %. Some sweet spices as well, coriander and cinnamon. Stunning!

Terrific beer.  Pours nicely.  The most remarkable part of the beer is that it has an almost champagne-esque quality that contains a lot of bubbles that really make the beer flavor come alive on the palate and provides for an incredibly complex finish in taste that makes it almost additive.

On bottle best before date: 03-16-09. Consumed July 2006. Murky brown color with explosive tan head. Bubbled right out of bottle before I could even begin to pour. Aroma of sugar, yeast and maybe lime. Massive carbonation upon opening but now not so much. It is just about right. Flavor is sweet sugar, coriander, a bit of cinnamon, plums and raisins.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 12oz, Best Before 01-26-09.  Pours a dark red-brown with a huge fluffy light beige head.  Aroma is of brown sugar, caramel, yeast, banana, apples,figs--lots of fruits.  There is a cherry tartness addition in the taste.  Full bodied, moderate carbonation, some alcohol warmth, creamy mouthfeel, dry finish.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Bottle.  Lovely Beligian - only outdone by the Belgians, in my small experience.  Brown body with creamy lasting white head.  Malty, creamy flavor, sweet fruits abound.  Not quite as much sediment as others.  
Very tastey.

Very dark brown apperance with fizzy head.  Gone pretty quickly and with very little lacing.  Aroma is very fruity as I would expect.  Typical cherry, apples, red wine, and bread.  A lot of carbonation, which Ive come to expect from this brewery.  A bit of a shock to the tongue.  Good long finish.  A very good example.
Very smooth, pleasant aroma, great pour with a dark body and white head, overall one of the most enjoyable ales I have sampled.  A good sipping beer to enjoy over 20-30 minutes.
This Ale has a fantastic palate.  It does not have quite the flavor of some others but that hardly goes noticed due to the power of the palate.  Quite tasty!

Wow, this is a big beer done well.  Hugely crisp yet battering palate to this one -- reminds me of a barleywine strained through a bit of hops, enough to foul the tastebuds just enough to be delicious and not bitter.  Enjoyed, thoroughly, on tap at the Dirty Truth, Northampton, MA.

Poured dark, almost bloody red with frothy, white head.  Aroma of malt and pine with floral undertones.  Medium carbonation with light frothy retention.  Thick, carbonated texture with a slightly bittersweet bite.  Flavors of pine, raisons, malt and slightly bitter hops mingle well with a presence of alcohol.  The high content is masked well with the balanced flavor.  The lingering aftertaste is poignant and citrusy, while the malt undertone remains throughout.  This was my second Chambly sampling and Im looking forward to trying more!
Bottle. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Powerfull hoppy aroma, a little malty. OK flavorm, average finish. Very oily palate, but how can this rate over 4? its not that good.
Bottle. Brownish colour with a nice off white head. Aroma and taste of malts, fruits, suger and spices. Alcoholic finish.
Very nice, complex and sweet.  Its syrupy, but not overly sweet.  It has subtle malts, a nice backbone, and great alcohol presence.  Its well balenced, a nice brew overall, and nicely Canadian :)
Bottled at Lunar in July, 06. At this point my notes started getting a bit jumbled. Dark, with hints of plum (both on nose and in color). Fruity taste, hints of raisin. Not heavy, but filling. Good.

UPDATED: MAY 12, 2008 Almost opaque, but a ruby mocha pour with a large creamy tan head and great lacing. The nose is of plums, raisins, and possibly sweet raisin bread.  As the beer warms, dates/figs jump in there, too.  Very syrupy fruit flavors, like plums, raisins and prunes (dried out first), with a light peppering astringency. There is a slightly sour take on the fruits, as the hops are well-hidden.  It does have somewhat of a vinous aura about it, as the finish combines both red wine, alcohol, perfect carbonation and a light cream.  The nice aspect of this offering is that all of its parts unify and point "in the same direction."  Good job.

Pours dark purple/brown with a medium tan head.  Aroma is of vodka, raisins, prunes.  Flavor has less of an alochol taste but a lot of warmth.  Raisins and prunes dominate the flavor, but theres a taste of almost woodiness to it at the endand small hints of clove.  Not bitter at all really, but finishes with a hint of sourness.  Mouthfeel is wonderful, very smooth, but still full.

Dark brown with red highlights. Disappearing tan head. Aroma is sweet with notes of raisins, prunes, and alcohol. Full bodied, and port-like. Malt, dried fruit up front giving way to noticeable alcohol (but not too much). Dry down the center on the back end and smooth on the edges.

Had this one bottled at Lunar in Villa Park, Illinois.  Very dark purple pour, nearly black, completely opaque.  Nose of grapes, tastes of vodka, plum and raisin.  This one was very unusual and very good.
It has a malty sweetness on the palate that reminds me of dried fruits. Little to no hops on the aroma or in the mouthfeel but a nice fluffy head and perfect carbonation for the style.
UPDATED: AUG 15, 2006 A homeless mans blue chimay. Similar except  UTP is less dry, and more sweet and soapy. This style doesnt work too well for me.

Bottle: Dark brown hazy colour.Aroma of Vinous, and alc-sweetnes.
Sweet maltyness and lots of alcohol taste, and bitterness in the finish. Medium to full body.

From a 12 oz. twist cap long neck brown bottle with a short blurb, picture serving instructions and a best before date, 09/27/08, on the back label.

Made a good appearance, poured a dark brown with a foamy beige head that settled into a thin soapy lacing, the usual good, tight Unibroue carbonation.

Had a nose of tart grapes, vinous, with whiffs of grass, roasted malts and alcohol.

A crisp and carbonated smooth lightish medium bodied mouthfeel, good drinkability.

Nice port wine-like taste, softly spicy, a subtle roasted chocolate maltiness, a bit bready towards the end and a dryish malty finish. The alcohol when noticeable is spicy, provides a good warming feeling in the palate, but overall, is well masked.

Another good strong ale from Unibroue, tasty and balanced, quite quaffable.
