Black colour, with some ruby, light tan head, some slight lace. Spicy, plums, alcohol, port, berries, late summer fruit, then malt. Some slight carbonation on the tongue, with some more alcohol taste, some more plums. Finishes malty and bitter. A good, nice and complex ale, but not as great as Id thought. Thin in the mouth, heavy on the stomach.

A dark brown pour that is kind of red when held to the light.  Light tan head that goes quick. An aroma of spicy clove and malt. A flavor of clove and fruit. The flavor is really alive in this beer. The mouth feel is a little over carboanated for my taste. This beer is a pleasant change up from your usual ipa, apa, and stouts. I have 6 and will probably drink them all my greedy assed self.

Pours a dark reddish brown.  Aroma is definitely belgian style.  Taste and smell are very spicy.  Flavor of strong spiced fruit.  Reminds me of dark holiday spiced fruit.  Sweet and no hint of alcohol despite the 9% abv.  Good but not my cup of tea.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2006 The last of the bottles Sasquatch911 brought for me from Canada (thanks!)The appearance... Hmm. It has a lovely misty deep red colour with a nice, thick tan head. The aroma... Its a typical Belgian-style aroma; some random spice, orange and tangerine. Not as complex as I hoped, but still lovely... (Edit: Wrong temperature definitely... as this warmed down, it got a lot more complex, with notes of prosecco, grapes, sugar, an alcohol). The taste... Agrumes again, spices (coriander), some apricot on the edges, with a....flat maltiness (dont know how to express myself better..wood? Nah.), and maybe some raisins. A touch acidic. No trace of alcohol at first, but it develops  in the end. Feels like it should be having one more dimension, one that got lost somewhere. Didnt impress me as much as I hoped it would. Its a very nice beer, but this sample lacked the complexity I expected.

Medium low density head, remarkably even in its distribution. High impact nose filled with classic high ABV porty, stewed fruit notes, very Belgian like and very expressive. Plenty of depth in the mouth, again more porty, stewed notes, but done very well in the correct context.  Alcohol never intrudes despite the 9%. Balanced finish with good depth and drive.  Yet another very good beer from Unibrou.

Poured a cloudy deep reddish brown that almost appears balck.  It is capped by a huge light tan head that quickly collapses.  Aromas are fleeting but exceptional, Bittersweet chocolate covered cherries, caramelized raisins, a side note of green apples, and a slight menthol-like tingle of alcohol.  Flavors are just as deep and enjoyable.  A sweetness shines through and blends with the fruit flavors to create candied cherries, strawberries, and plums.  The flavors mellow out in the finish and leave a gentle sweetness that does not create the syrupy condition of some overly sweet beers.

The Trois Pistoles pours a very dark color with some burgundy highlights. The aroma was not good at all in my opinion. I thought it smelled musty, with a little bit of raisin coming through the must. The taste was intriguing however, and the mouthfeel was spot on. The flavors were a mix of alcohol, dark fruits, and maybe green raisins. This beer reminded me quite a bit of DFH Raison DEtre. Not bad, but seems a little overrated to me."
I have to say I think this is the best beer that Unibroue makes. What a rich malty and fruity flavor. Deep and rich, a nice beer to relax to at the end of the day.

UPDATED: JUL 27, 2006 On Draft @ Liars Club.  Yuuuuum.  This one is a dark, rich delicious beer.  Despite the color and overall look of the beer, its really actually quite light on the palate.  I like it.  Got all the great smells and tastes of a good belgian.  Just wonderful ale.
Bottle @ Ds 6 packs, PGH, PA. Pours red brown with tan head. Aroma is musty raisin malt. Flavor is raisins with cinnamon, coriander, cloves, and low wheat notes.

12oz bottle. Pours dark, almost black with a thick off-white head. Aroma of malt, yeast and wild berries. Fruity malty taste, and causes a warming sensation in my chest. Alcohol not noticeable in the palate however. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but not to the point of being a flaw. Lingering alcoholic and spicy finish. Good for almost any meal.

Chewy bubble gum aroma like a hefe with maybe some notes of caramel in there, but dominated by the gum.  Nice dark charcoal pour and very spritzy pillowy head (characteristic of Unibroue).  Very light flavor, not much alcohol present.  A little watery in the mouth.  An enjoyable beer, but not at all like port wine.  Whoever said that hasnt tasted port in their life.
Bottle. Amber brownish in colour with an off-white head. Roasted malt and caramel with a hint of berries. Too carbonated.

Aroma of ripe, dark fruit....mostly plums and grapes. Very carbonated taste at first, warms to a very tasty, thick bodied beer.  The alcohol becomes more noticeable late in the glass, and leads to a very warming finish. This is most definitely a beer that I could only enjoy sipping slowly, and one a night (Max), but a very good drinking experience.
Bottle.  Pours ruby-brown with beige head that disipates slowly.  Rich roasted caramel body.  Last sip is quite high in alcohol.
Very dark burgandy, thick slighty tan head.  Aroma is fragrant of dark berries.  Has a distinguished Belgium maltiness with a spicey licorice and a tart cranberry and plum like finish.
12 oz bottle.  Dark redish color, thick white head that lasts quite some time.  Strong belgian ale flavor that actually is quite sweet with a hint of berry.

Pours very dark brown with a bit of a reddish tint.  Thick pillowy off-white head.  Aroma has dark fruits, spice, earthy yeast and a rich malty sweetness.  Medium to full bodied beer.  Inital taste had dark fruits, spice and anise.  During the intial taste the carbonation feels fairly soft, but then a fizziness kicks in and wipes out the taste and leads the way for the finish.  The finish has more of a tart fruit flavor, spicy hops and earthy yeast.  A very nice Belgium dark beer.

A Pegasus of doom flies above a monastery or state capital building, looking nervously over its shoulder as if being pursued. I dont know what to make of this Magic: The Gathering artwork, and I wont know until I have finished this bottle. The line between pretentiousness and genius is razor thin, you see, and I can already tell that this beer is going to be either a work of art or pure wankery. 

Deep purple, very fizzy with a small head that goes away quickly. This is a strange, very pretty plum color.

Complex and welcoming smell. Fruity esters somewhere between tart apricots and mellow grapes. Cloves make their way in there, as well.

What a pop of flavor upfront! A mad rush of sweet and sour fruit balanced out with a bland sweetness. The finish is clean--almost too clean. Nice and dry, but the flavor doesnt linger at all. Still, this is a damn fine taste and, surprisingly enough, theres almost no trace of alcohol. 

Very fizzy, goes down nice.

This is one of those dark, wonderful ales that you should surprise guests with by serving at a party in lieu of wine. It would go great with red meat. And hell, you can get a 750 ml bottle of this for much less than a bottle of good wine--and this is better than good wine.

This poured beautifully. The head was pillowy tan and sat pretty the entire drink. The color was dark brown to black (somewhat stout-like). Richer than a dubel (but not to the level of a quad), this had a mouthfeel that was almost creamy. Aroma and flavor were spicey and fruity, which I didnt find to be all that distinguished from many of the Belgian ales out there (which isnt a bad thing).

Picked this one up earlier today. Dark as you can possibly get when it comes to color. Taste is full of fruits. Caramel and malts reign in this strong ale. Alcohol is bearly noticeable.  Thought it would be rated a little bit higher than it actually is. Didnt think it was that carbonated. Palate was very enjoyable. Surprisingly smooth for being as complexed as it is.
This brown ale poured with a fluffy tan head. The mouthfeel is chewy and the flavor is indeed port-like and fruity with a long malty finish. Goes well with a good cigar.

Unibroue Trois Pistoles.  Corked bottle.  16 June 2005. 
Light brown (why do I remember this being darker?), with an almost immediately vanishing head.  A hint of vinegar upon opening, but not offputting.  So fruity - love this.  One of my earliest Unibroues, and still one of my favorites.
Overall great beer, deserves its high ratings.  Not quite as good as one would expect from a 99 rating but darn good.

I wonder what this would taste like from tap! To have bottles shipped all over in the heat and cold and still sell in macro cuantities a strong ale from Canada is a masterfull feat. It sinks into the the glass a brown caramel color with an overflowing brown head, that does go away and leaves little traces on the sides of the tulip. (the younger cousin fin du monde has better body and head). It smells of Belgium Beet Candy, Plums, asparagus, caramel and spices. The buttery body leaves a slightly oily and creamy palate to savor this very sweet brew of cloves, cinamon, dried strawberries, plums and a whole world of backbone chiling flavors that last forever on the throat. Like a Fine Port it warms the body and leaves you wanting more. I could say this is the best of the Macros ived tasted yet. Salud!

I bought this to be used in a pork roast it tasted marvelous. Aroma was very fruity, probably plums and figs. Flavor was also very fruity and felt highly carbonated in my mouth. A great belgian but i think i like terrible a little better.
malty, but fruity at the same time, slightly sweet with a hint of spice.  I just love when the cork hits the ceiling when I let it go :)
Bottle, 330 ml. Thick, light brown head, hazy dark brown colour. Complex aroma, berries, figs, plums and a tone of yoghurt. Sweet taste with dark fruits and hints of alcohol. A nice & smooth beer.

This beer pours a dark amber pretty much black color with a thin tan head leaving no lacing down the sides.  It has a very sweet floraly smell(ginger?)!  I like that!  Taste very sweet, like licorice.  You dont taste the 9% abv.  Very sweet and smooth beer!  A great beer from a great brewer.  Cheers! ps.  my 100th beer!!  yay!!

Gravity defying head on top of opaque ruby color. Then your at the Thanksgiving day kiddie table with your Aunt Elma pushing the mince meat pie your way. Which is to say, Im getting a huge raison clove allspice rush. I hate mince meat pie. I love this beer. Little dryness somewhere in the finish. My apologies to Aunt Elma,where ever you are.

From a 12 oz bottle.

Pours dark with a vigorous head; the aroma is dates and dark caramel and wood with a hint of yeast and mulling spices. 

Frankly, I dont understand the full magnitude of the hype surrounding this beer. Its a very nice beer, I agree, but comparing this head to head with other dark belgian ales I dont pick up nearly the complexity that some describe in this particullar attempt at the style. 

Instead, weve got a relatively sweet, relatively smooth-drinking dark Belgian ale; the flavor is dried fruits and the molassay part of molassas (as opposed to the sweet part of molassas) coming in relatively late in the flavor profile. Again compared with other dark Belgian ales of comparable strength, the alcohol is hidden as if by alchemy. 

This is a perfectly nice beer, and a very drinkable beer, but for me it falls just  short of the stand-out reputation that goes before it.

750ml bottle
Pours cola-brown with a quickly disappearing ample head.  Smells musty and moldy with some fruit as well.  And yeast.  Nice smooth flavor with no bitterness.
Bottle. Dark brown colour with an off-white head. Mild roasted chocolate and yeast aroma.Flavour is roasted chocolate mixed with elements of fruitiness and hops.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 Bottled. 33cl. Dark, reddish-brown, with an off-white head. Candi-sweetness, caramell, blackcurrant and dried fruits (figs?) in the aroma. The flavor is lightly roasted, with a gorgeous candi-sweet fruitiness and some hops. Light dusty in the mouth, yet with a fizzyness. The finish is sweet and bitterdry with the alcohol shining though. A very good and balanced beer. (060422)

Bottle -- Hazy dark brown in color with very thick, foamy head.  Bready malt and slight fruit aroma.  Tastes of raisins and bittersweet cherries.  Pretty smooth for such a high alcohol beer.  Overall, very good beer but not something I will reach for often.

Poured from the bottle into a tulip glass, this beer develops a lasting light brown head on top of a slightly hazy dark brown body.  Very pretty!  This gem develops a rich sweet aroma of dark fruits (Im thinking of plumbs, specifically).  I cant exactly put my finger on it, but both the aroma and flavor are unmistakably "Belgian" in character.  A very smooth beer, considering the strong abv.
A realy nice beer with a  thin head and high  carbonation. Good tast hint of fruit and nice palate

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2009 This is a rather interesting beer, pours with a fairly thin head and has what could be described as a rich black berry, alcohol and raisiny aroma. The flavours reinforce the aroma of alcoholic stewed fruits and dark roasted malts. The flavours are clean and well defined and is a very good technical beer

re:rate - My rating has improved, this time i notice the black fruit a lot more and the alcohol a lot less.
750.  Pours a dark brown with ruby highlights.  High carbonation. Aroma is of fruit and roasted malt.  Taste is of dark fruit, roasted malt with a smooth, slightly sweet finish.  wow, this was good.

Bottled.  This pours a dark brown with a fizzy light brown head that really releases the aroma of this beer, which is a compelling combination of fruity and a roasty malt aroma.  This is a medium body ale that goes down smooth with a fruity roasty taste that ends sweet with a hint of spice that pops at the tip of the tongue.  Another big win for Unibroue in my book.  Excellent beer.

Hmmmm . . . this is a hard one to peg.  One sip . . . I like it.  Two sips . . . Do I?  Three sips . . . I think so.  Four sips . . . maybe not.  Five sips . . . Maybe its kind of off.  Six sips . . . now, hold on, I think I do like this.  Seven sips . . . Dont I.  Eight sips . . . Im not sure.

Poured dark amber/brown.  Looks intriguing.  Strong alcohol and malts (and roasted fruit?!) in the nose.  Unique and strong taste which somehow reminded me of barleywine.  Which I cant figure out if I like or not.  Strong palate, odd flavor.  Intriguing yet repelling at the same time.  Kind of like a car crash.  Yeah, maybe thats what this is - some sort of spectacularly wild car crash in your mouth.  Its kind of cool, but you know you shouldnt like it.  Yeah - thats what it is.

UPDATED: AUG 23, 2007 Pours like a beer, drinks like a wine.  Nice addition of the vintage to the cork topper.  Rich, thick flavor with a big blast of alcohol at the front, which subsides with later sips.  Great variety in the palate, less appeal in the flavor.

Foam white on top of a dark burgundy that offers a sweet nose of raisin, wheat, and oak. Palate is a bit thinner than expected and highly carbonated. Flavor is rich, chewy malts that ends port-like and dry. Solid, impressive, and enjoyable it is definitely worth having. I was, however, put off a bit by the carbonation and the monotone impact of the malts.

On tap at the Brick Store Pub on 04/15/06 and of course served in the appropriate glass.  0.3L 9%ABV for $5.  This guy showed up a dark brown with a little amber color if held up to a bright light.  It had a spicy peppery aroma.  The taste was very complex with a clove dominance and a little chocolate if bounced around on the palate.  More of a late fall to winter beer to me, but very good.
A very dark brown beer with a sour bitter taste. The after taste is very diiferent because you have a sweet feeling in your mouth.
12 oz bottle.  Lively carbonated chestnut colored w/ a substantial frothy white head.  My personal fav from unibroues catalogue.  Suprisingly refreshing for its 9% abv.
poured a dark black color with a thick dirty white colored head which thins out but still very carbonated. has a very strong rippened fruit tast and smell. good with a meal but not in large amounts.

12oz bottle. Dark brown with tan head. Huge nose, with aromas of various dark fruit, black cherry, molasses, smoke, rotting apples, woodsy notes, and yeast. Flavor is nicely balanced between sweet, sour,  and bitter, focusing on a dark-fruit sweetness and dryness, with a present alcohol warmth and yeast bite throughout. High carbonation helps smooth out the sweetness and contributes to a quick, dry finish. Very tasty stuff!

Fascinating deep brown, ruby/amber beer with a soft, light head.  Aromas are caramel, wine, cherry, plum, fig and other dark stone fruits with light yeast and lemonade in the background.  Full, long and deep palate.  A little vinuous.  The roasted malts provide a ton of structure to this beer.  Very good Belgian strong hides its alcohol well.  Still, fruit sets this beer apart from its peers, especially on the finish.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark murky sandy brown color with a thick beige creamy head.  Aroma is of rich spices, figs, nutmeg, freshly toasted bread,bananas and malts.  Flavor is spicy with hints of nutmeg,banana,figs,yeast and other ripe fruits.  Excellent overall !!

My 12 oz bottle was a big-time gusher, foaming all over the table. Once things settled down, it was a deep carmel, almost black in the right light, with a cap of fine tan head. Dry, spicy rye cracker aroma, with grape skins and maple syrup. Flavor is lively and spicy, with toasty bready flavors a little reminicent of fresh cornbread. Substantial sweetness up front, but a bone dry finish, with just a little lingering yeast flavor. A very flavorful and rich beer. My first from Unibroue, and it was a great first impression.

bottle.. caramel colored pour , little cloudy. big white to off white head with a great lace. nose of yeast and bananas . excellent dark fruit and malt  flavor. dry finish ,good medium body .even better as it warms some .
Bottle. Pours a dark amber colour with an big off-white head. Yeasty, fruity aroma with some hints of alcohol. Yeasty flavor with some fruitiness and some spicy hints. Spicy warming aftertaste.

12 oz bottle

The last Unibroue bottle in the fridge - having worked my way through I decided to save the best for last.  Three sniffs revealed three facets - first peppers and spice, then chocolate and licorice, ending with hints of apples and pears.  The opaque caramel colored body had a slight head that soon dissapated.  My first impression upon taking a sip was of chocolate dipped bananas blended with caramel dipped Granny Smith apples.  Extremely full bodied, later sips reminded me of the spicy heritage of most Unibroue beers.  I was detecting a distinct peppery taste.  Fortunately it soon faded leaving behind just a weak reminder of the experience.  The only weakness of this brew is that finish which fades too soon and leaves little trace.

This is one of those beers that you feel obliged to give a good rating, though its difficult to drink.  Tastes wonderful with fruity undertones amidst the darkness of this brew.  Very pretty in the glass, with an amber head and lacing.  Its just sooo strong.  I did drink the whole bottle myself, but that was only about three glasses.  Very similar to Port wine, this one will knock you out, but its wonderfully complex and enjoyable.
UPDATED: AUG 23, 2006 it taste more like over ripe bannas and dried fruit than ripe fruit. it is very sublte it says like a port wine i figured more like a sherry not bad

From 750mL bottle.  Pours a deep, dark brown with ample tan head.  Nose is doughy, with brown sugar, dark fruits and some hints of pear and apple.  Flavor is complex, dark and smooth, following the nose with the pear adding to a dry finish.  Excellent.

Aroma of prunes, sugar cane, berries, earth.  Appearance of a deep cup of coffee with a smooth, slowly receding khaki head, like drinking a pair of dockers pants.  Quite dry.  Some really nice berry tartness, a touch of bready malt.  Mild Belgian spiciness.  Easily the most complex, most outstanding Unibroue beer.
UPDATED: FEB 21, 2009 Yet another winner from Unibroue.  Nose is full of dark fruits, delicious.  One of the best strong ales around IMHO.
Bottle.  Dark pour with a thick off-white head.  Plums, raisins, cherries, prunes, figs, molasses and other dark fruits not yet discovered.  Finishes sweet.

12 oz bottle poured a dark brown with a thick foamy head.  Malty aroma with lots of fruit notes.  Lots of fruit in the flavor as well, prune, raisin and a hint of lemon.  Good roasted malt flavor as well, with a warming alcohol finish. 
A very good beer, and at $2.39 a bottle, a good deal too!

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 Draught and bottle at various times. Pours a dark brown-black with moderate beige head. Aroma is blackcurrant initially, plus spices, yeast, and caramel. Flavor is quite bold, with a semi-sweet, semi-tart blackcurrant, spice, yeast, and malt character. Somewhat sharp and carbonated palate. Rather unusual, and quite good.
Unibroue is quickly becoming my favorite brewery, and this is definitely one of the reasons why.  Fruity and full of mellow malt.

25.4 oz bottle.  2005.  Cloudy very dark brown body with a small off-white head that dissipates quickly.  Aroma of dark ripe fruits and English steamed puddings.  Flavor is complex and balanced.  The dark fruit and pudding breadiness lead, but I tasted some wheat and caramel as well.  Body is full but seems slightly more carbonated than necessary.

12oz bottle:  This pours out a dark, mahogany color.  There was somewhat of a tan head, but it doesnt last long.  The aroma contains many of the dark fruits that are indicative of this style.  Also a touch of breadiness and yeastiness.  The taste is very smooth.  It is full bodied, yet the individual tastes are quite subdued.  They all blend together to form something quite nice.  A definite keeper.  Dont mess with this beer, Sleeman!!

Pours a dark brown with a large, frothy tan head.  Huge aroma of dark fruits - fig, raisin, plum, black cherry, and pear.  There is also a spicy aroma with cinnamon raisin bread.  The flavor is a pretty good impersonation of a belgian quad, but its just not quite as complex.  There are some wonderful ripe fruit flavors that almost make up for the lack of complexity.  However, the texture is thin.  Overall, this is a good belgian coming from a Canadian brewery.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2007 Hazy dark brown, like burnt honey. Massive fluffy head. Thick aromas of dried figgy/plummy fruits, sweet spice, and raisin bread. Sweet palate, heavy mouthfeel, lots of complex flavours backed up by a warm alcohol finish. This was better the second time around.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Brown, with a little golden and red behind, fast disappearing light brown head; Very nice nose, a lot fresher then expected, it actually has a little aged Flemish Sour Ale character, the nose isnt  huge, but it is great. Behind the fresh sourness it has warmer notes of dried fruit like raisins and fig; The body is very well balanced, a little oily and quite small/thin; The finish is warm, a little sour and quite watery, despite its thin character it last very, very long.  From reading other ratings, I am not sure that my beer is not broken , it doesnt taste anywhere near an old Port Wine either (it was still good though).
750 ml-Nice dark color which is deceiving. One might think it would be very srong,yet very easy to drink. Strong spices present with hints of licorice and cinnamon. Another great beer from Unibroue.

Bottled.  Great looking, hazy brown color with a marvelous tan head.  Ultra yeasty aroma dripping with overripe pear.  Mildy sweet cinnimon sugars coat the tongue in an almost unexected turbulent manner.  Slighly thin texture overall, but extra rich flavors make up for this minor deficiency.  Fairly typical dark ripe fruits of raisin and plum, but the yeastiness of this brew is what really gives it a unique signature.  Quite tasty, and only a hint of the 9% shines through on the palate.  Smack of light prune.

This beer offers a crisp aroma of berries and fruit.  It is a mahogany colored solution with a decent sized cashew head that dissolves rather quickly.  This beers crisp aroma deceives the taste buds suggesting the beer is lighter in texture than it really is.  This beer is dry and mildly bitter as it flows through the mouth.  The fruity flavor resembles that a mild port wine except for the hint of wheat that creeps in at the end.

2005 Bottle. Awesome, Awesome strong Belgian!!! The aroma hits you right away, not over powering and not lite. Slow pour brings a dark brown color with a lot of tastey head. Great flavor, gets better with every sip. Palate stays with you for awhile . A must try. Cheers Canada!

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2006 I had no idea what to expect when I picked this up.. Pours very dark with a small tan head.  Aroma is very fruity, I think I smell apple.  Flavor is malty and very fruity, but well balanced. Very very good tasting.  This is up there with some of the best Belgians.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2006 Black coffee in color, medium headw/ beachball size bubbles. Sweet malty nose. Medium nectar w/ a defined sweet character with coffee and rootbeer flavors. Alcohol flavors persist to the finish. Overall; a descent brew that tastes like rootbeer.

a dark murky ruby that is almost black.  small off white head.  dark sugary fruits, candy, yeast, and licorice.  certainly mellow as there is no sharp carbonation or alcohol bite.  everything seems to mend well together in this one.

Bottle. Yeast and metallic scents. LOTS of head, was overflowing as soon as I took the cap off. Whole lots of complex flavors - peach, orange, summer sausage, dried apricots stand out the most. A pretty heavy beer but very drinkable. And for being so dark I could see myself drinking this in the summer time. Great beer!

Unibroue makes some great beers and this is one of them.  The super sweet aroma crossed with the  intense bottle and the promise of 9% alcohol can make this beer pretty intimidating.  I like this beer and it is really nicely complex, but when beers get this sweet and boozy it can be a bit much for me.  Not my favourite, but a very well made beer.

On-Tap, Sharp Edge, Pgh, PA

Murky brown with fluffy white head. Aroma of faint fruits, yeast, and candy. Flavor was all light fruit goodness with some sweetness. Notes of plums, dark fruits, apples, bananas, pineapple toffee, and caramel. All nicely balanced. Alcohol is well hidden not noticeable at all. Very smooth, light bodied. Velvety mouthfeel. This quickly became a favorite.

Bottle poured a clear dark reddish brown with a large lasting amber head. Aromas of plums, raisins, carmel and hint of brown sugar. Palate was medium bodied and smooth. Flavors of pineapple,toffee, dark fruit and pepper with a sweet, warming finish.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2011 In a La fin du monde glass. Dark brown with an éphémère beige head. The aroma is fruity with hints of caramel and alcohol. Taste of raisins, caramel, pineapple. Quite sweet but well balanced. One of my favourite Unibroue beer.

Excellent slightly fruity pungent bev!  Smells like apples, bananas, and pineapples over a musty background.  Pours very dark brown with thick long lived head.  Tastes like a sharp barleywine with apple, pineapple, banana overtones.  Best canadian beer ive ever tasted!

Dark brown beer with a short lived off-white head. Unusual aroma of dried fruit, apples, port and ... seaweed?
Quite sweet flavour, but well balanced with bitterness and sharp alcohol (in a pleasant way.

Musty peat aromas mingle with apple sweetness over a body that is dark brown with a slight reddish coloration.  Head is huge... I think at one point I had six inches of foam to one inch of brown liquid, but it dies down leaving some nice lacing.  Flavor is interesting... quite sweet with some plum/apple sweetness in the background that occassionally overpowers the grainy-earthy-wood body.  Alcoholic content is nicely disguised and doesnt distract from the flavors, in spite of the massive 9% punch that it packs.  Body is a little thinner than I expected, but still nice and pleasantly mild.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
Pours a nice mahogany with a medium foamy off white head that stays put.
Aroma is fruity plum and alcohol spice.
Flavours of molasses, caramel alchohol sweetness, deep ripe fruit/ruby port.
Smooth and easy sipping.

Shared this one with my family at my nieces 21st birthday party, and it was well received by everyone. An absolutely beautiful pour with an incredible purple/burgandy color. Aroma had notes of plums, raisins, figs, caramel...just really really complex and interesting. Flavor had the same profile as the nose but also had some roastyness and a creamyness that was really impressive. Loved the brew and love the brewery!

Tasted 04/02/2006.  330ml bottle from Rumbles, Wellington.
Dark-brown, copper-hued in the light, with a lasting light-tan head and an effervescent look.  Nose is very spicey with loads chocolate, wheat, apricot and some winey character.  Flavour is big and bold - sweet chewy malts with lots of chocolate in the middle, almost liquer-like, and a port and cognac hints in the finish.  A bit too sweet for me.  Lingering aftertaste is woody, spicey and warmingly alcoholic.  Medium body, effervescent and a touch hot from the high alcohol content.  A very well-made and interesting beer that didnt quite grab me as much as it has everyone else.
Bottle.  Interesting aroma with hops and an bit if oak. A rather plain looking head with a nice uniform size of foam. Dark and clear. Tastes very much like a Belgian ale with a nice lingering tang.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text:
341 ml Bottle, 9% a/v

First of all, GORGEOUS bottle. Good work unibroue. 
Pours a thick and cloudy ruby red/brown color with a large brown head. Nose of fruit, particularly plums, apricots and raisins, with a hint of spice. Tastes quite spicy, with an aftertaste which is a little too sweet and fruity for me. Definetly a cloying aftertaste. 
Not a bad beer but far too fruity for my tastes.

Very high quality beer from this great brewery.  Dried fruit/prune/date/spice/raisin/caramel/toffee/and licorice.   Very sticky palate, almost cloying...no, not almost...it is cloying.   But I still enjoyed the lingering finish immensely.

330 ml bottle. Reddish black. Thick fine laced head. Marzipan and apricot aroma. Some apple aroma. Sweetness in the nose. Oily texture. Marzipan on the palate. Roasted, soft, malts. Some hoppy notes that lingers on the tongue. Well rounded.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2008 bottle. This pours a rick dark mahogany with a  lighter head. The aroma is deep of plums, cloves, and many other vinous notes. Theres a sticky fig sweetness, cinnamon, some dry twigs, and ample complexity. 


[Aug 2, 07]

 Had this once again on draught. Its a very solid take on the style which I often crave and feel comfortable recommending to anyone. It has the moderate dryness and vinous character in a soft presentation like a solid quad with plenty of yeasty, fruity notes with hints of licorice, bread, bubblegum, chocolate,  banana, cloves, and more. Very good.

[may 31, 2008]

Small bottle. Pours a cloudy, murky brown. The aroma has lots of sweet toffee, molasses, tobacco, and very light spices. This is malt heavy with prickly carbonation. This is more one-dimensional that I remember. Not much in the way of esters is noted. Some very light peat, fruits, and toffee are hinted at. Drinkable enough. I need to visit this again a few more times.
Bottle 750ml. Appearance:  dark brown with a tan head. Aroma: fruity, sweet. Flavor: spice, caramel malt,  sweet fruit.
Bottle. Pours dark, cloudy, and slightly thicker than water, with large, bubbly tan head. Fruity, alcohol alroma. Flavor is similar, with lots of sweet fruits, alcohol, molasses, and coppery malts.

Bottle. Pours slightly hazy brown with a full light tan head that lasts nicely and cover the glass very well. Fruity oakish aroma. Medium full body and complex flavors of caramel malt, fruits, and spice. The alcohol is strong, but not a dominant feature. Almost too many flavors.

Slightly hazy brown under a full light tan head that lasts nicely. Fruity aromas as advertised. Medium full body and complex flavors of caramel, dark fruits, clove, and peppery spice. The alcohol is obviously a presence, but not a dominant feature. Almost too many flavors to adequately identify or describe. Not at all bitter, but not sickeningly sweet. A wonderful, easy to drink beer.
SUBLIME. Le petit Chamblyen que je suis ne pourrait être plus fière de la marque Unibroue (basée à Chambly) pour avoir brassé une boisson comme celle-ci. DÉLICIEUSE.

AHH! la couleur goudroneuse de la trois-pistoles (nom dune ville québécoise) est relégué en strapontin dégustatif dès la première gorgé, suplanté par son gout dune coriacité incomparable et....traitre

The bottle pours a clear deep garnet beverage with a medium sized light tan creamy head that lasted throughout sampling and it left beautiful lacing on the glass. The aroma was wonderfully complex with loads of sweet maltiness, notes of pepper, dried cherries, raisins and caramel. The body was full with smooth carbonation and a smooth creamy texture with a light alcohol warmth. The flavor started off sweet and continued sweet throughout the long finish.
2004: Poured a dark brown (coffee) with a creamy head.  Fruity aroma with a hint of chocolate.  Slightly carbonated.  Taste of apple, other fruits, and caramel.  A very good occasional beer.

Pours a dark brown that will show light through. Tan head fizzles then spreads out. Nose is fruity and sweet, very common with unibroue. Flavor is fruity and acidic, with plenty of carbonation. Subtle as usual with unibroue, the devil is in the details indeed.
I will drink more of this beer.  A dark amber pour with an off-white head. A very smooth and drinkable beer.  This is another one that a six-pack could disappear before you knew it.
Drove this home from Indiana.  Oh so lovely.  Deep rich dark-coffee color, winey-molasses aroma, fruity malt flavor with layers and depth--toffee, raisin, chocolate, toast.  One of my favorites.

This beer is simply perfect. A chocolate aroma, a great black appearance and a creamy and fruit flavor. This beer hide really well the 9%...the best product out of Quebec Province...and surelly one of the best in the world.
Aroma of toast and leaves.  Very dark mahogony apearance.  Small to medium bubbles in head.  Flavor is yeast, molasses and caramel. Very active carbonation.  With sweet short finish.

Dark amber or brown with a big off white head.  Aroma of yeast and a good bit of fruit (I cant pinpoint which fruit exactly). Very nice.  Flavor is yeast, caramel malt, some fruit but less than in the aroma.  A wonderful Belgian.

First impression is vinous/winey/acidic/tart.  Roasted malt is apparent, but dryness persists.  Large range of fruit flavors including apple, plum, cherry, apricot.  Alcohol presence, but not overbearing.  Shows up more as it warms.  One flaw is the high level of sharp carbonation.  This reminds me of a much better version of Chimay Blue.  I wouldnt call this a great beer, but it is very very good.
I  will drink more of this beer. Rich brown color a little cloudy. carbonation just right for me. Smooth taste it is a drinkable beer in spite of the 9% alchohol. Carmel, sweet citrus taste.
"Wow what a beer poured a dark brown color with a huge fluffy head which lasted most of the beer. Felt very very creamy aroma was of fruits (plums?). overall very nice."

2005 12 oz bottle. Enjoyed with good friend Randy, not on RB. Pours a decent color. Way too much carbonation, however. On the nose and palate theres a lot of plum, clove, and nutmeg, with some banana and a bit of brown sugar sweetness. Somewhat thin of palate. Tasty, but nothing overwhelming.

750mL bottle, 2004 on bottle, 4-5 on cork: Pours a dark brown, almost black, small light brown head, diminishing.  Aroma of hops, sweet, molasses, citrus.  Taste of molasses, heavy body, slight coffee, plum.  Tasty.
UPDATED: MAR 3, 2007 Superbe bière, riche, saveur un sucré avec un goût de malt roti délicieux. Une bière dapéro dexellance.

12oz Bottle - This pours a very dark brown with a slightly murky look to it, with a huge creamy tan head. Lacing is minimal. Aroma is full of sweet malt & yeast with strong nuances of dark fruit. Flavor is nicely complex, with nuances of black cherry, figs, rasins, apricot and semi-sweet malt. Mouthfeel is rich and silky. Aftertaste is long and smooth, with the hops & alcohol becoming noticeable. This is a very nice beer. I plan to pick up a few more to to cellar and enjoy over the next four or five years.

The 12 ounce bottle, labeled Best Before 07-13-08, pours dark amber in color, with a huge tan head that leaves good lacing.  The nose features a rich aroma of floral hops and dark, dried fruit.  An intense and saccharine roasted malt backbone yields to mid-palate fruit ester flavors of plum, raisin and ripe banana; orange citrus notes are also quite evident.  The hop balance is appropriate and a warming alcohol sensation contributes to the drying and long-lasting finish and the advertised port wine comparison.  Very Good.
This is an excellent BSA.  Tastes like a not so good st. bernardus.  Lots of alcohol and  some fruit and flowers.  The heads on the unibroues are truly amazing as well.

UPDATED: JAN 11, 2006 Bottle.  Pours a very dark brown mahogany with a huge quick fading soapy white head.  Aroma is soap-like, sweet with strong fruit and floral notes.  Flavor is of sweet oranges, citrus, some floral/viney notes.  Finish is warming with alcohol.  Carbonated bubbly mouthfeel that finishes smooth on the palate.
Dark color with a nice head and glaze.  Very interesting taste.  Full bodied bitter and metallic from the alcohol.  A little fizzy but a great beer.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2006 Interesting smell.  Smells like cereal...coco puffs maybe, like I used to eat in the morning at the Tar Heel basketball school.  Also floral notes.  Appearance is black w/ a thick foamy off-white head.  Very fizzy, medium body.  Flavor is slightly metalic.  Fruity, floral, smooth.  The alcohol comes through significantly in this tasting.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2006 [bottle; re-rate] Pours an amazing, dark amber color, with a light head. Aroma is huge fruits and mild spices and yeast. Flavors are smooth and extremely complex. Oily, almost fizzy mouthfeel and a super-long aftertaste. This beer is intense.

UPDATED: JAN 10, 2006 Huge red wine taste, very fruity.  Took me a while to finish.  Some serious alcohol content in this one.  My bottles seemed to have been a little old, yet it still tasted very good.  It felt odd after drinking, it felt heavy in me.  Enjoyable to drink, though it was hard to follow with much else other than a glass of water.

A thick tan head sits atop a dark hazy maroon color.  The heffe-like aroma with fruity and slightly malty notes.  Bits of grape and sweetness with a trace of malt as well.  The strangest part of the taste reminds me of... blood.  Im dead serious.  I dont mean it in a bad way, but mine has a trace of blood in the taste.  This one will be tried again.

12 oz bottle: another staple from the boys (and gals...gotta be PC) at unibroue. very fruity aftertaste as it mentions on the label. wouldnt say it goes as far or as sweet as port and for that i am thankful!  yummers.
Cloudy dark brown with diminishing tan head.  Smells and tastes of fruit, malt, and slightly of alcohol.  Great beer.

Dark reddish brown pour with appealing thick, creamy tan head. Sweet aroma with fruit notes of raisin and ripe plums and spice notes of ginger and coriander. Alcohol comes through in the nose as well. Multi-layered flavors of sweet orange and apricot, ginger, sugar, clove. Lingering finish with nice touch of alcohol warmth. Thick, firm mouthfeel but  carbonation keeps it from becoming too sticky. Well-crafted, complex strong ale.

Bottle. Pours tea or coffee brown, with a very thin head. No lacing with my sample. Strong alcohol in the aroma, along with dried fruit and sweet malt in the background. Sweet (but not overpowering), with notes of raisens, plums, and a touch of alcohol. Finish is acidic and sweet, but crisp. Lingers nicely, but not too heavy. I may come back an re rate this, and I am currently developing my palate for Belgian style ales.

The Unibroue sampler case only has 6 of these so hmmmmmm. It has an interesting pour of brownish melded with buttery tones. A complex fruity aroma of dark fruits breaks through despite my week long cold. The flavor is somewhat like port with the cherryish prune flavor and alcohol kick but if you like port as much as I do, stick with it for its alcohol content. As far as this beer is concerned, enjoy its fruity mix and the way its effervescent mouthfeel approaches your lips and tongue.

(Bottle 34,1 cl) Unclear brownish with a thick, creamy, beige head leaving a nice lacework in my glass. Vinous, port-like aroma with very evident alcohol. Lovely, full body with plenty of roasted malt. Quite fruity notes - dried fruits as raisins, dates and prunes - and also overripe plums and apricots. The flavour is sweetish but never cloying. The alcohol is warming but never overpowering. Has to be one of the best Trappist-style beers produced outside of Belgium. 281205

Brickskeller, Washington DC.  Very nice beer, lemon zesty, celebratory.  Fun.  A better selection from this brewery.  Want to know the story behind the label however.  Sidenote:  this does not taste like port wine.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2006 12 oz bottle - Excellent beer.  It pours a hazy dark brown with a huge, rapidly fading head.  Aroma has yeast notes and is also very fruity, enough so that I feared it would taste too sour for me.   Not so.  The flavor is sweet, fruity as expected, but also well balanced.  I didnt detect much bitterness.  Finish is surprisingly smooth with that warming 9% alcohol well hidden.  This is a really excellent beer.   Ill definitely look for other Unibroue brews.

Bottle.  Apple/banana malt aroma.  Orange brown color with ample head.  Slightly sweet cider flavor with a mild hops finish.  Mild carbonation and moderate acidity.  Well blended.  Spectacular -  has saison qualities.  Easy drinking - a great beer.
Yet another winner provided by MrManning. Cloudy, deep brown, decent off white head. Yeasty, fruity nose, light carbonation. Somewhat sweet, fruit and malt flavors. Very nice. Thanks Len!

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2006 Pours a very dark brown color, fully sedimented, cloudy beer with a huge beige and creamy head that shows good retention and leaves a great lacing with a thin film over the body. Aroma is powerfully malty and yeasty, very spicy with notes of ripe fruits, caramel, orange, red wine and coriander being very complex as other Unibroue beers. Strong initial attack in the flavor, sweet and spicy as the aroma showing hints of brown sugar, red wine, orange and a little of coffee in great harmony. Big sweetness in the middle, ending with a more bitter character that leaves a good aftertaste. The mouthfeel is powerful but mellow disguising very well the 9% ABV which makes it dangerous. The body is thick and well rounded and shows and oily texture. Perfect amount of carbonation and long finish. It has a warming effect. Absolutely wonderful. A gem!.

Thick Foamy head, fruity aroma, almost too sweet smelling.  Thick foamy palate evolves into a smooth drinking swallow.  True to the aroma fruityness is first on the tounge, malt soon follows, finishing with a smoky slightly acidic finish.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2006 Reminiscent of a nice fruty sangria, with malt, it does indeed have a port aftertaste.  Dont know if this is aged in oak barrels, but I feel like I can taste smoky wood.  Tastes like one of the best and most unique beers I can imagine.  Smells like ripe (almost overripe) exotic fruit and wine.  The palate is thick and extremely complex.  Long, wonderful dry finish.  Clearly a winner, a favorite.
White head on a deep earthy dark brown body. Complex malty aroma.  Sweet body finishing on lots of alcohol.

A nice thick white head when poured.   The aroma is of cirtus and lemons.  A very dark brown body with some cloudiness.  Ripe dark fruits dominate the taste of this beer, though there is some elements of muskiness.  Nice mellow ending, another winner from Unibroue.

A lot of fruit on the nose.  Pours dark as night.  Not sure about the Port references as I love good port.  But for a beer this is good.  Slight raisiny quality on the palate.  Any more might be too much.
Very, very good.  Fruity essences, and some wheat flavor as well.  Very unusual, highly carbonated.  Rich, yet bright and crisp.  Definitely one of the best beers Ive had.
This was a an excellent brew.  Aroma was smiliar to a raison smell.  Flavor was a good cinnamon/ spice.  Alcohol well hidden, and very smooth to boot.

bottle, from RSVP. pours black with some hints of brown. great head that never fully disapates, fruity aroma. taste of grapes, raisins and fig and stuff like that. sweet, but not overwelming. feels thick in the mouth. goes down smooth. gets u warm in the belly. good stuff

Bottle, from Julios. 2005 vintage, Best by 08/09/08.  Good nose, fruity spicy. Cherry, plum/raisin. Lite sherry. Corriander.  1st pour was clean with good head, 2cd pour slight haze, third pour cloudy. Nice lacing too.  Bitter spiced flavors, like aroma, has a balsa wood too. Medium body, creamy oily mouthfeel, bitter fruit finish. Still hot, not that much though. This one has grown on me over the years. Warms up nicely.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: murky dark brown body with small off-white head...aroma is full of spices, dark fruits, prune, and raison....flavor is very similar with sugary kick and a whit beer afternote....great palate
Absolutely wonderful.  Somewhat fizzier than other beers but extremely reminiscent of belgian brews, and from CANADA?  Love it!

Pintbypint hit this exactly.  Deep burgundy/brown color.  Small tan head that quickly fades away.  Decent lacing.  Wonderful aroma.  Lots of raisins, fruits, banana-cloves.  Same combination continues on in the flavor.  Hint of spice in the finish.  Alcohol noticeable but fairly well subdued for 9%.  Very nice!

341ml brown bottle. Deep brown pour with ruddy edges, dark tan head was billowy and thick but short lived, my only real complaint about this beer. A lot going on in the aroma - fruity, slight clove/yeast note, with faint red wine. More fruit in the flavour, raisiny, sweet dark malts and more wheat beer like banana and clove notes. Finishes with a bit of alcohol bite and trace sourness. Medium body, softly carbonated.

Bottle, dark brown in color with decent beige head, mild lacing, nice aroma of fruit, grain and alcohol, the tast is just as good, nice balance with fruit and malt...leaves a good aftertaste.  definitely worth drinking again.
I really liked Trois Pistoles, like I like everything Unibroue produces.  I must say that as a strong ale, I slightly prefer Maudite which I find to be a bit more complex and flavorful.
Pour is dark and cloudy.  Aroma is malty and peat moss.  Flavor is dark fruits and candy sugar.  Decent but there are better out there.

(341 ml bottle) After years of drinking macro mediocre beers, I have recently discovered this  wonderful  beverage. Being fairly new to craft beers I am leaving the description with the proper words to more experienced raters . I could kick myself for not trying this sooner. I like everything about this beer.

Iv had 3 outstanding beers tonight, this was one which i had been recomended and so got it shipped in having no idea what to expect, and well after looking at the ratings it makes me wonder what the hell was in my bottle. Aroma is straight away weizenbock, i can only discribe the aroma as an overly fruity aventius. Taste is oh whats that weizenbock, this fellow is absolutly cardimon podd out its nut. Seriously this must be a wheat beer, or else weizenbock, its the only beer thats ever reminded me of aveninus, and how many ppl have said that about any beer. An excellent excellent beer, however i dont get any port or roasted malt, fruit yes very very fruity, but mmmmmm.......

Bottle. Fruit, phenolic aroma with hints of dark fruit. Flavor is nutty with some warming alcohol and a slightly dusty aftertaste. Ends a bit watery. Dark brown with big bubbled moderately stable head. High, but style wise, accurate carbonation. I had bottles which is a lot better.
an overwhelmingly great beer, but for christs sake, the guy below me really needs one of three things: a life, a job or a sex life. what a douche.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2007 Ancient Chinese civilization has at its core a geometric design that defines itself and the world around it.  The dome of the sky is the heaven under which the square of the earth resides, and on each side of the square is a color and a direction symbolizing the people who live there and the terrain they live in.  There are four pillars then, which define this square of the Earth.  Id like to take a different approach, maybe even propose a historical hypothesis.  The beer making world follows the same guidelines.  There are civilized breweries, and there are barbarian ones.  The civilized ones reside in the center of the square of the Earth, and at its apogee is Unibroue.  Upon four pillars sits this magisterial brewing company; four columns of their own design that lend strength to their claim to sophisticated hegemony.  I have seen, and drank, them all: Maudite, Don de Dieu, Fin du Monde, and finally Trois Pistoles.  This last one is, I believe, their finest work, no doubt honed from the labor they put into the other three.  It is the most curious of them all as the one without form.  A quiet, pensive beer living in haughty solitude, and one who developed its character from an eccentric existence.  What is there in this beer that pushes Unibroue to the apex of beer crafting?  
	When I look at this beer I think of that mysterious sage in the public park, an eremite and an introvert, but seemingly bursting with wisdom.  The Trois Pistole fulfills this characterization with a very dark color which, when put up against a light produces a light brown halo on the top of the beer.  The foam is a modest light brown that fades away after proper admiration.  The smell is of earthy vegetables, with an apple and banana sidekick.  You can also tell by the aroma alone how smooth and creamy the beer will be.  I also picked up some asparagus in the odor, alongside a slight scent of cinnamon, a pinch of licorice and a good slathering of sweet-salty sauce (teriyaki).  The beer, though by appearance a laconic philosopher, has some bite.  The carbonation and 9% alcohol serve to give your tongue a little chastising, but nothing that doesnt contribute to the wonderful taste.  Above all, Trois Pistole is creamy, with a long, mellow aftertaste.  The cling of this beer forces you to take breaks between sips, to recover your breath, recollect your mind and go in again for another exhausting sip.  It deserves its reputation, and it deserves praise as the strongest of four well crafted beers that Unibroue has been kind enough to hand down from its lofty throne.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2005 Nice cloudy brown pur with thin tawny head.  Robust citrus/malty aroma and taste that really hits the back and sides of the tongue.  The taste is complex and malty with fruits. You can definitely taste the 9% alcohol and it very much lives up to the description of resembling a port wine.

Dark brown ale, unclear, small but lasting beige head. Yeasty fresh aroma. Dades. Muscovado sugar. Good carbonation. Mild malty flavour. Smoke? Wheat. Alcohol. Roasted malts. Apricots. Mango. Notes of underlying sourness. Sugar sticky palate. Overall good, medium complex belgian style strong ale.

Pours a very dark brown with a small  tan head. Aroma of fruit and caramel. Dee p and complex flavor. The complex fruit, malt and spice combination of a fine Belgian quadrupel. Finishes with a reminder of the hops and high alcoholic content.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2006 For my first evaluation on RB, I chose the beer that started all for me. a few years ago. I believe this beer will always be my reference.
   
[BOT341ml/2004-6m/12,4c] 
The opening: Dark ruby-brown color with a fine slightly brown-tainted head. The complexity to the nose is consistent with the quadrupel style. Therefore, we find the typical malted dominance: roasty, caramel, toast. But moreover, we find deep fruits as well. And of corse, that Unibroue yeast.
   
The contact: I wish I just could forget everything I know about this beer and taste it for the first time over and over again. The nose was right: It taste malty. There are spices...  Licorice, prunes.. Would that be cloves?  Then you feel the alcohol. Long. 
  

This beer definitely evolves through time.

(BJCP Class)  Dark copper brown color with a great strong Carmel aroma. Rich in malt semi fruitiness lingers in the flavor and aroma.   Strong in alcohol.  A good peppery flavor in the first and last of the beer.  Slight clove feel also in the flavor.  Damn strong beer.  Semi dry strong aftertaste which feels very sweet.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with a medium frothy tan head and lined lacing.  Fruity oak cellared (cobweb) yeast aroma with medium roasted caramel malt and peach notes.  Alcohol and moderately acidic caramel malt, hoppy fruit and yeast (dough) flavor with wheat and prune notes.  Dark and full bodied fizzy and slightly dry palate.
I had high hopes for this beer after trying and enjoying Unibroues Maudite, however the beer really didnt have a very distinct taste, it was fairly bland and strong.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2005 Pours dark brown with a foamy mostly receding tan head.  Aroma of raisin, plum, cloves, light note of alcohol, and dark brown sugar.  Taste is dark and sweet, spicy and fruity, with elements of soda, notes of alcohol.  Mouthfeel is lightly heavy with lush carbonation. Delicious beer, though maybe a tad too fizzy and sweet.

Pours a deep reddish brown with a nice tan head.  The aroma is of malt, bananas, and a hint of the alcohol.  There is a spritzy feel to Trois Pistoles on the palate.  The taste is sweet and finishes with a dark fruit presence on the palate.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2007 Porter-like appearance with a spritzy, tan head that quickly fades.  The nose is dominated by malt sweetness, noting figgish sugars above wet wood and earthiness.  A light yeasty fruitiness helps to tie it all together.  More sweet fig dominates the complex body, which moves to a more smokey profile towards the finish.  I love the subdued yeast Unibroue uses, giving their beers a distinct Belgian fruitiness, but keeping it soft and in the background.  Plain and simple, this is a meal of a beer that  just doesnt seem fit being served in twist-off bottles.
reddish brouwn with a thin head.smells lof sweet fruit. I love belgian ales.this is good stuff!

11/6/05 bottle, best before 3/16/07.  Pours dark brown with small fizzy head that quickly diminished. The aroma is raisins, prunes, bananas, clove, with some citrusy notes. The flavor is prunes, raisins, and candi sugar. Finish is long and warming. Carbonation is a bit on the fizzy side.

Bouteille-Odeur de fruits et de fleurs. Noire opaque, mousse résistante, belle dentelle, mousse blanche-jaune. Goût fruité difficile à cerner. Une explosion de saveur mais très dure pour moi à élaborer.--Fruity smell. Dark brown-black, resisting yellow-white head. Fruity taste and an explosion of flavors in mouth difficult for me to describe.

Bottle.  Poured out a dark brown with some reddish tones, almost like a cola, and had a thick tan head with some great lacing.  The aroma was spicy, yeasty, with some dried fruits and a touch of alcohol.  The flavor was sweet malt at first, but then showed an almost red wine characteristic with some raisin, pepper, clove and leather coming out and then a bit of bitters on the finish.  Greatly complex on the palate, plus it was bubbly and slightly viscous.  Very good overall, not quite as playful as the Maudite, but its complexity gives it a slight advantage.
This is my favorite UB. I like Maudite too, but like all the other UBs theres too much stuff floating around...no good for my stomach. TP is excellent.

Clear brown body. Fizzy off-white head.
Caramelly apples and wood beef broth aroma.
A bit fizzy and liquor-like (but not alcohol-forward). Bitter sweet oak leaf finish. Its almost like a hopped cola flavor to me. Spicy grapes. Sugary plums. Some bitter tomato in there too.
Robe brune très foncée surmontée dune mousse blanche épaisse. Arômes de raisins et de sucre brun. Saveurs de raisin, de curaçao, de sucre brun et de dattes.

33 cl
Nice brown/black color
Withe head
Good and strong taste
I like this beer...
750ml bottle.  My favorite from Unibroue.  Caramel taste.  Great foamy head.  I buy this beer on regular occasion.  Its more like a dark brown beer than a black beer.

12 oz bottle. Ive been greatly looking forward to this beer, almost certainly because it is a) 99th percentile b) only $3, even though its a belgian style beer and c) has a really sweet bottle. On pure beer quality alone I would probably have given this a 3.8 but I had to give it a bonus point for those reasons... 

Aroma is very vineous, fruity, lots of plum, dark grape, some spiciness as it warms. Pours with a big, aggresive head, that unfortunately fades fast. Color is a very deep, dark brown, though certainly not black. At first the taste seemed pretty uncomplex and boring (though nice full palate), though as it warms much more is coming out.  Rich, dark malts, slight fruitiness, caramel, good belgian spiciness (pepper, allspice maybe?). Also takes on some nice yeastiness as the last remnants of the bottle pour.  Certainly a fine beer to be enjoying on this Monday night.
19OCT05  Bottle from Valley Wines and Spirits  in Wayne. My favorite of the Unibroue offerings. Pours a reddish-brown with a big, lasting, brownish head. Good malty, raisiny and spice flavor.

Finaly found a Unibroue I can drink. Not a fan of  Belgian ales, but this one is realy REALY good. I recomend a snifter for this one, realy brings out the aroma. Pours a deep chocolate black, with a thin whispy head that quickly disapates. Aroma is of dry black plumb with a little sweet malt, yeast, some smoke, and just a TRACE of boose. Mouthfell is slightly thick and very silky, like a glass of 1/2 milk 1/2 cream. Taste is dominated by a sweet robust roasty malt, combined with a bubblegumish yeastyness, and a blend of plumbs and prunes. Undertones are very simple, {unusual for Unibroue, normaly there are levels upon levels of undertones in their beers} sweet bread, biscuit, dry grape, oak, anise, some milled spice, and I think I can taste some coconut. Aftertaste is sweet with a trace of burnt shugar, and a little floral hoppyness in the finish. Normaly I only like the B.S.As with a high bitter content, but this one is very mild and understated and thus quite   enjoyable for a person, like myself, who is not a perticular fan of  Belgian beer. Robust enough to share a snifter infront of the fire, yet strait forward enough to split a six pack. I like it, and Im shure you will too. cheers
UPDATED: DEC 19, 2005 this beer is great.  sweet, fruity aroma, drinks smooth and finishes dry with lingering fruit notes.  Alcohol is well hidden.  another great brew  by unibroue

Dark cola brown with a quickly disappearing tan head.  Aroma is nice dark fruity and yeasty. All sorts of dark fruits running rampant in the flavor. Prunes? Raisins? Its a party going on in there. A tasty mood beer for me (gotta be in the right mood to drink it).
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: A hazy deep red beer with nice brown head. The aroma is very sweet with notes of prunes, raisins, wood, oranges, yeast, and ginger. The flavor is also very sweet - a little like eating English Licorice Allsorts - with notes of oranges, licorice, prunes, wood, cinnamon, and even coconut.

2004 750mL bottle.  Poured a beautiful deep sparkling ruby with an ample 1" well-retained beige head.  Deep fruits (plums, berries, raisins), cobwebby and bready Belgian yeast, cloves, and an underlying malty sweetness graced the nose.  Flavors blended wonderously together... like a dry spicy bread with baked in dark fruits.. and booze.  Thick and kind of chewy on the palate, allowing the subtleties of the flavors to find all the taste buds... but the sweetness almost became cloying at the finish.

From the bottle this beer pours a nice dark brown with a tan, creamy and fizzy head. The aroma is yeasty and not unlike raisin bread with a touch of cinnamon. Lively carbonation on the tongue with subtle flavors of cinammon bread, banana, clove, sugar cane and many others. Spicy mouthfeel with sharp carbonation becoming more balanced as it warms a bit. This is a truly unique and great beer.
dark brown w/ lively carbonation.  yeasty, fruity and slightly bitter.  full bodied.

Bottle.  Pours deep dark brown white thick and fluffy off white head.  Smells sweet, fruity and spicy.  Raisins and honey come to mind.  Taste is very mild, but not in a bad way... I was expecting a more bold taste.  A little fruity and yeasty.  Somewhat carbonated mouthfeel and spicy on my lips and tongue.  Finishes smooth.

UPDATED: JUN 16, 2008 Re-rate: Bottle has been aged approximately two years.  Mouthfeel is exquisite, champagne-like.  Little hop bitterness or sweetness, strong dry flavours of dark fruit, spices, and herbs from the hopping.  Amazing.

Original review:
Fascinating aroma.  Smells of fruit, but not fruity, if that makes any sense.  Taste is very unique, and other reviewers are accurate when they say that it tastes of port.  Mouthfeel is excellent.  Just the right amount of carbonation, not so fizzy as to distract from the flavour.  More than Guinness, less than most lagers.  You have to be careful drinking this one: it has a 9% alcohol content, but (if anything), the alcohol is less noticable than in your run-of-the-mill macrobrews, as its overpowered by the flavour.

Aroma: Light hint of plums and apricots ... Appearance: Cloudy, dark brown with a head that just wont die. ... Flavor: Honey, nutty, sweet and smooth with a hint of roasted grains.  Unlike any beer Ive tasted.  Not the greatest flavor, but perhaps the most unique. ... Palate is unsual as well.  I compare it with copenhagen snuff, which for me isnt unpleasant. ... Overall a very unique beer that I enjoyed a bit, but probably wouldnt buy again.  I realize this beer is in the 99 percentile and the beer snobs rave about it, but it just didnt trip my trigger that much.

Pours dark mahogany with a thick, off-white frothy head that lasts a long time and leaves a fair amount of lacing.  Prunes and raison aroma with notes of yeast.  Flavours are more subtle than the other Unibroue products I had but still very enjoyable - Raisins, prunes and bread (Kinda like oatmeal cookies).  Finish is fairly dry.

New to Belgian style ales, but not so new that  dont know how delicious they can be.  The description on the package seems to be spot on.  Obviously high quality, excellent mouth feel.  Taste started with a salvo of dried fruit and an encore of dry red wine.  Surprising that this is beer, yet oh so satisfying.  Next up La Fin du Monde!

Bottle, 2004 vintage. This is one of the best beers that Ive had so far. After not liking a few Belgian style ales, I was very skeptical when a friend brought a bottle over to split. Poured a viscous brown with a thick creamy head that lasted for a long time. The aroma was enticing - plums, port, cherries and roasted malts. Tasted like a cross between an excellent tawny port, a barleywine, and dried fruit. Im definately going to be trying other Unibroue beers.

Really dark with medium coloured, medium sized head.
Smells of malt, plums, fruit, red berries, estery and strong.
Tastes sweet, malty, rich, good bitterness, not that sourish.
I really love it, now I have to have the other Unibroue products.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2006 The graphic design of Unibroues bottle must be mentioned. For the visually inclined they are a pleasure. 

This beer is a superb and luxurious experience. The aroma is intoxicating and transcendent even before the first sip. The nectar of the gods could not exceed it by much, pleasure greater than this would be illegal.

It explodes in the mouth like a low voltage rush, filling the pores with an electrifying yet warm surge of mellow flavor. There are shades of Port, but a distinct and original flavor unlike any other. 

The aftertaste is thin and does not linger, like the fleeting sensation of a drug-induced heightened awareness that makes no sense on return to normal  consciousness.

The head effect is light and ethereal, an easily controlled giddiness, a sensation worth the price of admission.

Rerate 4/06. I just bought a 12 oz. bottle. What a huge difference. I wouldnt give it more than a 3.2.   a huge dissapointment.

How could a beer be so different by being put in a smaller bottle? It makes no sense, yet it is a fact. ONLY buy the 22 oz bottle or bigger.
-

WOW! Tap...ashleys in ann arbor. A mysterious dark ruby liquid with the aroma of a tropical fruit paradise. Very loathy head with hints of a malt backbone in the smell. Mouthfeel is silky smooth with the same fruit and the same smooth finish, alch content is hidden. awesome.

Black. Dense, bubbly, off-white head. Yeast, light and dark fruits-both fresh and dried, roasted malt-aroma. Accurate commercial description. Definite port flavors with some yeast, roasted malt, dark fruits, touch of subtle alcohol near the finish, also. Full bodied, plenty of carbonation but it somehow stays in the background, yeasty aftertaste. Drinks very easy at 9%. Beware the pale rider.

This bottle was aged for two years. A dark brown beer with a small head.  Still. Pleasant fruity aroma.  Not really similar to port wine, not even a vinous aspect at all really.  It is sweet, heavy, and malty however.  Full bodied and tasty.
It was ok. Dont belive the hype. I would not buy again. Didnt taste like port to me. Tasted like some kind of brown ale or something. Was brown in the glass.

341ml bottle. Finally!  Deep murky brown with amber highlights, everlasting rocky tan head. Lotsa little bubble spots. Aroma is very pleasing. Initially roasted malt with candied sugar. Sweet fruit, dark cherries & plums. Hints of a spice I cannot quite name. Flavor is bitter,  slightly toasty as well as sweet, a good balance. Alcohol is well hidden. Body is a high-medium on my scale with the effervescence of pop rocks almost. Very warming finish leaving a plummy & slightly sour aftertaste. Will be buying more soon.

Bottle. Pours a dark reddish brown with a large frothy light-brown head. Lots of nice bubble action. Aroma and flavour of sweet malt, dark fruit, alcohol, banana and spices. Medium body with a little too much carbonation. Not as good as I remembered but still very enjoyable and one of my favourite Unibroue beers.

Bottle.  Dark brown, not exactly see through, with medium, slightly fizzy tan head.  Nutty, yeast, malty in aroma.  The flavor is really hard to pin down.  It is almost easier to guess what is not in this beer.  I taste yeast, spice, malt, and a little afterburn from alcohol.  Finish is a little sour.  Very good.

UPDATED: AUG 3, 2006 Re Rate August 2006

This is one of the few beers I got more excited after tasting it for the first time. Aroma was wonderfull, appareance was great, very tasty, vinous, riped fruits, very complex, heavy but astonishingly drinkable. A wonderfull experience.

Bottle - September 05

Pours an opaque colur, couldn´t say exactly which one, maybe similar to red wine, develops a fine ( maybe not so lasting and rocky as one would like) head. Aroma is very intense and complex ( as with everything relating to this brew). Taste is very dense and complex (maybe too complex!!), winey, malty, warm, liquorice, fruity. Aftertaste is lingering, a little sour. I enjoyed this one, but maybe i prefer Maudite or Fin du Monde...

Near black and barely translucent in appearance with cherry accents when put to light.  Audibly fizzing with a mossy and tan head.  Aroma is one of a kind, with Fruity Pebbles, grapes, currant, black cherries, liquor-lacquered chocolate cherry cordials, prune juice, pepper and nutmeg.  Rich and expressive flavor.  Chocolate, cloves, pepper and figs invigorate while a wrap-around fruity nature comprised of plums and chocolate covered strawberries pull at the heart strings.  Some cherry pipe tobacco and a spicy complex akin to Christmas (cranberries, orange peel and nutmeg.)  Effervescent, but not over the top.  Titillating on the palate.  Balance speaks for itself, finishing with chocolate raspberry liqueur and a lasting holiday spice that sings its song long after each sip.  Im falling in love with this brewery.
Very  drinkable, almost perfect. My favorite from this great brewer. Can sit and sip this all day. Wonderful spicy/fruity tast which goes down smoothly.
chocolate, red, brown, clear, tan foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, creamy, lively, long finish. Not as good as I expected.

Poured from a 750ml Bottle. Mahogany coloring with a light head that foamed away quickly. Smells of black cherries and soil. Taste of molasses and plum with a very malty finish. Excellent as usual, but not my favorite from Unibroue.

Poured a very dark brown, with two finger thick head, that slowly faded to a good cap that lasted for the entire time that I enjoyed this beer.

Smells of plums, mild apples, slighlty doughy and earthy.

Taste is sweet dark fruits, yeasty, with some of the earthy tones in there. Very smooth, rich beer. I could barely pick up any alcohol in the smell or taste, even with the 9% abv.

Kind of a heavy beer to have more that one or two of, but very good.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Bottle: Poured dark brown color with light brown head. Soda like head with lots of carbonation. Hoppy smells of grapefruit and flowers with some malty undertones. Nice mix of malt and hops in the flavor with citrus, molasses, and spices present. Medium body, creamy texture, and lively carbonation.

Deep, complex, and entirely satisfying, this belgian strong doesnt pull any punches.  Dark fruitiness provides most of the flavor, as it comes across as sweetly balanced.  I wouldve preferred a little more maltiness, but I couldnt complain.

Very dark brown color.  Noisy head that looks and sounds almost like youve poured soda.  The head goes away quickly.  This style of beer isnt my favorite but this is a very good beer.  The taste doesnt linger like other ones.  It also leaves a warm feeling in you which is quite nice.  My favorite Belgian strong ale.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark mahogany with ruby highlights, 1/4 head composed of fine bubbles that settles into a thick creamy mass that lasts till the end.  Aroma is heavy in plum fruitiness, heavy malt, and a general sweet smell.  Very complex aroma, I can see the comparison to port that they mention on the bottle.  Flavor is very port-like as promised.  Deep rich fruit, very light sweetness, a rich nutty flavor similar to Frangelico without all the sugar.  Soft on the palate with a lively carbonation.  This coats the mouth providing a long finish with prominant alcohol warmth that reaches down to your belly and a lingering sweetness.  This is just overall a really enjoyable brew, this really defies any classification to a real style to me, which is why I guess its put into the Belgian stong style.  Definately my favorite from Unibroue so far, but Ive got lots to go thankfully.

This beer, which is one of my favourites, has the typical Unibroue yeasty aroma as well as some plum and hints of bread.  Pours a large off-white head which doesnt last as long as desired.  Colour is a hazy dark brown.  Flavour is well balanced: starts with light sweetness and bitterness and finishes with light-to-moderate sweetness and bitterness.  A light fruity sweetness flavour remains for a long time after each sip.  I find it hard to tell how dense this beer is because of the lively carbonation but I think it is medium to full body.  There is also a nice warming effect from the alcohol in the finish.

[bottle from beers of europe] pours a mahogany colour with a dense lacing head. Full aroma of prunes, apples, yeast, liquorice and some port notes. The liquorice is more pronounced on the palate with a long dry finish.
This beer is certinely dark and warming, like the label!  There is a taste of fruityness, special b malt, and belgian yeast spicyness that i really enjoy.

Out of a bottle.  Aroma of a mature hard liquor.  Poured a nice dark brown with a sufficient tan head.  Flavor was about average for a belgian strong.  Sweet and sour almost kept it evenly balanced. Flavors of sour cherries and apple dominated.  Palate was good a mouthful for sure.  Overall it was ok.

Opaque dark brown with a short tan head. The aroma contains brandy and dried fruits, which burst forth upon tasting. The flavour is well balanced, bitter and sweet with the 9% carried through to the stomach where it warms the cockles (cue Denis Leary). Damn fine beer this. PS A waggle of the bat for the half-century
good beer. way different than im used to. i thought it makes a good beer and wine combination if thats what those french canadian dudes were going for than right on. smells like grapes.

alright..Pours a prune colour, fruit and choc smells, lots going on....very balanced on the first sips...good head, ...is smooth full sweet ...as they say, good body to it....its warmly...even better when room temp..this brew has it goin on!

Has a cherry licorice aroma. Body is dark brown with good off white head that disipated. More of a wine flavor than beer. Alcohol content well hidden in this beer. Smooth and easy on the palate. Like a porter with out the extra sweet flavor and aftertaste. A good brew.

Cant say Ive ever tasted anything quite like this before, theres almost a fruity taste like currant in there but maybe my brain is playing tricks on me.  Several other unidentifiable but delicious flavors, beautiful appearance and lasting taste.  Who says you cant have a high quality belgian ale in Canada? ;)  Still kicking myself in the ass for not trying this sooner.. delicious.

Brown caramel with hazae and medium tan, slightly lacing head.  Sweet aroma of ripe plum, raisin with slight licorice. Well blended flavor that was sweet and mild nutty.  Smooth palate with low alcohol until the finish which gives a nice warming in the back of the mouth and stomach.

Much lighter in taste than I was expecting.  Bottle at home, served in wine glass.  Dark reddish brown, fairly opaque with an attractive tan head.  Smells very yeasty, and tastes very yeasty with banana/vanilla esters that I usually associate with hefewiezen.  The malt flavours and the fruity esters are nice, but more muted than I would like.  Alcohol is definitely noticable, but I like that in my belgian ales (especially tripels).  Much cheaper than the imports from Europe, and not as deep, but still very much worth drinking.

Nice dark ruddy brown color. Barely able to get a half finger of head even with an assertive pour. Sweet malts and a cherry raisin aroma. Raisin, cherry and malt blend continue through tasting and a perfect carbonation carries the mouthful to a lingering sweet finish. Top notch brew that will bought many times again.

Very foamy dark brown beer. Aroma is sort of bready with lots of fig and cherries. Not as fruity in the flavor as the yeast seems to dominate the taste. Slight alcohol burn. As I continue drinking I get some molasses on my tongue. Not my favorite from this company but still very good.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark red/brown with persistant head. Vinous aroma with dark fruits, licorice, port, prunes. Rich mouthfeel, dry fruity finish. Very pleasant.

From 330ml bottle.

Pours a deep opaque brown with a frothy tan head. Smells fruity, mostly of plum and other dark fruit. Vanilla and molasses. Sweet spice, clove.

Taste is quite malty and yeasty. Lightly tart apple and plum. Vanilla, spicy like pepper and coriander. Lightly bitter in the finish. Mouth is rich and lightly sticky. Good stuff, I can never do the Unibroue beers justice with my words.

Pours dark, dark brown, with a massive, rocky tan-colored head. Aroma is yeasty, with hints of fruit. The alcohol comes through in the tase, though its not not overpowering, and an overall roasty character really comes through. The mouth feel is thin, and the finish is dry, with a lingering fruit taste to it. Very enjoyable, and a fine Belgian strong ale!

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2005 Wine like aroma with sugar and some malt. Appearance is hazy and dark brown with a large head. Strong alcohol taste but it does have beautiful toasted malt and caramel with figs and nuts. A little vinegar in the aftertaste but overall its good tasting. I will have to say that I would enjoy it more if I was a fan of high alcohol beers.

Bottled 33cl (BB 01/2007)
Dark hazy nut brown, almost opaque color, small tanned head. Nose has plums, roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and hints of metal. Medium-bodied. Starting with tickling carbonation, mouthfeel is actually relatively thin. Toffeeish, fruity (raisins), sweetish with loads of roast with some licorice in the finish. Some warming alcohol in the finish, long roasted-sweet aftertaste. Complex and enjoyable - and dangerous - easy to drink.

UPDATED: AUG 2, 2005 Couleur auburn parsemé dune mousse crémeuse beige pale et très persistante.  Arômes très levurés et épicés laissant une place de choix au toffee, aux cerises et autres fruits foncés.  Dune complexité remarquable en bouche, bonne présence de malt, pain brun, sensation de lait au chocolat, prunes, pruneaux et douces épices sous une empreinte de levure restant toujours marquée.  Carbonatation très piquantepeut-être exagérée, texture laiteuse, corps dépaisseur épaisse à pleine.  Finale essentiellement alcoolique sous une touche anisée, apparaissant étrangement quelque peu aqueuse.  Bouteille achetée en Janvier 2004, Montréal.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2005 Is as dark as can be, mellow in taste with an aroma of ripe fruits. It can be compared to an old porto and is brewed from well roasted malt.  Nonetheless is a bitter and stale beer.  Dont drink this one again.

Pours a dark opaque brown, nearly black with a rapidly-dimishing fizzy beige head that leaves sparse lacing. Many fruity aromas intertwine to produce a blanced and complex nose. I noticed apples, apricots, cherries, figs, red wine, bread and a slight soapy undertone. The spices and above average carbonation intially hit the tongue but smoothen out to a velvety creaminess.
