Roasted malts shine as it slips across your tongue, reminding of caramel and dark chocolate. Definitely has some rich wine-like qualities and a long dry finish. Some bitterness lingers for a while. Leaves a very satisfying and warming feeling.
Velour, brune, caramel, caractère, douce dans la gorge, un petit peu acre mais moin que la Gladamor.  Merci pour une aussi bonne bière de chez nous dUnibroue.

this was pretty freakin sweet.  very dark.  got some weird fruits, like strawberries and melon and raisins, some peaches and pear juices joined in for the chorus.  very sweet on the palate almost to the point that it makes the palate dry, but the flavor saves it at the last possible second.  however, i really liked it,one of my fave unibroues.

Pours a cloudy dark brown with about half inch of white head.  Soft, fine bubbles.  Has a spicy and fruity aroma like a witbier.  Full bodied and full of flavor.  Complex, lots of stuff going on.  Some nutty flavors and some raisons.  Kind of sweet.  No apparent alcohol flavor.   I kind of hate belgian ales but I really like Unibroue products.  This one is pretty amazing.

Brown, dark brown thick color with a large sandy colored head, very thick head.  I get alot of dark fruits in the aroma, however i also get some funky ass paste aroma.  Starts out with sugar coated peaches in the body, then some slight bitterness and alot of raisons.  I also get a really dry feel from it, maybe if you made wine out of raisons you would get this.

Poured from a 750, this has a thick rocky beige head atop a dark black/red body.  So-so lacing and the head disapates pretty quickly.  The aroma is like a nice $20+ bottle of tawny port wine.  (I cant recall the brand I sampled at my Aunts...).  Plum and bing cherry, nuts.  The flavor is plums, nuts, raisins, grapes, quality bread, good port wine, light chocolate.  The palate has a little bit of alcohol present.  Vinous qualities, tons of carbonation, light dryness.

im quite surprised that this one has such a high rating... but lets take it from the top: The aroma is absolutely fantastic. In my nose, it resembles chocolate. The flavor has some raisins and bread (not bad really) but also lots of alcohol. And the palate holds way too much alcohol for my taste. -and thats rare!

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2006 Re-rate:- I was hoping for this to get better but it just got worse. The second try was just a fizzy, thin, sherbet candi and artificial fruit flavoured mess that did not sit well on the palate. Poured a clear deep brown and this time lacked a head completely. Zesty, candi fruit nose with a light hint of alcohol spice. Utterly woeful as a Strong ale in the mouth, sat firmly amongst Mountain Dew and Pepsi as far as fizzy drinks were concerned. I cant see the follow the leader mentality of this one. At 860, it still reads 99 on the overall. Just not good at all.(345ml, BBE 07/06)  
Really cannot see the fuss made about this one. Expected a lot more, as the ratings suggest, of this high scorer. Poured into a chalice, cool but not cold, head formed and died back quickly to a short off-white lather that left a lovely amount of lace. The body of beer a deep ruby-brown with a lot of yeast that sunk quickly to the base. Initial strong, fruity, plum and cherry nose, quite spicy and sweet. Almost port-like and slightly musty, the aroma lapsed after the first sip to reveal nothing more than yeast and alcohol spice that remained for the length. Lighter than expected body, the harsh persistent carbonation bit at my tongue and obscured things. Very dry overall, vinous red wine flavours with dried fruits, earthy malt and yeast. Finish is quite long and dry, border-lining on astringent. Overall it wouldnt have been that bad a drop if the harsh carbonation didnt rip threads from my already dehydrated palate. Not the best offering from Unibroue, but I may give it another try, to be fair!!! (bottle 02/07)

Bottle at Kulminator, Antwerp, Belgium  Deep brown body with a creamy, light brown head which diminishes mostly.  Fair lace.  Nose of spices and malts (roasted).   Lightly sweet, moderately bitter initial flavour.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter finish.  Medium bodied.

Bottled.
Hazy brown coloured with a beige head.
Fruity and spicy aroma.
Spicy and fruity flavour with notes of dried apricots and celery.

Pours darkbrown with a small head. Aroma fills the room: especially raisins, fudge, grapes, christmaspudding...
Initial taste is a bit weak but comes in very strong with dark fruits and roasted malts in the aftertaste...together with a warming alcoholpunch.
Trois Pistoles just hit me..
Drak ruby red to black in color with a foamy head. Sweat malt and fruit flavor. A slight bitter aftertaste. I am not normal a big Belgian fan but this one is nicely done.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2016 Dark brown color, moderate head, good lace/retention. Aroma is a Belgian Brown - yeast, light caramel and chocolate, some darker fruit, lightly sugary. Its interesting that a decade ago this was mindblowing and now its just pretty good. Where will we be in another 10 years?

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2005 Pours an extremely deep dark brown with a small amount of offwhite head that quickly dissapates.  Aroma is sweet malts, slightly smoked, and candied fruits with no annoying overpowering spices. Flavor is strong alcohol that warms as it goes down, and some bittersweet malts.  Overall, a very pleasant tasting beer and well priced.
Not as strong as it look. Belgian type with creamy head. Nice spicy aroma. Actually, nice beer overall.

very dark brown, very fine beer. lovely fruity and woody nose. taste: fruity, yeasty, bit coffee/chocolate(roasted malts), bit bitter, lots of esters. finish is bitter, fruity, sweetish but also dry/tart. i wonder what some aging will do to this beer (more port taste?). delicious!!! Unibroue is ok

Spicy and strong. 

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA

A cloudy, deep red-brown with a thick creamy head. Fruity, spcy aroma, with a litle tartness masked slightly by the strong fuitiness. It says it is brewed with roasted malts but it tastes fruity, caramelly, yeasty- but not really roasty. This is a very well balanced beer, being dark and deep without distracting from the fruity/yeasty character with a strong roasted element. Excellent.

Had as part of a flight at the Washington House Unibroue beer tasting. This was the fourth I had in the flight.  Floral aroma that poured a mahogany in color.  Some citrus candied sugar and molasses in the aroma. Can sense the alcohol in the initial taste.  Tingles on the tongue. Another nice beer from Unibroue.

33 cl bottle. What an amazing beer, dark brown colour, with a little white head. Amazing aroma of dried fruit. The taste are incredible too, smooth, tasteful and are amazing long aftertaste. One of the only not belgium beer, that taste like the real stuff....

750ml bottle poured out a murky, rust-colored body under a tight, small head that fizzed away quickly... an appearance that I rated a 4 until I took into account the cork and caged bottle labeled with Rennaisance-quality, metaphoric oils through which Unibroue continually pushes the boundaries in a field dominated by mediocre typography, faux heraldry, saturated logotypes and cheapish landscapes. Aromas held some potency with musty prunes, licorice and spices. Flavor held a dominant fruity-sweetness that lingered for a long while through a semi-syrupy, rich palate. Despite the alcohol presence, it was not as overbearing as others in the Belgian Strong style. I will buy this again as my wife will enjoy it as well.

<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL<font size=-1>

12oz bottle: Leather brown that is somewhat of a cloudy dark appearance. A fizzy head was created, but before i could take a sip it had died out.  Very hard for me to pick up any aroma in this beer, but i can smell few minor things such as rotten apple and some sort of spice. The flavor is of sweet malt, nutmeg, candy sugar, raisin, green apple, and a note of plum as well.  I think Unibroue beers are way over rated and not impressing  at all. Thats the main reason i bought a 12oz instead of the bigger $8 bottle because i didnt want to get stuck with another beer i hated from them.  However, i found this attempt at a Belgian strong style to be a chewy and pungent drink, holding a consistent sweet and sour tartness to it that i liked enough to give it the points i did.
Pours a deep black almost plum color with little head.  Has a fruity aroma with light hints of roasted malts. Tastes dark and thick but finishes smooth with a plummish quality to it.
UPDATED: FEB 11, 2006 Nice nutty aroma.  More mellow than I expected from such a dark ale.  Good balance of carbonation and alcohol content -- made for a smooth, very flavorful beer.
Dark with large head which lingers quite a while. Taste is of dark fruit and malt. Smooth and does not taste too strong despite the alcohol.
Dark brown, medium white head. Fruity vanilla nose. Thick mouthfeel. Fruity, peach, cherry flavour. Notes of plum and liquorice. Slight alcoholic. Sweet, yeasty palate. Full bodied.

Smells strongly of cherries and fruit, mixed with sweet malt. Pours deep sweet brown. The taste is a delicious mix of dark cherries and port. Finishes with a light malty sweetness with no trace of alcohol. YUMMY.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2005 Another great brew from one of my favorites, Unibroue. Its got that great fruity bite thats to be expected from a Belgian ale, but it goes down smooth and is very drinkable. Sour cherries dominate flavor, and belgian yeast bite lingers after each sip.
UPDATED: AUG 3, 2007 Beautiful head, brownish red color, unique great smell,nice strong bite, but very smooth going down, very impressive beer, as most unibroue beers are.

Great deep brown color.  Aroma is nutty with a touch of fruit.  Flavor is fruity and smooth.  Like all good high alcohol beers, you would never know it is high in alcohol.  One of the better Belgian Ales brewed outside of Belgium.
Smells very nice of fruits and nuts.  Taste is dominated by fruits but not too much to make it overpowering.  The look was pretty bland head was pretty small and color wasnt all that appealing.

Pours a dark ruby color with nice thick head that diminishes quickly.  Smells of fruit with some resemblence to a hefe style (banana and clove).  Taste is pretty damn swell.  A fruity spiciness dominates the palate and allows for a slight alcohol warmth in the finish.  It hides the 9% ABV quite well.  A well crafted brew.

12 oz. bottle.  Poured deep mahogony with a decent off-white head.  Did not leave much lacing to speak of.  Aromas of raisins and other ripe, dark fruits.  Alcohol notes in the nose and the flavor.  Flavor also brought in grape and spice on the aftertaste.  Quite vineous and very smooth.  Nice beer.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2005 Bottle.  Very dark ruby black pour with large off beige head.  Nice full body with lots of earthy fruits - plums and raisins.  Carbonation was very well done for my pour.  Good stuff.

Pours a dark mahogany, very transparent, with a tall off-white head. Lots of dark fruit and spice with a fizzy carbonation that dries it out. Sweet up front, but the carbonation breaks up the body keeping it from being too heavy.
Bottle. Rocky off white head with a ruby colored body. Nose is raisins, plums. Mouth is raisins, plums, something sweet, possibly cranberries?

Aged 12 oz. bottle from my cellar. Freshness date of 05-07-06 on back label. Its been sitting in my cellar for close to 2 years now. Decent pfftt when opened. Poured out a deep maroon color, almost the color of a stout. Slight red highlights around perimeter of the glass. Served in a Duvel tulip. Medium tan colored head.
Aromas are of macerated dried fruits. Plums soaked in fine brandy comes to mind. Sweet, earthy malts and hops blend well. It must be from the extended aging that really pulls this beer together. It has sherry notes, as well as a slight oxidation. Dry on the palate, chalky aftertaste. Tart cherries in the mix as well. Grapeskin tannins dry the mouth out, but not overly so. Medium mouthfeel, rich thick body. Decent take on the style.
Wow!  This is great!  Dark red color with a nice bready aroma.  I like wine a lot and this is similar in that yummy way.  Malty and with plummy fruity stuff in there.  Great!

Bottle:  Pours a ruby/brown with a rocky tan head, moderately carbonated.  Aromas of light raisens and plums, sweet malts.  Flavor is slightly sweet and bready, mixed with all sorts of darker dry fruits.  Wonderful lively mouthfeel on the roof of the mouth (like champagne almost, but slightly flatter) mixed with smoothness up and down the throat.

In the 750 ml bottle. Pours dark, real dark. Pillowy white head. Incredible fruity wine-like aroma. I really liked this. Im surprised that the alcohol is so high, as the balance hides the fact. My guess was that it was an Abbey ale due to the smoothness. This was truly one of the best Unibroue ales that Ive tried.

Pours a dark ruby brown with a copious foamy white head.  Sweet malt aroma with huge dried apricot undertone.  Cornicopia of dried fruit flavors, apricot, cherry, apple, plum.  Nice roasty malt notes with a residual sweet and sour character in the finish.  Mouthfeel is full, but smooth.
Bottle. Nice malty, sweet aroma. Cloudy dark brown colour. Strong, sweet flavour of dried fruit. Grape aftertaste.

Big frothy slight-tan head, Dark ruby/mahogany color. Bitter sweet fruity flavor cant really pick out what the flavors are just that its fruity but not too fruity at all. Slightly bitter that got more bitter as it went down. Dont think Ill get again because its too sweet of a beer for me to drink a lot of. But gave it a good score for having great qualities  and craftmanship put into it.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Bottle (341ml).  Proudly Canadian, I point to this beer and cry "see!"  Seriously, amazing intersection of the "unibroue taste" with strong roasty stout and Belgian influences, very dark, sharp, dark fruits, maltiness, that Belgian tang in the background, the alcohol (9%) behaves itself and has been known to sneak up on the unwary.  This and McAuslan St. Ambroise Oatmeal Stout are my easily available go-to six packs if nothing else appeals.  Try it, eh?

Very hazy and dark brown pour w/ copper and reddish highlites supporting a dense wet sand brown head.  Complexities start with an aroma of roasted malt, dark fruits, caramel and chocolate covered cherries.  Layers of flavors that start with plums and caramel giving way to sweet malt, a liitle spice and more cherries and ending with a mildly peppery/alcohol and surprisingly hoppy taste.  Mouthfeel was soft and silky and the finish was long, sweet and complex.  Unibroue is an inconsistent brewery but when theyre on - theyre on!  This is a fantastic evening ale.

A champion from the land of les Quebecois.  It really does have a port wine feel to the whole enterprises--a sour-fruity aftertaste belying a well rounded, roasted-malt front.  Aroma is mildly caramelized, though this isnt the dominant flavor of the beer.  Reminds me of Three Philosophers with deeper beer flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2009 (Bottled) Very dark reddish brown color with a small head. Quite mild aroma of slightly roasted malt, licorice, lots of (dried) fruit and caramel with some lightly port-wineous feel. Coriander-anise-spicy, moderately hoppy, sweetish-roasted-malty, fruity flavor. Alcohol is completely hidden. Smooth, medium to full-bodied palate with very soft carbonation. A very pleasant and enjoyable, carefully crafted, balanced and stylish, very Rochefort-like brew.

This is a deep, dark beer with a good amount of sweetness and other malt characters.  There was some substantial sediment in the bottle which did seem to make it port-like as the description suggests.  This is a great late night sipping beer to warm you up.

spongy light brown head.  Smells like ripe fruit but i cant really pick anything else out, it is nice though.  Taste is fruity as well, i can make out figs, green apple, cherry, and a kind of jam like flavor.  Might be a little too sweet.  Mouth feel is quite full.  Very nice, liked it a lot.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2005 Tried this in a small tasting glass at Cleveland Ale Fest (5/05).  Poured into my little tasting glass with a nice chestnut color, good looking carbonation.  The aroma (as with others tasted in this forum) was hard to detect, but I noted some musty sweetness.  The flavor was interesting with sweet malts and fruit which included apples and something darker (plums?).  The body was sticky syrup lightened by the ample carbonation.  Not too bad.  


Re-Rate on a full bottle.  Much better take on the aroma, in which I noted prunes, dark dried fruit (like cheeries) and some alcohol.  Very enjoyable.  I wont change my flavor notes, but I will add prune, raison, spice, and red licorish.  As for the body, disregard the carbonation bit.  medium round body, a bit watery on the finish but nice.

Pours a murky brown with a foamy white head that dies quickly- almost like pouring a glass of cola.  Leaves no lacing.  Aroma is not very pungent, hints at fruit and a bit of spice.  I was blown away by the first taste, though, after having tried to smell it for about ten minutes.  Rich, vinous character with a warm alcohol bite but no real flavor of alcohol.  Sweet in the mouth but without any lingering sweetness that would make it overpowering.  Wonderful fruity flavors coupled with dried fruit flavors, like prunes or raisins, and some caramel or toffee notes.  Aftertaste definitely reminds me of raisins.  Nicely carbonated, balancing out the sweetness exceptionally well.  Overall, a truly exceptional beer.

Corked 750ml Bottle. Murky pale reddish brown. Pours immense, crackly tan head which almost completely fades by end of glass and doesnt cling.  Probably a tad too much carbonation. Close to nose smells vaguely of an emptied wine glass. Zings onto tongue! I think theres some prune-like flavor here... aftertaste definitely reminds me of port. Kind of filling.

UPDATED: NOV 19, 2005 Dark brown beer with medium beige head.  Nice caramel/toffee aroma.  Sweet and fruity, but nothing overpowering. Hints of apple.  Lively carbonated beer.  Nice lacing. Medium-bodied. Sour, dry and slighly bitter finish.  Not anything bad to say about this one.

An intensely fruity and port-like strong Belgian ale. Poured the deepest brown with an airy 1.5cm head that settled disappointingly quickly. Rich vinous aroma has me thinking of dusty wine cellars and the jam factory in the NSW cherry town, Young. Dominant characteristics are plums, sherbet, merlot, cherry jam and blackcurrant cordial. Medium-bodied, creamy but arguably over-carbonated. Fizzes on the tongue. Flavourwise, the port comparison in the description is valid. Its intense, with sweet cherries and merlot-like notes to the fore. The finish is dry, with lots of lingering fruit. Its an excellent strong ale but I find the alcohol a fraction too prominent. Don De Dieu remains my desert island Unibroue. (341ml bottle, Liquor on Parade)

UPDATED: APR 17, 2009 Dark brown body with a medium frothy tan head. Caramel, molassas, anise, belgian spice, and candi sugar aroma. Sweet caramel, anise, and light molassas flavor with lots of belgian spice. Medium body with moderately high carbonation. 8/4/9/4/17 - 4.2

11/20/2006: Dark brown body with a medium tan head. Sweet caramel, molassas and lots of candi sugar. Sweet candi sugar flavor with caramel and lots of spice.
8/5/9/4/17 - 4.3

04/30/2005: Dark beer, with lasting white head. Fairly sweet taste with a nice aftertaste. 9/5/9/4/19 - 4.6

750 mL Bottle.  Amazing pour.  Black color with white head that just wont got away, even to the last sip.  Smells very sweet.  Taste is a lot weaker than the smell but still very smooth.  Leave a nice warming finish.

Dark burgundy, brown, cola-like in appearence. Delightful fizzy sound. Head is a tan foam that settles quickly to a thin sheet barely capping this sweet smelling brew. The aroma is splendid with cherries, caramel, toffee and pit fruits.  Completely, the scent reminds me of a black cherry tootsie pop.  Taste is bold, full with flavors, but too sweet in its ending, and that detracts from it a tad.  However, core flavors are solid and succulent: pit fruit, plums, black cherries, figs, toffee, hints of cocoa.  Mouthfeel is full, with seemingly every liquid particle possessing a carbonated pop. Roll it around your cheeks and youll know what Im talking about.  Dusty, musty basement spices, typical of Belgians, lurks about the palate.  Alcohol bites but is not overly sharp. Remniscent of the Celebrator.  Fun, invigorating, and delectable.

It is always tough rating a Belgian, not one of my favorite types.  Within its style its a good one.  It had a large, foamy head standing tall over a cloudy, dark brown beer with tiny bubbles rising through it. It had a sour fruit aroma, a sweet fruity taste with a dry mouth feel. There was a lingering taste of fruit that seemed kind of light, missing a hop finish. Although the big head dissipated quickly, there was a quarter inch left in the bottom of the glass.  The alcohol hit I expected from the high ABV was absent..  It was gassy, big burp beer, as I expected from the tethered cork in the bottle, but not fizzy.

Dark, very dark. Similar in color to a porter. Nice foamy head. Roasted malts and ripe fruits followed by a warm tingly alcohol finish. Drank this at almost room temp and it tasted great. Gotta love the bad ass apocalyptic picture on the label.
UPDATED: FEB 2, 2006 For being a stout, I expected more form this brewery, but it was nice, with the bubbling and orange characteristics of Unibroue. NIce beer, for a nice meal.

Very good beer this is! This brew pours nice and dark with a nice rocky head. This brew is very very easy to drink. In fact, its so easy to drink that my fiance wanted a bottle of her own! (before she would only drink two other beers... New Belgium Frambozen and Michelob Ultra) This is a nice complex brew that really starts to shine as it warms up a bit.

Pours really dark with a thick brown head.  The aroma is of chocalate/carmel, with a hint of fruits.  The carbonation of this beer is similar to another Unibroue; Maudite.  The flavor is very smooth yet relly complex.  Great beer.

One of the best belgians I have had the pleasure of tasting.  Pours a nutty brown, overflowing with aroma and anticipation.  I would have liked a larger head when poured, but am happy with what I get.  Fills the mouth and senses with a rich warm feeling.  Wonderful throughout, recommended, and worthy of extreme accolades.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2006 Wonderfully smooth and malty combined with a bitter spiciness in the finish.  Spices and fruits (apricots-raisin) mix well with the alcohol & tight carbonation to generate a deep and complex taste that really lasts.  Just a little bitter and overly alcoholic to be truly top notch, but excellent for a non-Belgian brewery.

Bottle. Poured a very dark brown with large tan head. Aroma was complex of coffee, chocolate and citrus. Complex mouth full of flavors same as aroma with long finish with an alcohol bite.  Very good brew.

Pours are dark red-brown with a thick creamy head.  Aroma of dark fruits and roasted malt comes through in the taste, rounded out by spice and a slight bitter finish.  An intriguing and very complex beer, a little too much carbonation and a thickness in the palate keeps it from blowing me away.

Pours very dark.  Almost like pepsi in the glass with a slow fizz.  Aroma is malty and almost alchoholic.  Little head on the pour.  Fruity  complex flavor and nice body.  Some plum flavor maybe some rasin.  It is definitely a unique taste.  Thick enough to stay with me for a bit.  I like this one and the chocolatey finish is outstanding.  Feels great in your mouth.  Id buy this again.

I slowly took in the aroma of this wonderful beer. It is as dark as any stoudt.  The first taste is very fizzy and as it warms it tastes even better. The taste is very complex and I love the body. I rate this as one of my all time favorites. I just wish I could get in by the case. I always have to buy the mixed case of uniboue and I am not a fan of the wheat beer.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2005 Rich dark fantastic beer.Shame that the head dissapears so fast,but the taste is really something special,very ripe fruity & delicious.Its my 100th beer and a great choice!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2005 341ml Bottle @ slight-cool temp - great! Easy to drink yet amazingly fulfilling and balanced. Pours puffy head, beautiful deep purple-black. Soft  clovey/sarsaparilla & restrained yeast aroma; generous plummy, grape & fig notes in taste with slight citrus on the long port-like finish. Does Chimay Bleu wish it were this interesting, I wonder? For my money, mais oui.

Weird brew, beautiful head (like none ive ever seen before)  pour was brownish.  This beer improved MAJORLY as it warmed.  from weird metalic tastes to a nice combo of malts, hops, fruits, and an almost chocolatey.  not a favorite

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2005 Oh my god...this is 9% ABV? This stuff is evil, because you dont notice it until it bites you on the behind. Even though I served it too cold at first it was still a taste explosion which obviously improved as it warmed up. Pours from the bottle murky brown with reasonable light tan head. Aroma of raisins and brown sugar which extended through to the flavour along with hints of bitter dark chocolate towards the end. Luxurious mouthfeel, with a hint of viscosity from the high alcohol. I think I have fallen in love with Belgian Dark Brown Ale.

Ive really come to like Unibroue a lot.  My first experience was with Terrible, which was overly sweet for what I enjoy.  I recently gave them a second shot with this, Maudite, and La Fin du Monde, none of which disappointed.  Great, affordable Belgians.

Dark brown hue, with a light foamy head, dry fruits of raisins, figs, prunes , dates with a malted chocolate note and sweet maltiness aroma. The palate is sweet and fruity of dark fruits, raisins, figs, prunes , dates with a spicy touch of curaçao, through a malty flavor of chocolate finishing in a good acidity.

UPDATED: JUL 3, 2007 Open carefully, this one likes to overflow maybe because it is refermented in the bottle, very good carbonation and head but not much lace. Cloudy reddish brown, nose is raisiny so is taste. Smooth, full bodied and malty - very easy to drink but savor at 9% ABV. $1.50 for a 330ml bottle from Capitol Convenience Concord, NH.

Poured a dark redish brown color with a huge head.  Aroma was fruity with malty and yeast additions.  Flavor followed suit with a very sweet maltiness and some fruits and spices along with a yeasty finish.  Medium mouthfeel with good carbonation.
Very dark brown. Flavor is fruity, sweet malts, yeasty, and some alcohol. Very complex, very good. The drink grew on me more and more with each sip as I took in all of the great flavors.

Dark plum like colour, lots of foamy light head that fizzels down to a nice coverign head. Plums in the aroma, how appropriate.Fun, fizzy, and light carbonation. Nice fruity bubblegum flavour. This is tasty!
Although I prefer the Maudite for some reason Ithink this is still a great beer. Good carbonation with a fruit-like taste and a tinge of alcohol.
There are so many beers, yet so very few as good as this. A good beer all around, in aroma, apperance, taste-excellant.

Pours a brown body with some wierd purple tints and a healthy tan head. Aroma has plums and caramel with a bit of alcohol. The flavor reflects the aroma, but also has that typical Unibroue yeastiness (which I love).

The high carbonation/concentration gives this beer a rather heady pour.  This beer has a very balanced malt flavor with a hint of caramel.  The taste is superb and is worth the price.  The high alcohol content leaves a warm sensation in the body which makes this an extremely excellent beer to have on that cold winter night while chatting among friends by the fire.

gigantic almoast over flawing head. granted i poured a little hastily. nice dark brown color. malt and bannana smell with a creamy mouth feel. taste is nutty and roasted malts. i enjoyed it thouroughly.
too much sweetie for me but in the end she was better with a taste of roasted bread.
Poured a brown color with a small white head.  Sweet aroma with brown sugar, dried fruit, and some yeast.  Flavor matches aroma with a semi-dry finish.  Medium bodied.

Bottle.  Black colors with brown reflection with thin white head thats goes to a ring and lacings.  Yeast, alcohol and some malt caramel aroma.  Taste of malt caramel, fuity (sometimes this beer can be highly fruity), nice carbonation (high) and alcohol at the end.  Nice beer for his kind.  

Bière de couleur noire avec des reflets brun et un mince collet blanc qui forme un anneau et qui colle au verre.  Odeur de levure, alcool et malt caramel (très subtile).  Au goût, cèest le malt caramel, légèrement fruité (quelques fois elle peut être très fruité), c02 ok (élevé).  Bonne bière pour sa catégorie

Aroma:Fruit,apricot and surgar...
Appearance:Brown,small head...
Flavor:Sugar,caramel,fruit,alcohol and plums...

2004  750ml bottle - Surprisingly, the aroma is my least favorite characteristic of this beer.  It isnt very strong, but hints at whats inside, raisin, malts, plum, and other sweet fruit.  A loud POP when I opened the bottle told me there was something working inside as well.  A nice big, quickly dissipating, off-white head that leaves pleanty of lacing.  Color is dark brown with a tint of red.  The flavor is oh so smooth.  Sweet malt, plum, raisin,  date and a touch of Belgian class.  Long lasting palate that leaves me wishing I had another bottle.

Pours like a glass of rootbeer...dark reddish brown with a large, persistent off-white dead. Aroma of sweet malts, touch of yeast, and fruit....raisin for sure, the rest uncertain....but good! Starts off smooth and sweet, balances out with a malty raisin/date flavor, then a nice, dark chocolate, bitter finish. Substantial mouthfeel without being greasy or syrupy. Very pleasant brew.
Pours on the dark end for a Strong Belgian with a small off-white head.  Nice yeasty aroma with some hints of banana, plum, raisin.  Well carbonated.  Smooth and malty flavor.  Good brew.

On draught at Delaneys in New Haven.  Pours out dark red with a nice lingering head.  Taste is very sweet with hints of raisins and bananas.  Ner perfect in carbonation.  One of the best beers Ive had from this brewer.  Excellent beer!

Bottle. Slightly hazy reddish brown with a small creamy head. Sweet fruity malt aromas with a delicious yeast character. Sweet fruity plum/raisin/date/banana flavors with a little alcohol and roasted malt bite bringing it to a fairly quick and dry finish. Warming on the way down. Lively carbonation. The alcohol seems to bring out the spiciness from the yeast.  Not real heavy in the mouth, but by no means a quick drinker. Interesting and very good, but I find La Fin Du Monde a more enjoyable and smoother drinking 9% ABV Canadian Pseudo-Belgian ale.

pours a nice deep brown with a small amount of white head. odor is sweet, caramel and raisin-like. taste is moer of the same.. similar, if i remember, to DFH raison d-etre, but more alcohol taste. . very nice.. good syrupy mouthfeel. very good, but I have to be in a certain mood for this kind of beer.

UPDATED: MAR 23, 2006 I guess this just isnt up my ally because I didnt even want to finish the glass.  Mine poured a murkey brown that made me think of an oil spill in a parking lot.  No head to speak of.  Aroma is of sweet malt and old fruit.  Taste is like prune syrup and spiced Coca-cola.  I know some of you really enjoyed this but frankly, I thought this was nasty.

Pours dark brown with a huge off-white head. Very sweet, fruity aroma, almost like a grape soda, with some earthy backing and port-like notes.  Fruity taste, with a great deal of raisin coming through. Quick dry finish with little alcohol burn to speak of. A little thinner than expected, but an excellent beer.

Pours brown/burdundy with dense, creamy, lasting head. Aromas of sweet ripe fruits and yeast. Specifically prunes and maybe even raisins come to mind. Flavor is sweet, medium bodied. Quick finish. The beer is good but I was expecting so much more. This beer really wasnt very rich at all considering its a belgian with such a high percentile. Ill definitely try it again but Im disappointed.

Acquired in trade with csbosox.Murky riverwater brown.Nose is Heavy on the dark fruits,middle eastern ones:figs dates.And sweet malts.I must look like some kind of freak sitting here with my big fat nose draped over this glass,but ,shit this is nice.Boy,thats nice.The taste is RIGHT in line with the aromas.Very good.
750ml bottle (J284). Hazy dark brown with red hue.  Highly carbonated. Alcool and dry raisin dominates the aroma. Fruity flavors with a tango of again raisin and alcool.  Good belgian example!

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2005 Updated Sept. 2005: Upgrade from 3.7 to 4, having more enjoyed the fruity qualities of this item.


Being that Im an arrogant and demanding hop fiend with a hankering for certain West Coast brews, I wasnt too impressed.  Ive also become more acutely aware of the gradations going in amongst Belgian-style ales.  Les Trappistes seem to have perfected the style, mixing in nice malty background and respectable hop character and a frothy mouthfeel.  This is down a level in distinctness, and even presents watery mouthfeel.  More pronounced alchol character.  Id place this in the same arena as Chimay Bleu as I recall it, which I rated a 3.8 many years back.  This is above 7/10 quality, but not quite 8.

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2007 Looks like a dark brown ale.  Pours with a thick tan head which dissipates quickly.  Tastes like a heavy brown ale.  I would not pay $7 for this beer again.  Not impressive.  Has a ordinary dark ale taste with no originality or different characteristics.  Basically a over priced malty brew.

1 yr old 341 mL bottle L133. Pre-Sleeman. Hazy dark reddish brown with a thick moka head.  Sweet raisin aroma with coriander notes, fruity, and alcohol.  Fudge develops as beer warms up. Sweet licorice raisins in mouth with tequilla alcohol. Notes of coriander and iron.  Earthy overtones. Rich and overpowering, but smooths out as beer warms up.
UPDATED: JUN 24, 2005 From A Bottle.Very dark brown in colour,big frothy head,aroma of fruit and malt,alcohol and marzipan,taste of alcohol and dark fruit,quite bitter.Not for me.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2005 whoa gotta get ahold of this head...dark nutty brown w/ huge head if poured improperly...smokey smell..muted malt/fruit flavors maybe a little bit of chocolate..very warming in the finish....i chilled it a bit and it got better/richer as it warmed ..this is one of the beers i wish i had more experience to properly evalutate...i have to be honest i was a bit disapointed...750 bottle (a310031)

Well presented.  Pours black with a purple tint.  The off-white head begins large and fizzes down to a thin creamy cap that retains well and leaves a good lace.  Complex nose of brown sugar, honey, spices, and traces of alcohol and iron.  Its body is big, warming and complex with a honey sweetness and notes of brown sugar, cinnamon and coffee.  The finish is port-like and a little bitter towards the end.

Pours dark brown with a big beige head made up of tiny bubbles. Strong yeasty grape/prune aroma is very pleasant for a belgian. Strong and muted at the same time, if that makes any sense. Flavor is the same with a slight alcohol presence. Full bodied mouthfeel. Very nice brew.

As the bottle suggests, aroma and finish of port, yet mixed with kool-aid or some other sweet fruity beverage.  Slightly greasy palate.  Beautifully simple complexity in palate and flavor (this makes sense after finishing the bottle).  I will definitely try this again.  Well done.
As I drank this, I envisioned myself lounging on the balcony of a Spanish castle as my lovely senorita Paulina gazed into my eyes with a longing so intense, the sun blushed.  Good stuff.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle from Beers of Europe. Deep black/burgundy colour, with a small ring of mottled froth. Faintly potent aroma of jelly, choc and icey Xmas pud. Very easy to gulp, a supremely balanced and flavoursome mix of root beer, herbs, caramel and vodka, with a smooth hit on the finish. Very tasty indeed - no way a 9%!

The aroma is nutella-like, but a little less sweet, definite hints of hazelnut and chocolate.  The head is beige, and the beer itself is brown bordering on caramel color.  The flavor is nutty and slightly smokey.  It has a light mouthfeel and a mild aftertaste.

Bottle.  One of my contributions to the 2004 beer exchange.  Pours a cloudy dark cherry amber with a huge head that never, never leaves.  Nose is like lots of these multi-fermented belgian styles as it has a sharp sourness that complements a sweet undertone.  Aroma also has a tart fruity quality... I like the nose a lot.  Immediate impression on flavor was the alcohol content, which sort of surprised me.  Nice spicy sweetness that gives way to that tartness that emerged in the aroma... I wish that I could dissect all of the tastes in this one.  Some sweet cookie dough and nice tart apples along with a great ending yeasty bite.  Fabulous feel in the mouth with a little less than full body, but perfect carbonation with both small and large bubbles rising in the palate.  Just a damn fine brew by Unibroue.  Another great story on the label as well.  Something about these French and their obsession with Lucifer...

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2005 Number 100, woohoo! :-)750ml bottle, specially selected for the occasion. Pours opaque brown with huge head. Sweet, fruity prune aroma. Deep, filling fruity-sweet flavour with a good mouthfeel for a beer this strong - a bit prickly. As it warms, toffee appears. Aftertaste is of Christmas pudding. Veh, veh good.

Woah, I can smell this one on the pour. No need to take a close whiff. Head disappears fast. Wouldve been nice if it lasted some time. Really raisiny with some plum, maybe? Nice malty flavors. Tingly to the tongue & dry to the palate. I dont doubt this is a great brew; I just dont dig raisins and thats what I detect. Will re-rate again though just to be fair.

Out of all of the Unibrou ales, this is probably my favorite. 

Still, Im not fond of their particular yeast. This is a well-crafted complex ale. Dark and smooth, yet strong.
A very darkish brown ale. Tastes of plums and spicy wheat; however, it is quit smooth for  a 9% beer. They did nothing wrong here!

Bloody ripper.  Taste and smell of ripe dark fruits, plums, raisins etc.  A little bit of bitterness, but soft enough to yield to the rich malty fruity flavours.  A dark plum-brown color with a thin off-white head.   A bit of warming alcohol taste, and a slightly bitter finish.  A pretty smooth trippel.
Small head, colour of cola.  Smell of plums, other fruit.  Nut much carbonation (which is nice).  Very pleasant & not at all heavy or overbearing for such a dark (and seemingly meaty) ale.

Pours a very dark black/brown color. Rich aroma of wheat, sweetness, fruit and spice. Rich fruity flavor up front. Nice spicy kick. Alcohol is present in the finish. Nice warmer for a rainy winter night.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2004   This beer is similar to Rochefort Trappistes 8 in that it has a raisin like taste to it.  The aroma is very similar to that beer also.  This aroma is a little stronger.  The taste is like wine, orange peel, raisins, plum, licorice and blackberrys mainly.  The aftertaste is sweet which I like.  Good beer.

75cl bottle, BB 03-19-07  Dark.  Big fluffy head, thick clinging lace.  Bananas, oranges, peaches, apple pie spicy aroma.  Very spicy, sweet beer.  Lingering sweetness.  Complex in its massive spicing.  Full body.  Orange peel nougat.  Pretty good, just a little heavy handed on the spice(o-peel?)...Ill bet sitting a few years would do it some good.

This is one of my favourites. I was hoping the stores here would get a 750er and then rate it but no. They have no love for the Trois Pistoles.. wankers. Very complex taste, one to ponder, of licorice, blackcherry, plum/raisin. Sweet and smoothe. Aroma follows in the footsteps of just the right taste in my opinion. Alchohol is hidden. I cant believe I ran out:( vaaaa

Bouteille de 341 ml. Arôme: Odeur de fruit, en particulier de raisin. Présence aussi de bois. Apparence: Couleur brune foncée avec des reflets de rouge. Carbonisation moyenne. Col mousseux moyen de couleur beige. Saveur: Goût de fruit sucré. Le haut taux dalcool est complètement caché. Palette: Aucune amertume. Agréable sensation de porto en bouche. (Rating #34)
Great beer.  Wonderful brew in every way.  Delicious in everyway.  Very fruity and smooth.  Similar to a Chimay in my opinion.  Great beer.

Smells of yeast, black pepper, cherry, maybe a little leather. Deep, opaque mahogany with thin tan head. Mellow in mouth feel with a slightly saccharine finish. Earth, plum, yeast and spice in the flavor. Exceedingly well balanced ale that continues to give up new flavors as it warms.

Had this in the MIGHTY HAMMS GOBLET!  Nose of cherries, plums, and anise.  Pours a dark walnut with a light brown frothy head, marginally lasting, no lace.  Hints of dried fruit and spice abound combined with a low acidic, warm alcoholic middle and full sweet finish.  Dry and fizzy body with a chalky feel to the finish.

12oz bottle. Sampled at 51 degress from a New Belgium   Dark reddish-brown color with a big off white head that stuck around for a couple minutes.  There is a good amount of particluate matter in the beer.  Sweet smell. Raisins?  The flavor is sweet with good amount of complexity.  Flavors of overripe bananas, raisins, sour candies.  I would not have guessed this was 9%.  The finish is bittersweet and fruity, but fairly dry. The mouthfeel is great. The beer coats the mouth and I think the fizziness of the beer (certainly not over the top) really "massages" your tongue. Pretty tasty stuff.  Resampled at 58 degrees and the hop character seems to emerge a bit more.
My Favorite beer from our neighbors to the north.  Theres alot of flavors happening under that cork!
Brown sugary aroma, dark brown cloudy appearance. Full and sweet taste. Almost similar to a sweet red wine.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2005 Dark, dark brown in color. Sweet in smell, sweeter in taste. Lots of ripe, dark fruit and roasted malt. Finishes with some familiar Belgian-style spice.  Smoother and lighter than would be expected considering the 9% alcohol content.

Pours a murky dark brown with a fizzy head. Head dissapates quickly, but returns with just a swirl of the glass.
Thin sheet of lacing. 
Aroma is sweet, malt, raisin, prunes, cooked bannana, alcohol. 
Flavor is sweet and tangy. ripe fruit, (apricot, prune, raisin) some spice, with a lemony tang at the end. 
Creamy mouthfeel. 
Alcohol is well hidden, and it sneaks up on you.

Bottle.  Deep, dark and murky, just like the bottle art.  Good head and great lacing.  Wonderfully complex aroma, consisting of banana, licorice, raisin, mustiness, citrus and some floral hops.  The alcohol presence makes the flavor a little unbalanced.  Other than the noticeable alcohol, its very malty and smooth.  The finish is a bit dry and bitter, but not too much.  As it warms, the bite get taken away, and it becomes very smooth.
Bottle: Dark brown, medium head, aroma of burnt coffee, toffee and dark chocolate. Taste is very complex and hides exceptionally well it´s high alcohol level. Great Brew.

Poured a giant head with large bubbles.  Head didnt last long and it seemed to be overly carbonated.  Aroma is strong with alcohol and slight over ripe banana.  Weird tangy taste with with lots of carbonation on the tongue.  OK...but probably would not buy again.
Excellent strong ale.  aroma is of banana, alcohol, and malt.   Very well balanced. Like a smooth, soft licorice pillow.  I was surprised to see 9% abv because it drinks much lighter.

Bottle poured a dark murky brown with no head in my glass.
Very small  fruity aroma but a very rich flavor of spice and fruit and a good tangy finish.
 this is a very good beer and very easy drinking.

bottle. deep, cloudy, cherry wood with an off white soap sudsy head... wine/spice aroma... bittersweet unrequited love flavors that linger on the tongue (almonds?)... a milky mouthful... best enjoyed while watching  a great Hithcock movie... suggested flick: Vertigo.

At the KULMINATOR in Antwerp.  Great reddish -brown color with a deep warm glow and a slightly beige colored froth. Nice aromas of dried fruits with a fine licorice touch and aromas of asian spices, good malts, tuttefrut, brown sugar and some yeast. Soft mouth attac with a light sweet caracter and with a fine spicy complexity. Lively aftertaste with some freshness that brings all the components well in balance.

Very nice strong ale, not unlike an Abbey dubbel. Pours a deep russet brown, almost opaque, with a thin, creamy beige head. Hints of plum and raisin in the nose. The taste is complex, dark licorice and fruit with a distinct alcohol bite. Creamy on the palate with a pleasant lingering sweetness. A very good beer.

Bought in the bottle from the excellent "Beers of Europe" shop near Kings Lynn.

Very dark brown. Distinct yeast sedement, nice taste but a bit to strong to be consideder very drinkable.

Nice lable too

Deep brown in color with a nice tan head. Aroma was a classic belgian with yeast, spice, and cloves. Flavor was yeast, spice, malts, nutmeg, and dark fruit. This had a nice malty mouthful. I could feel the bubbles run across my tongue with the initial taste. Starts sweet and finishes with a toned down sweetness.

Light, frothy head.  Aroma resembles strong wheat beers; clove and yeast predominate.    Fruity palate, slightly yeasty, with alcohol and sugar aftertaste.  Unlike Maudite, which surpasses Duvel in my opinion, the Belgian strong ales have much more character than Trois Pistoles.

Bottle:  Pours a dark coffee colour body with think foamy mocha coloured head.  Aromas of citrus and yeast.  Very sweet smelling.  Tastes of alcohol is strong, fruity and has slight bitterness.  Has bitter and alcoholic aftertaeste.  Not too bad!
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2004 This is my favorite from Unibroue so far.  Very balanced malt flavoring with hints of berries and grapes.  Only a slight alcohol presence.

Dark ruby color with a coarse, quickly fading head.  Aroma is fruity and wine-like with hints of dark cherry and spice (clove?).  No malt aroma to speak of. Flavor not as complex as hoped - slightly fruity with some spice and malt.  Moderately dry with no hop bitterness.  Balanced, but has a thinness to the flavor.  Highly carbonated and effervescent, with a much lighter body than expected.  9% ABV not evident until later.  Pretty dissapointed with this one - maybe got a bad four-pack.  Not as complex as expected for a strong dark belgian.

11.01.04  750ml bottle.  Dark brown pour, like rootbeer, little head left after initial foam.  Aromas of Christmas -- not the spicey, mulled Christmas, but the Christmas morning in the kitchen smells like brown sugar, fruit cake, deep vinous notes.  Lovely.  Flavors remind of a dubbel that has been reduced over a stove...deep and malty, its too complex for my amature palate to understand.  Has some recognizable Unibroue characteristics.  Dark fruits all over the place, each in its place as the balance of this brew is sublime.  Nice dry finish.
UPDATED: NOV 14, 2007 I could only taste the alcohol...and like the description, its similar to Port wine.  If you like port, youll like this.

Brown small head with a dark borwn opaque pour.  Amazingly well masked alcohol.  Smells better than it tastes.  Sweet malty yeasty in flavor.  Slight citrusy bite to the finish...took very few notes on this one.  Suppose I was in more of a mood to just enjoy than analyze.

Dark murky reddish colour with small off white head. Aroma is heavenly, you can sit with your nose in thiss stuff for hours. Strong malts, some sweetness with dark grapes. Flavor is also very good, malty and sweet, lots of fruit.
Pours out a dark brown with a lacing head. There is a nice aroma of fruit. It is a nice complex taste with notes of fruit and malts. The ABV is well hidden and doesnt hit you until afterwards.

750 Botle  Pours a very dark, cloudy redish brown.  Small light tan head that maintains a nice film on top and leaves very nice lacing.   Aromas are sweet pitted fruit and grapes and some of that belgian spice.  Flavor cant quite keep up woth the aroma.  Those fruity notres dont come through much, and the belgian flavors are sudued compared to others of the style.  Nice smooth feel with mefium to lively carbonation. Pleasant and drinkable with a well hidden ABV, but a bit over rated maybe.

Someone on this site (I forget who) told me a while back that Unibroue was seriously overrated and generally far too sweet. At the time I didnt believe them because my experience a few years ago, especially with La Fin Du Monde, was particularly good. Im beginning to believe them now. Its not that this is a bad beer (though Eau Benite was pushing it) theres just no way it deserves top 100 status. I didnt find it too sweet though...  Looks quite transparent in the bottle and when pouring, but is completely opaque in my Duvel tulip. Decent thin smooth head. This actually smells really good - vaguely reminiscent of Rochefort 8 with the gingerbread dough and allspice, quite a bit of toasted sugar, cinnamon and a bit of egg nog. The aroma really sets you up for a big letdown in the flavour stakes. Its really watery and thin, with a faint malted milk flavour and little else. No discernable alcohol, though I wouldve appreciated anything to make it more interesting! No dark malt character in flavour or aroma and no hop character. Its really quite stunning how little flavour they manage to pack in a 9% beer. Thanks to ol_juntan for lugging this across the country for me! Oh yeah, Ive heard people compare this to Chimay Blue too - I disagree completely.
Dark-dark brown and a fine big head. Real pure aroma and flavor of the typical strong belgian ale. Caramel. Well-balanced. And a bit boring.

There is no doubt its a Unibroue with the first sip.  Not much head, but the flavor!  Smooth and delicate, with that yeasty spicy Unibroue character. 9% alcohol completely hidden, until you get to the bottom of the glass and realize you have a nice buzz and enjoyed every sip.
341ml bottle from Beers of Europe. Pours dark, murky and with a slight head. Almost like a Rochefort beer, dark and malty, chocolate, spice and plenty of alcohol. This is really nice.

I really enjoy this Belgian Strong Ale.  I really like the Belgians and this is the best I have had in this category.  When they say it is similar to a port wine...it really is.  It is a nice dark beer and the head really depends on the bottle.  One bottle I had there was a nice head and another there was almost no head.  The spice and flavors are very pleasent.

Bottle.  I thought this was a very nicely done belgian strong ale.  It wasnt super super, but it was very nice.  It did impress me and Im rating it highly although I dont feel that its as amazing as its made out to be.  Try it out nonetheless

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2004 A wonderful fruity nose, a rich umber color, a flavor most unexpected in a dark ale of ripe plums, cherry, yet not sweet or cloying, a pleasing aftertaste.  I had this excellent brew at a football party and even the Coors Light devotees (what can I say, old friends of mine) agreed that this is one mighty tasty ale, perhaps there is hope for them ;-)
An old favourite from my pre-RB days. Dark mahogany colour with quickly dissipating head. Great flavour of dark fruits. unibroues yeastiness and spices. Youd never know this was 9%.

Pretty nice! Poured a hazy dark red with a moderate sized even after a fast pour. Nice head to start out but died quickly and left a slippery lace that didnt stick. This saddened me.

Nice fragrance on this one but nothing special. Dark fruits, bready malts and yeast. High alcohol well hidden in the aroma.

Outstanding flavor! Raisins, yeast, plums, prunes, buttered bread and alcohol. Very smooth going down with great mouthfeel.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2004 (Bottle) Delightfull darkish color, needs a larger head. Christmas pudding like aroma. Great drinkability needs a little more mouthfeel but the flavors are even better that the hints of fruit from the aroma. Superlative

Deep dark hazy browns and oranges, thin tan fizzy head.  Ultra complex nose of raisin, plum, cherry, brown sugar and spice, with additional red wine notes to boot.  Intense vanilla coated dark fruit and spiced fruitcake flavors blend beautifully.  Hint of alcohol shows up at cellar temps, but does not overwhelm.  Full bodied, fizzy carbonation, dry, dark fruit and caramel finish.  Awesome brew!

Pours reddish brown and murky with an off-white head.  The aroma is not as strong as I would have liked, but pleasant nonetheless.  The initial taste is sweet with the taste of fruits and a little spicy, leading to a clean finish, with the alcohol hidden.  The body is pretty full and well-carbonated.  It was very refreshing overall.  My only complaint would be with the sweet character, which could have been toned down.  In its strongish moments, it almost reminded me of iced tea.  Although a stronger brew, I would bet this would make a great thirst-quencher on a hot day.
Rich brownish head, slightly sweet smell, lots of fruits in the taste, no taste of alcohol, very well balanced. A bit sweet, but a very well made brew.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 [12 oz. bottle] Dark brown color with a fizzy and puffy white head. Spicy and sweet malt aroma with hints of dried fruits, cloves and licorice. The flavor is very spicy and fruity with those same licorice hints throughout and a finish that tastes exactly like grapes. Hides the alcohol well. Very sweet and fizzy.
Dark brown with nice head. Malty, dried fruits, spice, liqourice. Fizzy. Very nice.
UPDATED: MAR 10, 2006 Dark brown color, spicy malty aroma, light sweet fruity taste, full body, light alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2004 Draft. I came to this beer the long way around. This was one of the beers tapped at the Oak Lawn "Fall on the Green" Festival the weekend. My homebrew club, <a href=http://www.bossbeer.org target=blank>BOSS, volunteers to pour the "good" beers, in return, we get to keep the leftovers for our picnic the following weekend (the village buys the beer, and their license is only good for the three days. If we didnt take it, theyd have had to pour it out! <font color=blue>Sacré!</font>) I couldnt make the picnic, but came in Sunday to help clean up, and this was still flowing! So after all that...
Pours a lovely brown. By this time, the head is kicking up pretty frothily, understandably. Has a great taste that to me gave just a light impression of cherries, more from the yeast character. Also a well-balanced spiciness that stays in the background for support. Overall great malty taste. This probably wasnt the best condition for trying it out in, but it held up very well. I even filled a growler for later!

This one pours dark brown with a thick tan head.  Aroma is spicy, with a sour presence.  Moderately thick on the palate.  Flavor is spicy, with the malts dominating.  This one is not as strong or complex as I expect from the style.  A good brew, but in my opinion not deserving of a 4+ rating.  Will try another to make sure.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2005 Dark brown with a small tan head. Aroma of dates, raisins and malt. Sweet
malt and dark fruit flavors abound but
the sweetness doesnt last and isnt
cloying. Flavor reminds me of Traquairs
Jacobite Ale with a little more bite.

Nice dark head. Complex taste that reminds me of an old ale. Very present alcohol at 9 percent. Tastes of dates and is pretty thick and complicated. This isn’t really my cup of tea, but it is very good nonetheless.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2005 A very dark, almost mahogany brown with little of any head.  Very aromatic - perhaps like marmalade with a hint of nuts and spices.  Strong alcohol presence.  It has a tart, spicy finish - not unpleasant in the mouth.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Oak Lawn, IL<font size=-1>

Pours out a cloudy brown. Little to no head.  Interesting full aroma. Smells of sweet dried fruit. Dates? The taste is sweet, malty and fruity. It glides over the tongue, and has an overall impressive mouthfeel. This is an excellent beer.

Bottle.  Dark brown pour.  Very flowery aroma - roses?? - not your typical unibroue aroma.  Nice malt taste, unibroue yeast taste present but not distracting - balanced well.  Strong alcohol presence as well but again, balanced well.  A fantastic beer, well done.

355ml bottle. Best before 5/7/06
Pours a full tan head, a deep brown color, hazy, opaque. CO2 rolling up along the edges of the lacing. The aroma is malty, spicy, and earthy with a background presence of alcohol and some tartness. The taste is sweet, roasted, and spicy, with a tart middle and a dry finish that lingers with liquorish and sassafras. A medium bodied mouth-feel with sufficient effervescence. A well-rounded brew. Not overpowering for such an intense style. Taste was best around 53 degrees ? started loosing its balance as it warmed more. Might have needed some more aging.
Dark brown, ok head. Aroma is fruity and from licorice. Floral flavor with fruity notes. Somewhat bitter in the finish. I could not see what is so great wit this beer.

bottle from pioneer 74th street NYC,
deep purple w/tan head.
nice fruity aroma,grapes mabey.
same kind of flavor thinnish head
good doe
Drank this in NYC at Grammercy Tavern on draft.  A pint of this big hitter was a lot.  Damn was it good.  Nice and thick with great Belgian ale taste.  Drink this happily, but dont drive afterwards.

Dark violet color, with a short tan head that recedes too soon. Rich, heady aromas come wafting out the bottleneck, plump with associations: Raisins, plums, spices, brandy, dark rum, smoke,, and so much more. Bracing onslaught of hops on the palate, but excellent buttress of malt backs it up.
Fantastic spark on the tongue, and a wonderful sweetness that follows after the drizzling of hops. Transendant complexity, utterly other-worldly, and overjoyous.
A real treat of a beer, and a rare delight. Only the finest of human beings should put this to their lips, as a benedicton and reflection of the worthiness of their souls. So, all you slobs, go better yourselves before daring to crack the cage and cork. So go do community service, adopt a stray kitten, give a street urchin a quarter, let someone on the freeway before you, be kind to our fine feathered friends, turn a Bud man on to oatmeal stouts, just do something to realign your karma to make you worthy enough to pour this fine beer down your gullet.

thin foamy tan head, goes fairly quickly.  cloudy dark brown color, ruby at tcenter and amber/tan at edges.  thin lace at rim or glass.   candi nose, yeast and plum/fig/cherry.  malty alcohol flavor, medium body.  lively carbonation.  creamy & foamy mouthfeel.  very clean fisnish.  I dont think this is overrated.

Pours a dark brownish black with a small dissapating head. Aroma is very spicey and yeasty. Taste is complex- wine, roasted malt, dark fruits, spices, cherry. Mouthfeel is very full, round and creamy. Lively carbonation and dry finish. Even though this isnt my favorite style, this is a great brew.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2006 7 May 2004 (re-rated 3 Feb 06) - Sampled AIBA 2004 - Cherry hop malt aroma. Clear dark brown colour, low head and suds lacing.  Spiritous cherry and big hop malt flavours.  Sweet malt hop aftertaste, with medium mouthfeel.
Pours of deep brown, large tan head.  Smells of sweet malts and some spice, raisons.  Tastes sweet with a weird mouthfeel, came off as overcarbonated.  very overrated.

Pours dark murky brown with a medium, very long lasting tan head. Rich malty caramel aroma with notes of plum, chocolate, port and alcohol. Silky smooth medium-full mouthfeel. Sweet, suprisingly inoffensive taste. Starts sweet caramel and progresses to raisins and chocolate. Slightly dry finish, with a hint of alcohol in the aftertaste, along with some lingering spices. Really top drop. I could sip this all evening.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2007 May 22nd 2007 re-rate

Dark fruit, candy sugar, mild spice, malt and a hint of yeastiness. The body is a dark ruddy brown and holds a rapidly diminishing tan head. Plum and sweet rum soaked bread pudding like notes int he fore. Light spice. Some faint raisin notes and a bit of candied dark fruit again int he finish. This bottle was a year or so old and seemed to have gotten more sweet.

Original Rating was a 3.8

One of my favorites from Unibroue. The malt, fruit and candied fig flavors mesh with the alcohol well to make a well balanced and fun drinking beer.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2004 Dark Burgundy Body with a distinct head without any residual.  Very Fruity with a touch of spice and hint of dark chocolate.  Savoured and Enjoyed immensely... its a perfect summer beer.  Even better on subsequent tastes.

Dark brown body with a tan coloured head. The head was mostly lasting but left very little lacing. Mainly a malty aroma to me, dry chocolate and then some dried fruit. Taste is nice sweetness, good alcohol, medium body to make it easier to drink, cherry, chalky and slightly zesty. Overall a good beer to drink.
pours dark purple/brown, strong flavors and taste. fruity and full. very nice flavors of stong alcohol % and full bodied flavors. mabey plum or grape. great beer.
Strong, complex flavors.  Lots of floral notes.  very malty, but too sweet for my tastes.  I can see how lovers of this style would rate this at the top.
UPDATED: OCT 12, 2005 Pours bugundy/brown with thin head...smells yeasty, earthy fruity with a hint of grape...port is a very accurate description, but very short...very complex...sweet and yeasty...
Wheat malt, dark fruits in nose.  Flavor is dark fruits, wheat, yeast with a sourish alcohol finish.  Fluffy light texture with champagne carbonation
Black, with a nice head. Aroma is fruity and a little vinous. Flavor brings some alcoholbut also offer a nice body. Fruity and malty.
Bottle. Dark beer with a thin white head. Aroma of figs & plums along with cotton candy. Medium body. Theres a rich malt flavor with some sweetness and plum fruits. Dry finish.

Pours a very dark ruby with little to no head. Aroma is of dark fruit but not strong. Flavor is complex.....a mixture of plums and malts and other stuff I cant describe right now. The reference to a port wine is deserving. Has a fizzy mouthfeel. It is almost too sweet but the hops and slight yeast bring it back with a solid finish. It smells better than it tastes.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2005 ReRate: 1/17/05: This has a yeasty, somewhat doughy aroma with a definite grape presence; flavors include raisin, port, plum, grape, cola, and heavy licorice; its a tad medicinal and peppery; note of oak and wood, adequatly carbonated, thick, and oily palate; a slight sourish and dry finish; very nice and very complex. This is stellar.

bottle. pours a purplish black with a thick tan head. sweet blueberry and yeast aroma. alcohol is very prominent. powdery dry yeast taste and mouthfeel.  dry apple taste is also noticeable on finish.  This is surprisingly dry. but its not bad.

UPDATED: FEB 8, 2006 I think this is tops of the regular line from Unibroue. Served in a wide goblet the perfume is rich and spicy with a fruit pie aroma. Wild carbonation keeps up a fine and rocky head that leads to and empty glass covered with lacework. The real key to this beer seems to be the yeast. It leaves the malt a touch sweet, but provides a dry and complex spice to the aroma.

Very dark brown with red tints and a small beige head.  Aromas are bready, yeast and earthy with some winter fruit.  A bit like St Bernadus Pater.  Flavours are yeasty with fruit, mild berries and a lack of alcohol considering its strength.  Better than the sum of its parts.

Dark beer with a light and initially frothy head.  The aroma is very, very light and the flavour is fruity but again very light and not as strong as what you would expect from the alcohol percentage.  Overall quite a plain and ulimately disappointing beer.
Pours dark dark amber with a small white head. Man this stuff is smooth. Flavor is fruity and malty with a small alcohol afterkick. Im working on a 750ml right now. Good stuff.
UPDATED: JAN 10, 2005 Bottle @ Akkurat, StockholmNice label. wineous aroma. Sweet and malty. Full bodied. Complex. Could do with some bitterness.

This is one of my favorites from Unibroue.  Murky dark brown; not the prettiest beer, but what it lacks in looks, it makes up for in taste.  It smells great, very unique in both taste and aromathe flavor is fantastic, only fleeting hints at its high alcohol content.  Grab this if you havent had it.

poured dark brown with a tan head. aroma sour alcohol,plums, molasses, dark fruits, port wine, very good. flavor the alcohol hits me 1st, thangot some honey , caramel, apple, malts, grapes, plums. another good one will buy more

2000 Vintage. Cloudy, dark brown, Light brown head. Some sediment. Fine bead.  Sweet, robust aroma of banana, peach, plums, raisins, port, cream, bubble gum, & pepper. Full bodied. Good carbonation. Complex, yeasty flavour of banana, peaches, pears, plums, raisins, bubble gum, & pepper. Some nutty & vinous elements in the middle. Lingering, alcohol laden finish.

My first Unibroue, and Im very pleased. Pours a creamy dark reddish/maroon. Thick off-white head that kinda vanished. Not such a strong aroma, but def good fruits (raisins, plums, slight alcohol.) The flavor was awesome. Maybe Im a little inexperienced, but I thought it was going to be stronger. Definately a lot like a barley wine. Full of flavor. Sick beer.

Day one of the new beer laws in Georgia.  No more 6% limits.  Let the drinking begin!  Pours dark brown with red highlights.  Wonderful fruity aroma, with port, apples and sweet malts.  This one smells good from 3 feet away.  Very sweet on the tongue with yeast coming out along with more fruit, sherry with a wonderful malt presence.  Very warming, but the alcohol is almost undetectable.  Stellar.
I dont know what the fuck I meant about this rating, so I will have to rerate it soon. It goes like this: Trois Pistoles - 3,3 (-5) aroma + ,flavour + alc = -

Pours a typical Belgium Strong Ale with a dark  rusty colour but without a lot of head. The Aroma is reminiscent of an aged wine complete with fruity overtones but with the added punch of yeast. Plums, Raisins, Grapes, and Berries come to mind. The Flavour isnt quite as effervescent as I would like but the mouthfeel is pleasantly full. The Brew goes down easy and leaves a sweetish malty fermented fruit finish with an alcohol kick that makes the beer satisfying to the senses. I would prefer a bit more fizz but for what it is and for what its worth I love this concoction. O Canada. Kuddos!
Dark burgundy brownish color. Fizzy lasting head. Fruity plum rasin cherry aroma with some alcohol. Tatse is strong on fruit, complex with a crisp dry finish.

Bottle: Well this is definitely a Belgian Strong Ale.  Someone claims this has no aroma.  Not true.  The aroma is more subtle than that of an IPA or Imperial Stout, but its there.  I can smell alcohol, pepper, clove, banana, and alcohol.  Had this beer at first almost fridge temperature....this beer is obviously not meant to be enjoyed cold.  It needs to warm up to almost room temp. before it starts getting really good.  Once mildly chilled however, the flavors come out.  This beer has its share of variety, leather, pepper, clove, carrot, melons, cherries, alcohol, and aged cheese.  Finishes very dry, with hints of spice and banana that remind me of a witte.  Interesting beer, I liked it.
Very dark, a mix of brown and purple.  Scent is subtle and hard to define.  Raisin/grape/plum tastes. Very smooth, easy drinking, and delicious.
No aroma.  Interesting taste.  Has the feel of a stout, and a  Beligan with a hint of fruit all rolled into one.  Works well for washing down the brats!

medium brown in color  w/ a thick dark head.
Carries a slightly sweet aroma similar to that of other belgins.
Carries a nice smooth taste w/ some surprising carbonation as i didnt think it showed in the glass.
I like this beer a lot.. great flavor good looks, nice smell, and a good kick.. this is the second beer Ive tried from unibroue and it was great again.

UPDATED: JAN 22, 2005 Nose of caramel, alcohol and fruit. Dark color head that mostly dimishes. Front is caramel and fruit malts. Finish is spicy and yeast. Delicous beverage. One of the best belgians I’ve had!
Retaste: Awesome fruit, yeast, spice, very underated.

Deep, murky brown color, medium but fugaceous head.  Nice aroma, malt, caramel and fruits with alcohol vapors, complex and inviting. Nice caramel, malt and alcohol flavors. Thin palate. Very good, a nice beer to have in the cellar, especially the 750 ml bottles !

12 oz bottle.  Pours dark with head that disappeared faster than alcohol around Ted Kennedy.  Arom is of alcohol (most noticeable), caramel, cherries, and roasted malts.  Solid and smooth, with aftertaste of caramel as alcohol taste dissipates.  Good, but not great.  A nice mouthfeel, though.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2005 750 ml Bottle.  Pour is deep purple.  Almost looks like wine but it has a lingering creamy head that is thin but always present.  Sweet smell, malty.  This would be a good way to transition from a wine drinker to a beer drinker.  Very tiny hint of the alcohol.  Pretty good.
Very Dark Red Coloring.  Good Had. Spicy/Fruity Aroma.... Sweet. Malt.  Fruit.  An excellent Unibroue.

Very cloudy dark brown with residents. Huge foaming tan head. Very pleasing nose with a sweet fruity quality (rasins, cherry, apricot). More fruit in flavor, again rasins but a fresh apple like quality too. Smooth and gengle palate, you hardly feel the 9% at all (in the taste at least ;-)

Deep copper in color with ruby highlights and  large off-white ehad. Aroma is of bread,yeast,nuts, dark fruit and caramel. Rich creamy mouthfeel, with a warming alcohol prescense,malty,fruity,yeasty,winelike.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2014 This beer is not as good as it once was. A fine brew still but no longer a world classic. +++  Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a hazy dark mahogany color with a large fluffy tan head that left a bit of lacing. The aroma was very yeasty with notes of cherry, fig, raisin, caramel, marzipan, brown sugar and alcohol. The favor was tangy, sweet and malty with molasses, toffee, bread, a strong yeasty presence and notes of cherry, raisin and jam. Long finish of yeast, cherry and raisin. Medium body but a bit overcarbonated. Excellent but no longer world class.

Bit of head that faded sorta quick. Nose not that impressive but typically Unibroue: somewhat complex and hopping. Tasted heavy as you can feel some alcohol in there. Not the best Unibroue product out there but nice nonetheless.

Bottle, GL snifter: Muddled reddish brown with a fading off-white head and some lace. The aroma has notes of roasted dark malts, caramel, pipe tobacco, ripe currents and pears, floral hops, and woody/ earthy yeast esters. The nose however is weaker than expected from style. The taste is what makes this beer. Wonderful fruity and spicy notes throughout with a light vinous nature. Mild bitterness and a touch of acidity provides depth and balance. Nice raisiny and mocha undertones too. The mouthfeel is lively and dangerously refreshing for the style and ABV (which is very well hidden). Started questionable but finished with a bang! This is one darn solid brew, now the question is, will Sleeman screw it up? Recommended.
I bought this beer in France, so it may have been a little old, but I really enjoyed it, It had a good head, A bit bitter, Spicy, Good finish, not bad!

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2009 Enormous of white head, deep mirky brown appearance, great aroma, citrusy tart with other fruit accents, real sweet flavor, alcohol is very present, spices, brown sugar, maple syrup and tobacco, raisins for sure, bitter malt finish, I really like popping the cork, it makes me feel like my 7 bucks was well spent.

pours dark brown in color with a nice tan head that goes away the more that is poured.  i must say, i was expecting this to be alot better than it was.  this beer is no where near as good as ommegang.  smell is fruity with a hint of raisins, and taste is smooth with a nice fruity flavor left after the beer is swallowed.  a bit over rated, but still a good beer that is worth trying.

Pours a dark carmel.  A nice head to start out with.  Hints of fruit in the background.  Alchohol tast is present.  I really like the job uhibroue does with their beers.  This is one of my favs.  Lets hope this one stays.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2004 Got in 12 oz. bottles. Has a dark clody brown color. The head is small and a light tan color. Aroma is brown sugar, and a very strange peppermint or menthol. The taste is peaches, tobacco and bread. The finish is a weird sourness. While very interesting, the entire package was thrown off a little by the astringent aroma. Still, an enjoyable drink.

Very dark purple brown with a medium light brown head.  Aroma of plum, raisin, pepper, straw, black cherry and currant with a hint of alcohol.  Medium velvety body with lively carbonation.  Vinous flavor of plum, raisin, berry, milk chocolate, currant, cognac and a hint of roast. Excellent.  Another winner from Unibroue.

Bottled. 
Hazy dark amber. Wonderful creamy-ish aroma with mostly figs, kind of velvetty. Rich tidbitty flavour from prune, Seville Orange and licorice. Also quite malty and with small notes of ginger. A bit frothy mouthfeel but this will turn creamy and velvetty in a year or two. Very well balanced. Thanks to Dixen for bringing this from Naestved.

Bottled.
Hazy, dark amber with a small head.
A smooth aroma with notes of toffee and coffee.
A soft palate with a spicy flavour with pomerance and citrus.

poured into a Chimay goblet;  smells of ripe figs and fresh bread with a slight alcoholic note.  brown with a reddish hue and almost no head. Very little lace.  Apricots, raisin bread, plums, and figs throughout the taste of this beer.  I really like the feel of this beer on my tongue.  Tingly with a full bodied feel that finishes dry and smooth.  A beer from our neighbors from the North that I could drink regularly.

Why the heck havent I tried this beer before?  Amazing stuff, I truly hope that Sleemans recognizes the value of the micro-geek market and keeps this baby around.  Dark brown appearance, fizzier than I was expecting.  Marvelous aroma of peaches and apricots that reminds me of a massage oil that used to be produced by Crabtree & Evelyn.  No comment as to the use of the massage oil.  Flavor is slightly of alcohol, but is dominated by a lush malt complemented by a myriad of fruit flavors.  A beautiful beer.  Incidentally, nice to have the Spaniard rate this right before me.

Pours nice but fades fast,which happens at this % level. Nice roast aroma, full mouth feel and very smooth pull. Residual sweetness is true to style, prefer more hops myself. Very enjoyable pint and it would be a shame if it got down graded by the takeover. An expensive beer to brew as far as grain bill is concerned and that could be its eventual downfall.
Muy buena cerveza negra o porlo menos oscurilla, la primera cerveza canadiense q pruebo en mi vida.

Bottle 3-3 on cork. Sweet and spicey cookie nose. Pours a dark orange/red but is very clear though the light. The flavor is sweet but not cloying, creamy in texture with a slighty dy chalky finish.
This is a great beer. It would be a shame if Sleeman stopped making this gem.
Nice pour, dark brown with little head. Smell of rippened apples or pears. Tastes of plum and hazelnut. One of the better Strong Ales ive had. Very nice!
Cool Bottle.  Strong smell and taste of fruits and fizz.  Very delicious and very high in alcohol.

341 ml bottle dated Feb. 2002. Murky amber brown colour with a thin but lasting tan coloured head. Cherries, raisins, caramel, bread, and yeast in the aroma. Moderately fruity (cherry and plum) and yeasty flavours leading to a port like quality before finishing lightly bitter. Notable alcohol presence, but dangerously drinkable for 9%. Full bodied dry mouthfeel.

A nice large head, with a dark brown and hazy body. Has a good and sweet, but not that strong aroma. On the other hand is it the one of best beer flavors i have ever tried! Roasted malt and nuts makes a bit bitter, but the variouse fruits makes it equal sweet! Very spicy and full of different flavors ... A F***ing good beer adventure! It is very tasty without biting bitterly ind your mouth, and is has a PERFECT consistency with the ultimate balance of bobles... I gotta drink more of these beers!
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 this beer is very smooth considering the alcohol percentage,dark in color but again,smooth in taste.excellent!

Great brew. Overwhelming aroma. Smells like a strange mix of fermenting fruit, jockstraps and chocolate. Looks fabulous. Chocolate...dark chocolate brown, almost black. Nice white head. In fact head was a brilliant white in comparison to the beer. Tastes thick and creamy. So mouthfeel excellent. Brew is complex. Noted: Chocolate, raisins, plums and jockstraps. Signature Unibroue jockstrap yeasty flavor. Good brew. To be shared with likeminded individuals.
G-rat
Awesome. Smells a bit fruity, and goes down fairly easily considering it clocks in at 9%. Bottle artwork is just as amazing as the beer inside.
Malt and cherry aromas which was very pleasing. Dark brew with a smallish head. Sweet malt flavours that were a bit roasty and didnt come across as rich as I was expecting.
Reddish-brown body.  Minimal head.  Nose was like a plum port.  Some spice.  Inviting.  Flavor was full and rich and fruity and satisfying.  Very good drink.
lightly alcoholic, maple-syrupy aroma.  complex sweet body with a mellow bitterness at the end.  perfect for a dessert beer, i think!

Uh, been waiting with anticipation for this one, and finally its in Denmark. Pours murky brown to very dark red, nice tan head although its fast vanishing. Aroma is incredible, spices, dark fruits, candi, chocolate, some red wine notes as well, could smell at this for hours! Flavor is very port alike, spicy, dark fruits, peppery. It has a good alcohol warmth also, rather highly carbonated. Very nice one, got to purchase some more, i think itll age very well.

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2004 Bottled @ DBF2004: Burgundy coloured. Chocolate brown head. Lasting. Fruits and spices in the aroma. Yeast, malt and alcahol is dominant in the flavour. Ends with some alcaholburnt and sweetness. Nice one, that I will try again under other conditions.

I decided Id better give this a go before Sleeman ruins everything.  Pours a dark, cloudy red color, with a toasted marshmallow head floating on top.  Aroma is largely of cider, some red wine, and a hint of spice.  Flavor is very similar to a port wine, which is good because I like port.
