The aroma is sweet of grapefruit.  The appearance is a cloudy deep amber, with a great off white creamy head.  The flavor is smooth, and nicely fruity, and did I mention smooth.  The beer is a pleasure to drink.  Overall a very nice one.
A little sweet for my tastes but very good nonetheless.  Great flavor and good aftertaste.  Strong just like I like them.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2004 A beer that, sadly, I only tried recently. Life is better for having tasted this excellent libation! A high recommendation to anyone. Good, complex, deep flavor, and a very nice aroma make this an always worthy purchase.

Signature Unibroue spicy, slightly fruity aroma. Pours a very dark brown, mid-range carbonation, and a frothy brown head. Spicy, alcohol taste. Well balanced; you appreciate it more if you experience it slowly. Is the finish smooth or is it lacking? The Maudite seemed to have more going on at the end. Still a good beer but not the best Unibroue.

Hazy brown/amber color with light beige head. Initial fruit like aroma as notes of yeast, spices and alcohol subtly present themselves. A delight for the taste buds (albeit confusing), taste varies from sweet to tart, acidic to spicy. Becomes more complex as it warms, with tastes of raisins, spice, and a slight chocolate touch. High alcohol fairly well hidden with a gentle pinch of a reminder as it reaches the back of the throat. Ill get this again, and although I probably couldn't drink more than one in a sitting, I'll enjoy every bit of it.

Reddish/brown/orange, quite opaqe, I like!  Very tiny bubbles, a tight, thick off white head.  Some smokey hints in there, or is that an oakiness? Yogurt raisins come to mind as well, on account of the vanilla and date/raisin notes. Some serious sweet caramely malts, some hints of milk chocolate as well. Alcohol and esters prevail the nose, along with ripe fruits as well.  Sweet taste and a somewhat dry finish, much like last night's cabernet.  Silky smooth and super soft but with an alcoholic tingle as well, quite a warming effect!!  This is a Belgian golden with ripe fruits and a greater barley character.  Maybe a half red wine, half golden ale thing.  Superior mouthfeel but could use a more complex finish. I could drink this stuff al day, every day.  That is if I didn't get hammered on account of it first.
Dark brownish red with a moderately full body. Very aromatic with a rich mouthfeel. Somewhat yeasty character with a winey finish and some alcoholic warmth. Excellent.

Thanks to NDmullet for this one, although it took me so long to get around to drinking it that it became available in Ohio in the meantime. D'oh! Anyway, this beer pours a deep ruby color with a medium beige head. Aroma of cherry, vanilla, figs, and raisin. Fruity flavor of plum and raspberry, with a lightly chocolate malt finish. Very easy on the tongue, unlike a lot of Belgian Ales. Absolutely smooth and easy to drink. Very good.
Good beer.  Nice head, quickly dissipated.  Nice dark color.  Beautiful aroma.

This cloudy, reddish brown beer has a quickly dissipating white head.  The nose is fantastic! There are nuances of wine, sweet malt and leafy, citrusy hops. The palate continues the vinous character, but is enhanced by malty sweetness and a tinge of hoppiness on the finish.
UPDATED: JUL 4, 2004 Dark brown/amber with a medium  dark beige head. Yeast and fruit aroma. Sweet, malty, spicey, a little acidic. Very smooth and drinkable. Alcohol is well hidden.

Quite the kick with this one.  A deep sepia color and a sweetness that was slightly syrupy.  A simple beer, I didn't pick up on too much complexity maybe some fruitiness but little if any spice. Still, a good, solid (if slightly stolid) beer.
Wonderful beer. Nice a smooth with a good fruity aroma. Alcohol flavor came in very late in the swallow.

Dark purple brown. . . fluffy light brown head that out of which floats vanilla, plum, and nutty aromas.  Wonderfully complex, creamy and smooth.  Spicy and delicious.  The big malts and alcohol soothe the senses, gorgeous.
Very flavourful.  You do no taste the high 9% ABV at all.  Only complaint as by the time I was finished I was a bit tired of it.  Still a great strong ale with a fruity tase.

Absolutely delicious.  Pours out to a plum color in the glass with a decent, brown sugar-looking head.  The aroma is all over the place, with fruit, plums, yeast and although it sounds strange, a sweet tart candy smell.  Taste is excellent, with a variety of spices lingering in the mouth.  Mouthfeel is near perfect and the finish, while warming, masks the high ABV.  Yum.

Dark purple color. Small head. Aroma is slightly vinous, fruity and dusky. Malty and fruity. Very complex flavors; raisins, grapes, figs with a musty undertone. This is a very nice beer.  Very smooth, it hides the 9% alcohol very well. There is a hint of alcohol tartness on the tongue. Tasty beer. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is slightly bitter.

Some Belgian ales are overpowering.  Trois Pistoles takes all the complex flavors of the better Belgians and makes them far more subtle.  There are times I want the strongest flavors out there, but this is far more drinkable on a regular basis than many strong ales.  A wonderful brew to complement a meal, for instance, rather than stand out from it.  References on the bottle to port wine are referring to the complexity and subtlety of the flavors - not that it tastes like port.  More like a tawny port (more subtle and complex flavors) than a ruby (more obvious and overt flavors).  Will buy and drink often.
I did not get any hints of a port wine as the bottle suggested.  However it had a wonderfuly dry taste and a nice fruit aroma.

Alcohol is hidden well - mixed in with many other fruit flavors. Nice deep dark ruby red appearance with a long-plasting thin white head.  Aroma - not very remarkable - but pleasant.  Good after dinner beer - to be enjoyed like a fine wine or port.

Definitely not one to remember that is for sure, and definitely not one to my tastes. Did i mention i dont like wine at all...and when i poured this..my first impression...yup...wine!!!. It poured a fiery red color with nice carbonation in the glass, with a minimal white head and a faint aroma of alcohol and wine...but nothing spectacular..a slight smell of dark fruit, but that was it!!! The taste is pretty repulsive on the tongue... over ripe plums batter the mouth in an acidic free for all, and leave a grapefruity dryness to all hell. Morbidly awful acidity level here that made my tongue curdle...sandpaper like almost. The roasted malt did come through more towards the aftertaste near the end of the bottle as the sudden shock of that horrid dark fruit (more like chewing on a grapefruit peel) faded. It took the malt base at the end here just for me to give this a half decent rating. I dont like wine and this was too reminiscent of wine..heavy on the alcohol, and heavy on the fruits...not my style, and no i dont think i will care to venture near this again.

Slight smell of alcohal/sweetness on opening.very mild.nice carmal flavour with a back ground of over ripe plums,the flavour sits in your mouth after its gone,very nice beer,but not really to my tastes.
a very strong beer but far too fizzy for my tastes. give it a shot
UPDATED: JAN 13, 2003 Dark brown colour, slightly cloudy. Complex aroma of fruits and hay. Tart and bitter, very pleasant.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2003 Another great Unibroue beer. Can they make a bad one? Strong maltiness and sweetness in the first whiff. Wafting more reveals slight fruitiness and some wheat aroma. The taste reminds me of a bock beer mixed with a strong Belgian ale. Finishes very smooth with a hint of fruit and chocolate. Well worth seeking out and trying. Highly recommended!

This is the tackiest beer label in the world, like something youd see painted on the side of a van.  The beer misses too.  Some rather excellent light chocolate, berry, peach notes--just like the best of the trappists--buried under a late sugary avalanche.  Inital flavor is coca-cola, pointing up this beers fundamental vulgarity.
Wonderfully dark and cloudy, with a nice sweet aroma and a great somewhat fruity flavor. Definitely my favorite from Unibroue.

Re-Rate 12/31/02: The pour a deep murky plum color, the head Bunyanesque and the texture spumous, the lace a sticky thick clinging sheet that completely obscures the glass. Aroma of malt, hints of ripe fruit I like to say plums, sweet and quite a clean and fresh nose. Malt dominates the start, sweet and the top middling in feel, finish is stingingly acidic, hops robust and plentiful, quite dry aftertaste also long lasting. The high ABV makes this a fine winter warmer, and a good beer to sample on New Years Eve. Ranks #189 on my current 1000 beer master list.
Damn fine.  Kind of like Chimay Bleu, only yeastier and with a quicker finish.  Beautiful to look at.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2003 Pours a lacy head and a reddish-copper body. Excellent aroma and flavour, hints of fruit and spice and fairly similar to La Maudite. The finish leaves a slight alcohol burn and a lasting Port wine taste. Very nice. God I love being Canadian!

I find this beer to be a lot like Westy 12 in that its a bit too sweet for my liking and there isnt enough creativity in disguising the alcohol.  Extremely strong nose with a fruity aroma as promised in the commercial description, great pouring beer with medium head and body.  Very fruity palate with traces of raisins and spices.  The comparisons to port wine are on the money although I couldnt distinguish between a tawny or a ruby port...
I did a side by side sampling against Chimay Red and White and I preferred the Chimay White.

Just had the Maudite before this.  Im a dark beer person but I like the Maudite better.  It was a little smoother and weeter.  It salso masked the alcahol a little beter.  This one is  a little less drinkable.  Excellent beer, but I had the Maudite before it.  Trois Pistoles is a little drier without the burst of fruitiness the Maudite had

Decent head from the pour but does not last long.  Good carbonation throughout.  Excellent color and clarity of dark red/brown.  Somewhat fruity aroma initially then the alcohol kicks in.  Not a beer for the faint of heart.  Warms you as you drink it.  Hints of a rich wine taste.  Finishes smooth and clean and with an alcohol kick.  Definately a sipping brew.  Excellent brew and one to savor.
UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005

Dark brown/purple color, with a rather thin head. Aroma was nice, although difficult to pick out anything in particular besides alcohol hints. Rather heavy flavor with hints of raisens and maybe dates. The alcohol comes through stronger than expected. Very good overall flavor.

Cloudy, brown body with a huge, tan, rocky head.
All yeast and bananas/clove in the nose.
Lots of yeast and banana on the tongue with no hop presence.
Alcohol is well hidden.
This has to be one of the best Belgians made this side of the pond.
Cant wait until I try some other Unibroue brews!

12/21/02:  bottle.  nice thick creamy head, with fair amount of lacing.  yeasty smelling.  hints of banana and high evidence of yeast.  i know that this is a beer of high quality, but for some reason i just don’t get it with belgians.
Smell was hard to get....  Nice brown foamy head... You would think by looking at it that it would be a hard to drink beer...  NOT at all.  I luv the sweetnessss of these unibroue beers.
WOW, dark amber, off white red hintish head, smooth. Aroma is sweet and spicy. This beer is great. Wish I had more than just one. Just made my top 10 for 2002

Very Very Very good beer. I am having this for the first time as I write this. I am very impressed. Nice head nice everything. Very lively in my mouth. This beer realy warms you up. Why have I not had this beer before! I will no longer forsake thy brew!
A great beer. Deep red color with full off-white head. Strong citrus and clove nose. The flavor matched. Tasted like a (very) alcoholic orange spice tea. Finished sweet and smooth.

[12/15/02] In a few short months, my palate has gained a bit more maturity, and I can say with confidence that this is one of the better belgian strongs on the market, and it is so ubiquitous, that accessibility makes it an even better beer.  This is one of the best unibroue has to offer, which is saying a lot, considering they make such great beer. [9/16/02]Very large head that disipates quickly.  Fruity aroma that gives just a hint of the sweet, smooth fruit flavor of this ale.  Very smooth considering its alcohol content.
This bewer can almost due no wrong most of their brews are fantastic and this is one of them.  Complex fruity spicy and malty with a nice roasty flavor. Abv well hidden.  Recommended.

This might be one of my favorite beers of all time at this moment.  If its too cold, you cant get a lot out of this beer, but once it warms, you smell dark fruits (plums, at least I think), malt, alcohol, and a nice spicey cloviness.  Taste is sort of the same but you get some carmelly flavors along with all the other aromas.  Some yeastiness comes into the back ground if you shake the bottle too much when pouring, but its not necessarily a bad thing, it just adds to the complexity.  Alcohol is a back seat driver with this beer, but its voice is heard in aroma and taste, but very slightly.  Very well balanced for the amount of malt that should be in this beer.  Coloration is deep, deep, copper to dark brown w/ some very nice ruby highlights and a fantastic head to start but it gets knocked down by the alcohol.  Highly evervescent as a Belgian should be, its a nice change from the norm.  Too much of this could be a good thing, but may very well be a very bad thing.  FYI, this was a World Beer Cup Gold Medal winner for Belgian Strong Darks.

This was far better than I even expected. One of the best beers Ive had in a long time.  Very memorable.  I loved the Belgium style ale with a great reddish tint. It has a wonderful dark brownish red caramel look.  It poured with a nice thick bubbly head and it almost resembled champagne in its carbonation.  My only problem with this beer was over carbonation. Otherwise it was fantastic.   The aroma and taste reminded me of raspberry brandy, with a hidden cherry flavor as well.  I felt that the alcohol was dangerously hidden as it was a very easy beer to drink.

First off, the bad: too much head when I poured it into a glass, with out excessive care.  Also, the carbonation and alcohol is readily apparent when drinking it.  Otherwise, this beer is amazing.  Briliant dark color.  Smooth finish but very complex right off the bat.  Has a very roasty flavor and manages to leave your mouth tasting sweet.

I am really beginning to love Unibroue, makes you want Quebec to stay in Canada.  Beautiful beer with a rich head that settles down but stays through the whole beer.  Rich flavour and texture.  A new experience with every sip.  As it warms the alcohol becames very apparant.

A very nice brew, though a little harsh for my tastes. Huge head, and a very nice formation of lace on the glass. The alcohol is readily apparent, which is kind of a problem in my book. The aroma is very fruity, and overall this beer is quite good.
Dark brown, fluffy bubbling head.  Flavors were plum, fig, rum, clove, and towards the end big time chocolate.  This was complex and I will seek it out again.
Cloudy dark brown with a head that vanishes all too quickly.  Initial impressions of wheat, banana, clove, and a little hop.  A really great Belgian-style Grand Cru from Canada.

Had some of this at a Unibroue tasting this week, and realized that it had been so long since Id had it last that Id forgotten how much I enjoyed it. Beautiful purple-black colour, spicy malt and dark fruit in the nose and flavour, ending with a warm alcohol glow. Lovely stuff, I really should drink it more often.

Wow.  Very dark and hoppy.  Roasted malts are apparent, and blend nicely with the silky belgian feel.  This beer put a hurting on me after only two......not the 750 ml bottles.  I got a six pack of 330 ml.  I like belgian styles with roasted malts.
Beautiful blackcurrant colour with a nose of malt,yeast, spices and, of course, alcohol. Complex flavour though the alcohol is more evident than in many other of Unibroues strong-but-smooth brews.

"Great bouquet" says Bill. Yeasty and fruity nose - rather strong. Dark maroon color and a low tight head with good retention. A big mix of tastes: yeast, spices, berries (black currants) and licorice. Got a slightly napkiny  aftertaste though. Medium body and a great balance. Powerful quality beer.
Very intense and complex nose. Malt, alcohol, dates, cherries, dough. Dark body with a light layer. Yeast, also plums taste. Smooth. Well done

this pours like a pumpernickel liqueur: a st. bernard dog of deep brown with a ruby russet glow cutting through the murk of yeast. the head is a big bubbled, mocha sofa cushion.  the nose too tells initially of that big wash of root beer bubbles. once it settles, aromas rise bearing gifts of dried fruits and woody incense, lemon and spiced cakes. its too aggressively carbonated right out of the bottle and needs a time out. while waiting one may choose to admire the subtle scent of sarsaparilla root that can be found just to the left of the abundant clove. flavor of soft brown apples, butter and english muffins. a sweetness best appreciated at the cerebral apex of the evening, whilst puffing luxuriously and dreamily on a cuban monte cristo pyramid.
A cloudy belgian wheat beer, a little on the alcoholy tasting unlike other Unibroue brew. Good looking but a little hard to drink.

Im not a huge fan of high alcohol content beers, and Trois Pistoles falls into that category. Belgian wheat aroma. Beautiful deep red hue, with off-white, creamy, lasting head. Sweet and flavorful. Although alcohol is noticeable, it is not as overbearing as a 9% ABV brew normally is. Solid, but is borderline hard to drink.

At first this seemed rather winey and cidery, but as it neared room temp it transformed into a completely different beer. Lots of fruits: plum, fig, grape...mixed well with the high alchohol. The malt really comes through beneath this with a musky peaty kind of punch to the palate. Very complex and very good.
Has a dark cider color with a wine smell.  Taste is wheaty with a strong spice/alcohol aftertaste.  Overall it is pretty good, not the best for me, but pretty good.
This was a great belgian ale, although brewed in Cananda. Lots of spicyness in the taste along with yeastiness. The finish was well hopped, leaving a dry and solid taste in the mouth. A suberp beer.

Very satisfying pop of the cork, and gorgeous in the glass with a deep caramel color and lasting head.  Aroma is understated, giving few hints of the plum, raisin, and apple cider flavors within.  A match for most Belgian-made Belgians.  The palate disappointed, however, being less lively than others in the style.  Should be matched carefully with food--I found it did not work well with all the flavors on my plate at Thanksgiving dinner, 2002.

UPDATED: APR 30, 2003    Amazingly complex beer. Hints of grape and plum, very smooth and somewhat spicy. Extremely sweet but not cloying, balanced well. Very dark body and incredible head retention. A world class beer.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2009 12oz.BB05/22/05.Huge pff cap explosion.Deep,dark red/mahogany color.Bursting carbonation unleashes a finely beaded,dense,entrancing head.Aromatics are literally slapping me from the La Chouffe tulip.Dark fruit,spices(pepper,corriander?)slight roastiness,and alcohol.The yeast gives the overall aroma a fresh rain touch.Palate is carbonated but very full.Flavors are defined and clean.Sweet,FRUITY,roasted,and vinous mouth flavors are followed by a defenition spicy/hoppy/alcohol finish.I havent had this for over a year and my taste has changed.
This is one smooth brew.  Not to be drank too quickly.  Complex flavoring.  Well worth the money. ;)
UPDATED: MAR 25, 2003 Very fruity and complex brew.Re-rate : I don't taste the roasted malt much.  Flavor is mostly of Belgian yeast and Fruity sweetness.
750mm Bottle. A strange ale that tastes of over ripened fruits.  With the 9% abv, a 750 bottle will get ya pretty tanked.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2003 Spritzy grapes and soda-like flair combine with leather notes and hints of alcohol and cheese and lift themselves above a plum colored vibrancy with glorious thin brownish suds coating the glass superbly with each aroma-lifting swirl…strong yeast and malt interplay with grape tartness…restrained sweetness and nice subtle yeasty spiciness seem to sing in complete harmony with slight but delectable dusty mustiness adding to the glorious complexities that live within this here trios pistoles.
Very spicy and fruity - cherry - tastes like a well rummed cherry cola in fact.  Not very beery.
Excellent, complex beer.  Right in the middle of my favorite Unibroue beers.  Complex flavor, but still pretty mellow, with a decent alcohol nose.
What can I say that has not already been said?
hell ya, great beer. Nice head, great color, and a blend that blinds that 9% abv very good. Ill get more of this for sure.

Wow.  Head is initially thick but goes down fast.  Aroma is that of fruit.  somehow reminded me a little of raisin cinnamon breakfast pastry.  alcohol content very well hidden.  i couldnt keep my hands off this one.

Murky is right...Brown appearance.  Lots of particles, and great lil things floating around.  Aromas of raisons and dark fruit, oak, vanilla.  Vinous all the way through, alcohol and full bodied.  This is great stuff, no doubt about it, a classic!

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Head is large and brown, however it quickly dissipates.  Color is a dark unfiltered cloudy brown.  Aroma is fruity.  This beer has a very unique taste.  Initially the fruit dominates the tastebuds but then their is a hint of grain.  Palate is fruity.

I enjoyed this one... quite similar to blue label chimay in its appearance and flavor; wonderful yeast aroma with subtle hoppiness and flavors of plum, raisin and spice... quite tart with slight roasted malt to give it that that full, rich flavor that only a belgian strong ale can deliver. Delicious.

Very nice beer.  One of my favorites.
Nice powerful fruity after taste.

John
Earthty,raisin aroma.Frothy carbonation.Mellow Sweet, ripe black cherry,flavour.Hides its %9 very well.Lingering rum raisin finish.
Dark brown with generous head.  Smells great--like fruit at first, then malt/yeast.  Nice fruit/spice taste.  Hints of berries and plum among others.  The finish is malty.  Very nice beer.
I love this one. I seem to love all of Unibroues beers, but this one might be in my opinion the best one.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2005 Wow.  Striking aroma of sweet fruit (berries, bananas) and caramel with some citric acidity or maybe green apple.  High, fizzy, champaign-like head, dissipates quickly.  Beautiful dark brown, slightly hazy.  A fantastic mix of flavors, from banana to plum, sweet malt, some roast, a little spice, etc.  Very pleasant and lasting aftertaste.  Very mellow and enjoyable.  Savor it.

Brown colour. Head dissipates fast. Wonderful complex aroma! Chocolate, bubblegum, orange peel, cowberries and even a touch of lambic! After all that the flavour is a bit of a disappointment! Sweet and warming, a bit like a young port wine.

Re-rate:  Well, ten months of drinking can really change your understanding of beer.  I still really enjoy this beer, but the initial 4.8 is a touch high.  There are so many things to find in this beer.  Plum, cherry, anise, sour apples, some nice spice and a hint of yeast.  Very well done, indeed. 12/20/2001:  My first impression of Unibroue, and I was highly impressed.  I loved the fruit.  Oh, and the head, marvelous.  Excellent Belgian Strong syle.
Dark brown with a big tan head. Wonderful fruity alcoholic aroma. Very malty finish with just the right amount of carbonation. Alcohol is well hidden. A fine Belgian Ale.

Massive thick head.  Dark brown suagr color.  Dont see much comparison to a port here.  Nice complex nose with an interplay between light tones of fruit with more heavy spices of pepper, caramel, and cinammon.  Extremely smooth, the alcohol is barely noticable.  Musky dark fruit flavors - raisins, bananas, nuts - dance on the tongue.  This is a good Belgian-style ale.

What a great belgian style beer, and from canada, to boot!  Its a nice dark malty ale, with some definite caramel and raisin overtones.  
I agree with earlier comments - i dont see any resemblance between this and a port wine, but its fantastic anyway!

Beer Markt 2002 October. Yup, after Cést What we had food and next was Beer Markt. Nice beer to finalize night Great look, dark amber , huge great looking head , one of the best looking beers I had . I found that it was also a bit cherry, fruity and nicely warming.

Nice sweet, rich malty flavor full of fruit flavors.
A bit too much carbonation for this style. (Only thing I can say bad.)
Deep dark in color, rich fruity malt nose.  Very complex flavor, slight hop in the mid-palate.  Excellent beer for this style
Dark, surprisingly easy ale with a slightly bitter aftertaste. Very much a Belgian - from Canada!
This didnt really remind me of old port. It was fruity berry/ plums. Very full body. with a some what dry finish. Not bad for Canadians.

This beer rocks.
Complex belgian ale...arent they all?
The aroma is very nice... malty, yeasty with hints of dates, plums, port and caramel. This dark, murky amber/brown ale has a large, off-white, rocky head. Excellent lacing and fully lasting. Tastes great... More filling!! Nevermind that. Its a little on the sweet side for me, but very enjoyable nontheless. Moderately malty with hints of honey and a nice alcohol flavor. Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel. Fizzy. Fuity, a bit port-like. The long finish is slightly pungent, and medium dry. Excellent beer. Try one.

A subtle raisin plumb nose with dashes of orange-lemon rind, rounded out with hints of green apples, taps you on the senses and lures you into the glass. Orange edges and a dark nut brown center lurk in the middle. Big foamy head, but submits quickly to the alcohol, yet there still is plenty of carbonation. The fruity template of this is very nice, if you can call it fruity, it is more of a delicate dance between alcohol, spices, and sweetness. Try this if you can, you cant go wrong.
A quality belgian from Canada. I found it complex but not overpowering.

I dont know about ripe fruits in the aroma & flavors, smells & tastes almost like a Belgian Wit, this has that taste like someone crushed up a bunch of veggies & threw it in a beer bottle, I didnt really like this beer at first, but then after a few some sips I did begin to appreciate it & like it, overall this beer isnt too bad, but not one that I could drink all the time

Turbid dark brown-amber with rich tan head and speckled sheet-lace. Aroma yeasty, fruity (as in fruit brandies), estery--a bit oaken. Malt front followed immediately by fruit essences: plums come immediately to mind here, pears as well--sweet and bright flavors coincide. Mild yeasty spiciness kicks in toward the finish and stays around for a while. This has outstanding smoothness and fine body...Carbonation is positively in play but does not mask flavors. This is outstanding in all major respects.
A dark brown colour with a creamy, yellow foam. Aroma of vinegar, chocolate and cherry. Vanilla flavour and a long finish with alcohol notes.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2004 Rerate 6/28/2004: Best before 5/23/05 cellared for over a year, pours a dark auburn brown with a puffy light tan head that leaves a sparse lace behind.  Aroma of musky aged caramel malts and a touch of tart fruit, with some subtle Belgian yeastiness.  Body is still thick and flavorful with nice sweet balance that continues to mask the alcohol very well.  This has aged quite nicely and gained some more complexity.

9/16/2002: Very dark and murky, but well carbonated.  Hints of fruit and oak in the nose.  Smells almost sour, but not noticeable in taste.  Coats and warms the throat on its way down.  Very little hop presence, but nicely rounded roasted malt mixture making it just sweet enough to mask the high alcohol content.  Only gets smoother as it warms.  One of the best Belgian Strong ales I have had.
Gorgeous dark brown, nice head, spicy aroma. Fruity flavor, definite raisin overtones, could use a bit more hops to balance the sweetness.

Deep murky brown in color.  Very complex nose with a vinous quality along with some figs, peach, cocoa and some dark candied sugar with just a bit of an alcohol presence.  Taste is complex as well with all those flavors dazzling the tongue.  Finish is lasting and very bittersweet.  This ones meant to be sipped and savored.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2003 Excellent, but drink it slooowly.  It was one of my first tastes in an evening and I hurried it a bit.  Later, tried it again (after MY head cleared)and discovered wonderful aroma, wine-like.

Beautiful dark amber pour, looks very nice in a Chimay goblet.  Crisp apples-n-alcohol smell.  Intensely rich flavor, with all kinds of fruitiness in it.  Very strong, in fact I drank a full glass at the end of a tasting session, around midnight after a long day, and the result was falling asleep on my couch.  I think its between this and Ommegang for the best Belgian brewed in North America.

The tops of the regular line from Unibroue.  Served in a wide goblet the perfume is rich and spicy with a pie fruit aroma.  Wild carbonation keeps up a fine and rocky head that leads to and empty glass covered with lacework.  The real key to this beer seems to be the yeast.  It leaves the malt a touch sweet, but provides a dry and complex spice to the aroma.
A favorite from Unibroue... pours well, sweet, spicy and the alcohol is not overpowering.... easy to drink, but dangerous!
perfumey, slightly spicy aroma...prune flavors. fairly sweet, but the high alcohol is very well hidden. great beer, just after a couple more tastings, i think i went a little high on this one

Average appearance for a Belgian, dark brown, light tan head, hazy.  Wonderful aroma of malt, cherries, and yeast.  Sweet complex flavor similar to the aroma with some hop bitterness in the middle and a sweet aftertaste.

Unique!!! The smell and taste are very sweet and the carbonation is somewhat like Coke but this stuff packs a punch. It looks very rich and has a nice foamy head. One reviewer said it popped when he/she opened it and they werent kidding. Unbelievable head. You dont drink this one to get drunk cause I bet youll pay for it later. Awesome label, why the complaints???
Really messes with my stomach!!!

By far the best belgian strong ale.  Full body and flavor, without apparent alcohol, but still has a certain kick to it.  My bottle was about 14 months past the best before date- but it still kicks ass.  There was nothing bad about it despite the old age- in fact the age may have made the flavors even better.  Very smooth and drinkable, with so much complexity.  Dark color and nice head.  Very spicy, with some coriander, and finishes off with a nice port/wine taste.
This beer is best described using the eloquent words of John Madden: "BAM! Tough actin Tinactin."
very fruity with an amazing mouthfeel.  one of unibroues best.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2003 Bugger this is sweet. Whoever said it tasted like cheap red wine was spot on, that, and cheap port and coke. I once liked this, but really don't know why, sickly and cloying, severely over-rated in my humble opinion, really flat uninspiring mouthfeel, bloody hell.
Very nice, but it not in the same league as a high quality trappist ale.  It does not have the fine aroma that I want in a BSA.  Taste is light for the style.

Hazy dark brown but lighter than I remembered.  Winey, spicy aroma with notes of bubble gum, bready yeast, green apples and blackberries.  Very complex.  It has flavors of berries,  alcohol, plums? and roasted malt.  A fine beer.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2003 Rerate - 10/20/03: I don't really like this now. It has an odd mix of Juicyfruit gum and tomato juice. Very complex, but I just couldn't shake this tomato juice thing...it really turned me off. The numbers reflect this sample. Original rating - 8/14/2002:Nice nice. Strong floral aroma. The taste was much like wine. The high alcohol content isn't really noticable in the taste. This beer is an opaque brown...really pretty. I'm not quite ready to rate beers this complex yet, so I'm sure I will re-rate this someday.

UPDATED: JUN 23, 2003 (Re-rate) A hazy dark brown almost ruby colored. Moderate but persistent tan head. Aroma is of vinous fruits(raisons,figs,berries), vanilla, subtle yeast and others, simply stellar. Flavor consists of huge malts that ride along the whole way,clove,maybe mint, marshmellow,vanilla, touch of honey,fruity sweetness (overly ripened cherries?) and yeasty twangs on the side of tounge. Almost thick bodied, very mellow,cant taste the alcohol but can feel it. The yeast is a bit more dominate as it warms but adds another dimension to this gift. This is why we drink beer boys..........
Caramel, chocolate and cherry taste. Excellent.
this was a very good effort for a belgian strong ale that surely lived up to its name. its a must try brew!

Very thick and potent. Its very port like. Its also not very much my style, i detest port. The aroma was like chocolate and cherries, other fruits. the finnish was something i couldnt describe, but the taste was just port and thats it. The alcohol isnt hidden too well at times. It kind of grows on you, but dont let THIS review influence you. I feel bad rating it lower due to its prestige.

Every beer I rate as I listen to Tom Waits  Sounds like sweet perfume  But theres never a rose in the night  The ale pours dark and smooth  Like blood seeping from a cut  And the flavor really shines  As it blossoms  Chocolate, orange, and cinnamon  Strikes against the tongue  Like a crooked tower bell  That I overhead one day As I drank down trois pistoles.

Wow... I bought this beer b/c this site rated this the 2nd best canadian beer... and Im not dissapointed.
I cant really taste the 9%.. the flaour is strong, fruity... sweet, sort of like a wine but still a beer.
Definately something Ill buy again.  One of those beers you sit down and enjoy.  Wouldnt chow this down at a party to get drunk.

Ive been beer hunting for about 8 years now, and for some reason, I never have gotten around to buying any of the Unibroue lineup.  I think that something about the graphics and the bottling sets me off.  So, it is with superb delight that I write this review.  The bottle opened with a champaign-like pop.  Surprisingly, some beer foam followed (I might have agitated this sucker during the car ride home.)  Alcohol was quite evident in the aroma, but I could sense fruit and malt hiding behind.  Now for the coup de gras, the flavor of this magnificent beer.  Fruit tones envelop the tastebuds as alcohol warms the tongue.  Wonderful malt complexity and the yeast go a long ways contributing a nice ester-y spiciness.  Overall, this is one of the best beers I have tried in the past year.  Thanks to Ratebeer for pointing me in this direction!

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2003 Not as good as other Unibroues I've had, but if you like the thick, port-like variety of beer this is for you. Very heady taste and aroma, dark, cloudy reddish appearance and a thick, almost too-sweet flavour. I like the fact that it's got a kick to it, but I find Maudite much more refreshing and tasty. Rerate: After my horrible experience with Blanche de Chambly, I can't help but notice similar Noxema-esque notes to this brew.

I initially had this too cold, and the aroma reminded me of smelly socks, with the flavor being like the sauce you get with broccoli beef at a bad chinese place with the broth from the socks mixed in. However the second one i had warmer and i noticed the fruity aroma a little more as well as the referance they make to port wine. However, still doesnt quite do it for me, perhaps the buzz helped it taste better as well. Still a decent brew all the same.
Nice Dark Amber brown color, the aroma and flavor are spicy yet sweet.  A very good brew.

The first thing that hits me is that this stuff tastes and feels like coca-cola.  Luckily that initial impression dims impressively as the spicy yeastiness rises through and a tasty warmth spills over, but the beer seems cheapened still, littler than it should be.
very nice spiced fruit flavor. remarkable rust golden color. perfect mouthfeel.

This may sound odd but the flavor reminded me a bit of watermelon. Maybe it was the esters combined with some of the other yeasty flavors but it was interesting. Smells like a good belgian should. Not as spicy as some, but the estery fruitiness is good. Having trouble with some of the spicier belgians, this is a good beer to me. It had less of the fuzzy mouthfeel that a lot of Belgians have. I think thats a good thing as some feel too fuzzy.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2005 7/12/02: Fizzy carbonation. Complex sweet, spicy flavor. Warms the tummy and packs a wallop. Im starting to like Belgians.
8/12/03: The pour is the color of prune with a thin tan head. Aroma is of sweet, fruity malt and yeast. Complex flavor includes hints of cherry, grape, spices, yeast and a little port wine. Mouth feel is champange like. It has a long dry mouth watering aftertaste. The 9% ABV makes its presence known.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2003 Decent tan head that lingers as a nice lace. Aroma is fruit and toasted malts. Nice palate just slides down tingling with carbonation along the way. Flavor is very similar to the better belgians but somewhat lacking in complexity. Very good beer overall.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2015 Bottle (BB 12-03-16).

Head is initially average sized, frothy/fizzy, light brown, mostly diminishing.
Body is dark amber/brown.

Aroma is lightly malty (cookie, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (flowers, herbs), moderately yeasty (cobwebs, basement), with notes of date, cola, orange peel, clove, alcohol.

Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter.

Medium to full body, watery texture, lively/fizzy carbonation, moderately alcoholic.

As with many other Unibroue beers, the mouthfeel is the weakest link...a bit watery and fizzy. Nice yeast and fermentation effects though. The nose has some allure and the flavor balance is decent, so ultimately its still a mostly enjoyable Belgian styled brew.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2006 A castle of abundance and fertilityIn one room, peppery port wine kissing plump black cherries on a bed molasses and chocolateIn another, listless burnt caramel embracing Christmas cookie dough on a table of clovesIn yet another, plums draw human blood and honey from roasted figsAnd this is just one royal corridor

A 10-year-old 1996 bottle revealed a decadent aroma of maderized berry sugars...Carbonation had lowered with time, but it still let the flavors express themselves freely...A marvelous aging experiment...(the same cannot be said of Maudite).
UPDATED: MAY 10, 2003 Upon opening this bottle you will soon see the bubbly foam. An amber color, it warms you up soon after the first sip.This is one quality beer. I recommend it highly.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2003 750 ml corked bottle Dark orange brown color, big thick clingy head, sweet fruity, bready aroma, full bodied, alcohol hidden very well, smooth and velvety this is a great belgian strong ale, very drinkable.
A nice looking brew. A little too sweet for me. It does have a dryness to it in the finish. Not something I would drink often but it is very good.
nice brown color with light beige head, fruit like aroma,very smooth and drinkable, becomes more complex as it warms, a delight for the taste buds, highly recomended

Bottle.  A deep orange brown color with minimal head.  This beer has the typical corked belgian beer aromas, but the taste is more mellow, watery, and drier than I expected.  The flavors become most apparant with a dry kick in the finish.  It did not have the robust mouth-filling charge that many Belgians have.  It had a dry fruit flavor, somewhat sour, and malty.
UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004 Incredibly smooth for such a high ABV beer.  A slight fruity sweetness to it.  Very mellow without an overpowering taste. Sip it slow.

Amazing beer!  Ive never had anything quite like it.

Re-rate: I sampled this beer again and noted that the aroma isnt as exquisite as I previously thought.  Not a 10.  But on the flavor side, I would choose 11 if I could.  Incredibly complex and wonderful.
Cloudy, dark brown color w/ a nice head, this beer is elegant. There are so many subtle fruity & spicey flavors that it was like tasting a fine wine. Dont miss this one.

I disliked this when I tried it once before, but I now believe that I had a bad bottle. Ive given it another chance, and I like it much more. It has a unique flavor, with a nice balance of hops, malt, and an unusual spiciness.

Cloudy ruby red color, nice head.  Smelled of raspberries, tasted of raspberries, as it warmed, it tasted of chocolate covered raspberries...not overpowering with the fruit, but definitely there.  Well balanced belgian with a moderate taste of alcohol.
Words cant describe this beer.  You have to taste it to believe it.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2005 Bottled. Complex aroma of licorice, cherry and blackcurrant. Brown color, beige head, fair lace. Sweet that becomes even sweeter towards the finish, light bitter, fruity (dark forrest fruits), chocolat, licorice, sticky and light warming. Medium body.
A very fine ale with a lot to offer as far as complexity and depth of character. Very well balanced with a STRONG taste of ripe prunes and a nice warming port-like finish. This breweries finest.

Very full flavored and full bodied.  Aromas of bread, yeast, light alcohol and spices.  Flavors of cherries and apricots with yeast, a healthy malt presence and a dry finish.  Yeast chunks floating in a rich, mahogony brew under a tan head.  Quite nice.
Very rocky tannish head with a lovely maple brown appearance. Very peppery on the palate. Aromas of bread and molasses. Hints of cinnamon and cane sugar flavors.

Dark ruby red-brown color.Vapors of burnt malt,raisin,brown sugar and dates.Decent head.Strong body consisting of ripe plums, bing cherry and a long tawny port finish .Very warming and also very recommended.
Holy Crap!

Very interesting beer and quite unique.  Mine is a dark ruby red with a mild head.  Cloves, spiciness, yeast and sweet fruity tastes are present.  At first I could also really taste the alcohol.  I also get the sensation of grapefruit, other fruits.  Id like to try this one again in the future, maybe let it rest for a while in my cellar.
Bizzare grape juice aroma and flavour, quite sweet with little aftertaste. Tastes unlike any beer I know. Id like to give one about 6 months in the cellar, to see if it becomes a little smoother.
i must say the first time i tried this beer i didnt like it i guess you have to get the acquired taste
This is an excellent beer. Very fruity...tasted like very ripe plums...has a nice lingering spicy aftertaste...a bit thinner than I expected...this is my new choice for pairing with cigars.

Mmmmmm.  Nice, rich, fluffy head that rises full, then quickly deflates.  Lovely caramel-y aroma thats sweet and inviting, with an alcohol bite in the background.  The flavor is smooth, but with an alcohol bite.  The port comes through strong.  Great for after dinner hanging out with good friends and good conversation.

Quickly dissipating head leaves a still liquid thats a little on the red side of muddy brown.  Aroma is curranty/raisin and sour cherry, with hints of malt and alcohol.  In the flavor, the fruity and malty richness is impressive, as is the complexity.  One drawback is that the alcohol presence is more than I would like.
Not my favorite beer, a little too sour. But Belgian Strongs arent my favorite style to begin with.

Sweet malty aroma with chichory and Liquorish.
Most enjoyable. etc.
A dark lively brew, very faint aroma, palate is smooth, finishes balanced with hints of grapes. Great brew, my favorite from Unibroue.
My favorite beer in Quebec.

I dislike gushers, even though I have made a few.  That said, my first taste came quickly - lips to bottle while I reach for the glass.  A bit assertive out of the bottle.  What remained poured to a high head with a murky brown color.  Scent of sweet lavender.  Very smooth feel.  The alcohol really comes out in the finish. Flavors of dark cherries, bananas and currents.  Slight oak in the dry finish as it warms.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2007 The best birthday gift I ever got. Brilliant cherry/berries/cookie dough aroma. Deep brown color with beautiful rocky light brown head. Just the right amount of bitterness and sweetness. Vinuous and fruity. Only gets better as I drink more. Watermelon aftertaste. I am going back to the store tomorrow to buy more. Best beer Ive had so far. UPDATE: this is just too cloying sweet for me now.

The aroma was an intoxicating blend of various berries and burnt chocolate.  The dark blood red-purple color was a superb.  Tastes so sweet to start, then turns sour, and then just the right amount of hops in the finish...incredible.  I also got a hint of chocolate after licking my lips!  Does share similar charactertistics with dark wine in the dry aftertaste, but thats not a bad thing.  The only neagative was that the carbonation was a bit on the extreme side, unfortunately.  Superb, and closer to a wine than a beer in my eyes.

I bought this because some have said it tastes like Rochefort 10.  Not quite... it tastes like Ommegang.  It lacks the thick and creamy mouthfeel, and the alcohol is too hot. Not bad, but disappointing.  Try Weyerbacher Quad if you want a REAL and acceptable substitute for the real thing.
Somewhat fruity, but yet complex aroma.  Very nice balance in the body between the alcohol, hops, and sweetness.  Another great beer from an incredible brewery.

Moderate rocky head with good lacing on top a deep red brown ale. Aromas of yeast, dough and berries. Tastes like a chewy fruitcake with hints of blackcurrant, cherry and a faint licorice note. Excellent mouth coating finish that never gets cloying. A top beer.

Dark, dark, almost purple or very deep red. Roasty-toasty aroma with a hint of apple, red grapes,  and something a bit tart smelling like cranberry. Alcohol was present in the nose as well. Sweet and malty with persistant alcohol tinge. Finishes with a apple-cinnimon sweetness that is almost lost to the alcohol.  A little less carbonation and better masking of the alcohol would make this even better. It is very available in the Chicago area, and I would have picked it up much sooner had I seen it was so well rated.
This beer ranks right up there with pond water. I think Im gonna yack !!!

Re-Reat 4/30/02 WEll im on resampling streak right now and although i still love this beer its not quite the perfection i once thought. Great wine/oak/ripe fruit flavors. A truly great beer. Perfect, simply perfect.

deep red-brown color, beige head.
sweet and spicy but  plenty of hop bitterness for balance. one of unibroues better offerings that lies somewhere between a dubbel and tripel.
A very nice Belgian style beer.  A nice sweet flavor with pleasant malt taste at first.  Well worth the money.
Not many better. To me a combination of the finest Trappist beers with a fine Belgian Strong. SO complex, yet easily drinkable. A new favorite!
My favorite Unibroue product - and Ive had lots of them.  A bit too carbonated, though.

Fruity malt aroma, dark brown body with a red tinge & beige head. Big initial malt flavour which seems slightly roasted. Slightly sweet with dark fruit notes but also some bitter elements. Really complex & winey in a great way. Absolutely to my taste. THANKS DUFF!

Interesting.  To begin, has possibly one of the coolest labels in the world.  Beer itself isnt bad either.  Pours darker than I expected, a deep brown with hints of red.  Much bigger head than anticipated, very thick and creamy, though it didnt last too long.  The head fizzed and popped loudly enough to be very noticeable; it was sort of like putting your ear over a bowl of Rice Krispies.  Nice scent, lots of caramel and raisins.  Flavor is very aggressive, with large amounts of maltiness.  Plenty of fruit here, plums, apples, and raisins along with nuttiness and breadiness.  Finish has exceedingly strong alcohol--no attempt has been made to mask the 9% abv whatsoever.  Is very spicy, with loads of clove, coriander, pepper, and rock candy.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2003 third try for the 3 pistoles and i still can't make up my mind. one sip and it's all class - rich vanilla, wood and port receding to raisins and cashews and other trailmix components, with a trace of gingerbread in the aftertaste. next sip and it's disgustingly sweet, sicklily overfruity, strangely thin and reeking of sweet bourbon. probably the closest beer gets to punch.

Goodness! I finally found a 6-pack of this at The Beer Store up here in Canada. This stuff is always sold out. If you like your red wine(like I do), then Trois Pistoles is a beer lovers choice. It doesnt make me sleepy like the red wine, though. I wouldnt recommend this as a summer drink, more like an autumn or winter warmer(seasonal) The *commercial description* nails it on the head. Read no further. :-)

(33cl)  Nutty red brown, with a few floaties.  Initially thick head, lasting and leaving subtle lacing.  Complex, fruity nose.  Mellow body is full of character, with sour grapes, plum, pear, spices, rapsberry?, and more.  The finish is slightly dry, with just a touch of alcohol, and the sublime aftertaste lingers indefinitely.  I hesitate to call this a world classic for my lack of breadth in sampling, but this has to be in the upper echelon for the style.
UPDATED: JAN 8, 2003 Best Beer I have had in a Long time! Smooth and tastey
definately a strong ale.  Appearance is out of this world.  The magic theme from the label carries over to the beer with the disappearing head trick.
I simply love this beer. Has a great rich, fruity flavor and a wild finish. Alcohol flavor is a litle strong but in no way harsh. Great Beer!
Head lasts in lovely islands in the glass. Very lively mouthfeel. Nice fruit, clove spiciness.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Very well balanced,fruity aromas with a great colour. Complex flavours make this a great ale.
A wonderfully aromatic brew. Too much for this as of yet still learning olfactory and palate to deduce. Color is rich amber and tastes of toasted caramelness with solid alcohol. Truly a fine beer.

This is a strong, dark ale that weighs in with a 9% alcohol-by-volume rating. It is a living beer, undergoing refermentation (secondary fermentation) in the bottle. It pours with a dark brown color and a very thin foam head that disappears very quickly. This ale is brewed with a roasted malt, which explains its dark color and its slightly nutty (hazelnut) aroma. This ale also features dark fruit aromas, plum in particular, and some have likened the smell to a fine glass of Port (fortified wine from Portugal or Spain). 

In flavor, this ale has a lively mouthfeel and is surprisingly light for such a high-alcohol beer. The texture is smooth and the flavor is fruity and round, turning slightly sweet at mid-palate, and ending with a mild amount of warmth, a slight but of sourness, and a gentle amount of hop bitterness. This is a complex, structured ale featuring many different flavor experiences and a pleasing aftertaste that makes for very easy drinking.
Im only halfway through the glass and Ive already caught so many of the different flavors mentioned here. The only bad thing is that the alcohol seems to linger in the aftertaste a bit much.

Very effervescent, though it doesnt produce a notable head. The biting spritziness gets in the way of the flavor, which is of a caramel-like sweetness, with some vaguely smoky notes. Not too complex--could perhaps use some cellar time to see if some more interesting flavors come out--and get rid of some of that gas!

WOW!!  Yeah, I think that should cover it.  Very dark, with a fluffy tan head.  Very fruity in the aroma.  The flavor starts with a touch of plum?  Then as the beer warms it gets more and more spicy.  Great drink for a night like this.  Very cold out.
Smells like fruit and nuts. Deep red nearly brown in colour. Taste like a mild rum cake, wonderfully balanced, an excellent strong ale.

This stuff rocks...what else can I say?  The aroma reminds me of spiced fruit, especially some spiced peaches I used to eat years ago.  The color is dark amber and almost opaque, and the head is a nice tan color.  Wow...a bunch of tastes in there...fruit, spice, malt, a little carbonation too but not too much.  It is a little winey but not like a barley wine at all.  It is much smoother and more mellow than those.  It warms well on the way down too...9 percent in this case is a good thing!  The only fault I see, and its a small one, is the body...its a little heavy, syrupy at times, but even that I could get used to. If not for that, this would be my highest-rated beer.    Overall, one of the most unique and best of its style.  Like Ive said before, I love this brewery!!!

UPDATED: JAN 25, 2009 Expected belgian aroma, full of bread and wine. Incarnadine appearance with a rich, strong body that packs a wallop, but is quite stream-lined and easily quaffed.  Could use a bit more carbonation, but loved the winyness--much different from barley wines as well as the breadiness and subtle piny hopping..  A smooth, hearty ale sure to warm the spirits.

Re-rated 1/24/09 - This is much more extraordinary than I had recalled. Lively body and a panoply of flavors make this a meal in a 12 oz class. Complex, sapid, and piquant yeast rumbles through the malt.  Sensational.  Will keep some bottles handy and look forward to imbibing again soon.
I do get the raisiny Port taste and the alcohol wasnt as over powering as I thought I thought would be. Fantastic!
Dark nut brown. Dry bitter and lively. Very complex & tasty!
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2003 Suprisingly easy to drink despite strong, but not overpoweing, alcohol presence. Sweet, fruity, malty flavor. Medium body. Reminds me a bit of Chimay when after it warms a bit.
this is the reason why im proud to be canadian

Head is excellent: thick, off-white, and enticing.  The aroma is complex.  The alcohol is very present and matched with a sweet malt and ripe fruit nose.  The taste is complex and satisfying at first but does not resolve very well.  The finish I find lacking.  Also surprising is the thin mouthfeel considering the gravity of the brew.  Overall, a fine belgian style dark but not on my list of favorites.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2010 2010-12-28, 8 years old, bb 17-04-04, 8-3-6-3-14=34Dark brown color; it pours watery, fizzy, with a medium sized head that disappears quickly, completely. The aroma, with caramel and chocolate, is distinctive and pleasant. The body is thinning, with caramel flavor, almost no sweetness, and a light oxidisation; the final is quite weak in the mouth, and also not much bitter anymore. Drinkable but too old.2002-01-08, 8-3-9-3-17=40Dark amber ale. Nice fresh aroma of hop and porto wine. Powerful brew, strong body, malt, raisin, alcohol, light liquorice. The palate is balanced but not very long and hoppy.To be aged.
The worst of the excellent Unibroue family. Not as in-your-face as La Fin Du Monde.

Whenever I drink a beer like this, I think about all those guys out there who never even bother to pour their beers out of the bottle -  and consider an iced-cold, skunky Becks to be the pinnacle of beermaking.
How can you not love this rich, complex, fruity dark beer. The further you drink down your glass, the smoother and richer the flavor. Addicting.
Each time i drink this i love it more and more. One of my favorite Belgian strong ales. Vinous notes and delicious fruit tastes. Very easy to drink and very good.

Reddish-brown, fairly cloudy, impressive tan foam sits on top and stays throughout, resulting in nice layers of Belgian lace. The nose offers up a deep sweet roasted malty aroma, and a fruity mix of raisin and prunes. Signs of a sherry-like aroma remind me a little of an imperial stout. The first sip is something of a surprise. Having braced myself for something thick, it washes over very light and is a little too easy drinking. There’s a good fizziness on the palate as well as instant signs of alcohol which warn you to take things easy. Initial taste is certainly sweet with a roasted malt and a mixture of ripe fruits, bringing to mind cherry, cranberry and prune, with an underlying yeastiness throughout. Further tasting also revealed a little spiciness, while there’s some coffee-like dryness in the finish. The aftertaste is very warming rounding out very much like a port. Good version of a Belgian ale.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2006 Light prune.  Fizzling off-white head.  Fruitcake, rummy aroma. Yeast and wood uindertones.  Spicy carbonation.  Very firm mouthfeel.  Medium body.  Finishes with plummy malts and very yeasty.  Almost excellent.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Delicious beer, smooth yet complex and interesting.  I is a touch too sweet, but it manages to remain good.

A much more caramel and mellow aroma than the other Unibroues that Ive had. Still has a crisp twang. Great appearance. Malty, pear-cidery, with carbonated zip. After venting, the bottom of the glass is better than the top.  I have to steal Heats analysis on the aftertaste. Very warm. A well-crafted brew. Hold some on the tongue and exhale through your nose

I had this again the other night and it really is magnificent. This time though, it had dominating apple flavours which I didnt pick up the first time. So smooth (dangerously so) for its strength. Just a note for the Australians giving this low ratings, I got a case ordered into my bottle shop especially so maybe it was fresher than the bottles you tried.

Great sweet, fruity, malty aroma with accompanying taste.  Very creamy and buttery with a strong alcoholic finish.  This is definitely a sipping beer.  It pours a very deep dark amber color and holds a great head.  The lace practically lays in sheets on the glass momentarily before very slowly making its way back down the side.  It does have a lingering buttery alcoholic malt aftertaste.  Great after a long cold day.  In my opinion, this is the best of the Unibroe beers.  I am usually not a fan of such dark and sweet beers, but this one does it for me.  Definitely gonna add this one to the buy list.
UPDATED: MAR 19, 2005 A real winner, extremely complex aroma with flavor to match. A very nice finisher to a winter night.

UPDATED: AUG 13, 2003 have had this twice since my first encounter and expected to be converted but found no reason to be. stupidly sweet, cheap red wine and baking soda yeast flavour. predictable. tastes a lot like their other beers. unpleasant burnt candy. one of the worst of its style.
Hoppy aroma.  Malty, winey, toasty, chocolatey, sweet taste.  Slight earthy taste.  Alcohol twang useful in countering sweetness but still a sweet beer.
Wonderful.
A nice beer but you can really taste whatever it is. Maybe the alcohol flavor turned me off. I think some higher alcohol beers can hide it better.
Very nice. But I cant help thinking how much it seems to be trying to mimic Chimay Grand Reserve. Not that that is a bad thing.
The color dark/red is a nice sight, the flavers countless. I was just tickled to death to drink this one.  I love it...a definite top strong ale for me.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2003 Dark rubyish color, thick, creamy tan head.  The nose is full of fruit with a nice sweet maltiness.  A touch of peppery alcohol and some light chocolate finishing the aroma off.  Very smooth with a firm malt backbone and some dark fruit poking through.  Some peppery alcohol on the tongue with a good balancing fruitiness finishing semisweet and pleasantly bitter.  Very nice, still a great beer after all these years.

UPDATED: JAN 29, 2004 Cloudy burgundy-chestnut colour.  Rich plummy, raisiny, port-like depths in both the palate and the aroma.  Notes of apricot, tangerine and Special B also noted.  A little fizzy (common problem with Unibroue these days) but with spectacular, unfolding fruits and dark malts.  Sleek and sumptuous, these raisins, plums and malts wash over the palate.  I remember why I love this beer.

Color is a great dark brown, with a beige head that is rich and dense.
The aroma is awesome! It is by itself extraordinarily complex, with hints of yeast and fruits, and even pralines.. The taste... the taste! It has the characteristic Unibroue yeastiness, plus a slight alcoholic pepperiness... it is definitely a sipping beer.. almost like carbonated cognac... there are several fruits in here.. figs? raisins? prunes? ahh lets just say its delicious.. the finish is dryish but satisfyingly warm.. this beer is definitely a good nightcap, good with a book in your favorite chair.
very nice.  complex fruit notes.  warm dry finish.
A classic!

Red clay color with a tan head.  Ripe plum aroma with a noticeable yet limited alcohol presence, reminding me of egg nog. The taste was also slightly reminiscent of egg nog, while boasting hints of grape and port wine.  Malty, delicious and slightly warming, the only characteristic preventing this from being a classic is the alcohol, which slightly over-steps its bounds.

My biggest complaint about this was the alcohol taste that you could feel all the way down your throat to your stomach, it was like drinking Southern Comfort (which is not a bad thing). Brown with a lacey head. Sweet aroma, but goes down like liquer. Sweet and fruity, overall this would be excellent if not for the alcohol taste, it is my only complaint.
Another winner from Unibroue, though I still think Maudite is their best.
The forbidden beer! Heavenly.
Very mature brew. Best of their line in my opinion. The taste just explodes as it warms. Would purchase again. Especially considering its price.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2004 Aug 2001:  I don't know where to begin with this one, so I won't.  Very vinous, strong, complex, but so smooth going down!  Little on the nose, or this would be a great one!   Will reconsider this rating when I have the rest of the 4-pack....rerated 8/14 mmm better.7/5/8/5/17

August 2004:  750 ml bottle corked & caged...dark maple/plum, largish medium-duration head.  Plummy/raisiny nose, not as assertive as it could be.  Hugely malty,  very sweet; some good raisin/cola/grape hints, very clean and fairly dry finish.  This is eminently drinkable and delicious, but at this moment I'm inclined to say, not one of the brewer's more original offerings.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2004 Spicy, heady aroma, estery and malty, with prominent red grape and banana notes, dark brown sugar sweetness, plum, clove and faint citrus.  Deep, opaque mahogany with burgundy highlights and a lasting, creamy, ivory colored head.  Initially tart and bittersweet, becoming more fruity and malty with a lightly alcoholic, acidic, spicy, yeasty finish.  Smooth, creamy and lightly fiery mouthfeel.  Interesting convergence of styles.  Very satisfying, makes a splendid nightcap or dessert, especially on those cooler nights.

Fruit and yeast in the nose, the aroma is rolling all over the table. Big malty flavors and a sucker punch of a 9% that both S. and I supposed as a 6 or 7.  Some fig and cheese flavors. May be the best Unibroue.
An Awesome brew
Of the Unibourne I have had this my third favorite. A bit less dynamic than Maudite, but also asmoother presentation. I like it alot.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2004 Exceptional beer.  Dark fruit,
vanilla, chocolate and caramel notes.  And yet with all this complexity, its remarkable quaffable.   Update with no change in rating: One of the new and fresh bottles arriving locally wasn't at all the same as my earlier sampling.  This one came out exceptionally attenuated.  Sweet and fruitier flavors are masked by a definite and unwanted alcohol presence.  The body was surprisingly thin.  The sample would barely warrant a 3 rating, but I'm leaving my original until I can verify what's what.

A distinctive beer in a rather impressive line up from Unibrou.  A bit of a progenator as far as style goes.  Outside of Belgium we can call it Belgian-like.  Made inside Belgium this would be an artisinal classic.
I have to say I think this is the best beer that Unibroue makes.  What a rich malty and fruity flavor, much nicer than La Fin.  Deep and rich, a nice beer to relax to at the end of the day.
Nicely balanced, a little bitter...good brew.
Alcohol warming, sweet, lingering (not unpleasent) sweet aftertaste.  A pretty damned good brew.
slighlty sour aftertaste, but true to form from Unibroue...smooth.
Looked very nice in the glass with a good head and moderate lacing.  The aroma seemed overly sweet and not very appealing to me.
maroon color.  Kind of cherry wheaty aroma, very interesting, very warming

A rich, very complex Belgian. Dark ruby red in color emitting a sweet fruity aroma. Highly carbonated to style which accentuates its beautiful sweet, dark ripe fruit taste. Reminiscent of raisin, fig and black cherry with a hint of vanilla. Must be enjoyed at cellar temps to fully bring out its complexities. The higher alcohol level really warms it all up nicely. A genuine treat!
Very good! Exceptionally smooth.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2005 dark ruby-brown colour with a fine slightly brown-tainted head, yeasty and malty, notes of prune and licorice, sweet and full-bodied, lot of carbonation, long and very malty finish with notes of bread and alcohol
Impressive by any means.  This beer is dark, fairly fruity and very strong.  This is an amazing beer.  Unibroue struck gold here.
